fields.headline: The networker
fields.body:
Timesheet

The crab fisherman
Richard Davies, 56, Cromer, Norfolk

4.30am: Gets up.

4.40: Puts kettle on for coffee.

4.50: Feeds dogs: Staffordshire bull terrier (Bruno) and bull mastiff (Cleo).

5.00: Takes out dogs and checks weather. If good: comes back, puts boots on and meets the lads in the yard. If bad: goes back to bed.

5.15: Loads bait on vans, drives to beach and launches boat.

"We work eight lines of pots, 25 pots on each line, mile each. We haul, empty, rebait every day and shift 'em. This time of year, crabs come inshore. We stay inshore till June. July and August, lobster come in to spawn.

My son's boat fishes all year round. I start March and finish September-October. The rest of the year I'm busy making new pots and nets. The nicest bit is getting up in the morning, when there's no wind and the birds are singing. I shove off and I see the sun rising in the sea. In summer, it sets in the sea. I hate autumn. Winter's coming, you never dry out, you wear oilskins all the time, your hands are cold. I love spring - everything's coming green."

9.00: Returns to shore. Unloads catch for inspection by fishery officer.

9.45: Returns to yard. Kenny, the boilerman, has warmed up the boilers.

10.00: Drowns crabs in fresh water. "Anaesthetised, I call it, 'cause they don't suffer - they just go to sleep."

10.30: Hand-scrubs crabs, puts in baskets or nets, places in boiling water.

10.50: Boils for 25 minutes, with salt.

11.15: Removes crabs. Washes fat off. "Crabs are fatty, they're greasy. And they have blood, but it's transparent."

11.45: Grades crabs to be sold in various shops, including his own.

2.00: Home.

2.15: Lunch: "Might be a sarnie. Or a crab. I eat a crab nearly every day." Kenny goes to market, for tomorrow's bait. Checks engines, gets fuel, checks nets. Waits for son to return from sea.

3.00: Snooze.

5.00: Prepares bait: cuts up and counts.

5.30: Wife closes fish shop.

6.30: "There's always something to do." Feeds chickens - keeps 100, for pleasure and eggs.

8.00: "The wife cooks us a tea, or we go out. We have an Indian meal once a week. On a Wednesday we deliver the crabs and go for a Thai."

Pay check

What you can do for £50,000

 University personnel director, Greater London

 NHS consultant (mid-range salary)

 Accountant, City of London

 Secondary-school headteacher (lower-range salary)

 Marketing manager, polymer manufacturer, Luxembourg

 Optometrist, Somerset

On the radar

Dress code change

Furrowed brows amid the crumpled khakis at Gap and Banana Republic, world headquarters of the business-casual revolution. Smelling profit in the dot.com downturn, 12 US menswear firms have launched the Men's Apparel Alliance, a $10m "awareness-raising" attempt to bring sharp suits and ties back into the office. Surveys suggest that 47% of senior corporate types support them. "The fact that a lot of dot.coms have done poorly may make casual attire guilty by association," says one major recruiter. The starting point: dress-up Thursdays.

Debunker

The Selling Safari

Folks, it's a jungle out there, and sooner or later you will want to be hunting the tigerfish, right. Never mind the oryx, or the sable. What you want is this fish. It's gold and black and red. And it's got a lot of teeth. It is also a slippery critter and won't be fooled. No, sir. You want a tigerfish, you gotta pursue him on his own terms.

But you can take off your thigh-high waders and put away your maggots, for, with a spot of debunking, we find that Alan Buhler, author of The Selling Safari (High Mountain) isn't just talking angling. He's talking sales.

"Prospects are like tigerfish," says Buhler, "As a salesperson you must uncover what will make the prospect bite on your bait."

He also says that while most salespeople will only consider a customer's "intellectual" reasons for "biting" we must also think about their emotional reasons.

Buhler advises in his Selling Secret number 10 that we must: "Use the right bait (pain), trawl with questions, then sink your hook into your prospect's personal compelling emotional reason to buy. It takes patience, determination, and tenacity, but the reward will feed your family for a lifetime."

Our man at the Angling Times tells us that tigerfish are a bit like piranhas. Toothy and ferocious. Perhaps you would be better off sticking to koi carp.

webTitle: Barclays offers aid to farmers in crisis

fields.headline: Barclays offers aid to farmers in crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Barclays bank today is expected to announce a fresh set of support measures for farming and other communities feeling the financial strain of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Barclays bank today is expected to announce a fresh set of support measures for farming and other communities feeling the financial strain of the foot and mouth crisis.

The bank has already extended the loan repayment break offered to farmers at the start of the outbreak to a wide variety of businesses, ranging from chip shops to hotels in affected areas.

The bank, which has some 20,000 farming customers, is now expected to announce measures which offer longer-term support for communities, which may involve donations to local charities, for instance.

While the initial concerns about the financial impact of the foot and mouth crisis focused on farmers, as the spread of the disease has widened financial experts have become increasingly concerned about other rural businesses, especially those which rely on tourism.

Barclays is now thought to be considering longer term help for rural communities in general. Under the terms of its loan repayment freeze already announced, Barclays is allowing farmers and other affected businesses to forgo repayments of the capital for three months but the interest is being deferred to the end of the period.

Royal Bank of Scotland is also taking a sympathetic stance towards the farming community and has donated £1m to charities helping farmers.

fields.headline: Overdraft bills hit £150m
fields.standfirst:
Current account charges ignore Bank of England rate cuts

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Current account charges ignore Bank of England rate cuts.
fields.body:
The cost of a bank overdraft is determined by the going rate in the industry and not the base lending rate set by the monetary policy committee, according to new research.

It shows that overdraft rates have barely shifted from 18% in the past five years even though official interest rates have been changed 23 times by the Bank of England over that period.

While the official base rate was cut to 5.5% this month, the overdraft rates charged by the "big four" - Lloyds TSB, NatWest (Royal Bank of Scotland), HSBC and Barclays - are all above 18%. HSBC raised its overdraft rate from 16.9% to 18.3% this month.

According to the survey by NOP, 11.5m people have authorised overdrafts totalling £700m a year on which interest payments of almost £150m are due annually. NOP found the average customer was overdrawn for 80 days a year. The research did not include unauthorised overdrafts, which can rack up even higher charges.

The importance of overdraft charges to the public was officially recognised in February when they were included in the basket of items used to calculate the official inflation rate.

The workings of the current account market are being scrutinised by the competition commission during its investigation into whether Lloyds TSB should be allowed to proceed with its proposed £19bn hostile bid for Abbey National.

The big four banks have a combined current account market share of more than 70% and research has shown that people are more likely to divorce than move their current accounts

Overdrafts are an integral part of current accounts but the way interest charges are set bears little relation to the Bank of England's base rate in the way that mortgage rates do.

Barclays, for instance, has charged 18.8% since 1996. But it has not always charged the highest rate among the big four.

HSBC's overdraft rate has dropped to below 14.5% during the period, but it has been alone among the big four in dropping its rate below 17% in the five-year period.

HSBC said: "Personal lending has never been tied to base rates. The rates are set completely differently."

Barclays said that its overdraft charges did not move with base rates. "We follow market competition."

According to Moneyfacts, which compiles listings of products offered by financial firms, Barclays' overdraft rate is currently 18.8%, HSBC 18.3%, Lloyds TSB 18.6% and NatWest 18.38%. In December 1997, when base rates were two percentage points higher than they are now, Barclays charged 18.8%, Lloyds 18.8%, NatWest 17.8% and HSBC around 14.4%.

While customers have proved to be reluctant to move their current account, the traditional players in the mortgage market, particularly Halifax and Abbey National are trying to challenge the dominance of the big four.

Halifax, which charges a 10% overdraft rate and commissioned the NOP research, said yesterday: "Overdrafts cost customers money. They should think very carefully before deciding which bank to do business with."

This weekend Abbey, which is offering an interest-free overdraft to rivals' customers, said it intended to speed up the time taken to move a bank account to one day.

The standard set by the big banks - which many fail to meet - is to swap all details about direct debits and standing orders within 10 days.

NatWest pointed out that the cost of overdrafts was more than just interest rates. "Until June last year there was a £5 monthly charge for overdrafts. You have to look at the overall cost of an overdraft," NatWest said.

Yet, despite the millions of pounds in advertising spent by Halifax and Abbey on their push into the current account market, Alliance & Leicester said its research showed that only 2% of customers planned to move their accounts, even though half of the 2,000 people surveyed said they were unhappy with their existing bank accounts.

webTitle: Classical Review: St Matthew Passion stripped bare

fields.headline: St Matthew Passion stripped bare
fields.trailText:
St Matthew Passion
Barbican, London

Rating: ****
fields.body:
It was almost a foregone conclusion that the Gabrieli Consort and Players' performance of the St Matthew Passion would be the most controversial version of the work to be heard over Easter. Paul McCreesh, the Consort's director, is drastic in his approach. His aim is to expose - to use TS Eliot's phrase - "the skull beneath the skin" of the music, to strip it down uncompromisingly to its bare essentials. Bach's double orchestra becomes two small groups of instrumentalists and the choral lines are allotted to single voices. Four soloists carry both the narrative and the arias, which means the singers cast as the Evangelist (Mark Padmore) and Jesus (Peter Harvey) have to leap suddenly out of character for moments of reflection and emotional commentary.

The result, contrary to expectations, is anything but austere, though it leads to a performance that doesn't always scale the tragic heights it should. There's a strong element of physicality in McCreesh's music-making, mirrored in the swirling, balletic gestures with which he conducts. He lays a hefty emphasis on how the explicit vividness of Bach's instrumental writing dictates an almost physical response. The instrumental obbligati trickle round the singers like rivulets of tears; the string chords accompanying the contralto's contemplation of the scourging slice the air.

The nakedness of suffering the work explores is reflected in McCreesh's exposure of the naked vulnerability of voices and instruments. As a result, you are sometimes aware of imprecision in the playing, although the singing is more cohesive. Harvey's Jesus mingles resigned divinity with palpable, at times excruciating, terror and doubt. Padmore's Evangelist is morally concerned, flaring into anger at the betrayal, and dismissing Judas with contempt, when a dispassionate approach might be more appropriate.

The soprano, Julia Gooding, is warmly vibrant and humane - earthbound rather than angelic. Contralto Sarah Connolly is, by contrast, a hieratic icon of grief. McCreesh sharply differentiates his two solo-voiced choirs, with the bright sound of the first counterpoised with the mellower tones of the second. Given the small numbers involved, the balance occasionally comes adrift. The all-important chorale that threads its way through the opening chorus, for instance, was inaudible.

Much of it is admirable, though much of it is also flawed. McCreesh claims authenticity for his procedures, though what really matters in the St Matthew Passion, as in any great Bach performance, is the cumulative impact, the ability to judge the relentless, yet measured pace of the work's emotional development. McCreesh often hovers in the moment, rather than seeing the whole. The second half, in particular, progresses by fits and starts when it should be absolutely seamless. He's unfailingly impressive, but you don't emerge from his performance shattered, drained and profoundly moved, as you should.

fields.headline: The King's Consort
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
So much wonderful church music by Bach has survived that it's easy to forget that by his lesser-known contemporaries. The Bohemian Jan Dismas Zelenka was much admired by Bach, who must have recognised in him a kindred spirit. Performing Zelenka's Lamentations of Jeremiah alongside one of Bach's cantatas, Robert King and his King's Consort demonstrated that Zelenka's music does at least make comparisons to Bach feasible. However, presenting the Lamentations end to end did make the evening rather a long haul.

Even the brief first half didn't fly by. Bach's Cantata BWV 161 was not written for Passiontide but, with its text concerning death and rebirth, it was still seasonal. Although it was played sensitively, King's stolid tempos at times threatened to hold back the musicians' momentum - and they, in turn, seemed to stifle alto soloist Robin Blaze. However, tenor James Gilchrist managed to convey the expressive yearning of Mein Verlangen. They were joined in the two choral numbers by bass Peter Harvey, singing above just audible florid recorders; soprano Rebecca Outram completed the vocal quartet for these numbers, but her bright, soloistic voice did not blend well with the others.

Zelenka wrote six Lamentations, a pair each for Maundy Thursday, Good Friday and Easter Saturday. They were never intended to be performed on the same day - let alone one after the other, as they were in the second half. Each one is like a mini Bach cantata, scored for alto, tenor or bass soloist with a different combination of instruments. And each has sections of declamatory music introduced by a more lyrical passage in which is sung the name of the Hebrew letter that begins the original verse. There is variety in Zelenka's music; indeed, there are lively, long-breathed melodies worthy of Bach. But after the third or fourth such piece one longed for a change in the format.

Harvey launched resonantly into the first Lamentation and he and Gilchrist negotiated well the many changes of pace within each piece. However, all six are a test of stamina for the soloist, and only Blaze seemed fresh throughout.

Happily, Zelenka saved his most beguiling music for the final day's settings, and the musicians responded: the cellos relished their duet in the fifth Lamentation, while a long-awaited bassoon melody in the sixth added new texture. But without this kind of interest throughout, King's enterprise seemed intended to educate rather than captivate.

Although it was played sensitively, King's stolid tempos at times threatened to hold back the musicians' momentum - and they, in turn, seemed to stifle alto soloist Robin Blaze. However, tenor James Gilchrist managed to convey the expressive yearning of Mein Verlangen. They were joined in the two choral numbers by bass Peter Harvey, singing above just audible florid recorders; soprano Rebecca Outram completed the vocal quartet for these numbers, but her bright, soloistic voice did not blend well with the others. Zelenka wrote six Lamentations, a pair each for Maundy Thursday, Good Friday and Easter Saturday. They were never intended to be performed on the same day - let alone one after the other, as they were in the second half. Each one is like a mini Bach cantata, scored for alto, tenor or bass soloist with a different combination of instruments. And each has sections of declamatory music introduced by a more lyrical passage in which is sung the name of the Hebrew letter that begins the original verse. There is variety in Zelenka's music; indeed, there are lively, long-breathed melodies worthy of Bach. But after the third or fourth such piece one longed for a change in the format. Harvey launched resonantly into the first Lamentation and he and Gilchrist negotiated well the many changes of pace within each piece. However, all six are a test of stamina for the soloist, and only Blaze seemed fresh throughout. Happily, Zelenka saved his most beguiling music for the final day's settings, and the musicians responded: the cellos relished their duet in the fifth Lamentation, while a long-awaited bassoon melody in the sixth added new texture. But without this kind of interest throughout, King's enterprise seemed intended to educate rather than captivate.

webTitle: Circus review: The spirit of Charlie Chaplin lives on

fields.headline: The spirit of Charlie Chaplin lives on
fields.standfirst:
The Junebug Symphony
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
The Junebug Symphony

Queen Elizabeth Hall, London

Rating: ****
fields.body:
Take a dash of Dali, add a pinch of Freud and some circus tricks and you have a cracking night out courtesy of a brilliant new French company La Compagnie du Hanneton, founded by James Thierree, the grandson of Charlie Chaplin.

This is the story of a man who goes to bed and, quite literally, loses his head. What follows is a waking nightmare of horror and beauty as physical theatre blurs into circus, dreams merge into reality, and a suit turns into pyjamas. Wardrobes play host to the fantastic, and even paintings take on a life of their own, à la Harry Potter.

The show is physically inventive, its mix of opera and jazz is full of musical cheek, and it is never just about doing tricks, although the cast of four take the trapeze, acrobatics, contortion and juggling all in their stride. What's so good about this piece is that it takes the circus beyond the mere act.

When the man bounces in and out of his armchair it is not just a clever piece of acrobatics but a physical manifestation of his inner turmoil and frustration. A beautiful sequence of swinging on a candelabra captures absolutely the feeling of what sex is like in a dream.

Most of all, the show has the Alice-in-Wonderland logic of a dream. Arms and legs grow out of plant pots, it is possible to have a fight with your mirror image, the tableware at a feast suddenly turns into the armour for an armadillo and a chicken, and peacock feathers suddenly become a shower of arrows. The evening is about transformations, and it makes you see the world just a little bit differently, as if through the eyes of a surrealist.

One of the wonders of this show is that only four people are involved. This may be small-scale circus, but there are no limits to its imagination and it owes as much to the art gallery and the theatre as it does to the big top. If you want to see how circus is beginning to grow up as an art form, this is the show for you - and the kids will thrill to it too. The only shame is that the run is such a short one, as this show definitely deserves to be seen.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

fields.headline: Heavy Duty
fields.standfirst:
Inverleith House, Edinburgh
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Inverleith House, Edinburgh

Rating: ****
fields.body:
Anyone expecting gymnasts and Olympic rings in this show of new work by Lucy McKenzie and Paulina Olowska will be disappointed. McKenzie, a fast-rising star, has been celebrated for her paintings of sporting icons and symbols but, such is the measure of the young artist's success, she already feels the need to move on. But this isn't a show about McKenzie and her development: it's about friendship, by two artists who met on an exchange trip between their two art colleges.

While there are some glorious new paintings by Olowska - enigmatic female beauties in 1950s fashion - and recent work by McKenzie on themes of heritage and commerce, the collaborative projects are the most engaging. A massive wall painting, Loved By Women Loved By Toulous Lautreca, borrows from Soviet propaganda posters and feminises the iconography; a video travelogue shows the pair in Poland, on dance floors and in art galleries, just hanging out together. Watching this, in a room surrounded by others full of their work, the show's whole point - to reveal affinities, experiences and contexts within which art is produced - hits home.

The same point is unmissable in a room containing work owned by friends and families - art the two women grew up with. It's the artistic equivalent of showing the working out of a mathematical puzzle and neatly defeats all our expectations.

Throughout, there's an emphasis on contradicting the conventional view of the artist as a genius working in isolation. The layering of references, the revelation of allusion and borrowing, is almost suffocating at times. There are images or text sent between the two women, scenes and typography from high and low culture, and namechecks for Armani, Hockney, Pollock and Glasgow artist Jim Lambie.

Olowska shows architectural models she found lying around in Gdansk poly; McKenzie's work is saturated with references to money and brand identities and the role they play in national cultural identity. This means a wall of paintings in the shape of bank notes, some splendid Charles Rennie Mackintosh-influenced curtains and a wrought iron panel, its pattern including a map of Scotland and pound signs.

There are, inevitably, some private jokes and (though this is deliberate) it can be hard to work out which work is by which artist. But this is a thrilling exhibition that makes you want to keep an eye on both artists.

 Until May 27. Details: 0131-248 2983.

fields.headline: Tchaikovsky's Bridget Jones
fields.standfirst:
Eugene Onegin
Grand Theatre, Leeds
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Eugene Onegin
Grand Theatre, Leeds

Rating: ****
fields.body:
An extract from the diary of Tchaikovsky's heroine Tatyana: "Shots of vodka: 7 (v. bad). Impassioned letters to Onegin: 1. Ohmigod - have just sat up all night pouring out feelings for Onegin on paper. Now will think am silly provincial peasant who will never find husband. Maybe should have just left message on answerphone."

Admittedly the above doesn't entirely do justice to the subtle play of irony and observation in Pushkin's poem, but then nor do the clodhopping couplets of David Lloyd-Jones's dutiful but dull translation. Onegin remains an opera so perfectly clothed in its own milieu, era and metrics that any attempt to dress it in foreign garb creates a slightly ludicrous impression.

Onegin is a delicate work that needs handling with care. Tchaikovsky himself was so anxious about this point that he preferred the piece to be premiered by students rather than mangled by the wooden work practices of the professional opera. Dalia Ibelhauptaite's Opera North production was hampered by some slightly incongruous casting two years ago but, having been revived with the breath of youth, it now captures something of the unfettered freshness Tchaikovsky was aiming for. Best of all, Giselle Allen's Tatyana could mark the arrival of a star.

To make your debut with a major company in this immensely difficult role is remarkable; that Allen's intensely credible portrayal of Tatyana as a youthful, rosy ingenue seems to have sprung fully formed from nowhere is astonishing. We are used to bigger voices, and much older women, in the role, but Allen's negotiation of the 20-minute solo of the letter scene is truly fearless. This is not only due to the fluid ease with which she unwinds skeins of silkily focused tone, but also to her uninhibited response to the request to roll around rhapsodically on the floor in nothing but a precariously wound bedsheet.

William Dazeley, in superb voice, is an actor well up to the task of suggesting that the surly object of this dreamy, proto-Bridget Jones's emotional fantasies is more than a desiccated cad. If Iain Paton seems slightly more inhibited as Lensky, he produces a fine burnished sound, and his farewell to life on a frozen Russian pond is a highlight. Richard Farnes conducts idiomatically with a fine sense of dramatic propulsion. Designer Giles Cadle's juxtapositions of blond wood and cool zinc blues have more to do with the tasteful restraint of a Swedish furniture shop than the salons of St Petersburg, but Sue Wilmington's costumes are a period delight, while the look and sound of the entire company is a delight, period.

Until May 10. Box office: 0113-222 6222. Then touring.

fields.headline: Avoiding holiday disasters
fields.standfirst: Travel money
fields.trailText: In response to concerns over deep vein thrombosis as a result of long-haul flights, Club Direct has become the first insurer to say it will pay the legal costs of passengers. Rachel Gordon reports. who sue airlines over potentially fatal blood clots.
fields.body:
Panic over the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) caused by flying to long-haul destinations should make holidaymakers ensure legal expenses insurance is part of their cover, travel insurer Club Direct has warned.

Managing director Brent Escott claims Club Direct is the only company that offers legal costs if an insured passenger contracts DVT. Mr Escott believes there will be a number of cases this year where holidaymakers are forced to sue airlines and travel companies.

Although rare, the condition that causes a potentially fatal blood clot in the heart or lung is believed to lead to about 10 deaths a year, according to government medical experts.

Other areas covered under the legal expenses section of a Club Direct policy could include tripping on faulty paving, swimming pool accidents and other injuries caused through negligence.

But while Club Direct includes legal expenses, it says many other insurers do not. Mr Escott says most others exclude the need to sue and that this is often hidden in the small print.

"The exclusion for the travel trade and airlines was originally introduced when travel agents had a stranglehold on the travel insurance market, and it has remained there ever since. Ironically, of all the people you are ever likely to have to take action against after a trip abroad, the travel provider and airline must be among the most likely contenders."

Mr Escott says holidaymakers need greater awareness. "My view is that more providers who operate directly, rather than for the travel industry, will start to offer better deals all round, including legal expenses cover."

He says among those that refuse to cover full legal action against the travel trade and airlines are Thomas Cook and Lunn Poly. "We want to see all travel insurance policies drop this exclusion now," Escott says. "It's a relic from the past and is not in the customer's interest. The only people it benefits are the travel agent, tour operator and airline."

Although holidaymakers should check that legal expenses are now included as part of their travel cover, most travellers would be better off if they avoided buying their policies from travel agents, says Escott.

A spokesman for Thomas Cook confirms that legal expenses against airlines is not included, but says his company would look at covering the "supplier" of services when it comes to legal expenses cover. This could mean legal expenses cover against a hotelier would be part of the cover. "This should include someone who had a swimming pool accident," he says.

Lunn Poly was repeatedly contacted but did not have a spokesperson with knowledge of insurance to comment.

But Ian Chalmers, the marketing director of Association of British Travel Agents (Abta) company, there is already consumer protection and they are available to deal with complaints from dissatisfied customers."

Mr Chalmers says DVT is now something airlines are aware of. "I know that British Airways, for example, is making sure its cabin crew are aware of the dangers and will request passengers not to sit still for long periods."

Mr Chalmers says those who had a legal case to bring against a tour operator and had a strong case could use the services of a solictor and then reclaim costs or use a no-win, no-fee lawyer. "I can see Club Direct is using this to raise awareness, but I would say to people who are worried that they don't really need this cover. It is more of a marketing exercise in my view."

While he says legal expenses cover is not essential, Mr Chalmers does believe holidaymakers should shop around before buying insurance.

Paul Charles, of online broker Screentrade.co.uk, agrees and says travel agents are the last place you should go for your holiday insurance. He says some agents earned hefty commissions and had limited expertise in selling insurance.

Consumer magazine Holiday Which? recently found that people buying from travel agents can end up paying four times as much than if they bought elsewhere. For example, broker TravelPlan Directcharges £10 for a two-week holiday in Europe, while the same cover with Going Places would be £40.99.

Patricia Yates, editor of Holiday Which? says: "Taking the time to look further afield than the main high street travel agents will ensure you are fully protected and that you pay a fair price."

Some years ago, government watchdog, the Office of Fair Trading (Oft) clamped down on travel agents who charged holidaymakers more for not taking tied-in insurance, stating the "large margins" made on insurance meant some consumers were receiving poor value.

Cheaper deals and equivalent cover can often be bought from specialist brokers, websites, direct from insurers or even retailers such as Boots.

webTitle: Power to the people in Co-op bank's ethics poll

fields.headline: Power to the people in Co-op bank's ethics poll
fields.standfirst:
2m questionnaires will ask whether repressive regimes, arms trading, animal welfare or genetic engineering are 21st century pariahs

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: 2m questionnaires will ask whether repressive regimes, arms trading, animal welfare or genetic engineering are 21st century pariahs.
fields.body:
More than 2m customers of the Co-operative bank are to be polled for their views on genetically modified food, animal testing and human rights as the bank begins the task of rewriting its ethical investment policy.

Almost 10 years after publishing its first ethical policy, the Co-op bank plans to update it for the 21st century at a time when two of the pressing issues of the last decade - fur trading and hunting - appear increasingly outdated.

In what it terms the biggest ever ethical consultation exercise, the bank plans to send customers a lengthy questionnaire.

The bank expects issues such as genetic engineering, animal experimentation, global climate change, human rights and the arms trade to be among issues its customers will want to debate during the exercise which it hopes to complete by May 2002.

The Co-op first embarked on such a wide consultation of customers in 1991 which led to the bank pledging not to back a variety of companies, particularly those involved in human rights abuses, the arms trade and animal testing.

Because of changes in recent years, the Co-op bank expects new issues to be added to the list of unethical practices by next year.

For instance, genetically modified food and genetic engineering of other products is one of the more recent subjects to be thrust on to the agenda. Attempts to ban hunting with hounds and stop trading in furs mean that these may now be on their way off the list of investments to avoid.

Some issues are likely to survive, however. "The arms trade goes on and on and human rights in general," a Co-op bank spokesman said.

The ethical policy, last updated in 1998, covers more than avoiding business with companies that abuse human rights and animal welfare. It requires the bank to avoid companies which contribute to "global climate change and acid rain" as well as avoiding currency speculation which might damage the country's financial health.

The Co-op, which believes a third of all new customers join because of its ethical stance, checks potential clients against its ethical policy before lending them money or offering them other financial services.

It has not emulated financial firms which run investment funds with an overt ethical stance. But its wide-ranging ethical approach has influenced the way other companies invest money on their customers' behalf.

Leading pension funds increasingly have departments responsible for "socially responsible investment" , which update investors with an "ethical audit" every year. Even the stock exchange is to get a new index which companies can enter only if they meet certain ethical criteria.

The FTSE4Good index may help to generate more ethical investment because it will allow big investment firms to set up funds that track the index. Around 60% of companies are expected to qualify for inclusion in the index when it is initiated in July.

The Co-op bank insists that its ethical policy cannot be analysed in this way, with companies being barred or included on a rigid blacklist. This is because it only scrutinises potential customers when they approach the bank for financing and does not disclose if it has turned away customers, citing client confidentiality.

The Co-op has completed three consultation exercises with its own customers in recent years which illuminate the public's changing passions about certain issues.

Ten years ago, financing oppressive regimes and sale of arms to them topped the list of concerns among the Co-op's customers. By 1994, those issues remained important but concerns had increased about animal testing for cosmetic purposes, factory farming and animal fur trade.

In 1998, the Co-op found that tobacco manufacturing had slipped back among its customers' concerns. The surveys found, however, a consistent amount of concern about financing oppressive regimes.

The bank has also tried to raise new issues during its surveys, such as introducing questions on money laundering in 1994. Answers to questions about currency speculators were measured for the first time in 1998.

In the same year, 8% of customers were starting to become aware of genetic modification and raised the issue for inclusion at the next consultation.

For the Co-op bank, sending out questionnaires to its 2m customers is the easy part. Getting them to fill them in is harder; in 1998 only 2% participated in the consultation exercise.

fields.headline: Bring on the recession
fields.standfirst: When times get hard, people make do and mend instead of spend, spend, spend. It's the pawnbrokers, discount stores and cobblers that do well when everyone else goes bust, reports  Laura Barton
fields.trailText: When times get hard, people make do and mend instead of spend, spend, spend. It's the pawnbrokers, discount stores and cobblers that do well when everyone else goes bust, reports Laura Barton
fields.body:
The shops shut down as though out of season in a seaside town. "Everything must go!" and "Closing down sale!" are scratched on to whitewashed windows. Shutters down, the pound shops set in, and then the charity shops, spreading like dry rot along the high street.

Recession is, for the most part, a gloomy time of thriftiness and the tightening of belts. We turn to the bottle and smoke like chimneys, we stop nipping out for a frappuccino and make do with vending machine coffee. I ask my mother what people eat during a recession. "Potatoes," she says, "a lot of potatoes." But for some industries, an economic downturn heralds a boom. In a time of mend and make do, it's the shoe-repair shops, the heel bars, that do well, along with the discount stores and the pawnbrokers.

Andrew Lazarus leans against the counter, his sturdy arms, like ham shanks, resting on a glass-topped cabinet full of chains, watches and christening bracelets.

Lazarus is a pawnbroker on Seven Sisters Road in Holloway, north London. He is within a mile of prosperous Highgate, but Holloway itself is a huddle of council estates, with a large ethnic community, members of which often queue up in Lazarus's shop to use the Western Union money transfer service.

"We catch both ends of the market in a recession. We do well in pawnbroking. In boom-time it's the retail side of the business," he says.

It comes as no surprise to him that pawning booms in times of trouble. "People use pawnbrokers because it's easier to pawn than to go to the bank for £300. All you need is ID," he says, with the bold, gleaming tones of the salesman.

Customers enter into a six-month contract, with an average interest of 6% a month. After those six months expire, they can either redeem the item, by paying back the loan plus the crude interest, or renew the contract just by paying the interest. Some people renew items for five years or so. During a recesssion, they renew and renew.

Seven Sisters Road is busy, drawing in a ragbag bunch of customers to the Gold Shop. "A few of the City boys draw up outside and pawn expensive items," Lazarus says. And then there are the regulars. "They'll come in a couple of times a week, pawn something and then put a bet on the horses. If they win, they come straight back. If they lose, you'll not see them for months."

During a recession, there is little change in the sort of item brought in to be pawned. "It's run of the mill stuff - rings, chains. There's the odd unusual thing - computers, cameras. We had a pneumatic drill once," says Lazarus.

Of course, it is the accountants who really profit from the country's financial losses. It's the insolvency accountants, the lawyers, the valuers, the bailiffs - everyone involved in the breaking up of a business who prosper. "It's not that they're doing particularly well," says Grant Jones, chairman of the turnaround finance group of the London Society of Chartered Accountants.

"They are just doing better than everyone else," says Jones. "When everyone else is doing well, they're doing badly. It's feast and famine. People who earn enormous amounts in a recession are people who restructure and buy debt. Certain banks buy debt from other banks. They earn huge amounts of money. And litigation lawyers do well because during a recession everyone argues about payment and fault."

The opposite of a venture capitalist is a "vulture" capitalist - already common in the US, these are now multiplying in the UK. They save companies in a downturn by converting debts to equity, refinancing and persuading creditors to own a share.

Accountants make enemies in hard times too. "There are the company directors called to account for their personal guarantee; the wives of bankrupts, who are being thrown out of their houses; the creditors, who have overexposed themselves and don't realise that the occasional bad debt is simply part of business, but these people have lost money, not their houses; and then, lastly, there is the government and the regulatory bodies," says Jones.

He does have sympathy for the entrepreneur who loses everything during a slump. "When I used to make redundancies, I used to not sleep the night before," he says. "Part of the problem in the UK is that banks rely on personal guarantees. On the continent and in the US they don't. The UK is more lazy. The entrepreneur puts everything on the line. In a boom he is taxed at 40%, then in recession the bank calls in the personal guarantee. It's less of a stigma to go bust in the US."

He says that, in reality, "for most people, formal insolvency is a blessed relief. And a recession is a good thing - it cleans out the stables, cleans out all the crap."

Recession is also good for the arts. The great depression of the 1930s may have prompted a rise in the suicide rate on Wall Street but it also led to a boom in Hollywood. And in hard times people are keener to stake what they do have, in the hope of winning a pile. They bet on the horses, go to the bingo, buy lottery tickets, keeping their fingers crossed for a miracle.

With bleak times in the offing, you might expect a sudden surge in church attendance, but Robin Protheroe, the Bishop of Bristol's advisor for inter-faith relations, says that is not how it works these days: "People are less inclined towards institutional religion." But he has observed an increased interest in new-age disciplines, such as feng shui. "I am staggered by the interest in eastern philosophy and religion in general - perhaps because religions such as Buddhism and Hinduism offer a direct religious experience. In a time of increasing materialism and consumerism, people buy and buy, but there's still a hollow." In the US it is a different story. There, preachers of the prosperity gospel flourish during recessions. "They preach that if people put trust in the church, if they give a donation, then God will bless them."

A slump can trigger creativity. We innovate, think laterally. We become a nation of Scarlett O'Haras, fashioning ballgowns out of the curtains. After all, it was in the midst of a recession that Charles Darrow invented Monopoly, the best-selling boardgame in the world. In recession, that's the only place where everyone has the chance to be a winner.

fields.headline: Mogwai
fields.standfirst:
Rothesay Pavilion, Isle of Bute
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Rothesay Pavilion, Isle of Bute

Rating: ****
fields.body:
It's unlikely Rothesay has ever seen anything like it. As 500 heavily inebriated indie kids stumble off the ferry, you sense that this genteel little town normally finds other ways to let its hair down. But then the main attraction tonight is Mogwai, a band never averse to exploring new territory.

Since the release of their first album, Young Team, in 1997, the Glasgow five-piece have stubbornly refused to conform to the post-Britpop consensus of "proper" songs, retro dues-paying and traditional arrangements. Their largely instrumental repertoire somehow manages to blend the avant-garde experimentation of America's so-called "post-rock" movement with a noisy punk populism. So while transporting their boisterous fans to this quiet seaside resort may be a shrewd ploy to grab headlines for their new album, Rock Action, it is at least a gimmick that conforms to the Mogwai blueprint.

The idea of a guitar act forsaking vocals is one that normally sets alarm bells ringing - is this not a reprise of bloated, self-indulgent 1970s prog-rockers such as Yes and ELP? Fortunately not: Mogwai all but eschew solos in favour of building up powerful sonic assaults from the gentlest of openings. However, as with all musical innovators, the band constantly run the risk of satisfying their own curiosity at the expense of the audience's patience.

It is to Mogwai's credit that their live act mostly avoids such pitfalls. Tracks such as Christmas Steps sweep the crowd along with their brooding dynamics, while the emotional pull of the elegiac Helicon 2 is hard to resist. Using brass and strings to broaden their sound affords them a heftier sonic punch, as well as emphasising the music's more melodic turns.

They don't always pull it off. The band seem to stumble when the brass section kicks in, suggesting they aren't yet altogether comfortable with outside musicians. And the spectre of self-indulgence is never entirely absent: witness, for example, the 10-minute blast of feedback that closes the show. Yes, it's "challenging", "radical" and "different", but the crowd is left stunned with boredom rather than awe.

Whatever their flaws, though, Mogwai still breathe life and energy into the guitar-rock format when so many of their peers sound tired and complacent. And it's not every band who can boast they've rocked Rothesay.

 At Planet K, Manchester tomorrow night. Box office: (0161-832 1111). Then touring.

fields.headline: European round-up
fields.trailText: Mixed fortunes for the opponents of English teams in this week's Champions League and Uefa Cup action.
fields.body:
Bayern Munich, with a 1-0 lead to defend at home to Manchester United in Wednesday's European Cup quarter-final second leg, suffered a demoralising 3-1 defeat at home to Schalke 04 on Saturday.

Bayern, like United chasing a hat-trick of domestic titles, were derailed by the three goals from Ebbe Sand which took Schalke to the top, and that after Carsten Jancker had given them an early lead. "We were far too nervous in defence," said Bayern's coach Ottmar Hitzfeld.

Deportivo La Coruna, who have vowed to overturn Leeds United's 3-0 lead in tomorrow's home quarter final second-leg, trailed 1-0 to lowly Osasuna but late headers from Roy Makaay and Fernando kept them eight points behind the leaders Real.

Valencia suffered a defeat at their Mestalla stadium where the season's surprise team, Alaves, earned a 2-1 victory. The visitors opened the scoring with a deflected shot after seven minutes but though Valencia's midfielder Vicente made it 1-1, Dan Eggen sealed Alaves' victory with a fine header after 74 minutes.

Thereafter their minds began to wander to what should be Thursday's Uefa Cup semi-final second-leg formality at Kaiserslautern, whom they lead 5-1.

Barcelona, Liverpool's visitors in the Uefa Cup that same evening, shared eight goals for the second week running. This time they were 2-0 down at home to Zaragoza before Marc Overmars pulled one back in the 53rd minute. The sides then exchanged four goals in a seven-minute spell, Patrick Kluivert scoring a neat double before Rivaldo curled in a last-minute free-kick to earn Barca's 4-4 draw.

fields.headline: Sky create a league of their own
fields.trailText: So all hail Sky Sports - ten years old and counting. A good point to try and dredge up the almost unthinkable iniquities that the BBC forced upon us in those dark days of old.
fields.body:
Those of you confused by the church bells ringing out over the weekend and the general carnival atmosphere, have clearly not been watching Sky Sports, where regular trailers have been inviting a grateful nation to give thanks for the channel's first 10 glorious years. And so we should.

Remember what televised sport was like before Sky, when the evil BBC empire purchased all sporting rights for 10s 6d, and ground its imperious jackboot into the face of sports fans, forcing all sorts of iniquities upon us; like replays from only one angle, single-occupancy commentary boxes, and football highlights played out without a rock music soundtrack? Unthinkable.

I have particular reason to be grateful to Murdoch's liberators, without whom this column and its legion of downmarket imitations would have no reason to exist. After all, there are only so many jokes you can make about Mark Lawrenson's moustache, and John Motson's tortuous way with a statistic. Without Sky, I doubt I could have sustained these outpourings for nearly five years. By now, I expect, my meagre stipend would have dried up; or I should have been shuffled sideways into some meaningless position like political editor.

So all hail Sky Sports. I gave thanks this Easter by enjoying two of the channel's great glories: Gillette Soccer Saturday and Super League.

Super League, especially, is a wonder to those of us who follow rugby league, and remember how the BBC covered the game before Sky came along.

For years, Grandstand treated it as a convenient filler between amateur boxing and the 3.15 from Chepstow. They would position a camera or two at bootlace level to ensure top pictures of the mud, never forgetting to interrupt the game if there were some important action going on at a swimming gala somewhere.

Thanks to the BBC, rugby league established a reputation it has still not quite shed, as a quaint northern pastime, like clog dancing, underlined by the presence for many years of Eddie Waring, as the "voice of rugby league". Waring was, of course, one of television's great "characters" for whom we were supposed to be grateful; but I never remember the BBC asking Magnus Pike or the Two Ronnies to front the Five Nations.

The beauty of Sky's coverage is that even rugby league fans not tooled up with the requisite technology feel the benefit. The BBC, who now cover just the Challenge Cup - apart from in the North, where an excellent Super League show using Sky's pictures goes out on Sunday mornings - has had to raise its game significantly to compete with Sky. The other week, Steve Rider presented Grandstand live from Wilderspool, the kind of thing that would never have happened pre-Sky.

Sky still beats the BBC hollow on rugby league, though; more camera angles, better analysis, better use of replays, and immeasurably better commentary. Eddie Hemmings and Mike "Stevo" Stephenson may overdo the hyperbole at times, but they communicate a genuine passion for the sport, and are brand leaders in the never less than entertaining art of talking total bollocks with absolute conviction.

When Leeds's Chev Walker fluffed a chance against Warrington, Stevo screamed, "Oh, the gate was open, I don't know whether it was pearly or not, but ... 'E 'AS BOMBED IT!"

The Wigan-St Helens match on Good Friday could have had commentary by the speaking clock and still have been unmissable. "Breathtaking," Eddie said, and for once he was not overselling it. Wigan were 10 points up with eight minutes to go. "If Saints score now, that will put the cat amongst the pigeons," said Eddie. They duly did. "Ooooh," went Eddie's orgasmic scream, "Where's that cat? Where are those pigeons?" That's the stuff, lads.

After celebrating Sky's anniversary, some of you may have had a drop or two left to toast Manchester United's premature championship. Gillette Soccer Saturday proved its worth once more to soccer-obsessed sports fans, securing a phone interview with Sir Alex Ferguson, who sounded like he might have been toasting the triumph himself.

Lest I be thought of as Sky's unofficial salesman, though, let me just add that you are unlikely to see anything on satellite remotely as good as the two music shows on Channel Four and BBC2 on Saturday night: the Miles Davis Story and Walk On By. What an unalloyed delight: the trumpet of Miles Davis and the voice of Levi Stubbs - the Eddie and Stevo of popular music.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Hapless Haffey finds absolution 40 years on
fields.trailText: Scotland's reputation for insecure goalkeeping took root on the day that England put nine past Frank Haffey in 1961. He carried the blame, but now, 40 years on, absolution has arrived.
fields.body:
In the Daily Telegraph on Monday April 17 1961 Donald Saunders' first paragraph crisply summed up the previous Saturday's match at Wembley: "Always the English will believe the genius of captain Johnny Haynes earned glorious victory; Scotsmen will forever blame goalkeeper Frank Haffey's shortcomings for ignominious defeat."

In this new century there is serious talk suddenly of reviving a regular England v Scotland fixture. If so, Scots of whatever generation will wince as poor Haffey's butterfingered "ignominy" 40 Aprils ago is recalled. England won 9-3.

Saunders had continued: "As Haynes was borne in triumph off the Wembley pitch by jubilant colleagues, Haffey set out, head bowed, alone, on the long journey to the welcome darkness of the tunnel."

It was understandable poetic licence from the press-box eyrie. The truth seems to be that Haffey put his afternoon's experience down solely to the commanding resplendence of Haynes and his artful lieutenant Jimmy Greaves, who scored a hat-trick. Those closer to the action reported the unfazed goalkeeper in his canary yellow jersey to be whistling unconcernedly as he made his way from that sunlit field.

Once in the communal post-match bath, by all accounts, the strapping Celtic fellow began to serenade his mortified colleagues with some traditional Harry Lauder numbers - until young Denis Law angrily demanded he pipe down: "Don't you realise you've just been responsible for Scottish football's most appalling catastrophe?" As their coach took them from the stadium, negotiating its path through jeering tartan-clad supporters along Wembley Way, the rest of the Scotland team ducked below the window level in shame - all except the still uncomprehending Haffey, curly brown hair accentuating the grin on his square, friendly face.

When the team boarded the train at King's Cross, Haffey was happy to enter into the spirit of things when Fleet Street photographers invited him to pose, arms outstretched, under a large sign that read platform "NINE".

By the time the night sleeper reached Glasgow, the Sunday newspaper billboards told the big engaging goalkeeper where blame was being apportioned. SLAP HAFFEY said one, HAPLESS HAFFEY another - and in spite of such legendary predecessors in the lore as Harry Rennie, John Thomson and Jimmy Cowan, Scotland's reputation for insecure goalkeeping took root there and then. The deprecating national joke, which one can still hear sometimes today among football folk, was minted for posterity:

"What's the time?"

"Almost 10-past Haffey."

Perhaps he was shrewdly aware of the only anniversary reason a stranger might be calling from an English newspaper. A Glasgow acquaintance did, however, speak to him a few months ago and reported him full of the joys and still in bonny good voice.

For instance, it was too easy to forget that the England team of 1960-61 was one of the finest ever, its forward line genuine vintage. At Wembley England fielded: Springett; Armfield, McNeil; Robson, Swan, Flowers; Douglas, Greaves, Smith, Haynes, Charlton.

In that period, ending with a defeat in Vienna, England's record was P8, W7, D1, with an astonishing 44 goals for and 11 against. In the 1960-61 Home Championship they scored a record 19 goals.

Armfield absolves Haffey for Scotland's failure. "He might have made a couple of mistakes but not half as many as the defenders around him. It is always too easy to blame your keeper."

fields.headline: Record and United fall to Larsson
fields.standfirst: Larsson 32, 79pen; McNamara 80 | Lilley 84
fields.trailText: Henrik Larsson was the difference between the two sides as Celtic set up a final showdown with Hibernian after the Edinburgh club swept aside Livingston 3-0 on Saturday.
fields.body:
A whole season, two enduring themes. Celtic remain on course for a domestic treble by dint of the two essentials that have taken them so far for so long during the course of this campaign: collective determination and one Henrik Larsson.

But for the scoreline, Celtic's passage into the final of the Tennents Scottish Cup had all the hallmarks of their recent wins, which have had a ground-out quality to them. Dundee United left wondering what they did to deserve to be on the end of a 3-1 defeat and Larsson left having set a scoring record.

The Swede, who scored twice - his first was a flying header from a barely credible angle and his second came from the penalty spot - now holds Celtic's post-war record for goals scored in a single season. His 49 in all competitions is one better than the previous record holder, Charlie Nicholas.

Nicholas said last night: "Actually I'm convinced I got 49 goals in 1982-83 - and I don't count headers or deflections, either. But he's been absolutely sensational. His confidence and fitness levels are right, and the service he gets makes him one of the finest players you could wish to have in this country. He's been wonderful, a treat - this record could go well into the 50s."

As if Larsson's record breaking two goals were not enough, he also assisted in Celtic's third, waiting just long enough for the substitute Jackie McNamara to peel to the right of United's 18-yard area before teeing up a pass just crying out for the measured conversion. At least United had the consolation of piercing the monolithic Celtic rearguard at least once.

But the sight of Joos Valgaeren failing to stretch far enough to cut out Jamie Buchan's long pass, thereby allowing Derek Lilley to round Robert Douglas for a late tap- in, was scant reward for their efforts.

The Celtic manager Martin O'Neill expects to use at least a couple of the next few games to give his youngsters a run. "Each one, to a man, said 'I hope it's not me', " he said of his plans to rest a couple of players. "They want to play."

His counterpart Alex Smith, who expressed pride in his players' efforts, believed a replay was tantalisingly close. "There was a 25-minute spell when I thought we dominated, but we needed to score at that stage," he said. "Had we scored at least one of a couple of chances, we would have certainly left with nothing less than a replay."

Vital blocks and nick-of-time headers by Dundee United's central defenders, Jim Lauchlan andJason de Vos, provided precious little warning of the strange seqence that led to Celtic's opener. Johan Mjallby's pass down the right side looked to be going out but, as De Vos slowed up, Chris Sutton remained in hot pursuit. The former Chelsea man's cross found Lauchlan unprepared as Larsson burst in.

Strangely, despite the routine beating of Jamie Buchan by Didier Agathe down the Celtic right, none of Celtic's goals came from that most productive of channels.

Larsson won the penalty he was to score from with nothing more complicated than cutting inside and inviting Danny Griffin to run into his back.

Celtic's opponents in the final will be Hibernian, who, thanks to two goals from the man of the match John O'Neil, comprehensively swept aside Livingston of the First Division 3-0 on Saturday.

The Edinburgh club reached the final of the tournament for the first time since 1979 - and will now attempt to win it for the first time in 99 years.

 Jim Baxter, the former Scotland, Rangers, Sunderland and Nottingham Forest wing-half, died of cancer on Saturday aged 61. He was capped 34 times, won three titles and three cups at Rangers and had his finest hour when Scotland beat England in 1967.

fields.headline: Chesterfield keep on looking up
fields.trailText: By rights Chesterfield should have been celebrating promotion on Saturday night. However, with a nine-point deduct- ion (and £20,000 fine), accruing from irregularities over gate receipts and the transfer of Luke Beckett, hanging over their heads, the champagne is still on ice.
fields.body:
By rights Chesterfield should have been celebrating promotion on Saturday night. However, with a nine-point deduct- ion (and £20,000 fine), accruing from irregularities over gate receipts and the transfer of Luke Beckett, hanging over their heads, the champagne is still on ice.

In truth, there are doubts whether the club could afford such luxuries. The financial crisis which has enveloped Saltergate has already seen the departure of six directors and a chairman this season; management and playing staff have not been paid for several weeks and bailiffs sought to claim the boardroom table - one of the few items of value left at the club.

But, despite the off-field problems, the reality remains that a win at Cardiff today could see Nicky Law's side confirm promotion, regardless of the points deduction recommended by the Football Association and Football League panel last Thursday.

Against Kidderminster on Saturday Chesterfield proved that they are peerless in this division on the pitch, with what Law described as their biggest 1-0 win of the season.

The hosts twice hit the woodwork and had a goal disallowed before taking the lead through a soft goal in first-half injury-time. A Rob Edwards corner looked to have provided Tim Clarke, the Kidderminster goalkeeper, with the simplest of catches but he dropped the ball on to the head of Beckett, who accepted the gift and his 17th goal of the season. An equally one-sided second period saw the visitors lead a charmed life.

fields.headline: Rix's steamroller stalls again
fields.trailText: Come April and Graham Rix usually finds himself in the business of preparing teams to play semi-finals of major competitions rather than muck-and-nettles six-pointers.
fields.body:
Come April and Graham Rix usually finds himself in the business of preparing teams to play semi-finals of major competitions rather than muck-and-nettles six-pointers.

But after failing to come up with three points here for his fifth successive game, the fledgling Portsmouth manager faces a series of matches as big as any he was involved in during his days as coach at Chelsea.

Next up is today's trip to Birmingham, a visit from Fulham and then a match at Blackburn. By then Rix may be regretting their failure to win this one, though in truth Pompey took a point from a game in which QPR did enough to win.

Part of Rix's preparation for the visit of the bottom club was to open the floor to his players. The two penn'orth he got from Lee Bradbury was: "We should steamroller teams for 15-20 minutes then, once they back off, we can play our football."

The striker was as good as his word and with barely a minute gone he ducked into a corner from Lee Sharpe and turned the ball home. But the steamrolling stopped after 25 minutes and it all fell flat for Portsmouth.

Rangers carved out several chances and Andy Thomson, who had what seemed a good goal disallowed in the first half, equalised in the second after Leon Knight's shot was parried.

"Three or four weeks ago we would have folded," said Ian Holloway, still to win as QPR's manager but who had the scant consolation of seeing his team climb off the bottom.

"You're going down with the Rangers," was the reaction of the visiting fans. With Pompey only two points above the safety mark, they may well be right.

fields.headline: Forest switched back on
fields.trailText: The DNR notices were out for Forest on Saturday as their season came within a minute of expiry. If Preston, in the last play-off place, had hung on to their early lead, they would have gone five points clear of Forest with five games to play, against Forest's four. Jon Olav Hjelde's header brought a three-point swing and resuscitation.
fields.body:
The DNR notices were out for Forest on Saturday as their season came within a minute of expiry. If Preston, in the last play-off place, had hung on to their early lead, they would have gone five points clear of Forest with five games to play, against Forest's four. Jon Olav Hjelde's header brought a three-point swing and resuscitation.

In the end a draw was fair and may have suited both. None of the clubs in the so-called chase for the play-offs seem sure they want it. In their last five games Preston have taken six points, Forest and Sheffield United five, Watford four, enabling Burnley (10) and Wimbledon (eight) to tuck in on the pack.

All are marching under the motto "Festina lente" of Suetonius, who gave the retardant pudding its name. Perhaps it is the thought of grinding on to the end of May or perhaps fear of the Premiership. Neither of these clubs are in any state of readiness for the higher grade, on or off the field.

Preston, with a nucleus of Old Trafford discards, play a neat terrestrial game. Anything else would be an insult to a pitch that Peter McCallion might have prepared for the Crucible; he has just won the Groundsman of the Year award.

They seemed to have given up goals for Lent, were glad to see David Healy's free-kick go in off the wall and could have shut the door after the interval as Francis Benali, owner of an Indian restaurant, was turned into a gosht saag. But the best of Jon Macken's three shots in four minutes twanged the bar.

Forest, reportedly looking to revert to their successful status as a club from their unedifying venture as a plc, reflected the lofty mess-up but Andy Johnson's drive deserved some reward. Besides, Graham Alexander cleared three shots off the line. He was one of two men sent off when the sides met in a red autumn mist. On that account the clubs are due in the FA dock on Thursday.

fields.headline: Ipswich survive Robson's return
fields.trailText: When a visiting manager receives a standing ovation then clearly the situation is not normal. After seeing the white-haired Bobby Robson make his first entrance back at Portman Road in charge of an opposing team, Ipswich played as if they had seen a ghost.
fields.body:
When a visiting manager receives a standing ovation then clearly the situation is not normal. After seeing the white-haired Bobby Robson make his first entrance back at Portman Road in charge of an opposing team, Ipswich played as if they had seen a ghost.

While a narrow win over Newcastle United, secured through Marcus Stewart's penalty 14 minutes from the end, has restored George Burley's side to third in the Premiership, Ipswich will need to perform more convincingly on Teesside today if they are to put points between themselves and their rivals for the last Champions League place.

When Robson's outstanding Ipswich side finished runners-up to Aston Villa in the First Division in 1981 the general feeling was that they should have won it. Losing seven of their last 10 matches did not help.

By contrast, should Burley's team manage to come third, the achievement, so soon after winning promotion, will be greeted with considerable acclaim and rightly so. As Ipswich's mentor said after Saturday's match: "They may not have outstanding players like David Beckham or Ryan Giggs but every member of this side plays to his potential and beyond."

Even as he said this, Robson must have wished he could praise his own side in similar terms. In fact until late January Newcastle were winning with sufficient regularity to harbour their own ambitions of European football next season.

Saturday's defeat, however, steepened a decline which has now seen them take two points from seven fixtures. Injuries to Kieron Dyer, Nikos Dabizas and Alan Shearer, who is almost certain to need another operation on his knee that will keep him out until next season, have weakened the spine of Robson's team but a serious reappraisal is surely needed for next season.

Newcastle could take a hint from Ipswich and scour the sort of boot sales which have seen Jim Magilton and the Dutch pair, Fabian Wilnis and Martijn Reuser, flourish at Portman Road. Where St James' Park might struggle is in reproducing the friendly yet business-like background against which Burley's team continues to thrive.

Not that Ipswich did much thriving on Saturday. Against determined but hardly daunting opposition their passing was tentative and their overall game uncharacteristically flabby.

Eventually Hermann Hreidarsson was given the chance to push up on the left flank but the Icelander still failed to shake off a general ennui which might have been punished had Carl Cort's bouncing header past Richard Wright on the half-hour not been disallowed for a push.

To be sure, a hard-hit, wickedly-swerving centre from Reuser did produce a diving header against the bar after 17 minutes but the marksman was a Newcastle defender, Aaron Hughes, who with Andy O'Brien suffered few other moments of anxiety before the moment when the match was won and lost.

This occurred in the 76th minute when Newcastle lost concentration as Mark Venus took a corner, allowing Hreidarsson the header which Nolberto Solano kept out with an arm. Off went Solano and in went Marcus Stewart's 21st goal of the season to end an uncomfortable afternoon.

fields.headline: Poyet prays for rich to get richer
fields.trailText: A rueful smile crossed Gustavo Poyet's lips as he admitted that Ipswich may well pip Chelsea to the Champions League place that the west London club so dearly covet. How ironic it must seem to the Uruguayan that his club, with the highest wage bill in the land, may miss out on qualifying for Europe to George Burley's relative paupers.
fields.body:
A rueful smile crossed Gustavo Poyet's lips as he admitted that Ipswich may well pip Chelsea to the Champions League place that the west London club so dearly covet. How ironic it must seem to the Uruguayan that his club, with the highest wage bill in the land, may miss out on qualifying for Europe to George Burley's relative paupers.

With a squad of superstars to keep content the least Claudio Ranieri must achieve this season is a place in the Uefa Cup but, while this win lifted his team to a season's-best fifth place, Chelsea did not display the form that will have Liverpool or Leeds - both of whom they must visit - let alone Ipswich quaking in their boots.

Chelsea will be reminded of what they are missing this week as the European competitions return. Tomorrow, as Leeds and Arsenal are trying to make the Champions Cup semi-finals, Chelsea travel to Spurs aiming for their third consecutive away win, with victory vital if their late surge up the table is to be rewarded.

"We all dream a lot about the Champions League but I think it's a little bit difficult," said Poyet, whose mishit volley won this match. "We will think about the Uefa position and hopefully the teams ahead of us will keep on making mistakes. You never know."

Failure to make Europe may not just hit Chelsea in their overstretched pockets. Gianfranco Zola is considering a return to Italy in the summer and the prospect of either the Intertoto Cup or nothing at all may help make up his mind.

Southampton's European ambition, alive when three consecutive victories lifted them to eighth, is now dead in the water after their three successive defeats since the departure of Glenn Hoddle.

This performance, with James Beattie hitting a post with a header, suggested that the blues are lifting although they have not scored since Stuart Gray took over as caretaker.

Dan Petrescu, who was devastated at Hoddle's leaving the Dell only two months after buying him from Bradford, said that he is unlikely to follow his old manager to White Hart Lane. "We have to look to the future," the Romanian said. "The manager said he was proud of our performance and things will turn for us if we play this way and keep working hard."

Petrescu was warmly welcomed back but should have had the home fans cursing the day he left when he was put through clear on goal with 20 minutes remaining. His shot, though, was easily gathered by Carlo Cudicini.

Petrescu and Poyet, whose friendship was described as being like "husband and wife" by Poyet, swapped shirts at the end. Chelsea will be hoping that this time next year Poyet's collection will have been bolstered by more souvenirs from the continent.

fields.headline: Wenger sees no end to the monopoly
fields.trailText: Second in the Premiership, FA Cup finalists and Champions League quarter-finalists: by any measure a successful season. So why is it that the overriding feelings about Arsenal this morning are disappointment and under-achievement?
fields.body:
Second in the Premiership, FA Cup finalists and Champions League quarter-finalists: by any measure a successful season. So why is it that the overriding feelings about Arsenal this morning are disappointment and under-achievement?

Most clubs would have given anything for Arsène Wenger's Premiership record: third in his first season at Highbury, champions the next, second by a point the year after and still on course to finish runners-up for the third season in a row. But to a bored and expectant nation that is not good enough. For once the English are not prepared to salute a gallant loser.

What they want is a team to wipe the smile off the faces of the Old Trafford fat cats, who in Premiership terms have not only got the cream but the run of the dairy as well. Three years ago they were the equals of United but even Wenger's famed managerial skills have failed to keep them there.

On Saturday the Arsenal manager was displaying a sense of resignation normally associated with top golfers chasing Tiger Woods. "I think you expect too much of us," he pleaded. "It's not just Arsenal's responsibility to push Manchester United. There are 10 to 15 teams with the potential quality of Arsenal."

That will sound dispiriting to many. But the gap is there for all to see: 18 points last season, currently 16 this. Arsenal were level with United after 12 games but slipped up against Derby and Everton, and off United sailed again.

"We were too poor away" was one of Wenger's excuses. Another was injuries, another the team's problems dispatching more lowly opposition.

To that can be added the lack of quality in depth in the Arsenal squad and the team's frequent inability to turn possession and chances into goals and points.

The farcical way in which a dominant Arsenal handed the title to United courtesy of two bizarre own-goals against Middlesbrough summed up another season in which their only consistent feature has been their inconsistency.

Why? Well, Arsenal's side is less settled for a start. While United have accommodated just two new big-name signings in the past two years - Fabien Barthez and Mikael Silvestre - Arsenal's squad has been overhauled with seven. In a similar vein Arsenal have not fielded the same side two games running in the Premiership this season.

Then comes this suggestion from United's Silvestre: "The reason Arsenal haven't been able to keep pace with United is that, unlike us, they don't have enough English players in their squad."

Whatever the reason, on Saturday Arsenal jeopardised their quest for second place with an inept display that helped ease Middlesbrough's relegation worries.

In fact Boro, though determined and well-organised, scored more goals than they had shots on target as, first, the hapless Edu celebrated his home debut by deflecting Dean Windass' off-target drive into his own net, then five minutes later Edu's fellow Brazilian Silvinho diverted in a hard, low cross for 2-0.

Early in the second half Alen Boksic's delightful back-heel set up Hamilton Ricard for number three.

Meanwhile, Wenger believes his squad will be bedded in for next season. But do not hold out too much hope of United's grip weakening. The Frenchman reckons that, as long as United hold on to their players, even the retirement of Sir Alex Ferguson will have no effect. Perhaps the only hope is to charge United with breaking anti-competition rules.

fields.headline: D-day for Derby as travel sickness deepens
fields.trailText: Perhaps Derby deserve to have spent the weekend feeling a little queasy. After all, they really have only themselves to blame. Rock-bottom Bradford City are the only side with a comparably poor away record and they have long looked doomed to relegation.
fields.body:
Perhaps Derby deserve to have spent the weekend feeling a little queasy. After all, they really have only themselves to blame. Rock-bottom Bradford City are the only side with a comparably poor away record and they have long looked doomed to relegation.

This latest away defeat for Derby leaves them, like Bradford, with just one win on their travels. Jim Smith's team are now only one place above a relegation spot.

Both teams needed this win badly, but only one team seemed to want it. West Ham were two up inside seven minutes, three ahead by half-time and are now all but assured of another season in the top flight.

Derby's capitulation means they must win today against Leicester to stand a fighting chance of fulfilling their own survival criteria of two wins from the last five games. Three of those five matches are against this morning's top three: Arsenal, Manchester United and Ipswich. At least Derby have a five-point cushion between themselves and Coventry.

Smith said: "We have got to beat Leicester, it's our biggest game of the season. We need more resolution and discipline, but I am sure Manchester City and Coventry would love to be in our position. We have got to stop the rot and I am convinced we can do it."

"We pressed the self-destruct button," admitted the assistant manager Colin Todd. "If you analyse when we have lost games, it's because we give away goals at bad times.

"Our destiny is in our own hands, but we've given ourselves a hard task. It's Leicester next, but they are all massive games."

West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp, despite such a comfortable win, seemed angry that his side have got themselves into such a situation this season and looked even more puzzled than Todd.

Redknapp is increasingly having to face up to the fact that a team overflowing with flair is not good enough in the modern game.

"I do still worry about the shape of the team," Redknapp admitted. "We have good days, but we go on a wing and a prayer at times. We look very open at times when we haven't got the ball and all the successful teams have a shape about them."

Redknapp would need to field 13 or 14 players to accommodate his dream team, but Cole, who had a sound game on his recall to the side, believes Harry's game can work.

He said: "Of course me and Paulo can play in the same team, we are two good players. We don't just do it against the smaller clubs, as some people claim, but it is a case of doing it more consistently."

A big day for Derby today then and a long trip to Newcastle for West Ham. The smart money remains on both these sides moaning about playing each other again in next season's Premiership.
