fields.headline: Doherty provides both Hoddle and Sunderland with a double headache
fields.trailText: The late chorus of "Cheer up Peter Reid" from the visiting supporters was drowned by the boos, but the Sunderland manager's mood was beyond repair anyway. Having watched his European drive stall on Saturday, overtaken by a second-half fight-back, Reid duly blew a gasket.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
The late chorus of "Cheer up Peter Reid" from the visiting supporters was drowned by the boos, but the Sunderland manager's mood was beyond repair anyway. Having watched his European drive stall on Saturday, overtaken by a second-half fight-back, Reid duly blew a gasket.

"That's the angriest I've seen him since I came here," said Kevin Kilbane, who had opened the scoring. "He only spoke for about a minute after the match and then walked out in disgust. That said it all."

"We were a disaster, a shambles," confirmed Reid. "That's the worst 45 minutes in my six years here. I feel sick."

While Wearside shares his peeky outlook, Tottenham's triers are earning their spurs. Gary Doherty, signed by George Graham from Luton, has switched between centre-half and centre-forward duties. His performance suggests life under Hoddle might live up to expectations.

Having spent the first half in a fruitless battle with Sunderland's back line, his endeavour brought reward after the interval. Slick passing on the touchline culminated with a Stephen Clemence volley inside Thomas Sorensen's near post. Then Tim Sherwood nodded the Irishman clear and he shot low across the goalkeeper and into the far corner. The shoddy mess that was his late winner prompted one angry Mackem to fling his scarf at the home dug-out.

"I like him up front, but we could have done with him in the defence earlier in the game," said Hoddle. "I'll need longer to assess him and work out where his best position is - that may depend on what players I can bring in - but his character typified the way we came back into it."

"I thought we showed a lot of spirit," added Doherty. "The gaffer geed us up at half-time and had a right go; but we deserved the rollicking. We were awful and hadn't got going."

That start left Tottenham in deficit after just three minutes. Patrice Carteron crossed for Kilbane to rattle home off the underside of the bar. Spurs's problems were compounded when Niall Quinn added a second 10 minutes later. Stefan Schwarz blazed a free-kick beyond the visitors' fragile wall and, although Neil Sullivan's instinctive save deserved better, Quinn was there to poke in the rebound.

The flurry brought hopes of a cricket score but Sunderland's momentum stuttered and Tottenham were spared a spanking.

"At half-time everything looked rosy, but they changed, caused us problems and we couldn't deal with it," added Kilbane. "We've let the manager down, but we've let ourselves down as well." At least this afternoon's trip to

Coventry provides a stage on which to make amends.

fields.headline: Villa's prize in Gallic guise
fields.trailText: An unbeaten run of seven games has done much to ensure Aston Villa manager John Gregory will not be scanning the job adverts this summer, but given Gareth Southgate good cause to consult a careers adviser.
fields.body:
An unbeaten run of seven games has done much to ensure Aston Villa manager John Gregory will not be scanning the job adverts this summer, but given Gareth Southgate good cause to consult a careers adviser.

Eight games ago Villa languished in 14th place and there was an ominous rustle of P45s being prepared in chairman Doug Ellis's office. Gregory's position, already tenuous following public cricticisms of Ellis and a club record £9.5m investment in Juan Pablo Angel - who looked more palooka than potent striker - was fast becoming untenable.

But victory over Everton, adds Villa to the posse of clubs pushing for a place in next season's Uefa Cup. "We're now one point behind Sunderland, who at one stage looked uncatchable," Gregory said. "There's still a lot of points to play for, so anything can happen."

All of which presents several players with a dilemma. Julian Joachim, not even in the squad here, is still transfer-listed following last summer's request and is demanding a new contract. Southgate , determined to join a club which boasts more ambition and regular European football, is fast running out of choice and, as he turns 31 in September, time.

For the time being, though, he is concentrating on the immediate rather than longer term future.

"Once the transfer deadline passed, all thoughts of a move went out of my mind and I just continued to concentrate on doing well for Villa," Southgate said. "I want the club to finish in as high a position as possible and qualify for Europe. Then I will go away on my summer holidays and think things over."

It was Ellis's holiday in Mauritius last year and his chance meeting with David Ginola that resulted in the Frenchman joining Villa - a rendezvous that Gregory had cause to be grateful for on Saturday.

The introduction of Ginola 20 minutes from time resulted in him delivering the cross from which Ian Taylor nodded home the winner. The Everton manager Walter Smith was duly left fretting over his side's prospects of Premiership survival.

"I've said all along that our total of 38 points is not enough," Smith said. "We still need another win to be safe - that's not me being nervous but being realistic."

Ginola's cameo also added up to more Villa Park frustration for David Unsworth, the player who moved there for just three days in 1998.

His stay proved embarrassingly brief because, much to the annoyance of his wife, Unsworth - seeking a return to his native north-west from West Ham - discovered home was 100 miles or so up the M6 rather than just down the road from Villa Park.

But his sense of direction was faultless when he volleyed Southgate's headed clearance past David James to cancel out Dion Dublin's opener. And despite losing the game, at least Unsworth retained his sense of humour.

"I've dedicated the goal to my wife. It was a little present from me to her," he joked. "Unfortunately David Ginola made sure it was not much of a present for us. He's an awesome talent and we couldn't stop him from turning the game for them."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Wanchope gives City a stay of execution
fields.standfirst: Blue half of Manchester kept alive by Costa Rican's backheel
fields.trailText: Now that Manchester United have done the decent thing and wrapped up their latest title, the Doomsday theory applied to next Saturday's derby is out of the window. So City's seasoned pessimists are grimly contemplating the second worst-case scenario: precisely when their team takes the big fall.
fields.body:
Now that Manchester United have done the decent thing and wrapped up their latest title, the Doomsday theory applied to next Saturday's derby is out of the window. So City's seasoned pessimists are grimly contemplating the second worst-case scenario: precisely when their team takes the big fall.

It will probably be not for a at least a week, which could well be a good one for City's legions. No chance of defeat today - they have already got the Arsenal debacle out of the way - and on Wednesday the delicious prospect of the other lot limping out of Bavaria and Europe.

And by Saturday England's champions might be so deflated - or delighted - say Light Blue optimists, that they will just go through the motions at Old Trafford and toss a point City's way.

Fat chance, says Royle, suggesting that theory is straight out of the Theatre of Dreams. When put to City's manager that United would relax, Royle responded: "If you ask Alex that question, you'd better duck."

Royle is more concerned that Leicester will give relegation rivals a helping hand. In the interests of equity they should oblige Derby today and Middlesbrough on Saturday, just as they have Coventry and now City. Leicester are playing poorly enough to do so. This was their fifth successive defeat - the sixth if you include their Cup humiliation by Wycombe - and their manager Peter Taylor is now being asked the kind of questions normally reserved for the embattled Royle and co.

City's manager would gladly trade places, even though he claims that would scarcely be a quantum leap. "I look at 10th position," said Royle; "and I don't think there is a ha'p'orth between us, and no disrespect to Leicester." Taylor's team, as it happens, are now 11th and playing with a lack of confidence - and variation - that suggests worse is to come.

Royle, like most managers in his position, craves that "little bit of luck", which he believes has largely deserted his team this season, but was supplied here when Shaun Goater's back saw the ball rebound into Tim Flower's net from the goal keeper's attempted punch. City almost enjoyed another dollop when Gerry Taggart's diving header, buckling the bar, almost produced a spectacular own goal.

By then City had conceded a muddled equaliser - Steve Howey having the final touch as Ade Akinbiyi attempted to jab home - before learning at half-time of Middlesborough's double slice of Brazilian fortune.

Back here, Paulo Wanchope's winner, an angled backheel, was utterly out of context amid the clumsy proceedings and the player's own downbeat form. Royle called it "pure Paulo", but reminded everyone about the transfer-listed striker that "there's more than just a goal involved in this situation - ask me again at the end of the season."

The Costa Rican, added Royle, is "enigmatic, he's unpredictable," though of course he might have been talking of City. The manager knows they will need all Wanchope's fantasy, as well as collective good fortune, to escape. Tempering the renewed optimism is the solar-plexus blow of Boro's startling victory and the inescapable fact that City must win two of their last four games and even then pray; their current ratio is two out of 17.

Two are at home, against West Ham and Chelsea, the first visitors running down their season but the other pressing strongly for Europe. Whatever the opposition's motivation, home fixtures seem to offer City little advantage; they have not won at Maine Road since early December.

Taylor needs uplift, too. Top in October and fourth early last month Leicester, in the manager's words, "are ruining a very good season - and it has been a good season until the last few games."

He admits the decline is a "big test" of his management. "I've never had such a bad run during my time in charge of a club. This is not the happiest job at the moment. In November, I was flavour of the month. Now they are saying ridiculous things about me. But when I see some of those things, it only makes me more determined."

fields.headline: Leslie Sykes
fields.standfirst:
Academic with a major role in Leicester University's development

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Leslie Sykes, who has died of lung cancer aged 88, played a major role in the development of the University College of Leicester into today's University of Leicester.
fields.body:
From his appointment as the first professor of French in 1947 until his retirement as deputy vice-chancellor in 1978, Leslie Sykes, who has died of lung cancer aged 88, played a major role in the development of the University College of Leicester into today's University of Leicester.

Although, by his own estimation, he was never a distinguished scholar, he was an outstanding teacher and administrator who built up the French department at Leicester to rival that at any comparable institution.

Born in Sheffield, he was the only son of a cabinet-maker who died when he was three months old. He and his mother went to live with her parents and he was brought up, in his own words, "as the only child of a grieving and exceedingly affectionate mother". After seven years' study at the Sheffield Pupil Teacher Centre, he won a major scholarship to Sheffield University, graduated with first-class honours in French and Latin in 1933, and obtained a diploma in education, with distinction in both theory and practice, in 1934.

The same year, he won a senior scholarship to Queen's College, Oxford, spending two years doing research under Gustave Rudler, and then two years in Paris, where he briefly became a member of the Communist party.

Returning to Sheffield as an assistant lecturer in 1938, he completed his thesis on the early 19th-century sentimental novelist Madame Cottin in 1940; it was published, in French, by Basil Blackwell in 1949.

After distinguished war service - the reluctant conscript of October 1940 rose to the rank of lieutenant-colonel by the time of his discharge in April 1946 - he returned to his post in Sheffield before being appointed to the new chair of French at Leicester, at the age of 34. Immediately, he set about turning what was a small and undistinguished department into one of the country's best. Some measure of his success is given in the remarkable results obtained by Leicester students in the London external French degree in the 1950s.

Leicester was one of the first institutions in the country to insist that all modern language students should spend a whole session abroad in the country whose language they were studying. Over the next 20 years, the department grew and flourished under his careful guidance.

Not the least of his achievements was the skilful way in which he selected staff of exceptional calibre, many of whom went on to occupy eminent positions elsewhere. A tall, authoritative figure, and a man who stood for no nonsense, he was fiercely protective of his staff and students and concealed behind a gruff Yorkshire exterior a profound sensitivity and a mischievous sense of humour.

As his administrative skills came to be recognised, he found himself increasingly in demand outside the department, particularly as Leicester prepared for university status, which was achieved in 1957. In the early 1960s, he was one of a small group of academics and industrialists involved in the planning of Warwick University.

In 1969, he was elected pro-vice-chancellor and, a year later, the post of deputy vice-chancellor was created specifically for him, so that the best use could be made of his extensive experience at the highest level. Perhaps his most significant contribution at this stage lay in paving the way for the medical school, which opened its doors in 1975. He also continued to teach a final-year translation class in French for as long as was feasible. He retired in 1978, and subsequently gave a great deal of time and energy to voluntary and community work.

His intention of devoting himself to writing was never realised, but his long-standing interest in electoral reform bore fruit in 1990 with a small, privately published pamphlet, entitled Proportional Representation: Which System?, which attracted wide attention.

After his first marriage ended, he married in 1967 his second wife, Patricia, then a lecturer in the department. She survives him together with Helen, a daughter by his first marriage, and two granddaughters.

 Leslie Clifford Sykes, university teacher and administrator, born November 11 1912; died February 27 2001

webTitle: NUT leaders see off left in fight for 35-hour week

fields.headline: NUT leaders see off left in fight for 35-hour week
fields.standfirst:
Call to reinstate action on staff shortages rejected, paving way for four-union campaign

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Call to reinstate action on staff shortages rejected, paving way for four-union campaign.
fields.body:
The leadership of the National Union of Teachers yesterday won a decisive victory over the left, paving the way for a historic campaign with three other unions in pursuit of a 35-hour week.

The union's conference in Cardiff rejected by 124,404 to 80,024 an amendment by leftwing activists that would have, in effect, scuppered the joint motion agreed by the executives of the NUT and the other unions.

The motion demands a full inquiry into pay and conditions and threatens industrial action to restrict teachers' working hours to 35 hours a week if the government resists. The action would be likely to hit schools in the autumn after ballots.

Supporters of the executive urged the conference to seize an historic opportunity to put its long-time call for teacher union unity into practice.

After the vote, billed as the most important of the conference, Doug McAvoy, NUT general secretary, predicted merger of the main classroom unions within eight years. The government had "lost quite a significant weapon, the weapon of division", he said.

The joint motion was passed last week by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' conference and is set to be accepted on Wednesday by the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers. The Welsh UCAC is likely to agree to it next month.

But NUT leftwingers are furious that the executive suspended last week the joint action with the NASUWT over teacher shortages, where teachers refused to cover for long-term vacancies and staff sickness. Their amendment called for the action to be reinstated until the full independent inquiry is established.

The NUT executive called the action off after the government promised a "review" of workload. The executive accepts that the review falls short of its demands but wants to negotiate over the terms.

But Ian Murch, Bradford branch secretary, said: "It's precisely because it [the motion] is a joint approach that it needs to be protected from the decision by the executive at the start of conference that threatens to undermine it.

"Instead of a new contract for teachers, we are in serious danger of grabbing defeat from the jaws of victory and ending up with nothing more than a bureaucracy circular." Kevin Courtney from Camden said he supported all the words in the joint motion but said the conference had not been allowed to debate the suspension. "We are being asked to acquiesce in the executive calling off the action when the aims have not been met." For the executive, Jerry Glazier urged delegates: "You have the opportunity to make history, to turn 'unity is strength' into effective action, not a cliched slogan."

Hank Roberts, secretary of Professional Unity 2000, said: "This motion represents the greatest opportunity for us in this union in the profession's history  Some people contrast professional unity with action. We need professional unity to be able to conduct positive action."

The vote was a significant blow for the left. Mr McAvoy told reporters: "Up to now the conference has been very positive, and more so than we have had previously." But the leadership had had to work to "change the atmosphere" after the education secretary, David Blunkett, was jeered by some activists when he addressed the conference on Saturday.

Martin Powell-Davies, activist in the Socialist Teachers Alliance and Lewisham NUT secretary, said some delegates had stopped coming to the conference because the executive ignored its decisions.

He said the amendment vote did not reflect the view of teachers having to deal with the consequences of staff shortages. "People will have to see next year if that unity is going to deliver anything. The test for the leadership is going to be: can it deliver on pay and conditions?"

Mr McAvoy said unity was unlikely to happen within the three years left of his term in office. "But I am confident it will happen within the first term of my successor." He said closer working with the NASUWT and ATL reduced the power of the left, which wielded more power at conference than in any other part of the NUT. "As long as professional unity and closer cooperation was a bit of a dream [the extreme wing of the union] could support it. Now it comes closer to reality it's a real problem for them." Eamonn O'Kane, who takes over as NASUWT general secretary next year, is known to be an enthusiast for union unity.

But the current general secretary, Nigel de Gruchy, is a sceptic. "I don't think it is helpful at this stage to be raising that issue," he said in Jersey on the eve of his union's conference. "We have got enough to be going on with."

webTitle: Cleared slap case head to sue for stress compensation

fields.headline: Cleared slap case head to sue for stress compensation
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared after 18 months of investigations of abuse allegations, is to sue her local education authority for compensation for stress.
fields.body:
Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared after 18 months of investigations of abuse allegations, is to sue her local education authority for compensation for stress.

Delegates at the National Union of Teachers' conference in Cardiff gave her a standing ovation yesterday before and after a speech about her ordeal.

"No one must ever have to endure the stress, uncertainty and humiliation inflicted by a minority of so-called colleagues," said Mrs Evans, who returned to her school, St Mary's junior in Caldicot, Monmouthshire, last month.

"I have asked the NUT, and they have agreed to pursue a claim for compensation in respect of the personal stress that I have endured. However, if Monmouth LEA [local education authority] want to short circuit matters by making me an offer now, I will consider it."

The conference voted to campaign for teachers in abuse cases to be given anonymity, and said a teacher facing allegations should not normally be suspended. David Blunkett, the education secretary, announced on Saturday that 25 troubleshooters would be appointed to speed up the investigation of abuse claims.

Mrs Evans was suspended in September 1999 after being accused of slapping a pupil and was convicted by a magistrate last July. The conviction was overturned on appeal, but she faced a further inquiry by police and governors into abuse allegations.

A Monmouthshire county council spokesman said: "We have not been advised of any claim. Our efforts are centred around supporting the governors of the school and Mrs Evans in her return to work."

webTitle: Spin, vitriol but little idealism as 90s soundbites enter political history

fields.headline: Spin, vitriol but little idealism as 90s soundbites enter political history
fields.trailText: Editors of the Oxford Dictionary of Political Quotations had to trawl through 443 years of British politics to find a remark free of sleaze, sycophancy, narcissism, malice, intrigue or pratfalls.
fields.body:
"This judgment I have of you," the Queen told her new first minister, "that you will not be corrupted by any manner of gift - and that, without respect of my private will, you will give me that counsel which you think best."

This is one of the few remarks added to the updated Oxford Dictionary of Political Quotations that is free of sleaze, sycophancy, narcissism, malice, intrigue or pratfalls. The dictionary editors had to trawl back through 443 years of British politics to find and resurrect the quote as a text for today. It was said by Queen Elizabeth I when appointing William Cecil as her secretary of state in 1558.

By contrast, most political utterances from the 1990s onwards that the dictionary finds memorable are vitriolically lacking in idealism.

The first edition was published in 1996. Since then, the chief editor, Antony Jay, notes in his preface to the second edition to be published on Thursday: "Spin doctors have moved rapidly up the national agenda."

Quotes by or about Peter Mandelson stalk the volume despite his fall from power while the dictionary was going to press. "Control-freak Tony [Blair] doesn't let Alastair Campbell and Peter Mandelson go around saying anything they like," says Ken Follett, the novelist and former friend of the prime minister. "Peter isn't the Prince of Darkness - though he may be Lady Macbeth."

Simon Hoggart of the Guardian wins immortality for writing: "Peter Mandelson is someone who can skulk in broad daylight."

Matthew Parris of the Times is quoted for his verse: I'm back in charge - don't mess with me. My cheeks are drawn, my face is bony, The line I take comes straight from Tony.

Mr Mandelson himself is in for saying while minister for the dome: "I can have a big say because I am the owner, the sole shareholder. I don't get involved in half measures." He is additionally quoted for refusing, while in the same job, to be photographed holding a balloon at Disney World: "You'll say I'm in charge of a Mickey Mouse project."

He also features for remarking that "every politician is allowed the occasional gaffe, if only to remind the public that they are still human". This was in apology for having called the Guards brigades "chinless wonders" in March 2000.

Tony Blair's new entries include "She [Diana] was the People's Princess...", his protest "This is not a time for soundbites" during the Belfast peace process, and "We need two or three eye-catching initiatives ... I should be personally associated with as much of this as possible" from his leaked memo to his pollster, Philip Gould.

William Hague earns a place for his tribute to Jeffrey Archer at the 1999 Conservative party conference: "This is a candidate of probity and integrity - I am going to back him to the full." The former Labour leader Neil Kinnock gets in for his tribute to Mr Hague: "I have a lot of sympathy with him, I was once a young, bald leader of the opposition." So does the former Tory leader, Sir Edward Heath, for his reply when told by phone of Margaret Thatcher's downfall in 1990: "Rejoice, rejoice, rejoice."

A later entry is Sir Edward's puzzling remark last year about the 1950s Hollywood starlet Jayne Mansfield: "It was not totally inconceivable that she could have joined me as my wife at No 10."

The education secretary, David Blunkett, is included for his pledge in 1995 - "Let me say this very slowly indeed. Watch my lips: no selection by examination or interview under a Labour government" - and his retraction five years later: "I was parodying George Bush ... Watch my lips was a joke. If I were doing it again, I would say 'No more selection'."

George W Bush gets in for a quote three months before his election as US president: "It's no sign of weakness to talk to your dad."

They said it first

"I have no intention of getting into a war of words with the Women's Institute" Alastair Campbell, after Tony Blair was heckled, June 2000

"A hard dog to keep on the porch" Hillary Clinton on her husband, August 1999

"It is becoming difficult to find anyone in the commission who has even the slightest sense of responsibility" Report on European Commission, the Guardian, March 1999

"The millennium is going to present us with a very sharp portrait of ourselves: drinking is to continue all night and religious observance, as far as possible, is to be kept at bay" Bill Deedes, journalist and former Tory politician, August 1999

"Under every stone lurks a politician" Aristophanes, Greek playwright, 400BC

Mr Mandelson himself is in for saying while minister for the dome: "I can have a big say because I am the owner, the sole shareholder. I don't get involved in half measures." He also features for remarking that "every politician is allowed the occasional gaffe, if only to remind the public that they are still human". This was in apology for having called the Guards brigades "chinless wonders" in March 2000. Tony Blair's new entries include "She [Diana] was the People's Princess...", his protest "This is not a time for soundbites" during the Belfast peace process, and "We need two or three eye-catching initiatives ... I should be personally associated with as much of this as possible" from his leaked memo to his pollster, Philip Gould. William Hague earns a place for his tribute to Jeffrey Archer at the 1999 Conservative party conference: "This is a candidate of probity and integrity - I am going to back him to the full." The former Labour leader Neil Kinnock gets in for his tribute to Mr Hague: "I have a lot of sympathy with him, I was once a young, bald leader of the opposition." So does the former Tory leader, Sir Edward Heath, for his reply when told by phone of Margaret Thatcher's downfall in 1990: "Rejoice, rejoice, rejoice." A later entry is Sir Edward's puzzling remark last year about the 1950s Hollywood starlet Jayne Mansfield: "It was not totally inconceivable that she could have joined me as my wife at No 10." The education secretary, David Blunkett, is included for his pledge in 1995 - "Let me say this very slowly indeed. Watch my lips: no selection by examination or interview under a Labour government" - and his retraction five years later: "I was parodying George Bush ... Watch my lips was a joke. If I were doing it again, I would say 'No more selection'." George W Bush gets in for a quote three months before his election as US president: "It's no sign of weakness to talk to your dad." webTitle: Motor Racing: A triumph of horsepower  and horse sense

fields.headline: A triumph of horsepower  and horse sense
fields.trailText: At the unveiling of the Williams-BMW FW23 at Silverstone earlier this year the team's owner Frank Williams quipped: "We hope for a win or two, if the grey cars or the red cars make a mistake."
fields.body:
At the unveiling of the Williams-BMW FW23 at Silverstone earlier this year the team's owner Frank Williams quipped: "We hope for a win or two, if the grey cars or the red cars make a mistake."

In yesterday's San Marino grand prix Ralf Schumacher delivered the first of what promises to be rather more than "a win or two" in a welcome and long overdue restoration of one of Britain's most popular teams to its familiar winning ways.

A bleak 54-race famine had followed Jacques Villeneuve's triumph in the 1997 Luxembourg grand prix at Germany's Nürburgring circuit, the longest absence from the winner's circle in the team's 24-year history. Since Clay Regazzoni posted the team's maiden grand prix win at Silverstone in 1979, only one of the following 18 seasons, 1988, saw a Williams fail to win at least one race.

Villeneuve's success marked the end of an era. It was to be the final victory for a Renault-engined Williams and instead Williams found itself having to pay a massive £14m in lease fees to use fixed-specification "customer" Renault engines - badged as Mecachrome V10s.

The moment the French company indicated their intention to quit, Williams and his technical director Patrick Head knew they needed to seek out an ambitious, high-technology partner, and as early as late 1996, Williams made their first approaches to BMW.

The German company had been an active engine supplier during the era of turbo-charged engines in formula one during the early 80s, scoring their final victory of that era when Gerhard Berger won the Mexican grand prix at the wheel of a Benetton in 1986. Throughout the mid-90s, however, BMW had taken careful notice of the promotional benefits their rivals Mercedes-Benz were gaining from their association with the McLaren team, however, and gave the green light for a formula one engine programme at the end of 1997.

On the driver front Williams also had a major clear-out. At the end of 1998 Villeneuve moved to the fledgling British American Racing team and Heinz-Harald Frentzen was dropped from the line-up, moving to Jordan. Villeneuve's sudden departure caused the most disruption to the team, who wanted to pair the experienced Canadian driver with the Colombian rising star Juan Pablo Montoya, who had been their test driver in 1998.

However, once Villeneuve left, they decided that Montoya had insufficient experience and sub-contracted him to the Ganassi Indycar team for two seasons. Instead they recruited Ralf Schumacher and Alex Zanardi, who had been racing in the United States for three seasons and was never to feel at ease in the new generation of narrow-track formula one cars. He was bought out of the remaining two years of his contract for around £3m.

Determined to give Montoya a chance to return to formula one, Williams then signed the British rising star Jenson Button to partner Schumacher in the maiden season with the new BMW-engined cars in 1999 and Montoya replaced him at the start of this season.

Williams did a remarkably effective job to finish a distant third in the 2000 world championship but it took the arrival of a brand new BMW V10 engine at the start of this year, plus a new tyre contract with Michelin, before the team could seriously aim for the big time once again. Before the start of the season the BMW executive Mario Theissen, who shares the role of competitions manager with the now retired Berger, said that BMW took the decision to build its new engine even before the start of last season and admitted: "It is quite difficult to hit the edge of technology required by the F1 business, without going beyond it." Yesterday it seemed that they not only hit the target but scored a bull's-eye.

fields.headline: Free trade causes consternation
fields.standfirst: Seattle-style anti-capitalist sentiment is building in anticipation of the pro-free trade Summit of the Americas in Quebec City, reports Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: Seattle-style anti-capitalist sentiment is building in anticipation of the pro-free trade Summit of the Americas in Quebec City, reports Anne McIlroy.
fields.body:
At least no one will be arrested for wearing a scarf. The thousands of pro-democracy and anti-free trade protestors expected to descend on Quebec City this week will face as many 6,000 police officers and a three mile long,10 foot high fence if they try to get anywhere near the 34 world leaders negotiating the largest free trade zone in the world. The local jail has been cleared of prisoners to make room for unruly visitors.

Unless the federal government loses a last-minute court challenge, protestors probably won't be able to get within shouting distance of US president George Bush, Canadian prime minister Jean Chrétien and the other leaders. Heck, local parishioners won't even be allowed in for Sunday services, lest they cause trouble. But in one of several small victories for citizen groups, local politicians have bowed to international pressure (they were the butt of jokes by the big American television networks) and revoked a by-law making head scarves and other identity-hiding clothing illegal.

The other triumph - this one more substantial - will see negotiators agreeing to make the draft text of text of the proposed free trade agreement of the Americas public. "It is a huge victory," says Maude Barlow, chairwoman of the Council of Canadians, one of the leaders of Canada's anti-free trade movement. She says citizens of all 34 countries have the right to know what their governments are up to behind closed doors.

The FTAA [Free Trade Area of the Americas] would create a giant free trade zone by the Arctic ocean to the tip of Patagonia. If negotiations succeed, it could be the most sweeping trade agreement in the world. Everything that is part of the North American Free Trade Agreement between the US, Canada, and Mexico is on the table, plus free trade in services, including health care and education. It would extend controversial provisions in NAFTA that give corporations the right to sue governments that pass environmental or health regulations that get in the way of profits.

The Summit of the Americas runs from April 20-22, and when Quebec City was chosen as host several years ago, it seemed like an honour. But that was before Seattle, when protestors shut down World Trade Organization negotiations in demonstrations that turned violent. The near riots in December 1999 caused $17m [£12m] (US) in property damage. In planning for the summit, Canadian officials say they had to ensure negotiators and world leaders are safe and able to work during their stay.

Officials insist they have gone out of their way to include public interest organizations in their planning. Yet while anti-free trade groups are encouraged to attend their own little summit, executives from corporations who agree to pay up to £250,000 to sponsor coffee breaks, luncheons and receptions will get to network with the politicians.

"Half a million dollars and you are in, no problem, instant access. No money, stay behind the chainlink fence," said New Democratic Party leader Alexa McDonough, who is planning to join the protests. Prime minister Chrétien says such subsidies save taxpayers money, but his plan does little to change the image that corporations are driving the trade negotiations and that ordinary citizens have no say.

fields.headline: Major blast at oil refinery
fields.trailText: Seven ambulances, an air ambulance and more than 50 firefighters were called to a "large fire" that broke out at around 2.30pm at the Conoco oil refinery in south Killingholme, north Lincolnshire.
fields.body:
Seven ambulances, an air ambulance and more than 50 firefighters were called to a "large fire" that broke out at around 2.30pm at the Conoco oil refinery in south Killingholme, north Lincolnshire.

The fire that resulted from the blast was confined to the Saturate Gas Plant, although windows of nearby offices were damaged. The affected area of the plant is used to separate gasolene, propane and butane but the cause of the blast is unknown.

There had been fears that up to four people were missing, but following a head count it was confirmed that all members of staff on shift had been accounted for.

"As far as we're aware at present there are no people unaccounted for," said a spokesman for Humberside fire brigade.

Mike Gillon, a spokesman for the ambulance service, said: "There may have been contractors there over the last few days and of course there may be some difficulty in establishing who was on site."

He said two "minor" casualties had been taken to Grimsby hospital. One was treated for cuts and bruises at the on-site medical centre. Details of the injuries to the second worker have not yet been released.

Local residents said the blast shook nearby buildings and the fire sent up a pall of thick black smoke which was visible for several miles. Black smoke billowing from the blaze could be seen six miles away in the town of Immingham, witnesses said.

Paul Huxford, who works in Immingham's Ford dealership, said: "It looks very bad. We can't see any flames but black smoke has been pouring out for about an hour." A local resident, Mrs Shelagh Bayes, 67, said: "We just heard a loud explosion and can see lots of black smoke.

A spokeswoman for the Diana, Princess of Wales hospital in Grimsby said that staff had been put on standby following the explosion but that they had yet to receive any patients.

webTitle: TV watchdog clears Anne Robinson over Welsh jibes

fields.headline: TV watchdog clears Anne Robinson over Welsh jibes
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Television watchdogs have warned Anne Robinson, host of the Weakest Link, that her controversial remarks about the Welsh "came close to the boundaries of acceptability", but ruled that they fell short of actual racism.
fields.body:
Television watchdogs have warned Anne Robinson, host of the Weakest Link, that her controversial remarks about the Welsh "came close to the boundaries of acceptability", but ruled that they fell short of actual racism.

Viewers inundated the Broadcasting Standards Commission with a record 427 complaints after hearing her describe the Welsh as "irritating and annoying" on BBC 2's Room 101 show.

The BBC and the commission for racial equality were showered with letters, Welsh MPs criticised the quiz show presenter in parliament, and North Wales police are investigating an accusation that she incited racial hatred.

But this week the BSC ruled against the many complaints it had received, deciding that "neither the overall content nor the style of this programme was inherently racist".

Ms Robinson said she would like to banish the Welsh into oblivion in Room 101, explaining: "I've never taken to them. What are they for?"

She admitted: "Being of Irish descent we are all terribly ashamed of ourselves because we can't sing like they can, we can't play rugby like they can and we can't be clever like they are. We used to go on holiday to Wales and they all used to speak Welsh there ... I've just grown to dislike them more and more."

The BSC said that the stereotypes Ms Robinson had raised had been positive ones, adding: "The committee also took into account Wales's position as a constituent nation of the United Kingdom and its achievements both historical and current, which the committee considered gave it a strength and resilience not available to other more vulnerable groups."

However, Eleri Carrog, of the Welsh civil rights group, Cefn, said yesterday: "This is nothing but a whitewash.

"Whoever described objections to people speaking Welsh in their own country as absurd is unaware of the attempts by the English to wipe out the Welsh language over 600 years."

webTitle: Aboard the slave ship of despair

fields.headline: Aboard the slave ship of despair
fields.standfirst: Traffickers buying up the young  in west Africa
fields.trailText: Traffickers buying up the young  in west Africa.
fields.body:
No one knows how many children die as they are shipped to the cocoa plantations of West Africa. What is known are the appalling conditions on many of the boats. Those who have lived to tell of such things say they were left with a tiny amount of food and only filthy drinking water for a journey that lasts days.

The story of the MV Etireno, with its cargo of desperate children, is almost routine in the harsh context of west Africa. So prevalent is child slavery there - the UN estimates there are 200,000 children working as slaves in the region - the boat's captain must be wondering what all the fuss is about.

The dilapidated Nigerian ship has been plying the west coast for years, transporting its cargoes of children to labour in the sprawling cocoa plantations, or to work as servants, and de facto sex slaves, in the homes of the rich. The MV Etireno sailed as freely as any of the slave galleys that once plundered the region of humans for the New World.

A fortnight ago, the vessel had no trouble loading its cargo of children in Benin. The ship had docked there many times before, one of a regular stream of such vessels. It is not clear exactly how many children were loaded this time, but they are likely to be very young and were destined to follow thousands of others to the plantations of Gabon. For once, though, the authorities in Gabon turned the ship away. Cameroon did the same thing, leaving the MV Etireno as a fugitive ship.

Many come from Benin, where they are loaded in the port of Cotonou, a thriving centre of the slave trade in times gone by. Today, selling children is illegal, but not uncommon. Brokers scout the country persuading parents to part with their offspring for a few pounds in return for promises that they will get an education or send money home. Thousands of children, almost all less than 12 years old, end up being shipped to cocoa plantations in Ivory Coast and Gabon.

Four years ago, the Gabonese authorities found 400 youngsters waiting to be unloaded from a ship anchored in the harbour. But mostly the trade is left uninterrupted. There is a long history of child workers moving around west Africa. But according to Esther Guluma, the Benin representative of the UN's children's agency, Unicef, it has taken on more alarming aspects in recent years.

"We have to distinguish between traditional patterns of child labour, that were positive and not negative, which involved children being taken from rural areas to work in their relatives' homes in urban areas so they got an education and a better life," she said. "But in the past few years, because of the deteriorating economic situation there has been a much bigger trade in children where they are very badly abused. Particularly, these large plantations need a lot of cheap labour, obedient labour and children are perfect for that. They work hard all day, you don't have to pay them very much and they don't complain.

"They are subjected to hard physical labour, they are uprooted from their families, they don't have any access to education. It has a real impact on their physical and mental development. Those trafficked as domestic servants, a lot of them are sexually exploited," said Ms Guluma.

The trade is barely hidden, if at all, in many countries, which is why the captain of the MV Etireno is probably so mystified. There is an open market in children in Ivory Coast's capital, Abidjan, where women come to buy them to "help around the house". Child markets also exist in Lagos. In 1996, dozens of malnourished children were discovered being held in the Nigerian city by traffickers waiting for buyers.

Girls from Benin and Togo are particularly in demand in Lagos where they are taken in to the houses of the relatively well off and forced to work for a pittance. But Nigeria also offers up its own, with a flourishing sex trade in young people to Europe and some wealthy Arab countries. Italy is a particularly favoured destination for the traffickers. Most children, though, are destined for the plantations. Even if they survive the long journey there, within a few years of slave labour many children are considered too exhausted or too old to be of any value and are discarded.

According to Unicef, many end up joining the ranks of the poor. And many will never manage to find their way back home.

fields.headline: Radio by numbers
fields.standfirst: The BBC has been slow to keep up with developments in internet radio. But, says Sean Dodson, a ground-breaking new drama looks set to change that
fields.trailText: The BBC has been slow to keep up with developments in internet radio. But, says Sean Dodson, a ground-breaking new drama looks set to change that
fields.body:
Four years is a long time to produce a half-hour radio drama. Unless, that is, that drama has billions of permutations. Einstein's theory that God does not play dice with the universe is the subject of Wheel of Fortune, the BBC's first ever interactive radio play. Due to be broadcast on the internet and on Radio 3 and 4 simultaneously, it offers listeners the chance to navigate their way through a 30-minute experience that, amazingly, offers 94 billion different narrative routes.

Achieving such a staggering number of choices isn't as complicated as it sounds. The producers have developed three separate but overlapping plays. Each has been cut down into 23 one-minute chunks with a narrative "junction" at the end. At each junction, the listener is invited either to continue listening to that stream, or to switch to one of the other two.

Hence, mathematically, the 94 billion options - three to the power of 23. Wheel of Fortune is a tale of chance that mixes the atmosphere of a casino with quantum physics. Written by Nick Fisher, a BBC radio stalwart, it follows a professional gambler, a professor and a hacker as they attempt to defy both God and Einstein's theory to build a system that lets them win at roulette. Wheel of Fortune offers more than just the form of multi-user perspective you find on Sky Sports Active or the latest computer games. Users actually alter the story when they choose to switch, as the same characters say different things in different streams.

"What we are hoping is that even people who don't have access to the net will take the trouble to have two radios or use a radio with presets and switch between stations," explains director Marianne Nancarrow. This will allow radio listeners a similar level of interactivity to that of net users - except that on the airwaves, only two streams will be available at once. To combat this, Wheel of Fortune will be broadcast over two nights. On the first night the hacker's story will go out on R3 and the gambler's story on R4. The following night the gambler's story will be on R3, the professor's on R4.

"They will possibly, probably, hear scenes that they have heard before, but they won't hear them in the same order," explains Nancarrow. "Also, because we are also going out on terrestrial radio we had to make all three configurations work as 30-minute plays. We realise there will always be a proportion of our audience who will not want to interact."

The task of making an interactive radio drama has been a logistical nightmare, says Nancarrow. Scripting and editing is far more complex and expensive than three stand-alone plays. Editing alone takes three times as long, but continuity was the real headache. As Fisher says, "Subatomic particles can be in two places at once, but characters can't."

All of which explains why the play has taken four years to produce. "It is longer than we would have liked," admits Nancarrow. "It's partly because this was a big, unusual project and it was difficult to get a slot on more than one station. And when we started the technology was not yet in place."

Initially scheduled for broadcast next week, Wheel of Fortune has now been put back until after the election. The online version will be archived for a month after transmission - rights issues prohibit a longer period. There will also be a random-access feature that chooses a route for the listener, should stream-hopping prove a little too interactive.

The BBC says Wheel of Fortune represents its wider commitment to audio on the net. While a number of commercial and independent net radio stations have been steaming into the digital future, the BBC could be accused of lagging behind. BBC Online began simulcasting (simultaneously transmitting its on-air content online) its five main stations in November 1999. And in the past six months, all five stations have relaunched. With the exception of a few sporting events, all of the BBC's national radio is now online. But can we yet say that the corporation that did so much to shape terrestrial radio is playing as important a role in shaping net radio?

Simon Nelson, the BBC's controller of new media, says that it is trying hard to catch up, and that Wheel of Fortune is the first in a raft of innovative projects from the corporation. "The thing we understood at the beginning," he says, "was that the amount and quality of content that passes out of our radio stations every day is staggering. If we can tap into that online, then we can effectively extend the life of audio broadcasting."

So as well as simulcasting, the BBC is now offering an increasing amount of "audio on demand". Programmes such as The Archers and Woman's Hour are already online and the corporation has just soft-launched its music portal, bbc.co.uk/music. The site is due to launch fully this summer, although much of its content will be limited to 30-second clips.

One of the ironies of internet radio is that it can often come with pictures. And this is an area that the BBC is keen to push. Last week it announced the launch of Cox TV, a series of webcasts featuring DJ Carl Cox as part of the new-look Radio 1 site. The majority of BBC DJs already have webcams in the studios and a number of outside broadcasts, such as the Leeds Love Parade, are part of the corporation's online remit.

'It's important to understand that we are not just trying to make cheap telly," says Nelson. "We are coming at this entirely from radio. But we have moved away from magazine-type sites and tried to give a more broadcast feel. These are small steps at the moment but it allows us to become a bit more responsive as broadcasters to what people want to hear.

"We have to keep in perspective that we are at the beginning, that analogue listening dwarfs online consumption. We've been given seed funding to represent our brands digitally on these new platforms and to learn as an organisation what audiences will value in the future."

But the BBC will have to be quick. Last week Capital Interactive launched three stand-alone net radio stations. ATK 13, aimed at skaters and gamers; Chyra, aimed at office workers; and Glisn, an R&B station. Capital claims that it has a head start on the BBC because it has fewer commercial restrictions.

Capital is entering an already crowded marketplace that includes such operators as Virgin, Chrysalis and MTV. Also, UK audiences are not restricted to UK sites. US sites such as Spinner.com, Echo.net and Radio Sonicnet have built cult followings in the UK by offering DJ-free, highly personalised stations. To them the future of radio means offering the listener a bewildering array of choice. So could we see these innovations at the BBC?

"We don't see ourselves as in that game," admits Nelson. "We are radio broadcasters and we'll leave the personalise-your-own-radio-station stuff to the commercial players."

Rights are part of the problem: the US and most of Europe have far less restrictive licensing agreements than the UK. Furthermore, the online jukebox model offered by commercial players does not sit well with the BBC's commitment to educate and inform. Still, they are willing to take a chance on an ambitious radio drama in Wheel of Fortune. Will we see more of them? That's anyone's bet.

fields.headline: Vous avez dit Motivés?
fields.standfirst: During the local elections in France a month ago, the media talked a lot about one specific list of candidates called Les Motivé-e-s, originated by a well-known music group. Many young people, who often don't vote, voted for them. Does it mean the younger generation is still interested in politics, asks Karine Vandenhove?
fields.trailText: During the local elections in France a month ago, the media talked a lot about one specific list of candidates called Les Motiv-e-s, originated by a well-known music group. Many young people, who often don't vote, voted for them. Does it mean the younger generation is still interested in politics, asks Karine Vandenhove?
fields.body:
Lors des dernières élections municipales en France, la liste associative « Les Motivé-e-s » a beaucoup fait parler d'elle. Initiée par un groupe de musique toulousain, Zebda, elle a remporté 12,3 % des suffrages à Toulouse. Fortement plébiscitée par les jeunes, elle a su convaincre grâce à des thèmes porteurs et une image jeune et dynamique, loin de celles des partis politiques traditionnels. Pour Laurent Visier, sociologue, cette autre façon - ludique et joyeuse - de faire de la politique séduit les jeunes. « Ils réalisent qu'ils peuvent s'amuser tout en étant militants, » explique-t-il. « Ils sont attirés par ces nouveaux hommes politiques qui leur ressemblent, et qui leur montrent qu'ils ont leur mot à dire pour améliorer leur vie au quotidien. Il sentent qu'ils ont un rôle à jouer. »

Où en sont les jeunes Français avec la politique ? C'est ce que nous leur avons demandé :

Pour vous, que représente la politique ?

Olivier, 17 ans, lycéen : Des promesses jamais tenues et des gens qui retournent leur veste une fois élus. Ça me saoule.

Alice, 21 ans, étudiante, adhérente du parti politique Les Verts et de l'association des jeunes écolos alternatifs solidaires, Chiche : Quand j'ai intégré Chiche, à 16 ans, je voulais prendre ma vie en main et changer le monde. Avec Chiche, je me sens la force d'agir, sans pour autant me prendre au sérieux. Pour nous, la politique doit être festive.

Chrystelle, 24 ans, chômeuse, inscrite sur la liste des Motivé-e-s : Elle devrait représenter ceux qui ont quelque chose à dire et les aider à se sentir bien dans leur ville. Ce n'est pas le cas actuellement et ça me chagrine.

Quels rapports entretiennent les jeunes avec la politique ?

Olivier : Ils décrochent, ne se sentent pas concernés. Avec toutes les magouilles et dessous de table, ils n'ont plus confiance.

Alice : Une fois élus, les politiciens disparaissent. C'est de la politique spectacle. Les jeunes en ont marre de cette mascarade. Donc, ils ne votent plus. Les politiciens devraient montrer qu'ils sont présents, qu'on peut leur parler, qu'ils sont proches de nous et qu'ils agissent pour notre bien à tous.

Chrystelle : Certains jeunes sont impliqués et veulent faire bouger les choses, d'autres s'en foutent car ils pensent que les politiques sont tous des pourris, et donc, baissent les bras.

Comment intéresser les jeunes à la vie politique du pays ?

Olivier : Que les hommes politiques soient plus proches de nous, plus présents sur le terrain, et arrêtent de nous baratiner avec leur langue de bois.

Alice : Rendre la politique intéressante et agréable. On peut rigoler tout en faisant de la politique. Or, les partis traditionnels ont une démarche vieillote. C'est ultra-chiant. Il faut favoriser la participation de tous aux débats et montrer que chacun est important. Comme le font les associations de quartiers.

Chrystelle : Leur dire qu'on peut faire la politique autrement et qu'on peut faire avancer les choses, que ce n'est pas trop tard. Ils veulent du concret. Ils ont des idées mais ont besoin d'aide pour les mettre en Ïuvre. Il faut leur dire que tout le monde est important, quel que soit son statut social. La philosophie des Motivé-e-s : faire bouger les gens en les impliquant dans la vie de la cité et en leur expliquant ce qu'est la politique.

Comment expliquer le succès remporté par la liste des Motivé-e-s ?

Alice : Ça fait partie des nouvelles formes d'engagement politique qui me rassurent sur le devenir de la politique. Les jeunes toulousains ont montré qu'ils étaient intéressés et qu'ils souhaitaient participer à la vie de leur ville.

Chrystelle : Les gens se reconnaissent à l'intérieur de notre mouvement et adhèrent à nos idées : que la politique se fasse avec tous, et que tous soient représentés. On a montré que la politique fait partie de notre quotidien, dans notre ville. Notre but : expliquer comment fonctionne la municipalité et montrer que tout le monde peut s'investir et agir. Si on prend les problèmes à bras-le-corps, on peut, ensemble, les résoudre, dans la joie et la bonne humeur.

Glossaire/Glossary

agir to act
baisser les bras to give up

baratiner to sweet-talk, do the sales pitch

bouger to change
ça me chagrine it bothers me

chiant, chiante boring, really annoying
décrocher (coll.) to switch off

un dessous de table a bribe

s'en foutre (v. coll.) not to give a damn

la langue de bois platitudes

une magouille a fiddle/scam

en avoir marre (v. coll.) to be fed up

une mascarade a charade

fortement plébiscité par les jeunes attracting a large number of young voters

prendre les problèmes à bras-le-corps to tackle problems head-on (lit. to seize them bodily)

un thème porteur a strong message

tous des pourris (v. coll.) all corrupt

ça me saoule that makes my head spin/does my head in

se sentir concerné to feel involved

retourner sa veste to be a turncoat

tenir une promesse to keep oneÕs promise

une démarche vieillotte an old-fashioned approach

webTitle: High-ranking Taliban official dies of cancer

fields.headline: High-ranking Taliban official dies of cancer
fields.trailText: Mullah Mohammed Rabbani, the second most powerful figure in Afghanistan's Taliban regime, died of cancer today, aged 44.
fields.body:
Mullah Mohammed Rabbani, the second most powerful figure in Afghanistan's Taliban regime, died of cancer today, aged 44.

Rabbani was head of the Taliban governing ministers' council, a position equivalent to prime minister. He died in neighbouring Pakistan, where he had been receiving treatment, officials said.

"The Taliban has lost a great leader, a brave and important mujahedeen [holy warrior]," foreign minister, Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil, told reporters in the Afghan capital.

A UN aircraft took Rabbani's body to his native Kandahar in southern Afghanistan, the headquarters of the ruling Taliban.

Three days of mourning have been declared in Afghanistan and Rabbani will be buried with full Taliban honors, said Mr Muttawakil. Mullah Mohammed Omar, the reclusive Taliban leader, will attend the funeral.

Rabbani was among the first wave of Taliban who swept into Kabul in September 1996, driving warring Islamic factions led by former defense chief Ahmed Shah Massood and President Burhanuddin Rabbani from the capital.

fields.headline: Eight injured in Bradford riots
fields.trailText: Three people were arrested last night after inner city rioting in Bradford that left eight people injured and caused thousands of pounds' worth of damage.
fields.body:
Three people were arrested last night after inner city rioting in Bradford that left eight people injured and caused thousands of pounds' worth of damage.

Smashed windows were being repaired and the wreckage of burnt-out cars removed this morning after violence involving hundreds of youths in the West Yorkshire city's Lidget Green area.

West Yorkshire police were today trying to establish what sparked the clash, though officers could not confirm initial reports of an argument between white and Asian youths.

Sergeant Paul Hepworth said: "People were fighting in the street when we arrived but it does not appear to be racially motivated at this stage. There were Asians youths in the main, fighting Asian youths and others."

Superintendent Mark Whyman later told a press conference: "Nobody is saying this is a racial incident to us at this time, but we are looking at the situation to take in all the facts. It is fair to say that our assessment is that there were mixed groups involved.

He continued: "There are tensions in Bradford, it is a multicultural society, but our work hasn't given us indications of problems that we saw in Lidget Green last night. It has blown up extremely quickly but we also gained control very quickly."

Mr Whyman said a 42-year-old dark European, a 19-year-old Asian and a 32-year-old white man were currently being questioned.

Police were called at 8.30pm last night to reports of a large fight at the Coach House pub in Legrams Lane, a West Yorkshire police spokesman said.

About 130 officers in riot gear attended the incident and were confronted by youths throwing bricks and petrol bombs.

The spokesman said: "The Coach House itself was badly damaged with windows broken and reports of a fire on the premises. A number of vehicles were set on fire. These disturbances were spread over a large area and involved a number of groups."

A second pub nearby, the Second West, was also badly damaged, a takeaway restaurant was broken up and a chemist's shop looted and set on fire.

None of the injuries were serious, though two people were kept in hospital overnight with facial fractures.

Extra officers will be placed on patrol in the area tonight.

The spokesman said: "The Coach House itself was badly damaged with windows broken and reports of a fire on the premises. A number of vehicles were set on fire. These disturbances were spread over a large area and involved a number of groups." A second pub nearby, the Second West, was also badly damaged, a takeaway restaurant was broken up and a chemist's shop looted and set on fire. None of the injuries were serious, though two people were kept in hospital overnight with facial fractures. Extra officers will be placed on patrol in the area tonight. fields.headline: Estrada arrested on new charges
fields.trailText: Ousted Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, today turned himself in to the authorities after a special court issued a warrant for his arrest.
fields.body:
Ousted Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, today turned himself in to the authorities after a special court issued a warrant for his arrest.

Mr Estrada has been charged with two counts of corruption while in office. A separate case was also filed today, linked to suspect land deals alleged to have defrauded the government of $16m (£11m) in 1999.

The former president avoided jail by posting bail, but he was fingerprinted and photographed. It was believed to be the first time a warrant has been issued for a Philippine leader.

Narciso S Nario, one of the justices in the Sandiganbayan, the special anti-graft court, said: "Nobody is above the law. We have to bring to court anybody who violates the law, whether he is the most powerful man in the country or the lowliest laborer in the country."

The charges that were the basis of the warrant were perjury and graft. The graft charge involves allegations that Mr Estrada skimmed $2.6m in tobacco taxes. The perjury charge alleges that he misstated his assets and liabilities in 1999, which he declared net worth of only $700,000.

Mr Estrada's presidency came to an end in January after public outcry at the collapse of the six-week Senate impeachment trial that threatened to reveal corruption at the heart of his administration.

He was indicted on April 4 on accusations that he received $82m in kickbacks and payoffs during his 31 months in office.

webTitle: Roy Greenslade's tale of two editors

fields.headline: Disasters and disappointments: a tale of two editors
fields.trailText: Two editors depart, one swiftly and ignominiously, another at her leisure.
fields.body:
Two editors depart, one swiftly and ignominiously, another at her leisure. The Sunday Mirror's Colin Myler paid the price for publishing an article that led to the collapse of a high-profile trial and departed within days of his "serious error of judgment".

The Independent on Sunday's Janet Street-Porter resigned because, despite what she says on this page, I believe she had no clear idea what to do next with her paper.

Her editorship wasn't a disaster, but has been a disappointment. Myler's editorship was a disappointment that ended in disaster.

For legal reasons, I cannot say too much about the reasons for his departure, but it would be unfair to him not to record that his decision to publish was taken with legal advice. It came from a lawyer considered to be an expert in the field who is highly regarded by his peers.

But the buck has to stop on the editor's desk, and Trinity-Mirror had little alternative but to let Myler go. The board also took into account the fact that the Sunday Mirror was deluged with protests from readers who were outraged that their paper had been responsible for such a catastrophic turn of events.

Perhaps Myler, an experienced tabloid hand, would not have had a much longer career at the Mirror anyway. The only reverse in the relentless downward sales drift was due to a marketing initiative, rather than editorial expertise.

Now, with the imaginative appointment of Tina Weaver, deputy to Piers Morgan at the Mirror, there is an opportunity to take a fresh look at a title which has been lacking in lustre for far too long. The clear pointer in the statement by Mark Haysom, managing director of Trinity-Mirror's national papers, about a closer alignment between the daily and Sunday titles is an interesting prospect.

I understand that it does not mean a merging of the two staffs, thank goodness, but will surely mean the kind of coherent branding, in typography, design and editorial content, that is evident at the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday. Doubtless, this could mean that feature pages and columnists currently appearing only in the daily Mirror will make an appearance in the Sunday title.

Weaver, 32, won plaudits for her creation of M magazine, which she has been in the throes of revamping since it moved from Tuesdays to Saturdays. She is renowned for her hard work and her ability to get on with staff.

She and Morgan will work closely together and they both have Sunday paper experience. When she returns from holiday to her new role she will probably take a couple of weeks before she outlines a new vision for the Sunday Mirror. Meanwhile, Myler's deputy, Fiona Wyton, will edit.

Myler's future is altogether less certain. He may face contempt proceedings and, therefore, could be jailed. Trinity-Mirror may also face a heavy fine, given that the aborted trial cost some £8m.

The Myler affair has tended to overshadow the absorbing matter of the Independent on Sunday's prospects once Street-Porter leaves.

The fact that she is staying on for a couple of months confirms that she and her editor-in-chief, Simon Kelner, have enjoyed a harmonious relationship. He chose her, stuck by her and now he must find a successor in whom he can have the same confidence.

There are three strong internal candidates, as our panel below on the runners and riders, reveals. By refusing to rush into an appointment, Kelner is obviously hoping to flush out other hopefuls from outside, and I understand some people called him within hours of his announcement. An editorship, even of the lowest-selling Sunday title, is a powerful lure.

The successful candidate will need to persuade more people that there is a good reason for buying the Independent on Sunday when its two main rivals are enjoying such success.

The Sunday Times, a behemoth which has apparently unlimited resources, defies the slippage in the market while the Observer, under editor Roger Alton, has managed that most difficult of tricks: reversing decline and winning new readers.

By contrast, the Sindy has been treading water and must find some flippers quickly if it isn't to drown. Kelner and his owners, Tony O'Reilly's Independent group, are obviously not going to panic.

But if a celebrity editor failed to raise the paper's profile, they need to take a new direction. I seem to recall that one of Street-Porter's predecessors, Rosie Boycott, attracted a big audience with her campaign to legalise cannabis. It may not have been popular with her bosses, but it was the kind of stunt that got the paper talked about.

When a paper is bottom of its market, it has to take risks, has to be a maverick. In many ways, that was expected of Street-Porter who, instead, chose to play it straight, producing a paper that tended too often to be rather dull, if also professional.

Perhaps our review of possible candidates will help Kelner make up his mind?

webTitle: Mandela hits out at Aids drug firms

fields.headline: Mandela hits out at Aids drug firms
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, has accused the world's biggest drug companies of exploiting his country by charging exorbitant prices for HIV/Aids drugs.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, has accused the world's biggest drug companies of exploiting his country by charging exorbitant prices for HIV/Aids drugs.

In a television interview yesterday, Mr Mandela defended the South African government's decision to circumvent international patent rules and allow manufacturers to copy expensive drugs.

Thirty-nine drug companies have taken the government to court over the issue. Mr Mandela is first defendant in the case, which resumes this week. "I think the pharmaceuticals are exploiting the situation that exists in countries like South Africa - in the developing world - because they charge exorbitant prices which are beyond the capacity of the ordinary HIV/Aids person. That is completely wrong and must be condemned," said Mr Mandela.

"The government is perfectly entitled, in facing that situation, to resort to generic drugs and it is a gross error for the companies, for the pharmaceuticals, to take the government to court."

Official figures show that one in nine South Africans is infected with HIV or already has Aids and only a tiny minority of those 4.7m people can afford appropriate drugs.

Mr Mandela's intervention comes as pressure is mounting on drug firms to abandon their insistence on enforcing patent rights in the developing world. Campaigners argue that poverty-stricken countries cannot afford the higher prices for patented products.

fields.headline: Australia's swimming in scandal
fields.standfirst: The crystal-clear reputation of the country's competitive swimmers has been muddied by a new performance-enhancing drugs case, says Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: The crystal-clear reputation of the country's competitive swimmers has been muddied by a new performance-enhancing drugs case, says Patrick Barkham in Sydney.
fields.body:
Australia is a nation of water babies. 85% of its population live within 30 miles of the beach and the country punches well above its weight in international swimming, consistently coming a close second to the US. Its swimming heroes - Ian Thorpe, Grant Hackett and Susie O'Neill - enjoy a sporting pin-up status comparable to that experienced by David Beckham in Britain.

Australia's swimming stars have also publicly prided themselves on being drug-free while being very ready to aggressively point accusatory fingers when other nations' swimmers post suspiciously good times. So it was a major shock and embarrassment for the whole country last week when Gennadi Touretski, the Australian coach of stars like butterfly world record holder and Olympic 400m relay gold medallist Michael Klim, was charged with possessing a banned anabolic steroid. Touretski maintains his innocence and will appear in Canberra magistrates court on May 3.

If found guilty he faces up to six months in jail and the cherished "clean skin" reputation of Australian swimming will appear seriously tarnished. This fear moved prime minister John Howard to make an extraordinary intervention late last week when he personally wrote to Klim. "I want you to know that you and the entire Australian swim team has the support and respect of myself and the nation," he said. "Your strong stand against drugs in sport is an example to young Australians and your clean record speaks for itself."

Touretski was headhunted by the lavishly funded Australian Institute of Sport [AIS] after his success with the Russian team at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. The brilliant Russian swimmer Alexander Popov, with four Olympic titles to his name, followed Touretski to Canberra to continue his association with the coach.

Popov, like Klim (who released confidential drug test results showing he had passed all of the 47 tests in his career), maintains his complete innocence. "I have had an association both socially and professionally with Gennadi for 11 years," he said. "I have never had any need to question his credibility or his ethics."

But the panicky Australian swimming agencies are already moving to isolate the coach, who became an Australian citizen in 1996, in an attempt to preserve Australia's drug free image. AIS has suspended Touretski, while Australian Swimming Inc has also dumped him from its coaching roster for the swimming world championships in Japan in July.

Touretski's friends point out that some things in the affair that just don't add up. The coach reported the theft of the safe to police after it was stolen from his Canberra home. Found by a dog walker in a shallow pond, inside it police allegedly found Olympic medals belonging to Popov and Klim and the banned steroid Stanozolol, for which Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson was stripped of his 100m gold medal at the Seoul Olympics in 1988.

But why would Touretski report the stolen safe to the police if he feared they would find it with the steroids inside? And what use would he have for Stanozolol, which is regarded as an old, crude and easily detectable performance-enhancing drug?

Despite these questions, shame-faced Australian swimming fans can hear the schadenfreude emanating from the international swimming community. English swimmer Paul Palmer said: "Some might say they're not surprised. I would just say that it is very interesting."

The Australians have upset plenty of people in the past with their whispers of drug-induced performances. Susie O'Neill last year called her rival Dutch swimmer Inge de Bruijn's world record-shattering performances "a bit suss", while Kieran Perkins - the Queen Mum of Australian swimming - publicly called US swimmer Gary Hall Jnr a drug cheat before the Sydney Olympics. He was hardly accurate: two years earlier Hall had tested positive for marijuana, which is about as far from a performance-enhancing drug as you can get.

Some Australians are conceding that the country needs to tighten up its drugtesting regime between competitions as well as stop its judgmental and suspicious attitude towards other successful performances in the pool. "Swimmers in glass pools shouldn't throw mud," thundered an editorial in The Australian newspaper. Many feel that Australian swimmers are now only reaping what they sowed.
