fields.headline: Look behind the dot.commotion
fields.trailText: The demise last week of the techy business read Industry Standard Europe coincided with the merger in the US of the two companies which provided commentary on the new economy, Powerful Media (owners of Inside magazine and the Inside.com website) and Primedia, owners of Brill's Content.
fields.body:
The demise last week of the techy business read Industry Standard Europe coincided with the merger in the US of the two companies which provided commentary on the new economy, Powerful Media (owners of Inside magazine and the Inside.com website) and Primedia, owners of Brill's Content.

The individuals mangled in this pile-up of content catastrophes reads like a Who's Who of the new economy. Steve Brill, owner of Brill's Content, Michael Hirschorn and Kurt Andersen of Inside and John Battelle of the Standard were all in the vanguard of spreading the electronic word. They were not the callow fools who cratered Boo.com but seasoned professionals whose very business was second-guessing the market.

Indeed, in Kurt Andersen's overlong byte-buster of a novel, Turn of the Century, he introduces the neat joke of a character made redundant by News International after Rupert Murdoch's great dot.com disaster. A masterful piece of prediction, but an irony which will not be lost on a journalist as sharp as Andersen.

Inside.com and Brill's Content will now merge and produce a "media industry (print) bible" entitled Inside Content, while the website becomes a paid-for only service. The Industry Standard Europe has rather reversed the equation by folding its glossy mag, but sticking with its core US publication and website.

The unhappy circumstances of these forced marriages and measures are the alarming economic downturn in the US and the dot.com crash in Europe. The fact that the publishers which were part of the story they reported are retrenching is apposite and will no doubt be interpreted as a further piece of evidence that the web don't work. Whereas in fact their lessons, particularly the Industry Standard's lesson, is that media doesn't work full stop. In a downturn, the overheads of a magazine are far scarier than those of a website and the revenues are no more secure.

What is blighting the publishing industry at the moment is the fact that there is a recession just around the corner. It is the economy, stupid, as the maxim runs. But because the seeds of the recession were sown in Silicon Valley, the issue surrounding dot.com viability has become clouded to the point of opacity.

On the one hand, we are assured that the advertising model for the internet does not work - advertisers report low "click through" rates, banners and buttons are not the panacea, we are told. Yet open the FT last Wednesday and there was the plain fact that, with more than 2% of all ad spend going on the net, it has overtaken cinema as a medium.

Obviously there are far more websites than cinemas, and herein lies a problem. But to crack 2% within five years is an astonishing achievement. Until recently, US research company Jupiter was predicting that online advertising would increase by 2005 to $16.5bn, which represents 8% of national ad spend, with 73% of advertisers claiming they would increase their online advertising within the next 12 months.

Undoubtedly this figure is revised downwards on a daily basis. But let's look at the alternatives. On the same page of the FT which featured the internet overhauling cinema, there was a quaint report about the Telegraph shrinking by four cm. Telegraph CEO Dan Colson, the cheeky monkey, pays homage to earlier editors with shrinking papers - resurrecting the old joke that a smaller paper will make it easier for women to read owing to the shorter length of their arms.

But in fact, it is a measure which reflects the imminent 11% rise in the price of newsprint. Couple this with the fact that the most exposed newspapers have seen a 40% drop in parts of their advertising business in the first quarter of 2001 and it is tempting to suggest that newspapers don't "work" either.

But of course we know they do, because we have 200 years of experience which proves it. If the portable printed word had been invented two years ago, then given a blank piece of paper now, you wouldn't think in a million years that putting ink and pictures on it would make a viable business.

Powerful, Primedia and the Standard do not prove that the internet is a bad place to be at the moment. They prove that publishing is a bad place to be at the moment.

The business cycle has always been thus. Johann Gutenberg invented the amazing moveable type printing process in 1436, but later incurred such a huge cost in the process of developing the technology that he was eventually sued by his partner Mr Fust. Fust and his son-in-law made a fortune from printing. Gutenberg died in poverty. It is a lesson every dot.com disaster victim can take some heart from, though sadly allegories do not pay the wages.

Johann Gutenberg invented the amazing moveable type printing process in 1436, but later incurred such a huge cost in the process of developing the technology that he was eventually sued by his partner Mr Fust. Fust and his son-in-law made a fortune from printing. Gutenberg died in poverty. It is a lesson every dot.com disaster victim can take some heart from, though sadly allegories do not pay the wages.

fields.headline: Alec Guinness's gay side revealed
fields.trailText: Sir Alec Guinness had a homosexual side which remained publicly unknown in his lifetime because of the flair for evasion and secrecy which was also his trademark as an actor.
fields.body:
Sir Alec Guinness had a homosexual side which remained publicly unknown in his lifetime because of the flair for evasion and secrecy which was also his trademark as an actor.

This is to be disclosed in three new theatrical biographies. They will reveal that Guinness, who died last August aged 86, was arrested, charged and fined in court in Liverpool in 1946 for a homosexual act in a public lavatory.

But the case went unreported because - unlike the late Sir John Gielgud in a similar episode seven years later - he had the quickness of wit to give a false name which aroused no suspicions.

Guinness called himself "Herbert Pocket". Police and court officials failed to spot the fact that this is the name of a character in Charles Dickens' Great Expectations. Guinness had played the part onstage in 1939 and, at the time of his arrest, was about to play it as his screen debut in David Lean's film of the novel.

By contrast, Sir John Gielgud was less astute when he was arrested for importuning in London in 1953.

He gave the name "Arthur Gielgud", using his less known first Christian name. He was quickly rumbled and the case made newspaper headlines which shadowed him for years.

In their deceptions, both eminent actors are thought to have been acting on private advice from sympathetic policemen who were impatient for homosexual law reform. But the less worldly Sir John failed to realise he was meant to give a false surname as well as Christian name.

The Liverpool prosecution is disclosed after 55 years in Sheridan Morley's authorised biography of Guinness, to be published on May 3. It is also to be disclosed by the novelist Piers Paul Read, Guinness's authorised biographer, and in another Guinness biography by Garry O'Connor.

Last night Mr Morley - son of the actor Robert Morley, a Gielgud contemporary - said Guinness's gay side had "always been known" to his father and family friends in the theatre such as Dame Gladys Cooper.

"As a character actor he was a sort of spy, which made him good at deception in life as well as art," Mr Morley said. "He was keeping secret this other side of his life. He was very, very high church and guilt-ridden." In 1946 Guinness was happily married with a young son. "If the case had come out, it would have traumatised him," Mr Morley said.

Guinness rapidly went on to become one of the British cinema's biggest stars, appearing in such films as Oliver Twist, Kind Hearts and Coronets, The Man in the White Suit and The Lavender Hill Mob. He was later cast romantically opposite Grace Kelly in The Swan.

"Because he was less established than Gielgud, disclosure would probably have done him more harm,'' Mr Morley said. "He was more vulnerable. But he would probably still have got character parts. He would always have survived."

fields.headline: Saddam supports sanctions
fields.standfirst: Iraq's dictator is playing a dangerous diplomatic game over UN sanctions, which he has been using to his advantage, writes Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: Iraq's dictator is playing a dangerous diplomatic game over UN sanctions, which he has been using to his advantage, writes Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Hands up if you know the answer to this: does Saddam Hussein want sanctions against Iraq to be lifted?

The question is trickier than it looks. Take last month's Arab summit in Amman, for instance, where a call for the lifting of sanctions was abandoned because of opposition from one country - Iraq itself. The draft resolution also called for an end to American-British bombing in the no-fly zones and could, if approved, have been hailed as a major diplomatic success for Iraq.

Instead, Iraq ended up quarrelling with the countries it had been looking to for support. One Arab leader who attended the meeting described Iraq's attitude as "perplexing".

In return for Arab support on the lifting of sanctions, the draft resolution did not require Iraq to do much beyond trying to resolve outstanding issues amicably and agreeing to respect the independence and sovereignty of Kuwait.

(To read the full text of the draft click here)

Iraq objected on the grounds that it has already said that it respects Kuwait's sovereignty, and asking it to say so again implies it cannot be trusted. Iraq's objections to other parts of the draft were equally pedantic and trivial.

Away from the cameras and microphones, the Iraqi delegation behaved in a generally belligerent manner that included personally insulting King Abdullah of Jordan, who hosted the meeting.

It became apparent to many of those attending that the Iraqi delegation had clear instructions from Saddam Hussein not to accept the resolution under any circumstances.

This lends further support to the argument - advanced by a number of experts - that Saddam does not want sanctions to be lifted.

Sanctions, they suggest, have facilitated Saddam's control over the population, partly because of food rationing and partly because the Iraqi government is able to use sanctions as an excuse for its own shortcomings.

Internationally, the disastrous consequences of sanctions for ordinary Iraqis have delivered a series of propaganda victories to Saddam.

If that interpretation is correct, the way to inflict maximum damage on the Baghdad regime would be to lift sanctions immediately. But, while there is no doubt that sanctions in their present form have helped Saddam in some ways, they are also causing him serious difficulties in other areas - such as having oil revenue controlled by the UN.

So the question is really whether the benefits for Saddam outweigh the disadvantages.

A more subtle interpretation of Iraq's attitude - which could also explain the Iraqi delegation's behaviour in Amman - is that Saddam finds sanctions an inconvenience, but not an intolerable one. He believes that they will fizzle out of their own accord and, if he makes no concessions in the meantime, he shall one day claim a final victory in the Mother of Battles.

In the dying days of the Clinton administration, it certainly looked as if sanctions might be on the point of collapsing. But Colin Powell, the new US secretary of state, has other ideas.

Although Mr Powell's plans for "smart" sanctions are not yet complete, the signs are that they will look gentler, but bite Saddam harder.

The gentle bit is to take a much more relaxed approach towards trade with Iraq and to allow a resumption of commercial flights. This will not only help ordinary Iraqis but will also reduce the scope for controversy of the kind that has helped Iraq to win sympathy abroad in the past. Publicity-generating "humanitarian" flights, for example, will simply become unnecessary.

The sting in the tail is that, even with greater freedom to import what it wants, Iraq's oil revenue - its only significant source of income - will still have to be channelled through the UN. At the same time, more effort will be made to block any sources of income that are outside UN control (such as oil smuggling).

Apart from the compulsory deductions for Iraq's oil revenue, which are made by the UN to feed the Kurdish minority in the north and to compensate victims of the invasion of Kuwait, this will mean that Saddam cannot regain full control of the country's finances.

Besides that, western efforts to cajole Saddam into allowing weapons inspectors to return - so triggering a suspension of sanctions - will probably stop.

Sanctions, for all practical purposes, will be permanent so long as Saddam remains in power. This ought to worry Saddam, since it combines the disadvantages (from his point of view) of lifting sanctions with the disadvantages of retaining them.

Before long, he could be regretting his missed opportunity in Amman.

fields.headline: Provos feel the pinch
fields.standfirst:
The government's attitude to Sinn Fein boosts the Real IRA

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The government's attitude to Sinn Fein boosts the Real IRA.
fields.body:
If the so-called Real IRA was indeed responsible for the bombing of a Hendon postal sorting office, it would certainly fit in with its strategy. It is desperate to pull off some kind of spectacular in Britain in order to supplant the Provisional IRA as republican superheroes. True, the target was rather odd. It didn't have the impact of the attacks on the MI6 headquarters and BBC television centre. But the fact that a team is active with enough explosives to do considerable harm illustrates that the group's statement just the day before about stepping up its campaign was no hollow threat.

The Real IRA has survived the ignominy of the 1998 massacre at Omagh, has recruited members of the Provos sceptical about the wisdom of abandoning military activities, and has emerged as a dangerous force. Its short-term aim is to shatter the faltering peace process and, in so doing, expose what it believes is the mistaken faith of Provisional Sinn Fein in the ballot box, the peace process and the conditions it accepted in the Good Friday agreement.

The Provos know their history and the perils associated with it. At several points when militants, feeling they had achieved all that was possible by violence, then pursued their goals without the gun, there were splits. Each time, the breakaway group carried on the military struggle and claimed to be the true bearers of the soul of Irish nationalism. The same happened in 1971 when the Provos, who were prepared to use physical force, split from what became known as the Officials.

Within a couple of years the Provos had eclipsed the Officials and, despite a series of splits afterwards - most notably in 1986, when one of the Provos' founders, Ruairi O'Bradaigh, left to form Republican Sinn Fein - they have remained the most potent republican force. O'Bradaigh left because he feared that Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness would lead the Provos towards a constitutional path which, he believed, would never deliver a united Ireland.

For their part, Adams and McGuinness argued a military victory was impossible to pull off. Though they would not abandon the use of violence, they saw negotiation as the only reasonable way ahead.

About six months before that strategy culminated in the 1998 Good Friday agreement, a number of disaffected Provos who appeared to have taken 12 years to reach O'Bradaigh's position turned their backs on their former comrades, picked up their guns, dug up explosives and laid claim to be the only true inheritors of Irish republican tradition as the Real IRA.

Provo wits lampooned them as "the Coca-Colas", a reference to the drinks company's advertising slogan for "the real thing", but their activities have been nothing to joke about. By threatening the stability of the Provos, they undermine their claim to speak for all republicans.

Bogged down in the continuing argument over arms decommissioning, and suffering from a consequent ban on Sinn Fein attending cross-border ministerial meetings, the Provos are worried by the British government's failure to share their analysis of the situation. They cannot possibly give any further concessions on arms without alienating IRA volunteers and supporters who remain concerned about the benefits of the peace process. In that sense, the Real IRA's main allies are the hard-line unionists and loyalists who oppose the agreement because both sides are keen, for different reasons, to see the collapse of the peace process.

Yet Tony Blair's administration appears becalmed in the face of the coming crisis, having shown scant regard for the fact that the Provos have shown remarkable discipline for three years in the face of provocation from loyalist paramilitaries. There has been no reward for good behaviour, no understanding of the warnings about the difficulties of holding frustrated militants in check and deterring them from joining the Real IRA.

The government played into the unionists' hands at the outset by making a fetish of removing arms from people who manifestly weren't using them. This single matter has bedevilled the whole process, preventing the Provos from being able to proselytise their political gambit as a success among the nationalist community.

That's why the Real IRA, despite its backwardness and lack of politics, has a constituency. If the government really wishes to defeat the bombers it has, belatedly, to bolster the Provos and show that peace is the only "real thing" worth having.

webTitle: Beeban Kidron: her life with two children

fields.headline: Three breakfasts, three bodies to dress, three sets of plans for the day
fields.standfirst: How is a woman supposed to achieve a thing for herself when she has two children?
fields.trailText: How is a woman supposed to achieve a thing for herself when she has two children?
fields.body:
Mornings

The body in my bed is not my own. Curled around me is Noah whose journey through beaded curtains and uncarpeted stairs to find mother's warmth was heralded by the baby monitor. My dreams were not my own. Blaze called out - first for her daddy and then for an orange. My journeys through cold corridors and up unwelcoming treads to cover a child whose blankets have been kicked off, or to accompany a restless bladder to the toilet, render me blank as the canvas on which I intended to make my mark.

My children know not to shout before Mummy has warmed herself into something human with her coffee. Three breakfasts, three bodies to dress, three sets of plans for the day. The illuminated clock on the wall inches slowly to a time when I can expect reinforcements. I hand over Blaze and try to get Noah to school before the lollipop man crosses to the other side of the zebra crossing - a sure sign that we will get a late note - again.

Lunchtime

Slips by unnoticed. I struggle to finish a book, that somebody somewhere thinks would make a good film. During my "difficult teens", I read about worlds that were mysterious. Of fallen women and whores with hearts of gold. Then both birth and death seemed more tangible, whole communities had something to say about each character's destiny. It was not, as now, every woman for herself.

Perhaps I should read one of the pile of polished but illiterate scripts sitting in unopened Fed-Ex packages marked "extremely urgent". Or I could fantasise about having found the perfect project [Kidron is a film director] and try to work out how to mother my children in some far-flung location while working 16-18 hours a day.

The temptation to order a staircarpet is overwhelming. It would unite us during our restless nights. The texture should be comforting, no harsh man-made substances, it should be welcoming to the soft soles of little humans and their tired mothers.

3.30pm

A time ingrained on the heart of every mother. School is out. Rachel, the person who makes life possible, will pick up Noah. For me it is countdown time. Which of the many undone tasks should I tackle?

I remember the accolades, the admiration, the flowers when Noah was born. Five months of prep. Four months of filming. [Kidron was directing To Wong Foo.] Male movie stars in dresses. More time spent discussing mascara and hemlines than in a lifetime of being a woman. Saved by hours from giving birth to a Midwestern baby, I arrived back in New York so pregnant, I never made it to my apartment. I was taken from JFK straight to hospital, my bags still circling unclaimed on the airport carousel.

From my hospital bed I wrote pages of instructions to actors, the editor and the producer who were due to shoot in Times Square. My assistant arrived looking very young and frightened. The father of my child(ren) begged me to stop making a film and just have a bloody baby - after 36 hours and an unspeakable amount of pain, I did. I was too exhausted to know how much my world had changed.

Teatime

As I walk in, I shout: "Anybody I know here?" and the children excitedly call their names. Noah turns to Blaze and says with the authority of the first-born: "I told you she was coming." This is our routine; my place at the table is always laid, whether or not I am eating, and the menu and the day discussed with equal solemnity. Unfortunately teatime in London is when people in Los Angeles arrive in their offices and pick up the phone.

The previous generation paved the way for my generation to gallop unheeded into jobs previously reserved for men. Being a woman was unhazardous; being a mother is quite a different matter. I am not always available. I no longer answer the phone on demand. The cute message from Noah on the machine makes inquirers doubt that I live at this number, and Blaze's penchant for answering the phone unaided to have rambling conversations makes even the most generous question their long-distance phone bill.

Men in Hollywood take photographs of their offspring out of their pockets faster than any western hero ever drew a gun. Further questioning invariably reveals a wife who "elected" to stay at home, or that they see their children only at the weekend. It's a tough business ... for a mother.

Bedtime

Is sometimes a victory - we survived another day. All tucked up, teeth brushed, books read, songs sung, experiences shared - I draw a breath.

Sometimes bedtime brings the terrible sadness of another day on which we failed to bake a cake, paint a mural, count to a hundred without making a mistake. Sometimes bedtime is merely a break in my working day followed by a return to the office. Sometimes it's the beginning of my adult life - a longed-for trip to the theatre, dinner with friends. Sometimes I am defeated by the distracting, relentless day.

I have been up for 15 hours and the muse has yet to appear.

Weekends

The trick is to undertake as little as possible and do it slowly. Today my children are away. After a week of wondering if anything will get done, I am listless with my freedom. Creativity turns out to be a slave to routine and petulantly avoids the available gap, turning its back on me like an ignored lover. Sleep-deprived and fragile without the protective, demanding, distracting layer of my children, seduction is out of the question.

Holidays

Unbelievably, they come around again. No sooner have you perfected your term-time childcare, and stolen every possible moment for your working life, than along comes another holiday.

I can't help wondering about times past - in all the marching and agitating to create opportunities in the public world for women, who did we think was going to bring up the children? We expect and are expected to work. We travel further, do longer hours. Live in streets where our neighbours are strangers. We are a generation of individuals. Where are we to find the energy for our children, our collective future? I was fortunate enough to end up with work that I love. Was it greedy to have children, a stake in the future, genetic continuity, unconditional love given and received?

I have been overwhelmed in Italy, France, the US, South America, the Middle East, my own home, at Christmas, Easter, August, spring/summer/autumn half-term. Overwhelmed by the need to entertain, the mountain of luggage, the heat, the cold, their desire to shit with no toilet in sight and no power to control themselves. I have been overwhelmed by having to carry sleeping children too far. Overwhelmed by buses that won't stop, cafes that won't serve, hotels that won't house, children.

I want to feel heat on my skin, taste new foods, see first-hand the colours of my imagination. But I am confined to short adventures. Travel is no longer the periodic wanderings of an inquisitive mind. We have holidays to "destinations", at peak times and peak prices. Then just as I despair ... I turn around to see Blaze lying on the ground, indenting the earth with her small presence. "That's Blazey," she points out as she stands to survey the indistinct shape. It is all the sensory help I need. Children have an eye for detail. That indentation is me, too.

Work

Is more difficult, fractured, elusive. The muse used to be easier to capture. My reserves of energy were legendary. My name and presence individual. Now I am often referred to as somebody's mummy. I am joined to so many others and separated from myself.

But what about me - the person who existed before childbirth and gravity had their way?

Night

My body twitches with exhaustion. My mind is tripping. I have stayed up beyond 3am reading something beautiful and purposeful. It would make a wonderful film. I am alight with possibility as I check the doors and windows, the baby gate and the nightlights. My children lie in abandoned sleep, they couldn't be more beautiful. I bend down to kiss each of them as I rearrange limbs and blankets. As I imagine the encroaching morning, I fall prey to the ludicrous hope that the children will sleep late. I laugh (quietly of course). They will wake early, I will need coffee, another day will begin. In my secular fashion, I pray. Pray that they, too, will grow to find satisfaction and inspiration in a day like today.

 From What About ME? by Beeban Kidron, from The Fruits of Labour, ed by Penny Sumner, published by the Women's Press Ltd on May 10 at £8.99.

The temptation to order a staircarpet is overwhelming. It would unite us during our restless nights. The texture should be comforting, no harsh man-made substances, it should be welcoming to the soft soles of little humans and their tired mothers. 3.30pm A time ingrained on the heart of every mother. School is out. Rachel, the person who makes life possible, will pick up Noah. For me it is countdown time. Which of the many undone tasks should I tackle? I remember the accolades, the admiration, the flowers when Noah was born. Five months of prep. Four months of filming. [Kidron was directing To Wong Foo.] Male movie stars in dresses. More time spent discussing mascara and hemlines than in a lifetime of being a woman. Saved by hours from giving birth to a Midwestern baby, I arrived back in New York so pregnant, I never made it to my apartment. I was taken from JFK straight to hospital, my bags still circling unclaimed on the airport carousel. From my hospital bed I wrote pages of instructions to actors, the editor and the producer who were due to shoot in Times Square. My assistant arrived looking very young and frightened. The father of my child(ren) begged me to stop making a film and just have a bloody baby - after 36 hours and an unspeakable amount of pain, I did. I was too exhausted to know how much my world had changed. Teatime As I walk in, I shout: "Anybody I know here?" and the children excitedly call their names. Noah turns to Blaze and says with the authority of the first-born: "I told you she was coming." This is our routine; my place at the table is always laid, whether or not I am eating, and the menu and the day discussed with equal solemnity. Unfortunately teatime in London is when people in Los Angeles arrive in their offices and pick up the phone. The previous generation paved the way for my generation to gallop unheeded into jobs previously reserved for men. Being a woman was unhazardous; being a mother is quite a different matter. I am not always available. I no longer answer the phone on demand. The cute message from Noah on the machine makes inquirers doubt that I live at this number, and Blaze's penchant for answering the phone unaided to have rambling conversations makes even the most generous question their long-distance phone bill. Men in Hollywood take photographs of their offspring out of their pockets faster than any western hero ever drew a gun. Further questioning invariably reveals a wife who "elected" to stay at home, or that they see their children only at the weekend. It's a tough business ... for a mother. Bedtime Is sometimes a victory - we survived another day. All tucked up, teeth brushed, books read, songs sung, experiences shared - I draw a breath. Sometimes bedtime brings the terrible sadness of another day on which we failed to bake a cake, paint a mural, count to a hundred without making a mistake. Sometimes bedtime is merely a break in my working day followed by a return to the office. Sometimes it's the beginning of my adult life - a longed-for trip to the theatre, dinner with friends. Sometimes I am defeated by the distracting, relentless day. I have been up for 15 hours and the muse has yet to appear. Weekends The trick is to undertake as little as possible and do it slowly. Today my children are away. After a week of wondering if anything will get done, I am listless with my freedom. Creativity turns out to be a slave to routine and petulantly avoids the available gap, turning its back on me like an ignored lover. Sleep-deprived and fragile without the protective, demanding, distracting layer of my children, seduction is out of the question. Holidays Unbelievably, they come around again. No sooner have you perfected your term-time childcare, and stolen every possible moment for your working life, than along comes another holiday. I can't help wondering about times past - in all the marching and agitating to create opportunities in the public world for women, who did we think was going to bring up the children? We expect and are expected to work. We travel further, do longer hours. Live in streets where our neighbours are strangers. We are a generation of individuals. Where are we to find the energy for our children, our collective future? I was fortunate enough to end up with work that I love. Was it greedy to have children, a stake in the future, genetic continuity, unconditional love given and received? I have been overwhelmed in Italy, France, the US, South America, the Middle East, my own home, at Christmas, Easter, August, spring/summer/autumn half-term. Overwhelmed by the need to entertain, the mountain of luggage, the heat, the cold, their desire to shit with no toilet in sight and no power to control themselves. I have been overwhelmed by having to carry sleeping children too far. Overwhelmed by buses that won't stop, cafes that won't serve, hotels that won't house, children. I want to feel heat on my skin, taste new foods, see first-hand the colours of my imagination. But I am confined to short adventures. Travel is no longer the periodic wanderings of an inquisitive mind. We have holidays to "destinations", at peak times and peak prices. Then just as I despair ... I turn around to see Blaze lying on the ground, indenting the earth with her small presence. "That's Blazey," she points out as she stands to survey the indistinct shape. It is all the sensory help I need. Children have an eye for detail. That indentation is me, too. Work Is more difficult, fractured, elusive. The muse used to be easier to capture. My reserves of energy were legendary. My name and presence individual. Now I am often referred to as somebody's mummy. I am joined to so many others and separated from myself. But what about me - the person who existed before childbirth and gravity had their way? Night My body twitches with exhaustion. My mind is tripping. I have stayed up beyond 3am reading something beautiful and purposeful. It would make a wonderful film. I am alight with possibility as I check the doors and windows, the baby gate and the nightlights. My children lie in abandoned sleep, they couldn't be more beautiful. I bend down to kiss each of them as I rearrange limbs and blankets. As I imagine the encroaching morning, I fall prey to the ludicrous hope that the children will sleep late. I laugh (quietly of course). They will wake early, I will need coffee, another day will begin. In my secular fashion, I pray. Pray that they, too, will grow to find satisfaction and inspiration in a day like today.  From What About ME? by Beeban Kidron, from The Fruits of Labour, ed by Penny Sumner, published by the Women's Press Ltd on May 10 at £8.99.

fields.headline: India's lawless roads
fields.standfirst: Navigating the streets of New Delhi can be a life-threatening experience, as Luke Harding discovered
fields.trailText: Navigating the streets of New Delhi can be a life-threatening experience, as Luke Harding discovered.
fields.body:
Seconds after getting into one of Delhi's many yellow-and-black Ambassador taxis, I realised that I had made a mistake. The driver grinned at me profusely. He then frantically revved his cab, before shooting off on the wrong side of the road.

Things then got worse. After successfully negotiating my local roundabout, with its blue-domed Mughal ruin, we turned left - cutting inside and almost hitting a Maruti car.

Ahead of us, some 500 yards away, I could see a private, white Ambassador car that had stopped ahead of us in the outside lane. Though it was blindingly obvious, my taxi driver somehow failed to see it.

Twenty yards before impact, he pressed on the brakes. There was a feeble response and we shunted cartoon-like into the back of the stationary car with a sickening crunch. After seeing that no one was hurt, I cursed my bad fortune and walked away.

My taxi driver was, of course, completely drunk - an all too common occurrence on Delhi's dangerous and profoundly lawless roads.

Reflecting on the incident this weekend, I realised that I had in fact got off lightly. The front pages of yesterday's Indian newspapers showed the maimed face of Pareksha Vihar, a four-month-old girl injured in the capital's latest road horror.

The baby and her family had been standing on the pavement when a speeding Maruti car hit them. Pareksha flew out of her grandmother's arms, crashed through the windscreen, and landed somewhere between its dashboard and the bonnet.

Instead of stopping, the driver sped off. He finally stopped five kilometres away, dumped the child on the road and fled. According to Delhi police, there was nothing particularly unusual in his behaviour: one in three Delhi-ites involved in an accident never bothers to stop.

The driver, Shravan Arora, a chemist, later claimed to have no recollection of the incident. "The accused refuses any part in the drama. He says he does not remember anything about the baby in his car," one police officer said.

Though charged with kidnapping, rash and negligent driving and causing injury, the police admit there is little prospect of him serving more than six months in prison. No breath test was carried out, so the police have no idea whether Mr Arora was drunk at the time.

Given the state of the other drivers, then, it is hardly surprising that most middle-class Indian families choose to employ chauffeurs rather than drive themselves. Whilst driving in north America or Europe is a straightforward and often tedious experience, in India it is rather like going into battle.

You would no more sit behind the wheel, if you had the option of paying someone else to do it, than drive a tank. There are de facto road rules in India: smaller vehicles always give way to bigger ones; with cyclists and rickshaws at the bottom of the heap.

However, the situation is always complicated by the unexpected: a herd of cows sitting in the middle lane, perhaps, or a tractor at night driving full speed down the wrong side of the road with no lights on.

Such is the congestion, it is hard to go faster than 40mph- the only reason why Delhi's appalling road fatality rate is not higher.

There is one piece of good news, however. A ruling by Delhi's supreme court forcing commercial vehicles to switch from diesel to less polluting compressed natural gas does appear to have made a difference.

The order provoked chaos earlier this month, when angry commuters set fire to buses and blocked highways in protest. But the air already tastes sweeter; the trees seem greener; and the pre-monsoon rains have come.

Perhaps Delhi may finally be on its way towards losing its deserved reputation as one of the world's most polluted cities.

webTitle: Digital giveaway planned to kickstart the big television switch

fields.headline: Digital giveaway planned to kickstart the big television switch
fields.trailText: The government is to give away digital television equipment to targeted 'neighbourhoods' to pave the way to switching off analogue television signals. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The government is to give away digital television equipment to targeted "neighbourhoods" in order to pave the way to switching off analogue television signals.

Ministers want to gauge reaction to digital television from the kind of households that have been slow to make the change to multi-channel television. There are fears that, unless the take-up of digital spreads to the middle-aged and elderly, a "digital divide" could open up.

At present just over a quarter of UK households receive digital television services .

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has said he wants to switch off analogue between 2006 and 2010. The process would be gradual and would not happen until almost all households in a given area are digital. The issue is a political hot potato because the government needs to persuade viewers to switch to digital or risk depriving them of their TV signals.

The main TV providers have signed up to the plan, and the location of the first "digital neighbourhood" will be announced in the next two months and launched by October.

The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, said: "Already, one in three households, and one in two families with children, have digital TV. We need to ensure that Britain leads the world in the development of digital television, that every community shares in the benefits, and that we don't see the creation of a digital divide."

Digital households would get free access to the internet, electronic shopping, and email, in addition to the five terrestrial channels in digital form (which typically means better pictures) and the free- to-air digital channels such as BBC Choice, BBC News 24 and ITV2. The BBC, BSkyB, ITV and ONDigital have agreed to take part in the scheme, which ministers said would "help government and industry understand better the practical and social issues people face in deciding whether to switch from their existing analogue television homes to digital TV".

Ministers will be monitoring viewer requirements of those taking part in the pilot projects, recording what people watch, noting whether viewing habits change and taking note of viewer's satisfaction levels.

He said the scheme would help the government to ensure "the viewer's point of view is paramount in deciding the best strategy to achieve the transition from analogue to digital television".

A £42m project to produce digital course materials in six GCSE subjects, called DCSEs, was announced earlier this month by the education sec-retary, David Blunkett.

This is aimed at giving teachers and pupils instant access to sound, video, interactive and 3-D educational materials.

fields.headline: Prescott prepares for new role
fields.trailText: John Prescott confirmed yesterday that he will move to another ministerial post after Labour's expected general election victory to allow him to take the lead in campaigning for a historic third term in office for the party.
fields.body:
John Prescott confirmed yesterday that he will move to another ministerial post after Labour's expected general election victory to allow him to take the lead in campaigning for a historic third term in office for the party.

Amid speculation that he will succeed Mo Mowlam as minister for the cabinet office, Mr Prescott indicated that he was preparing for a move, although he would retain his title of deputy prime minister.

In an interview with GMTV, Mr Prescott said: "I am very proud to be the deputy prime minister and I think, with Tony [Blair's] agreement, that will probably still continue, but it's his decision. As to what I do then, what I really want to see is a third term Labour government and I am going to be playing a part in that party role in the later stages of the electoral cycle.

"But in the early stage I have still got some ideas about the contribution that I can make, things that I want to do and things I want to do with the prime minister."

The remarks fuelled speculation that Mr Prescott, who is currently secretary of state for the environment, transport and regions, would move to the cabinet office where he would take a key role in campaigning for the election after next. There has been speculation that Mr Prescott could take on a role similar to Tory party chairmen, who always sit in cabinet.

Mr Blair is under pressure to improve links between the government and the Labour party after the selection fiascos over Ken Livingstone for London mayor, and Alun Michael for Welsh first secretary.

Mr Prescott, who will have his own battle-bus this election, is seen as the ideal figure to reassure the party's grassroots supporters, who are likely to grow restless during a second Labour term if public services fail to improve.

Although the interview was somewhat forward-looking, Mr Prescott showed that he still relished his current job. As he prepared to fly to New York, he said that he would make no attempt to hide his anger about George Bush's decision to reject the Kyoto climate deal.

"We must argue with them and get them to agree that we have to have a global solution," he said.

Mr Prescott's remarks about his own future gave viewers a rare glimpse of the manoeuvring which is taking place behind the scenes ahead of the post-election reshuffle. He is widely expected to take the regions portfolio from his current job to the cabinet office.

David Blunkett has made no secret that he will move on as education secretary. At the NUT conference on Saturday he said that he would miss the job "terribly". There is speculation that he will become home secretary in a direct swap with Jack Straw.

Mr Blair will also appoint a new leader of the Lords after Baroness Jay announced that she would stand down after the election. She is expected to be replaced by either Lord Falconer, the cabinet office minister, or Lord William of Mostyn, the attorney general.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: £1m payout to Devon farmer pinpoints cost of crisis

fields.headline: £1m payout to Devon farmer pinpoints cost of crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The spiralling cost of the foot and mouth crisis was starkly illustrated yesterday by news that one of the farmers identified as being at the centre of the spread of the disease has received more than £1m in compensation for the destruction of his livestock.
fields.body:
The spiralling cost of the foot and mouth crisis was starkly illustrated yesterday by news that one of the farmers identified as being at the centre of the spread of the disease has received more than £1m in compensation for the destruction of his livestock.

Willie Cleave, from Highhampton, was the first farmer in Devon to have the disease confirmed after he transported 40 infected sheep from near Carlisle to his slaughterhouse and 13 farms in the county.

"I know it is a lot of money, but then I had a lot of stock. The government revised the figures down just after my livestock was valued. I reckon I'm £100,000 down," he said.

The farmer, who had all of his animals destroyed, is thought to have received £1,000 for each of his 950 cows, £90 for each of his 2,700 ewes.

But despite the large sums being paid, a farmers' leader said yesterday that the compensation may not be enough. The director of the NFU in the south-west, Anthony Gibson, said there was a risk that the current outbreak could follow the same pattern as 1968 when the government had to top up compensation after livestock prices "went through the roof".

Mr Gibson said that with more than 1m animals slaughtered nationwide, there was going to be a "big shortage" of breeding stock. "The cost of replacement animals is going to significantly inflated, and that has got to be taken into account," he said.

Farmers were not allowed to restock their farms for six months, and compensation also covered loss of income for that time.

It also emerged yesterday that the Environmental Services Association, representing private landfill companies, was seeking indemnity from the government for any environmental contamination from cattle buried with the BSE prion. It said that until the foot-and-mouth outbreak, the carcasses of cattle over 30 months which could be carrying the prion had always been incinerated.

"We are very concerned about taking a very resistant prion into a landfill site," said the association's head, Dirk Hazell.

The Ministry of Agriculture said it was working to ensure regulations were complied with. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, acknowledged there were problems with the disposal of carcasses. "There are no easy answers. Each disposal route has arguments against it as well as in favour, and what we have to do is minimise the risks involved," he said.

"There are difficulties with burial and landfill. We must protect the water course and minimise any long-term damage."

webTitle: Teams get ready to vaccinate cattle

fields.headline: Teams get ready to vaccinate cattle
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government appeared to edge closer to a partial foot and mouth vaccination programme yesterday as the crisis across the country deepened with fresh outbreaks in Northern Ireland and vets warning it could be years rather than months before the virus is totally eradicated.
fields.body:
The government appeared to edge closer to a partial foot and mouth vaccination programme yesterday as the crisis across the country deepened with fresh outbreaks in Northern Ireland and vets warning it could be years rather than months before the virus is totally eradicated.

Downing Street was clearly smoothing the way last night towards an announcement on vaccination, highlighting the significance of the publication of a report by the government's chief scientific adviser, Professor David King.

His report said vaccinating cattle before they were moved from winter barns to spring pastures could reduce infection levels in hotspots like Cumbria and Devon.

The need to move the cattle means a decision within the next 10 to 14 days, although the revelation that cold storage for vaccines is being prepared in Cumbria and that dozens of people have been trained to inject cattle has led to speculation that the decision has already been taken.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, was adamant yesterday that nothing had been decided and insisted ministers would consult fully with farmers first.

"Vaccination would only work as a strategy if everybody involved was committed to making it work. I don't think it is a strategy the government could force in," he told BBC1's Countryfile programme.

He acknowledged there were misgivings among farmers, some of whom believe vaccination would only delay Britain regaining its foot and mouth free status and the resumption of meat and milk exports, and could even prolong the outbreak.

"I need to explore all these objections very carefully indeed and then discuss it with people who would be affected before the government moves to such a strategy," he said. "Nobody wants to make a mistake at this stage and do anything that would prolong the disease or compromise the local area."

The Tories, who called for a quick decision on vaccination, jumped on Mr Brown's comments as evidence of dithering by the government. "The longer the government delays deciding about vaccination, the more confused farmers are and the less help it is likely to be," the shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, said.

The report by the Scientific Committee on Foot and Mouth, chaired by Prof King, said experience from the 1967 epidemic suggested that once the cattle were in the open the risk of infection would double. Vaccination, as well as protecting the cattle from the disease, would also stop them from going on to spread it to other livestock, reducing the potential level of infectivity in the area.

Yesterday the number of confirmed cases of foot and mouth in the UK rose to 1,316, - an increase of 27 over the weekend - but it was the two new cases in Northern Ireland that caused most concern. The only other outbreak of foot and mouth in the province was six weeks ago in a flock of sheep at Meigh in South Armagh. Officials believed they had contained the disease and the EU export ban was lifted in most of Northern Ireland two weeks ago.

But last night culls of thousands of cattle, pigs and sheep were in progress in Cushendall, Co Antrim, where foot and mouth was confirmed yesterday and Ardboe, Co Tyrone, where the disease had been diagnosed two days earlier.

The new outbreaks raise the spectre that the disease might have been incubating in livestock across the province for weeks. If that worse case scenario is confirmed it will have a devastating effect on the economy of Northern Ireland where agriculture and the food industry is worth £800m a year - 6% of GDP.

Brid Rodgers, Northern Ireland agriculture minister, said investigations were continuing into the causes of the outbreaks, but confirmed the illegal movement of animals was suspected. Ulster's chief veterinary officer, Bob McCracken, confirmed that none of the cases had been wind-borne. The return of the virus to the island prompted Joe Walsh, Irish agriculture minister, to order stricter border controls in a bid to prevent the disease spreading.

In England a group of vets has written to the agriculture minister calling for an end to the slaughter policy, warning that the tail of the infection should now be measured in years rather than months.

"We must face the fact that FMD may already be endemic in UK sheep," the letter, signed by nine vets from across the country, said. "Other countries have successfully used vaccination, and eminent vets and scientists abroad and at home cannot understand our delay."

webTitle: Comment: The weather is tourism's problem

fields.headline: We're in denial about the weather. That's the problem.
fields.standfirst: It's not foot and mouth killing tourism. It's the rain
fields.trailText: It's not foot and mouth killing tourism. It's the rain.
fields.body:
A prime member of that most cherished, government-sanctified species, the American tourist with big bucks to spend, came back from the New Forest a few days ago. "How was it?" I asked. "Disgusting," he said. "You mean all the fear and disinfectant and funeral pyres?" "Oh no, that was all right. It was just that I'd forgotten how disgusting the weather is here."

Pause there, among the frantic wittering. Up to 2m Brits - a record - jet out this Easter to the sun. They are somehow traitors. The Scottish tourism minister who went to Italy for his break is certainly knee-deep in haggis lasagne. Newspaper reporters - six from the Telegraph, alone - fan out across the nation eating in deserted restaurants and sleeping in lonely beds. Headlines talk of "cash lifelines" for "devastated tourist industries". We might be watching a particularly blood-boltered episode of ER.

This pulsating dispatch comes to you from a natural front line, from Manchester. It is raining (as it has been raining for most of the past three months). It is raining in the Peak District and the Lake District. It is cold and it is miserable. I have bought a dozen pairs of socks in TK Maxx and eaten decently tender squid in an Italian restaurant. My foot and my mouth.

Meanwhile, in London, harassed ministers plot their responses to the sudden crisis of tourism. Mr Blair wants cash hand-outs, Mr Brown hates anyone but himself handing out "his" cash: Mr Meacher touts an ad hoc bank holiday in September for extra spending purposes, Mr Blair prefers a ninth regular break - maybe Trafalgar Day - every October. Nobody acknowledges the awful truth. Our weather is lousy, our footpaths - closed or open - are quagmires. None but the hardy few would, in any case, be venturing out through this frigid murk. We are in denial about our weather.

How can that possibly be? We seem, from mindless habit, to talk of little else. Our forecasters, after the debacle of 1987, are the glummest warners in the world. And yet, as tourism supposedly catches pneumonia in early April, it is the sensible souls who pack their suntan lotion and head for Luton or Stansted who are dubbed deserters in this new battle of Britain. Bravery means remaining behind in the rain and watching John Prescott declare some stile fit to pass.

Why on earth should anyone desert Los Angeles (17C and sunny) for this? Or Washington (23C)? Or New York (18C)? Why on earth stay here if you can get to Malaga, a sunny 20C? Diseased animals don't help, of course, any more than a holiday rail network back in the doldrums or the odd bomb from the Real IRA: but let's be real about the problem in turn. For all our ritual introspection, we delude ourselves about our own weather. We pretend - fatally - that it doesn't matter. We start the cricket season any second now and spend its first month in the pavilion. We have the opportunity to put a roof over Wimbledon's centre court and walk away.

An extra bank holiday in October, as the leaves fall and the first storms of encroaching winter come, is pathetically more of the same. Bank holidays in Britain are anyway statistically doomed to frustration - damp opportunities for the burgeoning service industries (including online banks) to serve and the contracting manufacturing industries to go shopping. Perhaps we have so few (16th out of 17 western European countries) because they're such a desultory ordeal? Time to think again.

European comparisons - as cited again last week by the Fabian Society - are meaningless in any case, for we do not have European weather. We aren't Spain or Greece or Italy (or even the mainland centre as the continent heats up). The Swedes and the Finns will look forward to more certain sun than we can. We can be cold and overcast any day of the year and when forecasters predict a glowing summer - as they did last month - the only evidence they cite under pressure is that we haven't had one since 1997.

Tony Blair supposedly believes in joined-up thinking. Let's tie a few ends together. His education department is pondering a supposed revolution in the school year, four shorter terms interspersed by shorter holidays. This is an effort to match standards of European or American achievement. But both Europe and America - the true comparison - don't go that way at all. They have far shorter breaks at Easter and Christmas and pack up for 10 or 12 weeks in June. Their years are geared to reality. They follow the sun.

We eschew reality. We truncate what passes, statistically, for our best chance of summer, and load in redundant weeks of chill dyspepsia after Christmas or through the sodden ides of Easter. And if hoteliers complain, we toss them a soggy October bun.

It defies common sense. Think of Scotland's embattled tourism minister. He may be as patriotic as they come, but there was fog in Glasgow this weekend. Come June, though, come the finest weeks of Scottish weather, the schools will be full of exam takers and the factories whirring with industry. At the very best time to be out, the Scots will be in. Think more closely about the complaining restaurant owners and hotel keepers. They insist on opening for ludicrously long periods by European standards. Because we have no defined holiday season, they potter along growing grim through the sodden spring or appalling autumn, watching staff pick their nails.

That, again, is not the European way, where most openings fit a defined span and staff from Paris or Madrid come down with their clients to open up. My local medieval village in Spain has 14 restaurants and no grocer's shop; none of the restaurants - even at 24C - dreams of opening through the week until June.

What do we have to offer? History, culture, rather better food - and the shimmering chimera of the occasional perfect day. Those are our tourist bankers; they have little to do with footpaths and much more to do with the state of the American or Japanese economy. The moment, in a redundant lather of "Backing Britain", we lose track of that is the moment we become utterly dotty.

One of the most fascinating books of the year so far is Queen Victoria and the Rise of the Riviera by Michael Nelson (IB Tauris, £25). It shows, in revealing detail, how the most British queen of an Indian empire - which she never visited - would slope off summer after summer to the warmth of Nice, and how the opinion leaders of her realm dutifully followed. Queen Vic helped invent international tourism, Britain's gift to the world: she was the trailblazer for Tony and Cherie. Perhaps she'd have fancied Antibes this benighted Easter.

webTitle: Clarke still clings to Tory leadership hope but heals rift with Portillo

fields.headline: Clarke still clings to Tory leadership hope but heals rift with Portillo
fields.trailText: Kenneth Clarke, the former chancellor and one of the few Tory "big beasts" standing at the election, sees himself as a future leader of the Conservative party, despite reports that he had given up hope.
fields.body:
Kenneth Clarke, the former chancellor and one of the few Tory "big beasts" standing at the election, sees himself as a future leader of the Conservative party, despite reports that he had given up hope.

Supporters of Mr Clarke, the unofficial leader of the Tory left, say he holds out hope that the party will abandon its lurch to the right and turn to one of the few Conservatives who is popular among voters.

"Ken still sees himself in the frame - why do you think he'd be carrying on at the age of 60 if he didn't think there was a hope," one ally said. "Don't forget that he came top in the membership section of the 1997 leadership contest." Despite his supporter's bullish remarks, Mr Clarke is said to be enough of a realist to acknowledge that his chances of succeeding William Hague are remote, not least because the new intake of Conservative MPs after the election will be overwhelmingly Eurosceptic. Mr Clarke has never been forgiven by many members of his party for sharing a platform with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown at the launch of the cross-party Britain in Europe campaign.

Allies on the "one nation" wing of the party say that Mr Clarke is warming to Michael Portillo, a ministerial colleague at the Treasury in the 1990s where they clashed over Europe. There were reports yesterday that Mr Clarke privately told allies recently: "I think Portillo would be more effective as leader than Hague has been."

Mr Portillo has issued strict orders to his supporters to say nothing about the leadership, for fear of unsettling the Tory election campaign. However, Mr Hague is expected to face a challenge if he fails to achieve a significant dent in Labour's majority. Most members of the shadow cabinet say that Mr Hague needs to increase the number of Tory MP from the 165 elected in 1997 to around 230, which would cut Labour's majority by 96.

Mr Portillo is seen as the frontrunner to succeed Mr Hague because he is the only candidate with any hope of uniting the party's pro-European and Eurosceptic wings. Allies of Mr Clarke were impressed when Mr Portillo appeared at an event organised by the One Nation Conservative Mainstream group at the party's spring conference in Harrogate.

Moderate Tories say they have been encouraged by Mr Portillo's political change of heart since he lost his seat at the last election, in which he has spoken the language of inclusivity. They accept that Mr Portillo is a strong Eurosceptic, but they believe he sounds less shrill than Mr Hague.

"It is interesting to note that Michael has made a point of saying he is not a never man on the single currency," one pro-European Tory said. "You could imagine a scenario after Tony Blair wins a euro referendum in which Michael will live with the result whereas Hague and his crowd will take to the bunker and fight to the death to save the pound."

Mr Clarke underlined his newly discovered admiration for Mr Portillo in a recent BBC interview. "Michael has persuaded me that he has had a genuine political rethink," Mr Clarke said, confirming that they are on speaking terms. "I think he has moved to a more comfortable and broader political ground. That is the secret of political success, because society feels more comfortable with politicians like that."

fields.headline: Prescott prepares for new role
fields.trailText: John Prescott confirmed yesterday that he will move to another ministerial post after Labour's expected general election victory to allow him to take the lead in campaigning for a historic third term in office for the party.
fields.body:
John Prescott confirmed yesterday that he will move to another ministerial post after Labour's expected general election victory to allow him to take the lead in campaigning for a historic third term in office for the party.

Amid speculation that he will succeed Mo Mowlam as minister for the cabinet office, Mr Prescott indicated that he was preparing for a move, although he would retain his title of deputy prime minister.

In an interview with GMTV, Mr Prescott said: "I am very proud to be the deputy prime minister and I think, with Tony [Blair's] agreement, that will probably still continue, but it's his decision. As to what I do then, what I really want to see is a third term Labour government and I am going to be playing a part in that party role in the later stages of the electoral cycle.

"But in the early stage I have still got some ideas about the contribution that I can make, things that I want to do and things I want to do with the prime minister."

The remarks fuelled speculation that Mr Prescott, who is currently secretary of state for the environment, transport and regions, would move to the cabinet office where he would take a key role in campaigning for the election after next. There has been speculation that Mr Prescott could take on a role similar to Tory party chairmen, who always sit in cabinet.

Mr Blair is under pressure to improve links between the government and the Labour party after the selection fiascos over Ken Livingstone for London mayor, and Alun Michael for Welsh first secretary.

Mr Prescott, who will have his own battle-bus this election, is seen as the ideal figure to reassure the party's grassroots supporters, who are likely to grow restless during a second Labour term if public services fail to improve.

Although the interview was somewhat forward-looking, Mr Prescott showed that he still relished his current job. As he prepared to fly to New York, he said that he would make no attempt to hide his anger about George Bush's decision to reject the Kyoto climate deal.

"We must argue with them and get them to agree that we have to have a global solution," he said.

Mr Prescott's remarks about his own future gave viewers a rare glimpse of the manoeuvring which is taking place behind the scenes ahead of the post-election reshuffle. He is widely expected to take the regions portfolio from his current job to the cabinet office.

David Blunkett has made no secret that he will move on as education secretary. At the NUT conference on Saturday he said that he would miss the job "terribly". There is speculation that he will become home secretary in a direct swap with Jack Straw.

Mr Blair will also appoint a new leader of the Lords after Baroness Jay announced that she would stand down after the election. She is expected to be replaced by either Lord Falconer, the cabinet office minister, or Lord William of Mostyn, the attorney general.

fields.headline: Railtrack handout rises to £2bn
fields.standfirst:
Company will ask for more as reliance on subsidy grows

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The amount of taxpayer's money given to Railtrack has been quietly ratcheted up by 33% to almost £2bn in a move which reveals the company's increasing dependency on state handouts, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The amount of taxpayer's money given to Railtrack has been quietly ratcheted up by 33% to almost £2bn in a move which reveals the company's increasing dependency on state handouts, it emerged last night.

John Prescott's announcement of a further £1.5bn of help to the company last week failed to mention that an extra £450m was about to be set aside to compensate Railtrack for a drop in rail freight charges.

The money had been agreed by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, after he allowed freight charges to drop by 50% to encourage greater transportation of goods by train.

Rail freight expanded rapidly after privatisation but has fallen back again, partly because customers have been unable to rely on the service. The Post Office, freight's biggest customer, has been particularly affected.

A senior industry source said yesterday: "The decision vividly demonstrates just how reliant Railtrack has become on the government for help. It is an absurd situation and cannot continue indefinitely unless Railtrack gets a grip."

The government's announcement of another £1.5bn for Railtrack was intended as a pre-election fillip for the industry and to give the electorate an assurance that Labour was backing rail. But the move has backfired. Mr Winsor's announcement went unnoticed, and within hours of Mr Prescott's statement, Railtrack said that it was not enough and it would be coming back for more.

Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, has indicated that the £1.5bn will not be enough to cover the company's renewals and maintenance programme. The money comes from the £1.5bn pot allocated for Railtrack's spending by Mr Winsor over the next five years.

Mr Marshall has also dismayed the government and the industry by admitting that the costs of the west coast main line upgrade between London and Glasgow have shot up by a further £500m from £5.8bn to £6.3bn.

This is the fifth time in less than two years that the project's costs have increased from the original £2.2bn. But Mr Marshall says that Railtrack will bear the extra cost.

If, as expected, Mr Marshall does require more money for the company, he will have to approach Mr Winsor directly.

Railtrack's accounts, due to be published next month, are expected to contain heavy losses this year of at least £500m, largely due to the Hatfield crash.

Mr Winsor is not obliged to provide the any extra money unless he is convinced that Railtrack has presented a sufficiently strong argument. But if the regulator rejected Railtrack's approach, the company would be at crisis point. Either the government would have to intervene or Railtrack would be split up and sold off.

Railtrack's problems are heightened by the fact that it has so far failed to find a new chairman, although it has been searching since the beginning of the year. Several candidates have rejected the job and no new candidate is immediately in sight. The appointment will lead to wholesale changes at board level, including the possible departure of Mr Marshall himself.

The company is also facing lengthy litigation from the train operating companies who are to seek considerably more compensation than the £100m they have so far received as a result of Hatfield. Virgin and Great North Eastern are the two worst-hit operators. They have put up their fares by almost 10% and 3.3% respectively.

Ministers are considering a change in legislation which would give them some access to private utilities, including Railtrack, so that the public's interests could be observed. The government has agreed with Railtrack the appointment of a "public interest director".

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: The king of spin is dead. Long live the spin. There are two levels to Thursday's splash in the Independent proclaiming that Alastair Campbell is "to quit as spin master after the election". One is the well-trawled question of Campbell's role and influence; the other is how Downing Street plans to strengthen its media operation more broadly. For all the talk of a government obsessed with the message, the feeling in number 10 is the opposite - that communications strategy is still in its infancy.
fields.body:
The king of spin is dead. Long live the spin. There are two levels to Thursday's splash in the Independent proclaiming that Alastair Campbell is "to quit as spin master after the election". One is the well-trawled question of Campbell's role and influence; the other is how Downing Street plans to strengthen its media operation more broadly. For all the talk of a government obsessed with the message, the feeling in number 10 is the opposite - that communications strategy is still in its infancy.

"Do we think we have a joined-up, well-planned, efficient, clear-sighted media operation across Whitehall? No," says one Downing Street operative. "We've been trying to develop one, but Kosovo, the petrol crisis and now FMD [one of the many acronyms so beloved inside the building, this means foot and mouth] show that we don't have a strong centre. That's our key objective now." The revolution is permanent.

Campbell's decision last summer to withdraw from most of the twice-daily briefings was the start. As director of communications (the provisional job title) after the election, he will take a longer-term view of the way the Whitehall press machinery operates. Downing Street believes the cull of departmental heads of information early on has worked, to a degree. But they see it as unfinished business, part of a bigger task of modernising government. A bigger, stronger Cabinet Office, charged with forcing through broad policy initiatives and knocking down departmental barriers, will be backed up by a bigger, stronger press team.

The three front-runners for Campbell's job are all expected to figure prominently under the new strategy. Final decisions have yet to be taken. The simplest option is for Godric Smith, Campbell's deputy, to move up a notch. In effect, he has been doing most of the job anyway in his more low-key, self-effacing manner. Putting the job of daily briefings back in the hands of a career civil servant takes much of the controversy out of it; however, Smith would have to hand over to others on questions deemed to be party political.

Under John Major, the job was split between a Downing Street spokesman and a director of communications down the road at Conservative Central Office. That division led to misunderstandings and a lack of clout. One solution mooted in number 10 would be to appoint a political number two, perhaps combining the job of Labour party head of media.

With Lance Price, the incumbent at Millbank Tower, said to be signalling his intention to move on after the election, a new role is being devised for Phil Bassett. Bassett has been very close to Blair since his days on the FT and Times in the early 90s. He was in the frame for the job that Blair gave to Campbell back in 1994. His long-term partner Baroness Symons is a defence minister. She is being thought of as a possible leader of the Lords, giving her cabinet rank. Bassett is now the senior special adviser in the Downing Street strategic communications unit, with a brief to look at the monthly "grid" and "develop strategic messages". Dual promotion would put this meticulously polite but fiercely ambitious couple at the heart of the nexus of power. What remains to be worked out is the demarcation between Smith's and Bassett's roles.

The other candidate for the top job is Tom Kelly, the director of communications at the Northern Ireland Office, who has greatly impressed Blair during his protracted meetings with the parties at Stormont. The plan, according to insiders, is for him to be brought into central command, possibly in a new role linking the Cabinet Office and Downing Street. "We want Tom in play," says one official.

So for all the musical chairs, the reinforcements, will anything change for lobby hacks and punters? Lobby meetings may become less theatrical. But old habits die hard. The off-the-record phone briefings will continue. Selected journalists are still likely to hear from Campbell. It's something Peter Mandelson found hard to drop long after professing to have grown out of his spin job. With more time to oversee media strategy, Campbell will be looking to cut down the number of image problems that have beset the government. That will be his barometer of success for the second term. He may be more out of sight, but he won't be any more out of mind.

fields.headline: An unforgivable delay
fields.standfirst:
Selective vaccination must begin now

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Selective vaccination must begin now.
fields.body:
It is now 18 days since Downing Street promised a decision within 48 hours on whether vaccination would be used to help curb the spread of foot and mouth. But Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, was still insisting yesterday no decision had been taken yet - and none would be until there had been full consultation with the farmers concerned.

Even 18 days ago, vaccination looked the obvious extra weapon needed in the fight to stop the spread of the disease. By last Friday, the government admitted for the first time that its slaughter programme was not working fast enough to meet its targets. There were 540,000 animals waiting to be killed - and another 400,000 carcasses still awaiting disposal. Over the weekend, news emerged that a committee headed by the government's chief scientific adviser, Professor David King, had concluded that vaccinating cattle in hot spots like Cumbria and Devon could reduce infectivity levels.

About 200,000 cattle in hot-spot areas are due to be moved from winter barns to spring pastures. One lesson from the last epidemic in 1967 was that the risk of infection is twice as high once cattle are moved outside. Vaccination would not only protect the cattle but also help prevent the spread of the disease.

Division within the ranks of the farming community is the main reason that ministers have delayed. Some farmers believe vaccination will prolong the epidemic as well as delay the restoration of meat exports. Ministers were right to seek a consensus, but have dallied too long already.

Moreover, vaccination should not be restricted to cattle but extended to rare breeds of sheep, such as Herdwick in the Lake District, which face being wiped out by the disease. If the sheep go, so will the landscape of the Lakes, with the current picturesque upland pastures replaced by coarse scrub.

A second decision facing ministers this week is even easier. Landfill site companies are seeking "unlimited indemnity" from the government before accepting dead cattle for burial. They fear burial could lead to the infective prion, which causes BSE, escaping and spreading CJD, the human form of BSE. They should be given immunity. The government's advisory committee on BSE estimates only 90 out of the 7m cows in the national herd are infected. Almost all are aged over five. There is clearly a risk, but a small one. Restrict it to cows under five if necessary, but get the carcasses buried.
