webTitle: Give lifestyle ultimatum to minor royals, Blair urged

fields.headline: Give lifestyle ultimatum to minor royals, Blair urged
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is facing pressure to warn Buckingham Palace that minor royals must be forced to make a choice between pursuing private business careers and carrying out public engagements.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is facing pressure to warn Buckingham Palace that minor royals must be forced to make a choice between pursuing private business careers and carrying out public engagements.

Downing Street refused to comment yesterday on reports that senior officials are advising the prime minister to take a tough line with the royal family after the Countess of Wessex admitted she cashed in on her royal status. "We do not dignify these reports by commenting," a spokesman said.

However, a Downing Street adviser, who was quoted as saying that minor royals must choose between their public and private roles, reflects the thinking of many ministers. "People like the Countess of Wessex have got to make a choice of whether to continue doing what they do as individuals when it is incompatible with their public position," one Blairite adviser told the Independent on Sunday. "The Countess of Wessex needs to make the choice between carrying on with [her] PR career and playing a full part in the royal family."

The criticisms of the countess come as Buckingham Palace draws up guidelines on the royals' business interests in the wake of the revelations about the business interests of the countess and her scathing private thoughts about the government.

The review, which is being conducted by the lord chamberlain, Lord Luce, is expected to be concluded within weeks, probably by the time the Queen returns to London following her Easter break at the end of the month.

Downing Street has been careful to distance itself from the review, not least because the prime minister does not want to be involved in a debate about the future of the royal family during an election campaign. However, a series of cabinet ministers have lined up to criticise the countess, demonstrating that there is an appetite in the Labour party for reform.

As the royal family turned out in force yesterday for the Easter Sunday service at St George's Chapel in Windsor, Berkshire, there were signs of rifts between the Prince of Wales and Princess Royal, who are both said to favour widespread reforms, and the Duke of Edinburgh who is apparently concerned the royal household is being panicked into action by media criticism.

Prince Edward and the countess attended yesterday's service, holding hands. Their show of unity came as Patrick Jephson, a former private secretary to the late Princess of Wales, warned the royal family was fearing serious trouble.

Mr Jephson, who was disowned by the royal family last year after publishing his memoirs, wrote: "Not only is the royal ship now heading for the rocks, but the officers are squabbling on the bridge and paying the pushier passengers to have a go at the helm. What is needed is real reform - a campaign for real monarchy. That means less of them, less of their opinions, less of their hypocrisy, less of their conspicuous consumption ... more modesty, more humanity, more industry, more spirituality and less mysticism."

Downing Street refused to comment yesterday on reports that senior officials are advising the prime minister to take a tough line with the royal family after the Countess of Wessex admitted she cashed in on her royal status. "We do not dignify these reports by commenting," a spokesman said. However, a Downing Street adviser, who was quoted as saying that minor royals must choose between their public and private roles, reflects the thinking of many ministers. "People like the Countess of Wessex have got to make a choice of whether to continue doing what they do as individuals when it is incompatible with their public position," one Blairite adviser told the Independent on Sunday. "The Countess of Wessex needs to make the choice between carrying on with [her] PR career and playing a full part in the royal family." The criticisms of the countess come as Buckingham Palace draws up guidelines on the royals' business interests in the wake of the revelations about the business interests of the countess and her scathing private thoughts about the government. The review, which is being conducted by the lord chamberlain, Lord Luce, is expected to be concluded within weeks, probably by the time the Queen returns to London following her Easter break at the end of the month. Downing Street has been careful to distance itself from the review, not least because the prime minister does not want to be involved in a debate about the future of the royal family during an election campaign. However, a series of cabinet ministers have lined up to criticise the countess, demonstrating that there is an appetite in the Labour party for reform. As the royal family turned out in force yesterday for the Easter Sunday service at St George's Chapel in Windsor, Berkshire, there were signs of rifts between the Prince of Wales and Princess Royal, who are both said to favour widespread reforms, and the Duke of Edinburgh who is apparently concerned the royal household is being panicked into action by media criticism. Prince Edward and the countess attended yesterday's service, holding hands. Their show of unity came as Patrick Jephson, a former private secretary to the late Princess of Wales, warned the royal family was fearing serious trouble. Mr Jephson, who was disowned by the royal family last year after publishing his memoirs, wrote: "Not only is the royal ship now heading for the rocks, but the officers are squabbling on the bridge and paying the pushier passengers to have a go at the helm. What is needed is real reform - a campaign for real monarchy. That means less of them, less of their opinions, less of their hypocrisy, less of their conspicuous consumption ... more modesty, more humanity, more industry, more spirituality and less mysticism."

fields.headline: Bombers widen the republican divide
fields.standfirst:
Dissidents show ruthlessness as Adams says violence belongs to past
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Dissidents show ruthlessness as Adams says violence belongs to past
fields.body:
Dissident Irish republican terrorists, who vowed last week to step up their campaign of violence, could not have picked a more symbolic target for their latest attack in London.

On the eve of the 85th anniversary of the Easter Rising in Dublin, when republicans attempted to overthrow British rule from the city's GPO, suspected bombers from the Real IRA exploded a device in a postal sorting office in Hendon, north London. No coded warning was given, showing that the Real IRA is even more ruthless than its rivals in the Provisional IRA.

The dissidents also showed they had learnt one key lesson from the provisionals, who secured worldwide headlines with "spectacular" bombings on mainland Britain between 1973 and 1996. By choosing a high-profile target they guaranteed huge coverage and demonstrated that they have not forgotten the old republican adage that violence and propaganda go hand in hand.

The bomb on Saturday night follows a pattern of recent Real IRA attacks in London where the terrorists have selected targets for their symbolic value. Six weeks ago the dissidents secured widespread coverage when they exploded a bomb in a taxi outside the BBC television centre in London. This followed a bomb attack last year on Hammersmith bridge in west London, scene of an IRA bombing in the 1930s, and a rocket grenade attack on the MI6 headquarters in London.

Security sources believe there are up to 10 Real IRA terrorists operating in London. They are drawn from about 100 active Real IRA supporters in Ireland, many of whom defected from the Provisional IRA in South Armagh after the signing of the Good Friday agreement.

The small cells of dissident republican bombers operating in England are waging a war on two fronts. Their main aim is the traditional republican goal of scaring the British people so that they lose interest in Northern Ireland remaining a part of the United Kingdom. They are also playing to a republican audience in Ireland.

Their bomb attacks are designed to show Sinn Fein's supporters that, in the absence of progress in the peace process in Northern Ireland, they should support violence. This was one of the main themes of the Real IRA's Easter message last week in which the terrorists took a swipe at the Provisional IRA for attempting to "uphold" the partition of Ireland by declaring a ceasefire.

Mitchel McLaughlin, the Sinn Fein chairman, said last week that the failure to resolve the current impasse in the peace process only helped the dissidents. "After Omagh [where the Real IRA killed 29 people and two unborn babies in 1998] they couldn't walk down the street to buy a packet of cigarettes," Mr McLaughlin told the Guardian. Since then, they had been able to argue that Sinn Fein had been "suckered".

At the main Easter republican rally in Belfast yesterday a leading member of Sinn Fein blamed the British government for plunging the peace process to "the point of deepest crisis". Angered by the government's call for the IRA to disarm, the Sinn Fein chief whip Alex Maskey said: "Make no mistake: British bad faith and failure to deliver on their obligations to the Good Friday agreement only fuels the 'no' camps and destabilises the peace process itself."

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, underlined his determination to stamp out the dissidents when he sent a powerful message to the republican movement that it should put its violent past behind it. In an Easter Rising commemoration speech in Co Donegal, Mr Adams needled the dissidents by invoking the memory of the IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands whose sister, Bernadette, is one of the leading figures in the 32 county sovereignty movement, the Real IRA's political wing.

"You have to accept that you have a role to play in this struggle," Mr Adams said, referring to Sands' famous remark from his prison cell that every republican had a role to play. "You do not have to emulate the men and women of 1916, you do not have to emulate the [1981] hunger strikers, you do not have to emulate the people who have died in our struggle."

Mr Adams insisted the struggle for a united Ireland continued, but told his audience this should now be achieved around the conference table. In an appeal to his audience to strengthen Sinn Fein's negotiators by voting for the party, he asked: "What about the big issues of getting rid of partition, of ending the union [with Britain]? That cannot be done without the active involvement of ordinary people."

webTitle: London Post Office depot is Real IRA's fifth bomb target

fields.headline: Real IRA makes a point
fields.standfirst:
London Post Office depot is fifth bomb target

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Real IRA underlined its ability to launch terrorist attacks on the British mainland when a bomb planted by the dissident republican group exploded outside a post office depot in north London.
fields.body:
The Real IRA underlined its ability to launch terrorist attacks on the British mainland when a bomb planted by the dissident republican group exploded outside a post office depot in north London.

No one was hurt in the blast which is thought to have been symbolic, marking the 85th anniversary of the Easter Rising when Irish republican insurgents seized control of the post office in Dublin before being overwhelmed by cannon fire from British troops.

The device, which contained about a pound of high explosive similar to that used in the bombing of Hammersmith bridge last year, detonated at 11.28pm on Saturday at a sorting office on the corner of Edgware Road and Goldsmith Road in Hendon, north London. No coded warning was given before the explosion.

The bomb was placed against a bricked-up doorway at the front of the sorting office and the force of the blast shattered windows on the ground and first floors.

The depot, empty at the time, employs 100 staff and is next door to a 400-pupil nursery school and an Irish pub, The Glen, which was full.

Speculating on the motivation for the attack, Alan Fry, head of the anti-terrorist branch, said the anniversary of the siege of Dublin post office was a likely factor.

"It is significant because this is a post office and fits in with the Easter Rising, which is being celebrated in Ireland this weekend," he said.

"You have to consider the state of the Good Friday agreement, and also the film Michael Collins [a dramatisation of the Easter Rising] was being shown on television last night at the time of the explosion."

Mr Fry said the nature and timing of the attack and the device used indicated it was the work of a Real IRA cell thought to be active in the capital.

Police now believe the Real IRA has caused five explosions in London since June, including a large taxi bomb planted outside the BBC Television Centre in west London six weeks ago. Devices were also planted at Hammersmith bridge and on a railway line at Acton, west London, while a mortar was fired at MI6 headquarters in Vauxhall, central London.

The brazen nature of the attacks on MI6 and the BBC has led security sources to speculate that the London cell contains at least one extremely audacious member willing to carry out high-risk attacks.

Mr Fry described the bombers as "reckless" and said only luck had prevented death or injury. "This is a particularly worrying incident, because there was no prior coded warning. It caught everyone by surprise," he said.

"It's just luck that no one was hurt. It's a residential area, there are pubs in the vicinity, and, as it occurred on a busy road, there was also a danger to any passing vehicles. "As everyone knows, flying glass can be fatal. When the windows exploded, they could have shattered over passers-by."

Des O'Kelly, 53, an electrician with London Underground who lives closest to the scene of the explosion, said the blast shook his house. "I was watching Michael Collins on the television when I heard the blast and the whole building shook," he said.

"I knew what it was straight away because I've heard them before in Ireland. I wasn't frightened because once you hear the bang you know the worst is over. But it doesn't make you feel too comfortable when they go off next door."

The Real IRA is still considered the main terrorist threat to the Northern Ireland peace process, and security forces had feared a mainland "spectacular" from the group, possibly a lorry bomb. The modest size and target of this latest attack, however, may indicate that recent developments in Ireland and the US have dealt the organisation a significant blow.

Last month Michael McKevitt was charged with directing terrorism under legislation introduced following the Omagh bombing in 1998. Twenty-nine people were killed in the attack which was carried out by Real IRA members.

His wife Bernadette McKevitt-Sands, the sister of Republican hunger-striker Bobby Sands, was also questioned but released without charge.

It also emerged recently that an American, posing as a wealthy businessman interested in the republican cause, had infiltrated the group. David Rupert is thought to have provided crucial information about the Real IRA to MI5 and the FBI.

He is likely to be the crucial witness at McKevitt's trial, which starts later this month. Last Friday, the Real IRA issued a statement repeating its opposition to the Good Friday agreement and pledged to step up its terror campaign.

fields.headline: Radio by numbers
fields.standfirst:
The BBC has been slow to keep up with developments in internet radio. But, says Sean Dodson, a ground-breaking new drama looks set to change that

More internet news
fields.trailText: The BBC has been slow to keep up with developments in internet radio. But, says Sean Dodson, a ground-breaking new drama looks set to change that.
fields.body:
Four years is a long time to produce a half-hour radio drama. Unless, that is, that drama has billions of permutations.

Einstein's theory that God does not play dice with the universe is the subject of Wheel of Fortune, the BBC's first ever interactive radio play. Due to be broadcast on the internet and on Radio 3 and 4 simultaneously, it offers listeners the chance to navigate their way through a 30-minute experience that, amazingly, offers 94 billion different narrative routes.

Achieving such a staggering number of choices isn't as complicated as it sounds. The producers have developed three separate but overlapping plays. Each has been cut down into 23 one-minute chunks with a narrative "junction" at the end. At each junction, the listener is invited either to continue listening to that stream, or to switch to one of the other two. Hence, mathematically, the 94 billion options - three to the power of 23.

Wheel of Fortune is a tale of chance that mixes the atmosphere of a casino with quantum physics. Written by Nick Fisher, a BBC radio stalwart, it follows a professional gambler, a professor and a hacker as they attempt to defy both God and Einstein's theory to build a system that lets them win at roulette.

Wheel of Fortune offers more than just the form of multi-user perspective you find on Sky Sports Active or the latest computer games. Users actually alter the story when they choose to switch, as the same characters say different things in different streams.

"What we are hoping is that even people who don't have access to the net will take the trouble to have two radios or use a radio with presets and switch between stations," explains director Marianne Nancarrow.

This will allow radio listeners a similar level of interactivity to that of net users - except that on the airwaves, only two streams will be available at once. To combat this, Wheel of Fortune will be broadcast over two nights. On the first night the hacker's story will go out on R3 and the gambler's story on R4. The following night the gambler's story will be on R3, the professor's on R4.

"They will possibly, probably, hear scenes that they have heard before, but they won't hear them in the same order," explains Nancarrow. "Also, because we are also going out on terrestrial radio we had to make all three configurations work as 30-minute plays. We realise there will always be a proportion of our audience who will not want to interact."

The task of making an interactive radio drama has been a logistical nightmare, says Nancarrow. Scripting and editing is far more complex and expensive than three stand-alone plays. Editing alone takes three times as long, but continuity was the real headache. As Fisher says, "Subatomic particles can be in two places at once, but characters can't."

All of which explains why the play has taken four years to produce. "It is longer than we would have liked," admits Nancarrow. "It's partly because this was a big, unusual project and it was difficult to get a slot on more than one station. And when we started the technology was not yet in place."

Initially scheduled for broadcast next week, Wheel of Fortune has now been put back until after the election. The online version will be archived for a month after transmission - rights issues prohibit a longer period. There will also be a random-access feature that chooses a route for the listener, should stream-hopping prove a little too interactive.

The BBC says Wheel of Fortune represents its wider commitment to audio on the net. While a number of commercial and independent net radio stations have been steaming into the digital future, the BBC could be accused of lagging behind.

BBC Online began simulcasting (simultaneously transmitting its on-air content online) its five main stations in November 1999. And in the past six months, all five stations have relaunched. With the exception of a few sporting events, all of the BBC's national radio is now online. But can we yet say that the corporation that did so much to shape terrestrial radio is playing as important a role in shaping net radio?

Simon Nelson, the BBC's controller of new media, says that it is trying hard to catch up, and that Wheel of Fortune is the first in a raft of innovative projects from the corporation. "The thing we understood at the beginning," he says, "was that the amount and quality of content that passes out of our radio stations every day is staggering. If we can tap into that online, then we can effectively extend the life of audio broadcasting."

So as well as simulcasting, the BBC is now offering an increasing amount of "audio on demand". Programmes such as The Archers and Woman's Hour are already online and the corporation has just soft-launched its music portal, bbc.co.uk/music. The site is due to launch fully this summer, although much of its content will be limited to 30-second clips.

One of the ironies of internet radio is that it can often come with pictures. And this is an area that the BBC is keen to push. Last week it announced the launch of Cox TV, a series of webcasts featuring DJ Carl Cox as part of the new-look Radio 1 site. The majority of BBC DJs already have webcams in the studios and a number of outside broadcasts, such as the Leeds Love Parade, are part of the corporation's online remit.

'It's important to understand that we are not just trying to make cheap telly," says Nelson. "We are coming at this entirely from radio. But we have moved away from magazine-type sites and tried to give a more broadcast feel. These are small steps at the moment but it allows us to become a bit more responsive as broadcasters to what people want to hear.

"We have to keep in perspective that we are at the beginning, that analogue listening dwarfs online consumption. We've been given seed funding to represent our brands digitally on these new platforms and to learn as an organisation what audiences will value in the future."

But the BBC will have to be quick. Last week Capital Interactive launched three stand-alone net radio stations. www.ATK13.com aimed at skaters and gamers; www.Chyra.com, aimed at office workers; and www.Glisn.com, an R&B station. Capital claims that it has a head start on the BBC because it has fewer commercial restrictions.

Capital is entering an already crowded marketplace that includes such operators as Virgin, Chrysalis and MTV. Also, UK audiences are not restricted to UK sites. US sites such as Spinner.com, Echo.net and Radio Sonicnet have built cult followings in the UK by offering DJ-free, highly personalised stations. To them the future of radio means offering the listener a bewildering array of choice.

So could we see these innovations at the BBC? "We don't see ourselves as in that game," admits Nelson. "We are radio broadcasters and we'll leave the personalise-your-own-radio-station stuff to the commercial players."

Rights are part of the problem: the US and most of Europe have far less restrictive licensing agreements than the UK. Furthermore, the online jukebox model offered by commercial players does not sit well with the BBC's commitment to educate and inform. Still, they are willing to take a chance on an ambitious radio drama in Wheel of Fortune. Will we see more of them? That's anyone's bet.

Still, they are willing to take a chance on an ambitious radio drama in Wheel of Fortune. Will we see more of them? That's anyone's bet. www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/wheel

webTitle: Israel attacks Syrian radars in Lebanon

fields.headline: Israel attacks Syrian radars in Lebanon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli army attacked Syrian radar targets in the central mountains of Lebanon last night killing at least three soldiers and injuring five, according to security forces in the country.  It was the first Israeli strike against the Syrian positions in the country since 1996.
fields.byline: Sam Ghattas and agencies in Beirut
fields.body:
The Israeli army attacked Syrian radar targets in the central mountains of Lebanon last night killing at least three soldiers and injuring five, according to security forces in the country. It was the first Israeli strike against the Syrian positions in the country since 1996.

"Air force planes this evening attacked a radar target of the Syrian army at Dahr el-Baidar, north of the Beirut-Damascus highway in Lebanon," an Israeli army spokesman said in Jerusalem last night.

He said the attack was in response to Hizbullah attacks in recent months, and most recently last week, when an Israeli soldier was killed in a tank hit by rocketfire near a disputed border zone at the southern Chebaa Farms area.

"The Israeli Defence Forces will not tolerate the continuation of the terrorist policy conducted by Hizbullah operating under the patronage of the Syrian government," the army said in a statement. "The IDF will use all the means at its disposal to ensure the safety of the residents of the northern border and its soldiers."

At least three bomb impacts were heard shortly after midnight in the region, according to witnesses and police.

Israeli jets roared past the mountains on several runs as tracers from ground anti-aircraft were fired at the warplanes.

The region is dotted with Syrian army troop positions that include radar stations, tanks and armoured personnel carriers.

The strike was the first by Israeli warplanes on targets deep inside Lebanon since Israeli forces withdrew from southern Lebanon last May. It was also the first time that Syrian troops were targetted by the Israeli army since 1996, when Israeli helicopter gunships blasted Syrian army positions near Beirut airport during a bombing campaign against Lebanon.

Syria, which has 30,000 troops in Lebanon and is the main power broker there, maintains bases and checkpoints for its forces along the crucial highway in mountains.

The area is strategic because it overlooks much of the Mediterranean coastline and the eastern Bekaa Valley, all the way to the mountain range that forms the border between Lebanon and Syria.

On Saturday, Raanan Gissin, a spokesman for the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said if Hizbullah attacks continued "we will be forced to take the necessary action and exercise self defence and strike at Hizbullah targets".

The Israeli defence minister, Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, late Saturday described the Hizbullah attack as "a sick provocation that has no explanation."

He said his government sent "a clear message to the governments of Lebanon and Syria that we see them as responsible for what happened."

On Sunday, a special UN envoy said the Hizbullah attack in the disputed Chebaa Farms border zone in southern Lebanon violated the UN-drawn line between Lebanon and Israel.

Staffan De Mistura met Sunday with the prime minister, Rafik Hariri, to relay UN concerns about the Hizbullah attack.

The Chebaa Farms area was captured by Israel when it overran the Syrian Golan Heights in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.

Its forces did not withdraw from the area when it ended its 18-year occupation of south Lebanon in May.

webTitle: Last week's failure of the Industry Standard

fields.headline: Bogged Standard
fields.standfirst: Last week, after six months of trying to conquer Europe, that arch-chronicler of the internet age the Industry Standard failed.
fields.trailText: Last week, after six months of trying to conquer Europe, that arch-chronicler of the internet age the Industry Standard failed.
fields.body:
On April 11 2000, I sat in a darkened auditorium in Kensington Town Hall and watched the tanned, sockless, well-coiffed publisher of the American magazine I wrote for bound on to stage to the applause of an audience of European internet cognoscenti.

Here was John Battelle, former managing editor of Wired, founder of the ill-fated Wired UK, returning to Britain to announce plans for a European edition of his latest project, the Industry Standard.

Achieving mind-boggling financial success in America, Battelle and his backers, trade publishers IDG, were thinking then the way all US internet companies were thinking: "We did America, now we do Europe." Somewhere on the horizon were plans for "doing Latin America", and then "doing Asia".

A year later to the day, the booze-sodden staff of the Industry Standard Europe rang me up from the pub (I had left four months previously). The game was over. The doors were shutting. Having raised $30m to expand internationally in 2000, one year was all it took to convince management that "doing" the rest of the world just wasn't going to pay.

The rhetoric of the Industry Standard has always claimed that this trade magazine wasn't a trade magazine at all. It was a business magazine, paying top-dollar for superior journalists to produce hard-hitting investigative pieces about the new media revolution. Editor-in-chief Jonathan Weber spoke often about the inevitable bursting of the internet bubble, telling staffers that the decline would be just as invigorating to write about as the inexorable excesses of 1999 and early 2000.

But trade magazines, after all, are dependent on the industries they cover. The companies you cover are the companies that buy ads, and the companies that subscribe. No one in the management of the Industry Standard can have failed to recognise this. With the first crashes of Nasdaq in March and April 2000, followed by the ominous crash of the well-funded Boo.com in May, the nascent internet industry that had transformed the Industry Standard from a 48-page twice-monthly news mag azine to a 400-page weekly selling $2m in ad space every issue couldn't continue to support such a publishing juggernaut.

After the sparkling success of those early days, observers are looking everywhere for an explanation of why, last Wednesday, IDG and Standard Media International decided to pull the plug on the six-month-old European edition. Its editor-in-chief Jim Ledbetter said news-stand sales were rising and that in terms of recruitment advertising it was already outselling its homegrown competition, New Media Age. Halting publication now is an uncomfortable echo of Battelle's last European venture, Wired UK, whose editors are still baffled by its closure - after 18 months of losses, the magazine was just starting to make money.

One explanation comes from the publisher of a competing publication, who is said to have crowed after hearing the news: "I could have told them the market was too small months ago!" To European observers, and particularly British ones, the money that the Industry Standard laid out on its staff and its parties was legendary. There was doubt from all sides, after our lavish launch party at the Coq d'Argent in October, as to whether the relatively small market for news about the internet industry could ever profitably fund a weekly magazine with a staff of 65 that had a taste for expense accounts.

The Standard's notoriously high salaries didn't go unnoticed here. Last week's press coverage of the Standard Europe's demise was written mostly by journalists who at one time or another during the hiring process lunched at the Standard's expense. Those who took the bait and leapt now join the ranks of other journalists who were lured into new media by high-flying American com panies such as TheStreet.com and the Red Herring who came to Europe with money to burn, burned it, and then headed home.

International expansion started at the Industry Standard because of a push in the US to bring the company to the stock market in an initial public offering. No one, not even IDG, had expected the magazine to be as financially successful as it was, but as the coffers filled, plans to float the company took over. International expansion was key to a float.

In June 1999, I met for the first time with Michael Parsons, then second-in-command on the American publication. A native Briton who had spent five years in California, he was keen to begin placing reporters in overseas posts, and I was his first. I was then a reporter for Wired News, the daily news site started by Wired magazine, and was planning to move to the UK anyway. Parsons suggested I join the Standard, and from August on, the "International" in Standard Media International consisted of an ISDN line into the front room of a two-up, two-down in Edgware, London.

On my second day here, still strung out from jet-lag and the exhaustion of trying to comprehend British Telecom's refusal to give me high-speed internet access no matter how much money we offered them, I attended my first First Tuesday at Home House in Portman Square.

In the next six months, Europe went internet mad and the Industry Standard, that bible of Silicon Valley, was suddenly the most desirable contact possible.

Stranger still was the influx of Americans keen (not unlike myself) to stake a claim in the goldrush territory of Britain and continental Europe. Those that hadn't managed to distinguish themselves in the US flocked here where their American-ness and Silicon Valley experience set them apart from the crowd. US internet and media companies started putting international expansion at the top of their list, and London was the place to begin.

The only drawback was the strange reluctance of the locals to be colonised. No sooner had the Americans arrived en masse than the Europeans were fighting back, accusing us of failing to understand the turf. Researching a story on this reluctance, I interviewed the head of Disney's international internet expansion. After he downplayed native resistance to the American media presence, I asked him where Disney would be expanding first as it "did Europe". He said Britain, since they had rejected France as too difficult and "Scandinavia was just too small a country". "You know Scandinavia's not a country, right?" I asked. "What?" he replied.

But it was six more months, and the goldrush had been and gone, before Standard Media International sent Michael Parsons back to his homeland to start building an edition of the Industry Standard in Europe. He arrived in May, hiring began in earnest in June and July, and preparations were made to launch in October of 2000. Jim Ledbetter, a star prize of the Industry Standard in the US who had spent eight years at the Village Voice, arrived to edit it. Staff were hired in five countries, and no expense was spared to poach the very best Europe had to offer.

Already disgruntled and cynical about the internet industry and my job, even I was impressed with the speed with which Ledbetter and Parsons assembled their star team. The magazine launched on time and was strikingly professional for a first issue. Morale was high, and at a small staff dinner before launch, publisher Neil Thackray tearfully told the assembled staff it was the most exciting thing he'd done in his professional career. Hankies came out again last week, when Thackray made an equally tearful announcement to the staff that, unable to find a buyer, the magazine would be closed.

The writing was indeed on the wall for some time. Layoffs had been made in the US. The Red Herring's international editor had departed for the far east to work for the Wall Street Journal, and two of its three London staffers had been sacked. Business 2.0, another competitor, was publicly on the block, and over the weekend before closure, the Industry Standard Europe admitted it too was seeking a buyer.

Although a skeleton staff will remain in London, the magazine will cease publication. Opinions on its success or failure as an editorial organ vary, but in the final analysis market forces have had the last word. To my mind, the excesses of 1999 and 2000 were the exception and not the rule, and to base a media business on an exceptional market state leaves little question as to the outcome. However, as one staffer said in the wee hours of Wednesday's pub crawl, as the gallows humour died out: it was a wild ride, and that's worth more than security any day.

Polly Sprenger, former London correspondent of the Industry Standard and senior editor of the Industry Standard Europe, is now a trainee cabinetmaker.

webTitle: John Sutherland: gambling is the real danger on the net

fields.headline: Forget pornography and hackers - gambling is the real danger on the net
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: If you believe Robin Cook, the main threat we face from computers is "hacking". Cyber-terrorism, he warned his parliamentary colleagues, can "cripple Britain faster than a military strike".
fields.body:
If you believe Robin Cook, the main threat we face from computers is "hacking". Cyber-terrorism, he warned his parliamentary colleagues, can "cripple Britain faster than a military strike".

It seems that Cook, like Ronald Reagan before him, has been reading too much Tom Clancy. Or, more likely, he knows that if you frighten the pants off us we may not ask awkward questions about the bill for £2.5bn that MI5, MI6, and GCHQ is presenting to British taxpayers for the privilege of having their email spied on.

There have been other recent warnings about the dark side of the net. Yahoo's confirmation that it is selling hardcore pornography videos and DVDs (to make up the bankrupting shortfall in advertising revenue) is seen as the opening of those floodgates about which Mrs Whitehouse and Lord Longford have been warning western civilisation for so many years.

The real and imminent danger of universal popular access to the net is less dramatic. Not from computer literate fundamentalists with their cyber-bombs or Levantine porn merchants offering us their sisters online, but gambling.

Every democratic society has discovered the hard way that controlling gaming by prohibition doesn't work. It simply cheeses off the electorate (who see nothing wrong in a "flutter") and it encourages crime. The only thing that does seem to work is keeping the level of inconvenience high.

OK, America says. You can gamble. But you have to fly to Nevada, or bump your way over some dirt road to an Indian casino to do it. OK, says the UK. You can gamble; but you have to queue up in a shop and do things with fiddly bits of paper. And, if you lose money (which you will) it'll take long enough to have second thoughts. Above all, if you gamble, the treasury will skim off a chunk as sin tax for good causes.

Gambling on the web is something else. Games of pure chance and part skill - slots, blackjack, poker, and roulette - are perfect for computer graphics. The action is magnitudes faster than in the slickest casino.

There's no need to shuffle the cards, or wait for the ball to bounce, the cherries to land, or for other players to get off the pot. Once you've downloaded and registered (most casinos will give you between $10-$100 starting bonus by way of hook) you can log on in seconds: 24/7.

You don't need chips: just a credit card number. Your winnings will come, by mail or wire, in five days (you'll need a double dose of luck to collect. Some 35% of net casinos welch).

As one dotcom casino puts it: "The comfort of playing in your own home makes online casinos a very attractive betting place." It comes to you, it's private. Not even your spouse or kids will know - until you give them matching Mercedes from your net-gotten gains.

For addicts, net gambling is the great rock-candy mountain. It's like an alcoholic being given a bathroom in which the taps run with iced vodka. It's growing explosively. Of the 90m web users in the US, some 5% have gambled online. A million do so every day. The turnover is estimated at $1.5bn annually - rising to $5bn by next year.

In America, net gambling is illegal by federal law. You can't gamble down telephone wires and that's where the digitized pulse travels. But the web is world wide. Some 1,500 online casinos have established themselves (by domain name) in the Caribbean. They can suck money out of plastic with no problem at all. And they pay no tax. Overheads are minimal. No need for all that expensive Las Vegas glitz.

Washington is powerless to control them, any more than it can control the Central American drug cartels. It's the poor, uneducated, lonely and elderly who are most susceptible. The nice old lady who would once enjoy a cheap night of bingo can now max out her credit cards in half an hour.

A few states (led by Nevada) have made it illegal to place bets online. But not one of the million who gamble every day has been prosecuted. Some credit cards won't pay gambling debts - but, as with porn ("discretion is assured") it's impossible to know what is a gambling debt.

The National Gambling Impact Study Commission (set up by Congress in 1996) firmly recommended that all forms of "convenience gambling" be banned. But there's no convenient way of doing it.

webTitle: Chantal Akerman's 'Proust movie': what, no madeleines?

fields.headline: Chantal Akerman's 'Proust movie': what, no madeleines?
fields.standfirst: A Proust movie without wit, social comedy or fancy costumes? What is director Chantal Akerman playing at, asks  Stuart Jeffries
fields.trailText: A Proust movie without wit, social comedy or fancy costumes? What is director Chantal Akerman playing at, asks Stuart Jeffries.
fields.body:
In Stardust Memories, Charlotte Rampling sniffs Woody Allen. "Mmm," says Rampling, "you smell nice." "Yeah?" replies Allen. "That aftershave," she says. "It just made my whole childhood come back with a sudden Proustian rush." "Yeah?" Allen replies. "That's because I'm wearing Proustian Rush by Chanel. It's reduced. I got a vat of it."

In recent years, there have been lots of vats of Proustian Rush slopping round. There was Alain de Botton's How Proust Can Change Your Life. There was a memoir entitled The Year of Reading Proust (what a great idea: don't read the 3,000 pages and six volumes that make up A La Recherche du Temps Perdu itself - instead read a book about someone else reading it). We've had Edmund White's queer life of the author, two massive biographies, and more academic Proustiana than you can wave a Belle Epoque cane at.

Then there have been the films: Volker Schlöndorff produced a polite costume drama of Swann in Love in the early 1980s, in which it seemed to take Jeremy Irons an hour and a half to pin an orchid on Ornella Muti's seething bosom. A couple of years ago, Chilean workaholic Raul Ruiz adapted the last volume of A La Recherche, a film entitled Le Temps Retrouvé. Harold Pinter's screenplay of the whole novel has not yet been filmed, but the National Theatre has offered a condensed version of it.

So why, after all these Proustian rushes, should we be interested in Chantal Akerman's film The Captive, an adaptation of one of the books from A La Recherche? The first reason is that La Prisonnière (on which The Captive is based) is the book that can most easily be lifted from Proust's great novel. Indeed, the story of Marcel's obsession with Albertine lends itself admirably to a cinematic treatment: here is a self-contained story about a man obsessing about a woman to the extent that he cannot allow her out of his sight. And when she is with him he only worries about what she will do when she leaves.

The second reason is that Akerman's austere but excellent film removes all Proust's softening diversions. Gone are the reflections on art and memory, as well as a 100-page musical soirée. This is Proust without the costume drama, without wit or social comedy, but with his vision of love as possession accentuated.

Akerman, 50, a Belgian director and writer with a reputation for taking risks, is well suited to adapting the book. She has regularly addressed obsession and rootlessness in the 36 films that she has made since her 1968 debut, Blow Up My Town.

But why is the captive of the title a woman (the film is called La Captive in French)? Surely Marcel (renamed Simon in Akerman's adaptation) is trapped by the obsession more than the female character. She seems to have another life about which Simon can only crazily fanta sise. Is she a lesbian on the sly? Where does she go when she leaves?

For Akerman the reason is plain: "She is the captive because she has no identity outside Simon's obsession." The woman's "autonomous" life exists only in his fantasies. Think of Violetta in La Traviata, Mimi in La Bohème, Manon Lescaut. These are not individuals so much as objects of male fantasy.

Akerman is clearly alive to this long line of non-beings. Like them, Ariane (as Albertine has been renamed) is unpredictable, enigmatic. If Ariane was merely a cocotte we would understand her but - like Simon - we don't. It recalls what choreographer Kenneth MacMillan wrote of the subject of his great ballet, Manon: "One of the things that intrigues me the most is that there seems to be no logic to Manon's behaviour."

While Manon is an enigma wrapped in a tutu, Ariane is an enigma wrapped in Simon's obsessions. "Ariane cannot be captured," says Akerman. "She cannot be possessed." Not by Simon, nor by those watching the film. The film presents us with an endless deferral that would appeal to Jacques Derrida. We can never know one another, never possess another as we want. This vision of love is tragic - Ariane is a captive but she cannot be captured.

In one scene, Simon invites her to his bed, but he can only rub up against her to orgasm through his pristine pyjamas. His obsession is ultimately narcissistic, masturbatory.

Never considered in Akerman's film, or in A La Recherche, is that love must grant the beloved autonomy if it is to survive. Simon is played by the beautiful Stanislas Merhar. In one particularly resonant scene, he pursues Ariane (played by the wonderful Sylvie Testud) in his car from the Place Vendme in Paris. It's the most languorous car chase in film history - this is not the French Connection - and recalls James Stewart's pursuit of the woman he believes to be Carlotta in Vertigo. But Akerman denies the debt to Vertigo, and argues that Hitchcock's concerns are very different from hers: "Hitchcock's film is fetishistic; mine is about obsession." But the distinction is surely not as clear as she suggests: Stewart's fetishism (dressing his doll-like surrogate in the clothes and wigs that remind him of the woman he never perfectly possessed) comes from an obsession with something he can't recover. Simon's obsession with Ariane is for a woman he can never have.

The film starts with Simon watching an old home video of some girls, among them Ariane, playing in the sea off the Normandy coast. Like Simon, we are going back to the primal scene of his obsession, revisiting the moment in which he first became captivated by her.

Or did he really become captivated? The first word that Simon says in the film, while watching the video, is "Je" ("I"). This suggests to us that he does not know this woman, and never will, because he is unwittingly bent on misinterpreting her. His tragedy starts with the first syllable he utters.

 The Captive is out on April 27.

fields.headline: No more working on Saturdays
fields.standfirst: Was she sacked? Did she jump before she was pushed? Did she fall out with the top brass? Forget the rumours and let  Janet Street-Porter  explain why she is leaving the Sindy
fields.trailText: Was she sacked? Did she jump before she was pushed? Did she fall out with the top brass? Forget the rumours and let Janet Street-Porter explain why she is leaving the Sindy.
fields.body:
Just over two years ago, I answered the phone to Simon Kelner, editor-in-chief of the Independent. He said he'd had an idea, and could he pop round and talk it over with me. He suggested breakfast. To this day, he still tells people it involved a cup of coffee and nothing else. I was probably on one of my hopeless weight control phases.

He asked me if I'd like to edit the Independent on Sunday - I was astonished. We'd started talking a few months before about the possibility of me contributing to the Independent papers regularly, but I could never work out what kind of format would work, and having written columns for quite a few papers in my time, I didn't want anything too constricting. I like big challenges and haven't been afraid to put my head above the parapet in the past. I read all the Sundays and had plenty of opinions about their shortcomings. The main drawback for me about the job was that it meant I would be office-bound again. And it meant returning to Canary Wharf, the scene of my tempestuous time at Live TV, documented in all its four-letter torment by the BBC in a fly-on-the-wall epic they seem to have shown at least three times.

I'd started at Live in a smart red suit from Joseph, and I ended it in a pair of sweat pants, banging my head against the lift doors in frustration. Having said all that, I really enjoyed setting up the station and building the studios, hiring the staff and working on the visual style of the station. I can't be bothered to rake over the boardroom shenanigans (why would I mind being fired anyway?). I was the woman who stood up at the Edinburgh TV festival and made the famous "four Ms" speech about the male domination of the TV industry (middle-class, mediocre and too many). So it wasn't a surprise that it went down like a cup of cold sick with another two Ms, Montgomery and MacKenzie.

I was surprised that my appointment caused M2 (the fat one) to be so pathetically rude about my capabilities. I note that he didn't exactly spend his teenage years picking up tips in local radio but now feels perfectly qualified for his current job heading TalkSport. The night when it was announced that Greg Dyke had been appointed director-general of the BBC, we were both dining in the Ivy; he with Melvyn Bragg. Greg came over to my table, punched his fist in the air and said: "I bloody well did it, didn't I? I pulled it off. I joined the club."

I knew exactly what he meant. The campaign against Greg in broadsheets such as the Telegraph implied he was some sort of cockney barrow boy who ate jellied eels and only used single syllable words. He had brought Roland Rat to our screens, so arts programming at the BBC would be axed if he got the job. Risible, hysterical twaddle put out by the media club. But the same old garbage was dished up about me. Obviously the Telegraph (where the previous editor's wife is deputy editor) had a good dig, but so too did this paper, particularly via Roy Greenslade and Matthew Norman, two men I've never met, but who seem to know my career and shortcomings even better than I do.

The atmosphere when I took over was tense, and the Daily Telegraph contingent who'd surrounded the previous editor soon departed. Six letters were received in mourning. I think the staff were surprised about how hands-on I intended to be. Again, having produced hundreds of hours of complicated live factual television at the BBC, why would I be intimidated by deadlines, and the juxtaposition of pictures and text? Why would I not be able to make judgments quickly about the prominence and relegation of news stories? I accept that I am loud, larger than life and common. But I am also funny, kind and sharp. I am a perfectionist, but I am not a bully. When these stories started appearing (from a disgruntled former member of staff) in Private Eye, I was appalled. But there's nothing you can do about them. Every week you have to kill stuff and there's bound to be fallout. Don't be an editor if you have a thin skin.

At the BBC I had a large staff, a much bigger budget, and the ability to move things around when they didn't work. Now I was working with limited resources, a small team and fighting my corner in a declining market. One of the criticisms of me was that I wasn't "zany" enough. How ridiculous is that? Let's just look at the Sunday Express. No matter how youthful it's tried to be, and no matter how many revamps it's had, the readership is still ageing and shrinking. I have tried to hold on to our existing readers, I've focused on the areas I know they are interested in - the environment, genetically modified foods, transport and the arts. I've increased our arts coverage and set aside space every week for our passenger power campaign.

When I took over in July 1999 the circulation was 235,000. The latest ABC figures show it was 252,000. Not a huge increase, but nothing to be ashamed of. I've brought in new editors for the review, culture and reality. We've just won scoop of the year for Geoffrey Lean's story about secret GM sites at the British Press awards the other week. I think the paper punches above its weight. It's read by opinion-formers and boy, do they give plenty of feedback. When I took the job, I had just spent a couple of years making two TV series, writing a couple of books and travelling a great deal. After nearly 10 years at the BBC, I had so enjoyed being out on the road. I told Simon Kelner I wouldn't want to do the job on a long-term basis, and after a general election seems a natural departure time.

Except I'm not really leaving the Independent on Sunday. I'll continue my column, and write features across both papers, from travel to opera. I'm sure I'll continue to irritate my detractors, but too bad. I feel comfortable with the agenda here, and still want to be a part of it. When I started on the Daily Mail in 1969, papers were set in metal, the back bench wore white nylon shirts with string vests underneath and Lynda Lee-Potter used to take her rollers out in the ladies after her train journey in from Bournemouth. So some things change and others don't. I have not found my working environment to be particularly sexist, and black, brutal humour was always my preference anyway.

I do think that a club exists in the media (to which Greg was alluding that night in the Ivy). It can be sneery and unwelcoming to outsiders and it is mostly male. It is obsessed with the masonic concept of newspaper editing being a craft it takes years of toil at the coalface to master. But it's nothing a smart woman won't be able to deal with. I just hope another woman edits a broadsheet before too long.

To her I say, get stuck in, and ignore the whimperings from the establishment. It's a great job.

Who will follow Janet? The runners and riders

Tristan Davies Age: 39. Current position: executive editor (features), Indy. Form: Flair for presentation, enthusiastic, confident, a smooth operator. Critics think he is too close to Kelner. But that friendship makes him the front-runner. Odds: Evens.

Michael Williams Age: 52. Current position: deputy editor, Sindy. Form: Intensely loyal to Street-Porter, politically astute, experienced, disliked by many staff. Does Kelner rate him as highly as he rates himself? Odds: 5-1.

Chris Blackhurst Age: 42. Current position: contract freelance contributor to Indy titles. Form: Long executive experience, politically independent, loves news stories but a bit of a conspiracy theorist. Kelner admires him, but probably not quite enough. Odds: 10-1.

Richard Ellis Age: 44. Current position: chief executive of Digital Sport. Form: Able senior executive on several titles, skilful writer and tough administrator with considerable charm. Even if he doesn't apply, Kelner may well consider him. Odds: 20-1.

Rosie Boycott Age: 49. Current position: ex-editor in search of backers for a London evening paper. Form: Three editorships, well-connected politically, cultivated a high public profile. Could O'Reilly's men stand the smell of marijuana again? Odds: 50-1.

Andrew Jaspan Age: 48. Current position: (Glasgow) Sunday Herald editor. Form: Edited three titles previously, likes challenges, wooed by Independent in the past. But loves kilts, and Kelner is aware of his disastrous Observer track record. Odds: 100-1.

Piers Morgan Age: 36. Current position: Mirror editor. Form: Twice censured by the press complaints commission, under investigation by the Department of Trade over the City Slickers scandal. Would give the Sindy a new direction all right, but would it survive? Odds: 500-1.

Colin Myler Age: 48. Current position: ex-editor in search of a good lawyer. Form: Deposed as editor of Sunday Mirror after making an error with cataclysmic results. It's likely that Kelner would treat his application with contempt. Odds: 1,000-1.

webTitle: Change of owners at Universe and Catholic Times

fields.headline: Seeking salvation
fields.standfirst: Sales of church publications the Universe and the Catholic Times are in freefall. Do they stand a better chance in the hands of their new secular owners?  Stephen Bates  thinks not
fields.trailText: Sales of church publications the Universe and the Catholic Times are in freefall. Do they stand a better chance in the hands of their new secular owners? Stephen Bates thinks not.
fields.body:
It is a fair bet that every Catholic in the country knows the Universe and the Catholic Times. Piles of copies sit at the back of churches each weekend, as familiar as the roast beef and yorkshire pudding that congregations go home to after mass. For many years, they were almost as essential Sunday reading as the News of the World or the Sunday Express, giving communicant members bland news of the church and the official verdict on events. You might say they had as captive a readership as any publication in the country. Plenty of pictures of smiling bishops and priests with their happy flocks and, with luck - as this is Easter weekend - a portrait of Pope John Paul II on the front.

But as it happens, this weekend all is not sweetness and light at the Universe - and this is not just because circulation has slumped. The Catholic bishops of England and Wales, who previously held a controlling 82% stake in the newspaper's Manchester-based publishing company, Gabriel Communications, have recently divested themselves of their loss-making publications. The bishops' hitherto more or less benign oversight - which ensured that nothing too controversial or critical ever appeared to upset the world-view of their congregations - has been surrendered to an altogether more problematic editorial future.

The Catholic Media Trust, an agency of the bishops' conference, has been looking for a buyer for the publications for more than a year and has now found one in the form of the company's current directors.

In 1998 Gabriel Communications - also the publisher of the Catholic Times and a number of other official church publications - received a loan of £750,000 from the trust, on the back of which it made a profit the following year of £21,000. Sales, however, are still in freefall: the Universe's circulation, which peaked at an astonishing 300,000 in the 1960s and was still more than 90,000 five years ago, is now down to about 45,000, and the Catholic Times sells even fewer. Even if former sales peaks are unattainable, now that church attendances are falling and Catholics have access to a wider variety of media, the current management has certainly proved incapable of arresting the decline.

Yet Gabriel Communications has been sold for an estimated £160,000 to a consortium of directors and senior management, led by company chairman Clive Leach, a Yorkshire millionaire and former managing director of Yorkshire Television who is a prominent donor to the Labour party. The consortium also includes managing director David Bould, marketing director Brian Ayling and editorial director Joe Kelly - a man who started as lowly features editor on the Universe as recently as 1994.

The consortium seems to have closed a remarkably good bargain with the bishops - and with no little speed. Shareholders, including some religious orders, dioceses and individuals, were told of the CMT's plans to sell only a week before the deal went through earlier this month. They were offered 16p a share.

Yet, as a correspondent to this week's issue of the Catholic weekly the Tablet points out, the company's last filed accounts show net assets of £61,876 and profits declared at £100,000. The firm's pension fund is itself thought to be in excess of £100,000. "Could the CMT have secured a greater return - in every sense - for the church by leaving their investment in... indeed, has it fulfilled its obligations under charity law to sell for the maximum price in order to develop its own mission?" asks the writer, Francis Davis, chairman of a Surrey-based multimedia company.

Journalists and former staff are already nervous of the new management. They cannot forget that these are the men who restructured the company three years ago, getting rid of three-quarters of the editorial staff. They refused to recognise the National Union of Journalists' chapel at the papers, even though the company publishes the Catholic church's official guidance that trade union membership should be supported.

In 1997, before the last general election, the bishops' publication the Common Good, printed by Gabriel, asserted that union membership is a right that the church upholds as a manifestation of the principle of solidarity and the right of association - Catholics, where possible, it said, should join an appropriate trade union. Yet only one bishop poked his mitre above the parapet to protest at the loss of staff.

Among the first moves of the new management, issued in a memorandum by Bould, is the decree that bad language is unacceptable in the office (it is not specified what exactly constitutes swearing) and will be punished by disciplinary action. Staff have also been warned that personal use of the internet will now be regarded as a sackable offence. Indeed, one staff member has already been dismissed under this new rule. One employee, understandably reticent of commenting publicly (even former staff have been threatened with legal action if they speak about the company), says: "They are making up the rules as they go along to get rid of the people they don't like."

The injunction does not so far appear to extend to the distributors, who continue to parcel out the papers under the vacant gaze of large posters of naked, large-breasted women. He has been on his own since his deputy went on maternity leave at Christmas.

In recent years, rants on police brutality and the British in Northern Ireland have sometimes tended to replace reports on the activities of the church in the rest of Britain. At one point, journalists were sent a memo telling them not to use the word Catholic.

webTitle: The first six months of Lorraine Heggessey's BBC1

fields.headline: She's the One
fields.standfirst: Head-to-head news, Anne Robinson's insults, and the face of the son of God.  Matt Wells  assesses the first six months of Lorraine Heggessey's BBC1
fields.trailText: Head-to-head news, Anne Robinson's insults, and the face of the son of God. Matt Wells assesses the first six months of Lorraine Heggessey's BBC1.
fields.body:
After a blaze of publicity topped with Times Square billboards, NBC launches the BBC's most successful entertainment show and its pseudo-psycho hostess Anne Robinson tonight. Neatly, the stateside launch of the rudest woman on television coincides with a six-month anniversary for the smallest woman in television. For it was in October last year that Lorraine Heggessey signalled the biggest revolution in BBC1 since the advent of EastEnders by remaking the schedule and moving the peak-time news bulletin, aided by Robinson leading the charge of the light entertainment brigade.

The success of the Weakest Link in denting the peaktime audience of ITV was a great boost to BBC morale. Although the corporation hype that it was more popular than Millionaire is a myth (albeit one that is being extensively exploited in the US), its highly visible success gave Heggessey an early fillip.

The schedule relaunch, precipitated by the hasty move of the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm, was a huge risk. Just weeks earlier, director of television Mark Thompson had insisted the BBC would not repeat the mistakes of ITV, which axed News at Ten without having sufficient programmes to put in its place. ITV was finally forced into a mildly humiliating climbdown after news ratings plunged. Yet such was the gung-ho attitude under new director-general Greg Dyke that the BBC thought it could get away with it.

With a bit of fancy footwork by the schedulers (which consisted mainly of raiding daytime for Weakest Link and BBC2 for Have I Got News for You), and some good luck with an extremely busy news agenda, ratings for the 10pm news have held up and peaktime BBC1 has declined only marginally. The government's dogs have been held at bay, the drama department is working overtime to bring on landmark projects for the autumn, and there are even signs of life in the notoriously unreconstructed BBC publicity department.

This October revolution may not have been as bloody as the original, but it was the marker of the new BBC. "I think it sent a very important signal that BBC1 is not going to be as slow to change as it has in the past, and we will take some risks," says Heggessey. "That's very important - if you don't take risks and fail, that's one thing, but at least if you take some risks and fail then you feel better, you can move on to the next thing and try something else."

Out of the risks, there have been some notable hits in the past six months. EastEnders has been on spectacular form, knocking Coronation Street for six with a series of slick storylines that culminated in the shooting of Phil Mitchell. Heggessey had the self-confidence to make a real event out of the attempted murder in the Square: the shooting episode was scheduled around a Weakest Link special with the EastEnders cast and a populist documentary on the yachtswoman Ellen MacArthur. A month or so later, the night on which the would-be killer was revealed handily coincided with a key Uefa football tie.

The Crime Doubles series, in which blockbuster shows were shown on consecutive evenings, was another Heggessey scheduling trick. Although the success was mixed: only Silent Witness and NCS Manhunt came out with any sense of pride intact. NCS - and the slightly weaker In Deep - will return.

It is clear that "event TV" - once the favourite term of David Liddiment at ITV - is now a buzz phrase at the new BBC1. "You always have to maximise your assets. If you behave as if you're confident with what you've got, then the viewers might feel that confidence too," says Heggessey.

But there have been some real stinkers. Adrian Mole was a flop, and the script for Office Gossip should never have made it past Pauline Quirke's shredder.

Perhaps the worst aspect of the past six months has been the drama disasters of Sunday nights. Five lavish shows went down the ratings plughole, with the woefully scheduled Rebel Heart collapsing to a record low.

The BBC wobbled, and the critically acclaimed Clocking Off was moved out of Sunday nights and sent over the top against Millionaire on Mondays. Even ITV could not believe what the BBC had done: drama chief Nick Elliott accused the corporation of panic, and writer Paul Abbott's unease appeared justified.

Heggessey believes there has been a fundamental shift in what viewers want to see on Sunday evenings on BBC1, and it seems to have taken her by surprise. "It's interesting, something is happening there. Viewers do not want to watch Take a Girl Like You or Love in a Cold Climate in as many numbers as London's Burning or Heartbeat. Maybe we have been doing too much of the same for too long," she says. Successful scheduling of Superhuman and Son of God in the traditional drama slot of Sunday evenings is a sign of things to come: more "quality factual" and "entertainment-skewed" shows will be Sunday night staples from now on.

And she defends the scheduling of Clocking Off. "Millionaire is a fact of life for us. You can't run away from it. You have to put strong pieces against it - if you put weak things against it then you just get nowhere." Heggessey also believes it offers viewers a genuine choice - which is why the Weakest Link will never go head-to-head with Millionaire. It seems that, in the long term, Heggessey believes that the potency of Millionaire can be diluted with consistent scheduling of strong, different offerings against it.

It is to the credit of the new regime that this image of dynamism has been maintained into the summer. In a breathtaking piece of spin, the recent launch of the BBC1 spring and summer schedule was dominated by a show that technically should not have been there at all. Son of God, the landmark series that prompted saturation coverage in the next day's press, was actually part of the winter schedule. But the dramatic story (it's not often that a picture of Christ lands on a newsdesk at lunchtime) obscured the lack of substance in what Heggessey had to offer.

There are 14 new dramas - but only one of them, Mersey Beat, has anything remotely resembling promise about it. And even then, it's another police series. The rest of the schedule was as thin as the excruciating jokes in the embarrassing, pun-laden speech that Heggessey had the brass neck to read out.

Clearly, all eyes are trained on the autumn, when the £100m extra investment in drama will begin to bear fruit. There will be some big events before then - key boxing matches and a new series of Friends Like These with Ian Wright for a start - but the Heggessey BBC1 will not be complete until the end of the year. Executives know that they are flying by the seat of their pants until then.

fields.headline: Media Monkey
fields.trailText: The recruitment drive for BBC Choice's showbiz-and-sport news service has provided comfort to execs. More than 700 hopefuls applied to display their combination of "poise and style with journalistic authority" (in other words, "Mingers need not apply"). Most intriguing were the applications from a Pizza Express waitress, a 15-year-old newspaper boy, a trawler skipper, an Australian barman and someone from Helsinki. You wouldn't have thought they'd heard of BBC Choice, frankly.
fields.body:
The recruitment drive for BBC Choice's showbiz-and-sport news service has provided comfort to execs. More than 700 hopefuls applied to display their combination of "poise and style with journalistic authority" (in other words, "Mingers need not apply"). Most intriguing were the applications from a Pizza Express waitress, a 15-year-old newspaper boy, a trawler skipper, an Australian barman and someone from Helsinki. You wouldn't have thought they'd heard of BBC Choice, frankly.

Two people who won't be too sorry to see Colin Myler's departure from the Sunday Mirror are Granada's countesses of spin, Sallie Ryle and Zoe McIntyre. They were last seen in "heated exchanges" with Myler at the PCC's 10th birthday bash - the Sunday Mirror had failed to get the exclusive it wanted on Popstars, much to the fury of the editor. "Somebody's going to lose their job over this," he blustered. Funny how things work out.

Last week's big powwow on how to modernise the radio ratings system, Rajar - which currently seems to run on blind faith and guesswork - revealed an unexpected gap in the service. It closes down over Christmas, and figures are not collected for the holiday period on the assumption that the festive period equals television for British households. That means that no one will ever know how many people tuned in to Radio 4's Boxing Day Harry Potter marathon, but no one at the BBC was able to tell Monkey whether this was good or bad news for controller Helen Boaden, whose brave idea it was.

Monkey was intrigued to learn last week that Today editor Rod Liddle was in the running for the Spectator job, should blond Boris decide to step down once he becomes an MP. We can't really see it ourselves, so it is with some relief that we hear of a more likely candidate from outside the Telegraph fold. After a stint honing his journalistic instincts on the Times newsdesk (it's hell out there), posh Portillista and Brylcreem boy Michael Gove is said to be a late entrant in the race. What is with Spectator editors and silly hair?

webTitle: Six months on: how the new-look schedule has performed

fields.headline: Six months on: how the new-look schedule has performed
fields.trailText: The top line is that BBC1 has improved its ratings between 9pm and 10pm since the news move.
fields.body:
The top line is that BBC1 has improved its ratings between 9pm and 10pm since the news move.

Between October 16 and March 25, the average BBC1 audience across this hour has been 6.6m. This is up by 0.8m compared to the equivalent period in 1999-2000. In audience share terms, BBC1 has raised its game between 9pm and 10pm year-on-year from 23.7% to 26.3%.

However, this improvement between 9pm and 10pm has not been enough to stem the overall decline of the BBC1 peaktime audience, measured between 6pm and 10.30pm.

Since October 16, BBC1 has averaged a 28.6% peaktime share, compared to 30.2% in the equivalent period 12 months earlier. But BBC insiders are quick to point out that peaktime multi-channel viewing has been rising over the same period, from an 11.1% to a 13.1% audience share.

ITV has hardly been affected by BBC1's news shift so far. Its share of peaktime viewing for the past six months is 35.9%, ever so slightly down from 36.1% for the same period 12 months ago. And between 9pm and 10pm, ITV's audience is actually up year-on-year by 0.3m to 8.9m, and a 35% share of viewing.

When it comes to the head-to-head 10pm battle of the news bulletins, both BBC1 and ITV can claim credit.

Between Monday January 22, when ITV reinstated News at Ten for an average of three nights a week, and Monday April 9, both the BBC1 Ten O'Clock News and ITV's late evening bulletin at 10pm or later have averaged 5.1m viewers.

When these later ITV bulletins are stripped out of the figures to leave a comparison of the head-to-head battle at 10pm, News at Ten comes out on top, averaging 6m viewers.

Overall, going back to the start of the 10pm news on October 16, the new BBC1 bulletin has still averaged 5.1m viewers - exactly the same as the average for the old Nine O'Clock News in 2000.

The BBC claims that so far the 10pm viewing figures vindicate the decision to move the news, which was taken with the aim of stemming the decline in audiences for the Nine O'Clock News. Between 1996 and 1999 this bulletin's average audience fell from 6.3m to 5.1m. If the Nine had stayed and this rate of decline had continued between October 2000 and now, the BBC argues, it would have been averaging 4.8m viewers - 300,000 fewer than the 10pm bulletin over the same period.

Winners at 9pm

The average BBC1 audience between 9pm and 10pm since the news move on October 22 has been 6.6m. But One Foot in the Grave is no more, a question-mark hangs over the Royle Family's future and Silent Witness is rarely in the BBC1 schedule.

1 One Foot in the Grave: 10.7m

2 The Royle Family: 9.3m

3 Silent Witness: 9.3m

4 The Inspector Linley Mysteries: 7.7m

5 NCS: Manhunt: 7.4m

Losers at 9pm

All these series were below the 5.8m average for the 9-10pm slot in 1999-2000, when the Nine O'Clock News was in place.

1 Adrian Mole: 4m 2 The Human Face: 4.3m 3 Office Gossip: 4.8m 4 State of the Planet: 4.8m 5 The Sins: 5.3m

If the Nine had stayed and this rate of decline had continued between October 2000 and now, the BBC argues, it would have been averaging 4.8m viewers - 300,000 fewer than the 10pm bulletin over the same period. Winners at 9pm The average BBC1 audience between 9pm and 10pm since the news move on October 22 has been 6.6m. But One Foot in the Grave is no more, a question-mark hangs over the Royle Family's future and Silent Witness is rarely in the BBC1 schedule. 1 One Foot in the Grave: 10.7m 2 The Royle Family: 9.3m 3 Silent Witness: 9.3m 4 The Inspector Linley Mysteries: 7.7m 5 NCS: Manhunt: 7.4m Losers at 9pm All these series were below the 5.8m average for the 9-10pm slot in 1999-2000, when the Nine O'Clock News was in place. 1 Adrian Mole: 4m 2 The Human Face: 4.3m 3 Office Gossip: 4.8m 4 State of the Planet: 4.8m 5 The Sins: 5.3m

fields.headline: Piat d'Or
fields.trailText: What is it? The wine made famous by the catchline: "Les français adorent le Piat d'Or".
fields.body:
What is it? The wine made famous by the catchline: "Les français adorent le Piat d'Or".

And do they? Turns out they'd never heard of the stuff. And now not even the Brits want to know; they'd rather have a nice glass of Australian chardonnay. Piat d'Or has gone from being Britain's biggest-selling wine to the naffest.

Sounds like a lost cause. No such thing in the world of drinks marketing, as the makers of Babycham will testify. A £1m facelift helped the brand increase its sales by almost a third last year.

What about Piat d'Or? It is being rebranded. The opulent red and gold labels are to go and the flavour has been subtly changed to appeal to today's more sophisticated palate. Most important of all, there is a new advertising campaign that makes no mention of the French.

None at all? None. "France and the French are no longer aspirational," according to Emma Chamberlain, Piat d'Or marketing manager. Instead, the adverts will position the brand as an easy-drinking choice with the line: "Relax. It's Piat d'Or".

History: Piat d'Or launched in 1978, but the brand really took off in the mid-80s, when those infamous ads first appeared. By the end of the 80s, Britons were spending more than £30m a year on the wine, but by last year sales were down to £20m.

What about the competition? It's pretty stiff. New world wine brands such as Jacob's Creek and E&J Gallo are hugely popular and have the added advantage of not making the shop assistants snigger when you pick them up in Oddbins.

Whatever next? A Blue Nun comeback? Funny you should mention that. The staple of the 1970s dinner party is being relaunched with a £1m global campaign. Not a fan of sweet white wine? Not to worry - the new range will include Blue Nun Merlot and Blue Nun Dry Riesling.
