fields.headline: My New Media: John Hardie
fields.trailText: My New Media: John Hardie, marketing and commercial director of ITV
fields.body:
Favourite websites?

olga.net, an online guitar archive where you put in the name of a song and somebody somewhere will have written down the lyrics and transcribed the guitar chords for it. I play guitar myself so I like to check that.

Last online purchase?

I bought the back-catalogue of torch singer Eva Cassidy from amazon.com. It came in a special offer with a packet of razor blades and if you've ever heard Eva Cassidy you'll understand why.

Most recent technological faux pas?

I haven't really made one online, but I did recently connect up my washing machine to the central heating system.

Main news sources on the web?

I have MediaGuardian.co.uk on for most of the day to get media news, but I still use television for general news.

What is the least useful site on the web?

www.soupsong.com/imovies. This is the definitive site for information on movies which feature soup. For example, in the film Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, there's a scene where Jen Yu is about to go into battle and before doing so she orders a plate of shark-fin soup.

Time spent on web?

I'm online all day long, but I probably sit and look at it for about 30 minutes a day, and at weekends I just check emails.

Which site do you think is least likely to succeed?

Retailers offering discounts which you could easily get by walking into a Dixons and negotiating with the spotty youth behind the counter. I wouldn't name any in particular but if you can do that, why would you do it online? I think our site will work because it's ideal for the web. It's about entertaining people and it will translate the experience from the television.

Most useful sites?

google.com is by far the best search engine.

Most irritating thing about web?

I hate these pop-up windows where the vicious bastards close down the website which you are in and make you go to their site.

Ever been in a chat room?

No and I've also never stood in a railway station taking down the numbers of locomotives. It's the last thing I'd be interested in doing. I'd rather go to a bar and talk to people.

Do you still bother with old media?

I take all the papers every day. I don't think newspapers have got to be that concerned except for the intrusion into the classified advertising market, but even that hasn't seen the light of day, yet.

John Hardie is marketing and commercial director of ITV which has recently launched an online version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire at www.itv.co.uk

webTitle: Nick Hopkins undergoes riot training for journalists

fields.headline: 'Never mind the danger, I've got a deadline'
fields.standfirst: Nick Hopkins undergoes riot training for journalists
fields.trailText: Nick Hopkins undergoes riot training for journalists
fields.body:
In the chaos and noise of the riot, I didn't see the petrol bomb whizzing at me, and would have taken a direct hit if Liz hadn't wrenched me out of the way a second before it exploded, scorching a violent, orange streak across the road.

We ran out into the road just as 30 protesters began another Braveheart style charge at the police lines, throwing more petrol bombs and lumps of wood. One PC must have taken a blow to the head because he fell flat on his back. And exactly the same thing is going to happen to me, I thought, unless we get out of here now.

I wondered what Liz and I should do next. A man had appeared at my right shoulder and had a suggestion. He said we've got to interview one of the riot ringleaders, who is in the thick of the action.

To get to him, we've got to push past the thugs who have already threatened us, including a man with a baseball bat and bad attitude, while avoiding charging policemen and dozens of wooden bricks which are flying in all directions.

Is he kidding? Obviously not. "Go on," he insists. It's all right for him, he's built like a tank - Desperate Dan jaw, barrel chest and thighs for forearms.

He served in the SAS for several years, including during the Gulf war, when he was a member of ill-fated Bravo Two Zero team which was dropped behind enemy lines in Iraq.

"Oh, God," I think. I'm under orders, so I've no choice. Liz and I head off into the carnage and smoke . . .

This wasn't a bad dream. It did happen. There was a riot, and a petrol bomb did explode two inches from my nose, Liz and I were bombarded with wooden bricks and flying glass, and hooligans threatened us with baseball bats. The man on our shoulder, Dr Mal Macgown did look like a comic strip hero and he is a Bravo Two Zero veteran, though he doesn't talk about it. But the riot we were caught in, though realistic, was not real. We were in Hounslow, west London, taking part in a pioneering safety awareness course set up by Macgown's company, Pilgrims Group.

It was asked to design a course by the BBC, primarily because of concerns that TV and radio crews were in frontline positions covering riots and civil disturbances, from the Drumcree marches to the anti-capitalist demonstrations, without proper training.

When it was launched two years ago, some senior hacks grumbled. Journalists can be peculiarly dismis sive of training, preferring to believe old-fashioned nous is protection enough in the sort of danger zones that police officers and soldiers spend years learning to cope with.

But there is a big problem with relying on common sense. It is a faculty that routinely goes Awol as soon as trouble starts.

One reporter sent to cover the Handsworth riots in Birmingham reputedly turned up after an evening meeting of the Territorial Army, where he was a senior officer. Other journalists, who were crouching for safety behind a car, saw their colleague striding towards them through the haze in a ceremonial white suit, plumed helmet, hand clasped firmly on the hilt of his sword.

Shortly afterwards, the reporter was seen trying to file copy from a telephone box that was being rocked backwards and forwards by a group of protesters. He survived this encounter unscathed.

Journalists, however, often get injured in far less extraordinary circumstances, or expensive cameras are stolen and films destroyed, leaving news coverage affected, which is where Macgown, 40, comes in.

With Russ Ticehurst - who also served in the SAS - and Malcolm Knight, a former police training instructor, he devised the safety course and has held more than 30 of them, putting nine journalists at a time through a series of exercises over eight hours, culminating in a full-scale night riot. As you might expect, it's a slick operation.

The training centre itself is like the EastEnders set. There is a mock-up town with a pub, bank, shops, a high street and side alleys.

I was teamed with Liz from BBC News24, and together we were led around the site by Macgown, who encouraged us to discuss "angles of vision", "proximity to safety" and "maintaining the integrity of exits and entrances".

Liz and I were hopeless at this.

Using innate wit and skill, our first task was to snoop on a group of pretend protesters and avoid aggravating them.

Yet our plan of action would, Macgown suggested politely, have had us running for our lives within seconds. The "conflict management" phase of the course did not start with any more success.

There's something about role-playing that I've always found a bit embarrassing, and this exercise involved trying to pacify and then escape from some farmers angered by the foot and mouth crisis who have turned on a film crew.

Liz and I were the film crew. Knight, who is 6ft 6in, was particularly convincing as a furious farmer, jostling and barging us backwards as we whimpered at him to stop.

We performed much better when we had a second chance. By then, we'd been told about "back-watching" and defensive arm positions. We'd also found our voices.

Nothing is left to chance. Car parking, first aid kits and wardrobe (best to be in cotton if you're about to go up in flames) were considered at length; measures that Ticehurst referred to as the art of "self-sustainability".

Before we were set loose in the riot, we had a rite of passage - the petrol bomb walk.

Dressed in fire-resistant overalls, boots, gloves and police helmets, we marched to a back street in the model town where three other instructors were waiting for us with a wheelbarrow full of petrol bombs.

"If one of these has your name on it," barked the man in charge, "if it's coming your way, don't just freeze. Sidestep - like so - and if it explodes in front of you, walk on through and stamp your feet."

He said our overalls would protect us from the standard petrol bomb - unleaded, no additives, half-full bottles - for eight seconds.

There is a technique for stopping flames rushing up your nose and scalding your lungs. It involves hunching your shoulders until you have no neck and wrapping one arm around your chin. Although only intended as an emergency brace, some of us were reluctant to take chances and managed to hold this undignified position for the rest of the exercise.

Nobody in our group asked any questions at the end of the talk. In fact, nobody said anything as we lined up at one end of the road, and the officers stood at the other, about 50 metres away.

At the signal, we inched forward and waited for the bombardment to start. One bottle did explode just in front of me and I walked through the flames, as predicted, unharmed.

But in my determination to remain cool, I hadn't realised the back of my suit had caught fire - "poor awareness" - and strolled on, oblivious. Knight put me out with a fire extinguisher before I'd noticed the problem.

Later, an instructor demonstrated what happens when protesters dissolve plastic cups and elastic bands in the petrol they use for their bombs.

"You'd be lucky to survive that," he said, as we watched the petrol ignite and then sizzle like acid.

That took us to the finale where 60 Metropolitan police officers are plunged into a riot with 30 rampaging hooligans. The rioters' job is to harass, humiliate and provoke the police on exercises like this. Our presence, as reporters trying to cover the story, is part of the experience for both sides.

Everything we were taught and told in the hours beforehand became urgently relevant once the battle began. We ran around like headless chickens, we got ourselves in and out of dangerous situations, and we sweated loads. We also survived, shadowed at all times by Macgown, who thought we'd performed reasonably well. "You dithered a little bit to begin with," he told us. "But you were much more decisive in the second half."

The BBC has a rolling programme to get journalists riot-trained as quickly as possible. Those who have been on the course have returned to duty somewhat chastened, saying they realised they'd been getting away with it in terms of safety. ITN, Reuters and other news agencies are also sending staff.

"There's been an increase in riots over the last five years, and some of our young reporters were being put in dangerous situations they'd had no experience of," says Tony Loughran, safety and security adviser for BBC News and the World Service. "We've had casualties in the past, but fewer now. The course helps to save lives, no doubt about it."

fields.headline: Bangladesh backlash
fields.standfirst: The BBC's Bengali section head has fallen foul of the Bangladesh government and lost his job.
fields.trailText: The BBC's Bengali section head has fallen foul of the Bangladesh government and lost his job.
fields.body:
Born of a revolution in 1971, Bangladesh has long been a country in which political passions run high, especially during an election year. But as the July date for this year's polls draws nearer, the BBC's Bengali section head appears to have paid the price for the intense media scrutiny that precedes any Bangladeshi election.

Syed Mahmud Ali was removed from his BBC radio post on Thursday, following complaints from prime minister Sheikh Hasina Wajed's ruling Awami League over comments he made in February.

In an interview with the Dhaka-based daily, Janakantha, Mahmud Ali had apparently unveiled his allegiance with the leaders of a 1975 coup in which 16 members of Sheikh Hasina's family were killed. His comments so infuriated the Bengali government that it demanded he be sacked. Failure to do so, it said, would result in the BBC's bilingual service in the country being severed.

After weeks of stating its "full confidence in the impartiality and objectivity" of Mahmud Ali and his section, the BBC removed him last week. An internal inquiry into the affair "judged that Mahmud Ali's conduct during the interview amounted to a failure of editorial judgment that compromised his effective stewardship of the section", the BBC said on Thursday. "The comments he made about politics in Bangladesh and [Sheikh Hasina] were not those expected of a BBC section head."

In what was the darkest day in Bangladesh's 30-year history on August 15 1975, the country's founding father, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, and 15 members of his family were slain at the presidential palace by dissident members of the country's military. Shortly afterwards, the coup's leaders commandeered a prominent radio station to announce their bloody victory to the nation.

Mahmud Ali said in the newspaper interview that he had rushed to the station when the coup was announced, apparently to join in. The BBC says that as an enlisted man he in fact went to the station to await orders. He went on to say that, under orders, he then personally arrested the country's first prime minister, Tajuddin Ahmed, killed in jail 10 weeks later as the dissidents fled the country following a counter-coup.

Abu Musa Hasan, a spokesman at the Bangladesh high commis sion in London said his government had tried to resolve the dispute through informal channels. But when the BBC didn't budge, the government last week lodged a formal complaint withdirector-general Greg Dyke.

"[The government] had expected the BBC to take punitive action against Mahmud Ali to restore its credibility," Abu Musa Hasan said. "We still consider the BBC a friend of Bangladesh, and we are very happy that they have decided to take the appropriate action. Justice has prevailed."

"Individuals are free to say what they want when they speak as individuals," he said last week. "But Mahmud Ali overstepped those bounds when he made these statements while officially representing the BBC."

Conspiracy theories abound in Bangladesh. When the row over Mahmud Ali began six weeks ago, sources at the BBC were quick to point out that there was a history of Bengali governments calling the broadcaster's objectivity into question in the run up to an election to engender compliance.

And the BBC is not alone in its criticism of Bangladeshi governance. The Awami League's complaint against the BBC, rights groups say, would have been more sympathetically received in the court of international opinion if its own pursuit of those who attack journalists in the country was more vigilant.

Last year nearly 100 journalists reported being attacked or arrested by the police, set upon by armed mobs, kidnapped, threatened or blackmailed. Two reporters were killed. "Not only has the government consistently failed to prosecute violent attacks against journalists, but in some cases Sheikh Hasina's ruling party has actively encouraged these abuses," says Kavita Menon, Asia programme coordinator of the committee to protect journalists.

According to Paris-based Reporters Sans Frontières, the "youth wings" of the three main political parties were responsible for more than half the assaults last year.

Only the brave continue to write critically for any of the country's 250 dailies during election time. And with this year's vote likely to be closer than most, the risk of their suffering reprisals grows exponentially. Whether or not they know of shady elements from the country's past, it will be another year of living dangerously for journalists in Bangladesh.

"[The government] had expected the BBC to take punitive action against Mahmud Ali to restore its credibility," Abu Musa Hasan said. "We still consider the BBC a friend of Bangladesh, and we are very happy that they have decided to take the appropriate action. Justice has prevailed." "Individuals are free to say what they want when they speak as individuals," he said last week. "But Mahmud Ali overstepped those bounds when he made these statements while officially representing the BBC." Conspiracy theories abound in Bangladesh. When the row over Mahmud Ali began six weeks ago, sources at the BBC were quick to point out that there was a history of Bengali governments calling the broadcaster's objectivity into question in the run up to an election to engender compliance. And the BBC is not alone in its criticism of Bangladeshi governance. The Awami League's complaint against the BBC, rights groups say, would have been more sympathetically received in the court of international opinion if its own pursuit of those who attack journalists in the country was more vigilant. Last year nearly 100 journalists reported being attacked or arrested by the police, set upon by armed mobs, kidnapped, threatened or blackmailed. Two reporters were killed. "Not only has the government consistently failed to prosecute violent attacks against journalists, but in some cases Sheikh Hasina's ruling party has actively encouraged these abuses," says Kavita Menon, Asia programme coordinator of the committee to protect journalists. According to Paris-based Reporters Sans Frontières, the "youth wings" of the three main political parties were responsible for more than half the assaults last year. Only the brave continue to write critically for any of the country's 250 dailies during election time. And with this year's vote likely to be closer than most, the risk of their suffering reprisals grows exponentially. Whether or not they know of shady elements from the country's past, it will be another year of living dangerously for journalists in Bangladesh.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: ongratulations to the lovely Richard Lord, editor of Revolution, who has been promoted to top dog in Asia, and jets off to Hong Kong in three weeks. Not that diary is envious in any way.
fields.body:
Congratulations to the lovely Richard Lord, editor of Revolution, who has been promoted to top dog in Asia, and jets off to Hong Kong in three weeks. Not that diary is envious in any way whatsoever, oh, well maybe a little. Lord has already shaved his sleek barnet off in preparation for a sweltering summer. The editor's job at Revolution Towers UK now goes to diary friend and deputy editor Phil Smith, who will no doubt do a splendid job. Big smiles all round. See, we can be nice to Haymarket every now and again.

Spare a thought for Lord's former adversary Mike Butcher (ex-editor of New Media Age), who sadly was part of the drastic shutdown of Industry Standard Europe last week (see left). He'll soon bounce back, though. It was a depressing day all round as the best source of new media industry news in the UK had the rug pulled from under it by IDG. Ironically, the Standard before last carried a rather prescient front cover: an employee was carrying a box with the words "Sack me please" emblazoned on it. Was this a subliminal message perchance? Anyhow, staff went out on their wake on Thursday after being told the news just two days earlier. I'm told it was a more intemperate bash than the infuriatingly sombre rooftop parties the Standard took to holding every month at the salubrious Soho House. At least that's one part of the Standard we won't be missing.

More bad news is rumoured to be coming out of FT.com within the month. Having already wielded the axe over 40 employees across the internet ops, the FT is now said to be deliberating its next move: another round of 40 job cuts according to spies. Diary called up Pearson to check the veracity of the rumour but didn't get much in the way of a convincing denial. The expressions: "lengthy review"; "current market conditions"; "can't rule anything out"; "not a decision to take lightly" and "never say never" certainly do not bode well.

Tesco may be the most successful internet grocery operation in the UK (see last week's staggering figures), but one has to question how far backwards it will bend over to please customers. Seems image is everything, and posh people and Tesco are like chalk and cheese. In case I'm not making any sense, the next time you're in the Sandringham area look out for delivery men disguised as chauffeurs driving Range Rovers. Sounds a bit far fetched? Not at all. It's a service discreetly tailored to snooty customers who are put off using Tesco's internet shopping service because of the ugly white Tesco-labelled vans which deliver the goods. Whatever would the neighbours think?

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: Terrible year left CNN's Turner feeling deathly

fields.headline: Terrible year left CNN's Turner feeling deathly
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Ted Turner, the founder of CNN cable news who is celebrated and reviled in equal measure as the "Mouth from the South", says that he has considered suicide in the past year.
fields.body:
Ted Turner, the founder of CNN cable news who is celebrated and reviled in equal measure as the "Mouth from the South", says that he has considered suicide in the past year.

Mr Turner, who once compared Rupert Murdoch to Adolf Hitler, describes the previous 12 months as among the most miserable of his 63 years, in an interview with the New Yorker magazine. At the beginning of the period he had seemed invulnerable as the biggest shareholder in AOL Time Warner, companies that were soon to merge. By the end of it he had been sacked; his eight-year marriage to the film star Jane Fonda was over; he broke his foot in a skiing accident; two of his grandchildren were diagnosed with a rare enzyme deficiency; and his much-loved labrador Chief was temporarily paralysed with coonhound disease.

"I felt like Job," he says in the latest edition of the New Yorker. Not for the first time, the biggest individual landowner in the United States - he has 2m acres - also felt "suicidal".

Mr Turner says that he received a telephone call last May from Gerald Levin, chief executive officer of Time Warner, telling him that Turner Broadcasting - his original media powerbase, which he had nurtured since 1970 - would no longer report to him. "Sorry, Ted, but you lose your vice-chairman title as well," he recalls Mr Levin saying. Fonda, his third wife, tells the magazine: "The way it was handled was really shocking. It makes me mad. How dare they give him a phone call?"

Mr Turner's father would beat him with a wire coat hanger and sometimes decided that a greater punishment would be to have his son beat him instead. Ed Turner committed suicide at 53. "Why this guy [Ted Turner] didn't go under psychologically at age five, I don't know," says 63-year-old Fonda. "It scarred him for life. It colours everything - his relationships and his anxieties. "I say this with all the love in the world. He has been severely, hauntingly traumatised. He always thinks something is about to be pulled out from him. He has no belief in permanancy and stability. It's one reason why I'm not with him."

Another reason is Fonda's religious conversion. Mr Turner says: "She just came home and said 'I've become a Christian.' Before that she was not a religious person. That's a pretty big change for your wife of many years to tell you."

Fonda, who won an Oscar for her role in Klute and was once known as Hanoi Jane for her opposition, since recanted, to the Vietnam war, does not disagree. "My becoming a Christian upset him very much for good reason. He's my husband and I chose not to discuss it with him because he would have talked me out of it. He's a debating champion."

Mr Levin tells the magazine: "I didn't fire Ted. I said: 'This is the way we need to run the company.' Ted is by far the most interesting person I've ever met - how he reacts to things. It's as if a child were speaking without any social inhibitions. "You don't say in business 'I got fired.' He'll just speak out loud what may be going through someone's mind I love and respect this about Ted but for other people it may be very difficult."

webTitle: Front-row scramble to film Pope's end

fields.headline: Front-row scramble to film Pope's end
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in the UK
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The world's media are tussling over the best vantage point to capture the puff of white smoke that will herald the eventual successor to Pope John Paul II.
fields.body:
The Italians call it the "war of the terraces". Discreetly, the world's media are tussling over the best vantage point in Rome to capture on camera the puff of white smoke that will herald the eventual successor to Pope John Paul II.

St Peter's square resounded yesterday to loudspeakers relaying the Pope's Easter message delivered in a frail voice. Despite frequent health scares, he made his annual address in 61 languages. He is a month shy of his 81st birthday.

Unknown to many of the pilgrims present, several of the apartments and hotel rooms around the square have been secured by broadcasters since fears of the Pope's impending death first arose in 1993. The deals are kept secret to avoid accusations of bad taste.

Competitive campaigns for the best camera spots have been waged behind the scenes lest the Vatican be offended, even though the Pope has joked about the media's obsession with his demise. Prices rise with every month for those who neglected to agree fixed rents, said a former BBC staffer. Most of the apartments remain empty, visited occasionally by technicians.

One estate agent in Prati, a select district that rings the Vatican, said some landlords had doubled their rents in the past year. "Time is on their side," she added.

More than 5,000 journalists and crew are expected to fly into Rome for the Pope's eventual funeral and succession process, which are expected to last around a month. White smoke from a chimney above the Sistine Chapel will signify habemus papam, the election of a new pope.

The US network CBS beat Japanese, French and German rival bidders to first prize: the 5,000 sq ft roof terrace of the Atlante Star hotel, from where Polish nuns can be seen moving in the papal apartment.

The network will pay a flat fee of $180,000 (£112,000) just for the terrace, said its owner Benito Mencucci.

"I try not to be superstitious. Preparing for the Pope's death doesn't change anything. We all must die some day," he said.

CNN was left to find another vantage point, which it will not reveal. The television news agency APTV will work from the modest Adriatic hotel.

The BBC has persuaded residents of an apartment block on Borgo Pio, a stone's throw from St Peter's, to rent out their terrace for less than £8,000 a month when the time comes.

The Pope has the trembling and paralysis associated with Parkinson's disease. For the first time he walked and carried a cross for only a small part of the Good Friday ceremony at the Colosseum. Yet during the Easter message he cheered a crowd of 100,000 with belief in a better world. "Men and women of the third millennium, the Easter gift of light that scatters the darkness of fear and sadness is meant for everyone.

"Rediscover with joy and wonder that the world is no longer a slave to the inevitable. This world of ours can change: peace is possible even where for too long there has been fighting and death."

webTitle: Leadership question leaves Scots in the dark

fields.headline: Leadership question leaves Scots in the dark
fields.standfirst: Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: Almost half of Scots do not know who their first minister is, and more than two-thirds believe the Holyrood parliament has had no impact on their lives, according to a survey which comes as the parliament prepares to celebrate its second anniversary.
fields.body:
Almost half of Scots do not know who their first minister is, and more than two-thirds believe the Holyrood parliament has had no impact on their lives, according to a survey which comes as the parliament prepares to celebrate its second anniversary.

Of those questioned, 43% could not name Henry McLeish as first minister, and a handful thought the post was still held by Donald Dewar, who died last year, the survey by Scottish Opinion Ltd for the Mail on Sunday found. Five per cent thought it was held by Tony Blair, 1% by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and 2% by the former leader of the Scottish National party, Alex Salmond.

Only 48% said they were happy with the way the parliament was being run, 39% expressed dissatisfaction with the devolved body, and 67% said they did not believe it had had an impact on their lives.

Mr McLeish has struggled to stamp his authority on the executive since Mr Dewar's death. Despite introducing a number of radical policies, such as free care for the elderly, the first minister has faced a barrage of hostile headlines for his style of leadership.

An executive spokesman said Mr McLeish would have been pleased that most people were satisfied with the parliament.

The SNP deputy leader, Roseanna Cunningham, said the findings showed that the parliament was working hard for Scotland. But, she added: "The problem is, Henry McLeish is running an incompetent Labour/Liberal Democrat government."

fields.headline: Decoding the 'productivity gap'
fields.standfirst: Nobody would argue with increasing economic efficiency. But how do you define it?
fields.trailText: Nobody would argue with increasing economic efficiency. But how do you define it?
fields.body:
The government is obsessed with closing the "productivity gap". The Treasury and the Department of Trade and Industry have signed up to reducing the difference in productivity levels between the UK and the US, Germany, France and Japan.

This target sits alongside others, including increasing employment and tackling child poverty, but there is a sense in which the Treasury sees productivity as the priority.

Who could object to increasing the relative efficiency of the economy? Perhaps no one, but there are problems with the way the Treasury presents its case and reasons why a Labour government should not see this as its priority.

First, the Treasury does not seem to know how to measure productivity - by output per hour worked. Government documents tend to present figures for output per worker. This measure will rank more highly countries with long average hours of work, such as Japan. Contrary to conventional wisdom, the British do not work long hours on average because of part-time working.

When productivity is measured properly, Japan ranks below the UK. The Treasury has finally worked this out and the recent Budget no longer referred to Japan as a country with which we want to close the productivity gap.

The table shows us something else. Productivity in a number of countries we are used to thinking of as relatively successful, such as Switzerland and Sweden, is not significantly different from the UK.

Switzerland's higher GDP per head is a result of much higher employment rates. A feature of the data is that most countries with relatively high employment rates have relatively low measured productivity. For many countries with relatively high productivity, such as France and Italy, this is offset by lower employment, so GDP per head is not materially different from the UK. It is GDP per head, not productivity, that is the best measure of average material living standards.

There is another reason to stress the position of countries such as Switzerland and Sweden. They offer good controls to test the ideas put forward as to why the UK has a productivity gap with, say, Germany.

Sweden's system of workforce consultation at least matches that of Germany and Switzerland has a vocational training system similar to that in Germany. These countries have the same productivity gap as the UK but do not seem to worry, and we should not do so either.

Boosting GDP per head by raising employment rates rather than productivity would be more in tune with Labour's social objectives.

Surely boosting productivity would help us to tackle poverty and better fund our public services? The surprising answer is no.

We define poverty in relative terms, so that if average real incomes are rising by 2% a year, the incomes of the less well-off have to rise by the same amount or relative poverty will increase.

Growth in average real incomes is linked to growth in productivity. If productivity growth improves to say 3%, then the growth in average real incomes will accelerate to this level too and the incomes of the poorest will have to rise by this amount or they will be left further behind.

Labour should care less about the productivity gap and more about the poverty gap - and the gap in public service quality between the UK and countries such as Sweden.

 Peter Robinson is chief economist at the Institute of Public Policy Research

webTitle: Analysis of constituencies involving tactical voting: Folkestone

fields.headline: Rivals aim to block Howard's way
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's decision to delay the general election has given a breathing space to those on the campaign trail. But it has not meant a slackening of the political pace. The Guardian has picked three constituencies where tactical voting will help decide the balance of the next parliament. Today we look at Folkestone
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's decision to delay the general election has given a breathing space to those on the campaign trail. But it has not meant a slackening of the political pace. The Guardian has picked three constituencies where tactical voting will help decide the balance of the next parliament. Today we look at Folkestone.
fields.body:
Not many MPs enjoy quite such a dramatic view of their constituency from their sitting room window as does Michael Howard, MP for Folkestone and Hythe.

Nestling on the rising ground above the English Channel, it looks down on the flat expanse of Romney Marsh, which some local voters affectionately call "the sixth continent".

The fact that the woods behind the house still contain a serious, round-the-clock police presence is a reminder that, in his time, the former Conservative home secretary made some dangerous terrorist enemies.

But as election day looms the more urgent question is: has Mr Howard made enough enemies among Folkestone voters for the seat to fall to Lib-Lab tactical voting ?

In 1997 the seat featured in a famous £80,000 exercise conducted by Peter Kellner and ICM for the Observer: 16 seats with tactical anti-Tory possibilities were analysed and advice offered. It worked spectacularly in Enfield Southgate, where Michael Portillo's wholly unexpected defeat was the biggest single upset of the night.

It did not work in Folkestone.

In 1992 Mr Howard had taken 52.3% of the vote against 35.3% for the Liberal Democrats and 12.1% for Labour, not far adrift from the 57:32:10 shares the three had when he inherited the seat in 1983.

On the night of May 1 1997, when Tory seats all along the south coast were falling to the Blair-Ashdown tide (nearby Dover, Hastings & Rye, Hove, even Torbay), Mr Howard's majority fell from 8,910 to 6,332, from 17% to 12.2%. If ever a seat was going to fall, surely, the moment must have passed that night?

But hope springs eternal as June 7 2001 approaches. This weekend both Peter Carroll, the new Liberal Democrat candidate, and Labour's even newer hopeful, Albert Catterall, have been out canvassing hard. Why?

"The difference between this time and last time was that then the anti-Conservative vote was split three ways because there was also a Referendum party candidate," explains the Lib Dem agent, Shaun Roberts. "This time it will come to us."

A familiar Lib Dem tale, but far from impossible. In 1997 Labour's big push failed to take second place, but got to within 1,042 votes of the Lib Dem, 24.9% of the poll compared with 26.9%. The late John Aspinall took 8% on behalf of his old gambling friend, Jimmy Goldsmith; the UKIP got 0.7%. It left Mr Howard on a very takeable 39% if the constituency's voters decide to gang up against him. Unlike 1997, when people voted "blind" on new boundaries, the route is clear. "I never take the constituency for granted," says Mr Howard whenever he is asked. "There may be a UKIP candidate, but I hope the Referendum party votes will come back and that we get a fair number of votes from the other parties too."

Along with the parlous state of local hospitals, he cites Europe and the asylum issue as important to East Kent. Mr Howard is a convincing tough guy on both. "My constituency is on the sharp end," he notes.

Literally so in the case of the Channel tunnel. There are about 600 asylum seekers in Folkestone, but things are calmer than two years ago.

Though a keen pro-European in 1983 the MP is no enthusiast for the euro. And though his father, a Romanian Jew, fled to the safety of Wales, Mr Howard distinguishes between real and unjustified asylum applications.

"When I was home secretary we changed the law and cut the number of asylum seekers by 40%. Labour failed to close a loophole, sent out the wrong signals, and the 'magnet' problem has flared again.

"It is a perfectly straight-forward proposition in theory: everyone agrees that we have to have a proper system of immigration control on this small and crowded island." Crisp and diamond-hard, like the successful planning QC that Mr Howard is. But one assessment he shares with Albert Catterall is that "Labour is not fielding a paper candidate" to help out the Lib Dems.

No paper candidate

There are pockets of poverty in East Folkestone and on the marsh. "The core Labour vote won't shift," says first-time candidate Mr Catterall, and there is no pact. No wonder Mr Howard is keen to agree. If they are right, he is safe.

But in the past year the Lib Dems have won two council byelection contests, one each from their rivals. In Mr Carroll, 40, ex-RAF, ex-research scientist, they have an eager novice who recently sold the family transport business to concentrate on politics.

We're pulling them across along, with Tory voters who are backing us at local level. I tell people 'I'm not a professional politician, I'm one of you, having a go'," he says.

fields.headline: Mayday for capitalism
fields.trailText: John Vidal and Nick Hopkins show what happens when journalists allow the Metropolitan police to set the news agenda (Mayday Mayhem?, April 14).
fields.body:
John Vidal and Nick Hopkins show what happens when journalists allow the Metropolitan police to set the news agenda (Mayday Mayhem?, April 14).

In the absence of actual information about the May Day demonstrations they echo the self-fulfilling prophecy of the police - violent thugs have taken over and peaceful protesters are staying away, with the result that "ordinary people" and "families" will be too frightened to attend. A relentless media campaign over the past few weeks, coupled with increasingly aggressive police announcements, is plainly intended to divide anti-capitalist activists and criminalise protest. But "ordinary people" and "families" are the anti-capitalist movement. We are part of society, not apart from it. We are your neighbours, the people you sit next to on the bus, in the park, in the housing office.

The whole point of the May Day demonstrations is their diversity - that there will be many different types of protest happening. There is room for all sections of the anti-capitalist movement to choose their own direction on the day.

No doubt there will be some demonstrators, embittered by the pollution, violence and exploitation of global capitalism, who will break windows in revenge. There will also be many more demonstrators who will be organising positive activities, parties and music that celebrate our worldwide resistance. The "call to action" asks everyone to choose their own way. Its not a secret society, but a very open one.

The police have demonised May Day since the very first demonstrations were called in the 1880s, and if the police want a fight they're sure to get one, but that's not the point of the protest. The anti-capitalist movement is a broad coalition, and the wider the police's net is cast, the more "ordinary" people are caught in it. We have something to say and we're not frightened to make our voices heard.
Jim Bradley
Red Star Research

 Special branch briefings concerning May Day have two purposes. First to discredit the anti-capitalist movement and deter demonstrators; and second, to prepare public opinion for a violent police crackdown.

The police will no doubt be delighted at the May Day features in the Guardian, which seemed designed to aid their cause. Whatever the opinions of Guardian readers on violence at demonstrations, it is the right to demonstrate at all that is under attack.
Phil Blake
Porthcawl, Mid Glamorgan

 Contrary to Edmond Warner's belief (Capitalism takes a hit in the media, April 14), it's not "anti-capitalist" schadenfreude that has pushed Marks & Spencer and other companies into the media spotlight but market demand, fuelled by two important social trends.

First, companies affect our lives far more than ever before, especially as more services are transferred from the public to the private sector. The public increasingly feels it has a right to know how businesses function.

Second, people realise that they can now influence how businesses behave. The balance of power is shifting from shareholders to customers, partly due to the web and other technologies that enable people to mobilise public opinion far more easily, quickly and effectively.

This shift contributed to the downfall of Monsanto in Europe and to Shell's Brent Spar volte-face and forced Pepsi and Ericcson out of Burma, among a growing number of examples. These developments might not conform to tidy business school models of economic rationality - but life is a messy business.
Keith Conlon
London

webTitle: Families welcome home spy plane crew

fields.headline: Families welcome home spy plane crew
fields.standfirst:
China
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: America wrapped itself in the flag this weekend to welcome home the crew of the US navy surveillance plane held in China for 11 days.
fields.body:
America wrapped itself in the flag this weekend to welcome home the crew of the US navy surveillance plane held in China for 11 days.

Applause, bouquets of flowers and banners greeted each of the 24 crew members as they emerged from the doorway of the plane.

Rear Admiral Michael Holmes said of the pilot, Shane Osborn: "I credit him with saving the lives of his crew," after a Chinese fighter collided with the EP-3 aircraft over the South China sea on April 1. Lieutenant Osborn, for his part, thanked God. "It was definitely him flying the plane" during its emergency landing on Hainan island, he said.

The homecoming was at Whidbey Naval Air Station, the crew members' base in Oak Harbour, Washington state. They have been sent on 30 days' leave.

"I'm here to tell you we did it right," Lieut Osborn told the crowd of about 5,000, echoing the Bush administration line after two "very sorrys" secured their release. "No apology is necessary on our part." He said the crash was the fault of the Chinese pilot, presumed to have been killed in the collision after he and another jet challenged the US plane in international airspace. "The first thing I thought was, 'This guy just killed us. Our aircraft was straight, steady, holding altitude, heading away from Hainan when the accident occurred. The sharp left [turn by the US plane] people were talking about was when the aircraft went out of control."

The Americans were treated well by the Chinese, said Lieut Osborn. "The only unpleasant part was the interrogation and lack of sleep. They were polite to us and respectful. We were seen by doctors. They obviously fed us well."

Yesterday China declared its fighter pilot, Wang Wei, a revolutionary martyr. The two countries are to have talks on Wednesday to discuss the crash.

webTitle: Lake District left clutching at straws

fields.headline: Lake District left clutching at straws
fields.standfirst:
Visitors' demands for discounts strike sour note
Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Visitors' demands for discounts strike sour note
fields.body:
From a tent in the centre of Ambleside village in the Lake District, hoteliers shook tourists' hands and thanked them for visiting at Easter.

B&B owners and shop managers wore badges saying "Ambleside: Smiles better" and handed out leaflets offering discounts. Others formed welcoming committees in carparks.

Three weeks ago, they had extended their overdrafts. Now, hordes of tourists in bright kagouls filled the streets, promising to spend money. But visitor numbers, though high, were not the usual Easter figures. There were vacancy signs in guesthouse windows, where once all were booked by Christmas.

As tourists continued to cancel May bank holiday breaks, it was unlikely the boom would last.

The Centre for Economics and Business Research yesterday forecast foot and mouth would cost British tourism £5bn. In areas like the north Lake District, tourism was down by 80%.

This Easter weekend, urban tourism boomed, with attractions like London's Madame Tussauds having 10,000 a day. Resorts in the south-west of England reported good takings. In Scotland, Sir Sean Connery reportedly attempted to lure tourists by taking a golf holiday.

But the English countryside was different. After a push by Cumbria tourist board to advertise Easter in regional newspapers, visitors repopulated villages that had been deserted in March. But it was not enough to secure the livelihoods of tourist workers until the summer.

At Ambleside tourist office, an adviser said: "In print, there are 100 paths open, but we are having to tell people, that is not necessarily the reality. Many are actually carparks or yards of footpath rather than the whole thing."

On the Stock Ghyll Park footpath that was reopened by the government this weekend, crowds of walkers rambled past waterfalls. Bill Courtney, from the US state of Michigan, said: "It would be immoral to cancel your holiday when the local population are in so much trouble." His family were spending five days in the north in solidarity.

Barry and Audrey Haycox, from Rochdale, had cancelled a holiday to Malta to come to the Lakes: "We saw through the adverse publicity in the media. It is rubbish. This holiday has been smashing. Surprisingly, there are sheep everywhere."

But the money pumped into the rural economy did not match last year. Rosemary Keen, a B&B owner, said some tourists tried to beat down prices. One man knocked asking for "foot and mouth specials" - when she was using her pension to pay bills. Mrs Keen said price-cutting did a disservice to other guest houses who were struggling: "It is insensitive."

Keith Morgan, with a guesthouse in Ambleside, said he had reluctantly offered discounts - "you have to take what you can get". His guest house was full this weekend, and he was optimistic. But he had stopped paying his mortgage and was doing the laundry himself because he could no longer afford to send it out.

Beside a shelf of Jemima Puddleduck souvenirs at the Lakeland Craftsman shop, manager Peter Lobb said he had cut his staff's hours. "This weekend, it has picked up substantially, considering that it will die as soon as Easter is over. We keep our fingers crossed, but we're not expecting too much."

In the north Lakes, Keswick showed signs of desperation. John Walker, an art gallery owner, and chairman of the foot and mouth-inspired Cumbria Crisis Alliance, had taken £150 by 4pm. On a normal Easter Sunday, he would take £2,500.

He said: "It's very strange. It is almost as if people are coming out because they have been told to come out. But the only bags they are carrying are from Woolworths, where they buy Easter eggs, or the Call of the Wild outdoors clothes shop, which is closing down and has a 50% sale. The bookings are just for one or two nights; there are a lot of local people here.

"It is very weird. There is a very strange atmosphere."

webTitle: Coastal resorts prove top tourist attraction

fields.headline: Coastal resorts prove top tourist attraction
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Coastal attractions proved the most popular tourist destinations.
fields.body:
Coastal attractions proved the most popular tourist destinations. The Sussex coast attracted thousands of visitors despite showery weather, as did Weston-super-Mare in Somerset where visitor numbers were estimated to have doubled on last year. Accommodation in Brighton was almost completely booked up.

 Longleat Safari Park at Warminster, in Wiltshire, was quieter than usual for an Easter bank holiday weekend. A spokeswoman said: "Obviously the numbers are down on last year because of the foot and mouth, but we are busier than expected."

 Many hotels at Newquay, in Cornwall, were fully booked as trippers and surfers descended on the beach. The Cornwall Tourist Board said: "Things in Newquay are looking great for Easter. About 60% of accommodation at pubs and hotels in parts of Cornwall are booked up."

Many visitors stayed away from the New Forest in Hampshire, where restrictions are in place. Christine Aimes, chairwoman of New Forest Tourism, said that firms in the area had lost between 20% and 80% of their business during the crucial holiday period.

The North Yorkshire Moors Railway reported a steady increase in numbers of tourists, claiming to have benefited from those using the train rather than the open footpaths to get around. But visitor attractions at Helmsley in North Yorkshire were "suffering very badly", according to local tourist board officials.

In Wales attractions had mixed fortunes. At the Dan Yr Ogof cave complex on the edge of the Brecon Beacons, numbers were down by 50%. But at Oakwood Park in Pembrokeshire in west Wales, which features a traditional rollercoaster, thousands turned out.

 On Dartmoor and Exmoor, where restrictions prevented walking over the countryside, accommodation bookings were on average 50% down on last year. It was predicted that tourist numbers in the south-west over Easter would be 90% of last year.

Travel representatives from around the world are to tour the British countryside. Some 40 leaders of international travel associations will see for themselves that the UK is "open for business".

webTitle: Debate: Control the monopoly builders or the bricks will fall

fields.headline: Control the monopoly builders or the bricks will fall
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: When children build a tower with wooden blocks, the real action is waiting for it to tumble. Devoid of global regulation, commercial monoliths are reaching the point where if they fall the livelihoods of millions are crushed.
fields.body:
When children build a tower with wooden blocks, the real action is waiting for it to tumble. Devoid of global regulation, commercial monoliths are reaching the point where if they fall the livelihoods of millions are crushed.

A report from the Group of Ten countries found accelerating consolidation in the financial sectors of the industrialised economies - 10 banks control 77% of business in the capital markets.

The problem is greater than abuse of market power. Beyond a certain size and complexity, lack of transparency makes it nearly impossible to hold firms accountable. The G10 found "non-bank financial institutions have the potential to be sources of systemic risk". The bigger they are, the harder we fall - and each day private sector power concentrates further.

Prudential makes a £14.6bn bid for American General, E.ON a £5.1bn bid for Powergen. The market capitalisation of AIG, the largest international insurance company, is greater than the combined output of the world's 43 least developed countries.

The big five accountants audit and advise the FTSE 100 companies. Ten firms control nearly 90% of the market for agrochemicals and GM crops. Three oil firms - ExxonMobil, Shell and BP Amoco - each are worth more than $100bn.

In pharmaceuticals, motor manufacturing and media, the same is happening. In software it has already happened.

Who really benefits from being big? Barclays' big bank for a big world ad campaign backfired after branch closures. The supermarkets' armlock grips more than food producers. A promise of jobs and one-stop shopping proves expensive to local economies - on average, out of town stores lead to the loss of 270 retail jobs nearby.

Accountancy KPMG earns growing amounts from merger advice. When its research showed that 83% generated no benefits to shareholders, the irony was inescapable. And the International Labour Organisation estimates that 300,000 banking jobs will be lost between 1999 and 2002.

Democracy also suffers. An international outcry tempered, but didn't stop, attempts by pharmaceutical multinationals to prevent South Africa setting its own drugs policy to tackle HIV/Aids.

Choice is another victim. When a few brand names dominate, leveraged by global advertising, barriers to market entry become too high for rivals.

As corporations go global, they get better at avoiding tax, too. In the OECD over the last 30 years tax on corporate profits has fallen as a share of the total.

Why should any corporation be allowed to control more than, say, 1% of any market? Management of the global economy is a one-legged affair. The World Trade Organisation promotes a corporate agenda. Calls for effective international tax, labour and environmental authorities fall on deaf ears. Another anomaly is the absence of global competition law.

Multinational corporations need a keeper - it could be a new global authority or a network of national bodies. Even that will be inadequate.

JK Galbraith observed that the lifespan of regulators began with a vigorous youth and moved rapidly from complacent middle-age to either senility or becoming an arm of the industry they were supposed to regulate.

There is also a revolution in economic democracy to embrace. From Russia to India, citizens' juries and forums are setting people's priorities on crucial economic issues.

Shareholder value, still archaically enshrined as the ultimate business objective, could and should change with experiments in corporate stakeholder councils. Management would have legal liabilities to everyone affected by what they do. There could also be mandatory social and environmental impact assessment of mergers above a certain value.

Gigantism is fragile and costly. We need a return to scale and new economic maps to find where social and environmental wellbeing are maximised.

webTitle: In global trade, west says one thing and does another

fields.headline: Qatar could see a first class beef
fields.standfirst:
The basic gripe of the developing world is that when it comes to trade, the west says one thing and does another

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: The basic gripe of the developing world is that when it comes to trade, the west says one thing and does another.
fields.body:
American lobbyists have apparently abandoned the real White House in favour of the virtual one. Instead of trying to interest President George Bush in their causes, they have been deluging the makers of the popular television series, West Wing, with requests for airtime on the show.

A recent episode featured Martin Sheen's character, president Josiah Bartlett, getting to grips with the ins and outs of the long-running trade dispute between the European Union and the US over bananas. Lo and behold, last week Brussels and Washington announced a ceasefire in the banana war: the US will lift its punitive sanctions on EU luxury goods and Europeans will abandon their banana quotas, which favour former Caribbean colonies at the expense of bananas from US-owned plantations in Latin America.

Like the spy plane saga, both sides have left the battlefield claiming victory although it's clear who the losers will be: small farmers in the Windward Isles whose produce cannot compete with the cheaper dollar bananas. When they are forced off the land, the EU should bear as much of the blame as Washington. Its import regime has encouraged former colonies to stick to single crop commodity economies - not smart in a more integrated world.

For years, the EU has been promising to help the producers diversify while actually delivering little. Now it looks as if many banana growers are diversifying into growing marijuana - one crop for which there is plenty of demand.

Primetime TV references aside, the real reason for the detente on the banana front is that both sides are preparing for a much bigger fight: the struggle to launch a new round of global trade talks at the World Trade Organisation meeting in Qatar this November.

After the debacle 18 months ago of the Seattle talks - which collapsed after a week of deadlock between the leading trading powers while pitched battles raged outside between anti-globalisation protesters and police - everyone is anxious to make sure Qatar is not a repeat showing. Ambassadors at WTO headquarters in Geneva have been given until July to thrash out the main issues for the Qatar agenda by the WTO chief, Mike Moore. If it looks like the "Quad" - the EU, the US, Canada and Japan - are close to agreeing what should be on the table, Qatar will be used as a launchpad for the new round.

What may have escaped the notice of the four big trading powers is that they no longer make the rules. The WTO is now dominated by developing countries, and it was largely because they became fed up with the Quad's high-handed tactics that the Seattle talks fell apart. To get them back to the negotiating table is not going to be a simple matter, and so far they are fairly unimpressed with what the Quad is offering.

The EU missed a golden opportunity recently to score some relatively painless public relations points with the least developed countries under the "everything but arms" proposal, which was supposed to allow tariff-free access to EU markets for goods from the world's 48 least developed countries, or LDCs.

The lobbyists got in first and carved out exceptions to the agreement which made it virtually worthless: 70% of its potential benefits to LDCs would have come from more liberal access for sugar, rice and beef, but liberalisation of those three goods has been deferred until 2006. The message appears to be that although Europe is committed - in theory at least - to offering poor countries a better trade deal, in practice even a tiny lobby group like the sugar beet industry can prevent it.

The basic gripe of the developing world is that when it comes to trade, the west says one thing and does another. While protecting its own vulnerable sectors from competition, it demands that southern countries liberalise. The two markets of most importance to southern economies, agriculture and textiles, are among the most protected in the west.

Forthcoming research from Oxfam will show the cost of trade barriers to developing countries is far higher than the amount western countries spend on official aid programmes. One recent study estimated that rich countries spend enough on subsidising their farmers to fly every single cow in the west around the world first class. That's not only a huge waste of western taxpayers' money but a huge cost to developing world countries which could be producing food for western markets more efficiently and at less cost to the environment - where land is cheaper, agriculture can be extensive rather than intensive.

Subsidy-bloated lobbies

The west shows no appetite to take on its subsidy-bloated producer lobbies, as the failure to unblock access to sugar, rice and beef under "everything but arms" shows. Although foot and mouth and BSE have sparked calls for an overhaul of the European common agricultural policy, the agenda is being driven by consumer panic over industrial farming - and the likely outcome is more subsidies, this time for environmentally approved farming methods. In the meantime, western trade barriers are costing farmers in the developing world $20bn a year.

While the west protects and subsidises, the developing world is being forced to liberalise. Though global trade talks have been on hold since the end of the Uruguay round in 1994, poor countries are slashing tariff barriers under the aegis of World Bank and International Monetary Fund programmes.

Most economists agree that in the long term countries with lower trade barriers do better, because they are exposed to global competition which makes their economies more efficient. Development experts point out that while the theory is fine, the reality is that poor countries have accomplished the kind of reductions in tariff barriers over the last decade which took the west 50 years to achieve. The adjustment costs have been painful in many cases and because the tariff cuts have been made outside a trade round, they have not even gained reciprocal market access.

Divisions between the west and the developing world on trade will be clearly visible at this week's Quebec summit to launch talks on setting up a free trade area of the Americas. Mr Bush is a strong supporter of the FTAA proposal, but Latin American countries want to see Washington delivering. The Brazilian government, for one, is sceptical about the US's commitment to the free trade agenda when Washington regularly uses anti-dumping measures to block imports from its neighbours and spends $20,000 a year per farmer on subsidies.

Quebec will also be the anti-globalisation lobby's first big outing for 2001. In response to the protesters, western policymakers often trot out the line that globalisation is good for the poor.

The truth about globalisation is that the west is using its control of the two big financial institutions to open up poor country markets while protecting its own. The message from Brussels and Washington alike appears to be, "you liberalise, we subsidise". Unless the rules of the game are tilted more in favour of the developing world, Qatar and Quebec could both be re-runs of Seattle.

fields.headline: Lemierre dismisses ECB reports
fields.standfirst:
Speculation about a French successor to Duisenberg embroils EBRD president

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Speculation about a French successor to Duisenberg embroils EBRD president.
fields.body:
Jean Lemierre, the president of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, has poured cold water on suggestions that he is being lined up to take over from Wim Duisenberg as head of the European Central Bank.

Mr Lemierre, who this weekend will host the EBRD's 10th annual meeting, described the reports as pure speculation.

"It is less than one year since I was elected president of this bank and I am committed to this job. I am committed to this mission," he said "There is nothing behind [these reports], they are pure rumour and speculation."

The scramble over who should be the next head of the ECB and when he or she would take over has been rife since Mr Duisenberg became president of the Frankfurt-based bank for an eight-year term.

His appointment was overshadowed by a behind-the-scenes row over whether he would serve the full term. Some sources, particularly in France, suggested that Mr Duisenberg had agreed to step down halfway. ECB officials are privately adamant that this was not the case.

At a press conference last week Mr Duisenberg was giving little away as to his intentions. He told reporters that he could only repeat earlier remarks that he did not expect to serve the full eight-year term but he also recalled that when a French newspaper asked whether he intended to resign after four years he had replied "no".

He said he would not be making any further comments on the issue.

The issue is unlikely to go away, however. Mr Duisenberg has come under fire for the sharp fall in the value of the euro against the dollar since the new currency was launched two years ago. More recently, there has been criticism of the bank's decision to keep interest rates in the 12-nation single currency zone on hold at a time when other central banks have been cutting borrowing costs to try to head off recession.

The next big hurdle for the bank will be the introduction of euro notes and coins in January. Though most of the direct responsibility for the project lies with individual national central banks, the ECB's close association with the currency makes it inevitable that it will get a share of the blame if anything goes wrong.

The French government is known to be keen for the job to go to one of its own citizens, with Jean-Claude Trichet, the governor of the Bank of France, its favoured candidate. Mr Trichet has been caught up in the investigation into the rescue of state-owned Crédit Lyonnais, sparking speculation that Paris might look to other candidates, including Mr Lemierre and its finance minister, Laurent Fabius.

Suggestions that the job should go to Mr Lemierre would cause political fall-out at the EBRD. Mr Lemierre's predecessor there, Horst Köhler, was sent to head the International Monetary Fund well before the end of his full term. For a second successive president to be moved on in such short order would surely create discontent among the EBRD's shareholders as well as undermining staff morale.

webTitle: Moscow reporters produce TV news to rival old station

fields.headline: Moscow reporters produce TV news to rival old station
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russian journalists were battling to continue producing independent news broadcasts yesterday despite the night-time takeover of the NTV network's premises on Saturday by Russia's monopoly gas company.
fields.body:
Russian journalists were battling to continue producing independent news broadcasts yesterday despite the night-time takeover of the NTV network's premises on Saturday by Russia's monopoly gas company.

The station's respected news operation was split in two, with the majority of its journalists and technical staff camping in the studios of a smaller television company owned by the exiled media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, who founded NTV.

All the cameras, computers and key equipment remained in their old headquarters on the other side of Moscow's huge Ostankino television complex, in the hands of the new management.

The latex puppets of politicians created for the Russian version of Spitting Image were left in the NTV studios, but the satirists responsible for the programme's biting scripts were among those who fled to the other company, TNT.

Some 350 staff resigned from NTV after Saturday's management coup, with almost all of the channel's best known journalists going over the road to TNT.

A small group of reporters stayed with the new management, appointed in a controversial boardroom putsch almost a fortnight ago by Gazprom, the gas monopoly which is 38% controlled by the state.

Both teams continued to broadcast rival versions of NTV's flagship news programme, Sevodnya (Today).

Media analysts were scrutinising the news aired by the new management at NTV for pro-Kremlin bias, but any change in style was evident only by omission: the material selected was uncontroversial, focusing on foreign news and on Easter celebrations. Much of it appeared to have been prepared by news agencies rather than NTV reporters.

The simultaneous broadcast of the exiles' version of the programme - from the TNT studios - announced that NTV's old management was preparing to challenge the takeover in court next month.

It was not clear how long the voice of the NTV exiles would survive. Pavel Korchagin, general director of TNT, said he believed his channel would now be targeted by state prosecutor, as NTV has been for the past year. TNT, which is primarily an entertainment channel, would not be able to afford to finance the expensive news-gathering operation for more than a fortnight.

NTV's ousted general director, Yevgeny Kiselyov, was also in negotiations yesterday to take staff loyal to him to TV6, owned by another notorious exiled Russian businessman, Boris Berezovsky. TNT and TV6 reach far fewer viewers than NTV.

Saturday's transfer of power appears to have left Russia without a nationwide television company prepared to criticise the Kremlin.

"Critics say NTV was never independent because it was dependent on its powerful businessman owner, Mr Gusinsky," said Mr Korchagin, whose channel is also controlled by Mr Gusinsky's Media-Most holding company.

"We don't believe that was the case, but the main point is that it was the only non-government nationwide television structure and it provided an alternative voice, accessible to the whole country. Russia no longer has that."

webTitle: Stroke tests go ahead despite US warning

fields.headline: Stroke tests go ahead despite US warning
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A British firm has vowed to press ahead with plans to implant genetically modified human stem cells into the brains of stroke victims, despite the severe side effects experienced by Parkinson's disease sufferers in a comparable trial in the US.
fields.body:
A British firm has vowed to press ahead with plans to implant genetically modified human stem cells into the brains of stroke victims, despite the severe side effects experienced by Parkinson's disease sufferers in a comparable trial in the US.

The firm, ReNeuron, based in Guildford, Surrey, has been encouraged by new research on rats which suggests the animal's modified cells are capable of repairing different kinds of brain damage.

In the US research, scientists drilled holes in patients' heads and inserted tiny amounts of foetal brain tissue inside, hoping they would manufacture a vital natural brain chemical, dopamine, which is depleted in Parkinson's sufferers.

Early results from those trials, reported last month in the New England Journal of Medicine, showed that while older patients were unaffected and some younger patients improved, a small number began to writhe, jerk, flail and move their jaws uncontrollably.

Martin Edwards, chief executive of ReNeuron, said: "We are quite determined to go forward into trials.

"My view of the New England Journal of Medicine paper is that it has taken the field forward. It has provided some objective evidence about both risk and benefit which is a step along the way."

ReNeuron has yet to apply to regulators to start trials, and has not begun recruiting volunteers, but Dr Edwards said the first phase would involve eight to 12 patients who had recently suffered a stroke.

He said he did not believe it would be necessary for the first trial to repeat one of the most controversial aspects of the US Parkinson's study - giving some volunteers sham surgery. To create a control group, which had not been given the grafts but believed it had, the US researchers drilled holes in all of the patients' skulls and only put foetal material in some of them.

Unlike the Parkinson's trial, ReNeuron's stroke trial will use stem cells multiplied in the lab rather than fragments of foetal brain. The company claims this technique will enable it to control the amount and type of cells implanted in patients' brains more precisely.

In a further control measure, ReNeuron's cells contain a temperature-sensitive gene. At laboratory temperatures of 33C they divide and multiply, but in the hotter temperatures inside the human brain - 37C to 38C - they no longer divide.

A stroke occurs when the blood supply to the brain is blocked. Of the 100,000 victims of first strokes in Britain each year, some 40,000 survive and experience varying degrees of paralysis and mental impairment.

ReNeuron's research is aiming to help victims in the months immediately following a stroke, when the brain's natural repair mechanisms are struggling to put right the damage.

Last week Helen Hodges, of the Institute of Psychiatry in London, told a meeting of the British Neuroscience Association that ReNeuron cells had improved movement and cognition in rats which had been given artificially-induced strokes.

Dr Hodges, one of the founders of ReNeuron, and other researchers, used genetically modified mouse rather than human cells to implant into the rat's brains, but she said the results were an important proof of principle.

Unexpectedly, the cells spread throughout the brain, rather than staying in one place, she said.

"The stem cells do not remain clustered in the brain, like foetal grafts, but disperse, integrate and improve function even in aged animals," she added. "We expect that stem cells will prove to be far safer and more flexible for brain damage repair than primary foetal cells because they are unlikely to worsen symptoms, as recently reported in some Parkinson's patients."

The firm, ReNeuron, based in Guildford, Surrey, has been encouraged by new research on rats which suggests the animal's modified cells are capable of repairing different kinds of brain damage. In the US research, scientists drilled holes in patients' heads and inserted tiny amounts of foetal brain tissue inside, hoping they would manufacture a vital natural brain chemical, dopamine, which is depleted in Parkinson's sufferers. Early results from those trials, reported last month in the New England Journal of Medicine, showed that while older patients were unaffected and some younger patients improved, a small number began to writhe, jerk, flail and move their jaws uncontrollably. Martin Edwards, chief executive of ReNeuron, said: "We are quite determined to go forward into trials. "My view of the New England Journal of Medicine paper is that it has taken the field forward. It has provided some objective evidence about both risk and benefit which is a step along the way." ReNeuron has yet to apply to regulators to start trials, and has not begun recruiting volunteers, but Dr Edwards said the first phase would involve eight to 12 patients who had recently suffered a stroke. He said he did not believe it would be necessary for the first trial to repeat one of the most controversial aspects of the US Parkinson's study - giving some volunteers sham surgery. To create a control group, which had not been given the grafts but believed it had, the US researchers drilled holes in all of the patients' skulls and only put foetal material in some of them. Unlike the Parkinson's trial, ReNeuron's stroke trial will use stem cells multiplied in the lab rather than fragments of foetal brain. The company claims this technique will enable it to control the amount and type of cells implanted in patients' brains more precisely. In a further control measure, ReNeuron's cells contain a temperature-sensitive gene. At laboratory temperatures of 33C they divide and multiply, but in the hotter temperatures inside the human brain - 37C to 38C - they no longer divide. A stroke occurs when the blood supply to the brain is blocked. Of the 100,000 victims of first strokes in Britain each year, some 40,000 survive and experience varying degrees of paralysis and mental impairment. ReNeuron's research is aiming to help victims in the months immediately following a stroke, when the brain's natural repair mechanisms are struggling to put right the damage. Last week Helen Hodges, of the Institute of Psychiatry in London, told a meeting of the British Neuroscience Association that ReNeuron cells had improved movement and cognition in rats which had been given artificially-induced strokes. Dr Hodges, one of the founders of ReNeuron, and other researchers, used genetically modified mouse rather than human cells to implant into the rat's brains, but she said the results were an important proof of principle. Unexpectedly, the cells spread throughout the brain, rather than staying in one place, she said. "The stem cells do not remain clustered in the brain, like foetal grafts, but disperse, integrate and improve function even in aged animals," she added. "We expect that stem cells will prove to be far safer and more flexible for brain damage repair than primary foetal cells because they are unlikely to worsen symptoms, as recently reported in some Parkinson's patients."

webTitle: Brown insists IMF can't drop all the debt

fields.headline: Brown insists IMF can't drop all the debt
fields.standfirst: Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has rejected calls from debt campaigners for the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to write off the outstanding loans of the world's most impoverished countries.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has rejected calls from debt campaigners for the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to write off the outstanding loans of the world's most impoverished countries.

Britain was at the forefront of countries calling for action on third world debt and unilaterally cancelled its own loans to most indebted countries. But the chancellor feels that the World Bank and IMF cannot afford to go further without compromising their lending programmes to other poor countries.

"Countries like Bangladesh, who have a great deal of poverty, rely on the World Bank and would lose out if the Bank diverted its resources simply to wiping out debt," Mr Brown said in an interview with the Observer.

Mr Brown, who is the chairman of the IMF's key policymaking committee, was responding to a report published last week by the Drop the Debt coalition which said the two lenders could afford to cancel the remaining $7bn (£5bn) owed to them by some of the world's poorest countries.

Both financial bodies granted limited debt relief last year to 22 of the most indebted countries. The campaigners say repayments have dropped by about a quarter, but most of the countries are still spending more servicing their loans to the West than on health.

In the report commissioned by Drop the Debt, accountants Chantrey Vellacott argue that the World Bank could use increased reserves to wipe off a further $2.8bn of debt without compromising its triple A credit rating. The rest of the debt-cancellation money could come from revaluing a further chunk of the IMF's gold reserves to market prices, and from earnings on loans to other countries.

"The World Bank can cancel debt and continue lending to low income countries, either from its profits or if its shareholders chose, they can increase their contributions," said Lucy Matthew, from Drop the Debt.

Mr Brown, who is preparing for IMF and World Bank meetings next week, had a stern message for protesters calling for the financial institutions to be abolished.

"The response to a global economy is greater cooperation and more involvement by the international institutions, not less," he said. "Therefore the aim of the anti-globalisation [protests] to diminish the IMF and the World Bank is actually completely wrong."
