fields.headline: Mushrooms in salmonella alert
fields.standfirst:
Food watchdog urges washing and peeling to minimise risk
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Food watchdog urges washing and peeling to minimise risk.
fields.body:
The government's food standards agency last night advised consumers to wash and peel all mushrooms as a rare type of salmonella was linked to the way vegetables were being grown by suppliers.

It also hinted that people should cook mushrooms rather than eat them raw in safety moves that have already seen some growers being told to stop selling their produce while checks are completed.

All the businesses so far hit have been in Northern Ireland but investigations are now being spread to every grower and fertiliser supplier throughout Britain in an effort to assess the size of the problem.

Salmonella, of which there are about 2,400 different types, can cause diarrhoea, vomiting and fever.

Although no cases of human infection have so far been linked to mushrooms, of which 300m lbs are consumed annually in Britain, the alert will strengthen the debate about the way food is prepared in this country.

Salmonella kedougou, a type previously associated with turkey meat and tripe, was identified in test samples from caterers and wholesalers examined by environmental health officials in Lancashire. They alerted the food agency.

Staff at the agency's Northern Ireland office have so far taken nearly 120 samples and found 14 instances of salmonella in a layer of organic material laid on top of compost to help promote fruiting, known as the casing, four in the compost and four in mushrooms themselves.

The agency said mushrooms were like any other salad vegetables in being at risk of contamination from bacteria during the growing process. "Vegetables and salads should be washed carefully to remove any soil and dirt which can carry bacteria and other organisms, making sure that any soil is also washed from hands, kitchen surfaces and equipment.

"Consumers are advised to peel their washed mushrooms, to minimise any risk from bacteria. Mushrooms for use in salads may be cooked, then allowed to cool before serving." The strain of salmonella identified in the mushrooms and their casings was first isolated in Africa in 1970 and only accounted for 20 infections of humans in England and Wales last year.

The salmonella in eggs affair of 1988 followed by the revelation of high levels of salmonella in chicken has led to a revolution in hygiene standards in the poultry industry, although some concerns remain about welfare standards.

The bugs are also found in red meat, milk and dairy products, but instances of all types of salmonella food poisoning have fallen from a 1997 high of 32,596 officially recorded cases in England and Wales to 14,844 last year. The true incidence will be far higher because most sufferers fail to tell doctors about stomach upsets.

There have also been continuing concerns that pesticide levels used to protect fruit and vegetables have been too high. In 1995 , the Ministry of Agriculture had to advise consumers to top and peel carrots before eating them because levels of the chemicals were up to 25 times those permitted.

The latest investigations will be proceeding with some care. Last May, Tesco threw away hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of organic mushrooms from 731 stores in Britain and Ireland after tests by the Public Health Laboratory Service wrongly suggested that they contained another, more virulent bug, E coli 0157.

webTitle: Madeline Bunting: Brian Eno's clock of the future

fields.headline: Thousand-year chime
fields.standfirst:
Along with religion, we have lost a sense of eternity. Enter Brian Eno's clock of the future.
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Along with religion, we have lost a sense of eternity. Enter Brian Eno's clock of the future.
fields.body:
Easter has shot by in a blur of chocolate, chilly showers and garden centres. No surprise there: it has long since lost its religious content for most people. As many as 43%, according to a Mori poll, don't even know what Easter is supposed to celebrate.

In all the arguments about whether this matters, one of the greatest losses rarely gets a look in. Woven into the Christian services is a powerful understanding of time; again and again, the responses and prayers refer to eternity. Only in a church does one hear words such as "everlasting" and phrases such as "for ever and ever".

At the same time as being invited to contemplate God as eternal, churchgoers remember their own place in a continuum of belief which spans generations before them with the implication of generations to come. In such a huge timescale, one's own 70-odd years are placed in their proper place - we're just tenants, passing through.

But we're losing touch with this timescale, let alone that of eastern faiths such as Hinduism, which refer to trillions of years. Given the pace of change, we find it harder and harder to focus on the future. Politicians see little further than the next election. Stock markets and the media can't see much beyond the next day and corporations beyond the next quarter. Intoxicated with speed and immediacy, our attention span shrinks to now! More and more, the environmental movement has come to recognise that its biggest challenge is to enlarge our sense of time: how do you persuade people to change their behaviour now so that their great-grandchildren won't have to suffer the consequences of it?

We seem to find it harder and harder to imagine the future much beyond the next decade, yet the consequences of our behaviour will last longer than any previous generation could have imagined. Nuclear waste, for example, will be radioactive for thousands of years.

All the biggest environmental problems, such as the destruction of biodiversity and global warming, sit in this gap between our failure to imagine the future and our unprecedented destructive capacity.

To challenge that failure of imagination is the purpose of the California-based Long Now foundation. It has started by building a clock that will last 10,000 years. It chimes every thousand years, it ticks every year. The slowest clock in the world was designed by Danny Hillis, who built the fastest computer in the world. The prototype now sits in the Science Museum.

The plan is to build four more around the world, and the goal is to use the clock to provoke or inspire people into thinking far, far into the future. Will there still be human beings to hear it chime the 10,000th year? The "long now" was a phrase coined by the musician Brian Eno, who set up the foundation along with the US environmentalist Stewart Brand. He argues that empathy with human beings across the globe expanded in the 20th century, crossing boundaries of race and faith. The task in the 21st century is to expand that empathy, respect and responsibility to other human beings across time.

That empathy across time is often palpable in an old church, and in its graveyard - in the memorials and the worn flagstones, as well as in services in remembrance of the dead such as All Souls' Day in November. Believer and non-believer alike can value in a church the sense of connection with the lives and sufferings of human beings across centuries. It is something of this which the Long Now hopes to reinvigorate through a new icon - the clock. Eno argues that our ability to imagine the future depends on our understanding of the past - the two are interlinked.

This is not about a theme-park past, but a sense of solidarity and continuity between the past and oneself. Put simply, if you worship your ancestors, you are more likely to care about the well-being of your great-great-grandchildren. Without an awareness of those who lived on the planet before us, we are less likely to have a sense of responsibility to those who will come after us.

For previous generations, it was routine to plan projects whose fulfilment they would never see - from the pyramids to avenues and gothic cathedrals. It seems harder and harder now to rally such faith in the future. The clock of the Long Now may seem a loopy idea, but that's the point. Perhaps inadvertently, it is a reformulation of a long Christian tradition of time-keeping. The first mechanical clocks were invented in 13th- century monasteries to assist in the measuring of their days in the sequence of services - matins, compline etc.

Then, the purpose of marking time was focused on imagining eternity. Now it's more modest - just imagining the lives of our children's great-grandchildren. Change is only possible once people have started to see its possibility. Imagining a future is the first step to creating it.

webTitle: Comment: Nader was right to make a stand

fields.headline: Challenging the big buck
fields.standfirst:
Nader was right to make a stand against the corporate domination of politics, even if it did let Bush win

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Nader was right to make a stand against the corporate domination of politics, even if it did let Bush win.
fields.body:
As George Bush plays chicken with the Chinese and fast and loose with the environment, it is time for the left to play truth or consequence with Ralph Nader. The Green party presidential candidate stood against the two main parties, arguing that there was no difference between them and that America needed an alternative. America ended up with what looks like being the most rightwing president since before the war.

Bush didn't win the election, he won a court case. But, with the slenderest of endorsements, he promises to inflict severe damage. In Congress, many Republicans are beginning to think he is beyond the pale. Even Uncle Sam's faithful poodle, the British government, is yapping at his heels. Some in the cabinet are calling on Tony Blair to put the special relationship "into deep freeze". John Prescott flies to New York today to try to persuade Bush to change his mind about scrapping the Kyoto agreement on controlling greenhouse gases.

So first, some truth. There is a difference between Bush and his Democratic challenger, Al Gore. For Nader to have claimed otherwise during his campaign was disingenuous and opportunistic. We do not know what Gore would have done by this stage had he won, but we can be quite sure it would not have been this. His first decision as president would not have been to deny aid to non-governmental organisations that support abortion overseas through surgery, counselling or lobbying. Nor would Gore have put forward a budget planning to eliminate $309m in grants to help public housing authorities get rid of drug dealers or a programme to preserve wetlands so that he could give trillions to the wealthy. And least of all would he have turned his back on the Kyoto accord.

Now, for a consequence. If Nader had not stood, then Gore would be president. This is as close to a political fact as a statistic dares to be. True, polls showed that one-third of those who voted for Nader would otherwise not have voted at all. But it is also true that more than half of Nader's supporters would have voted for Gore, delivering him majorities in both Florida and New Hampshire and winning him the electoral college.

For the left not to acknowledge this is spineless. If it wants to be taken seriously it must first take itself seriously. Nader stood to make a difference and he succeeded. In politics, as in life, a sign of maturity is accepting responsibility for your actions. Moreover, only once those points have been conceded is it possible to mount a credible defence of Nader's candidacy. Because Nader not only had a right to stand but was right to stand. The problem with George Bush is not that he is a vicious rightwing ideologue - the man can barely tie his shoelaces - it is that he is the paid representative of corporate America.

It is no good challenging Bush without challenging the system that produced him - a system in which big money, not ideas, selects the candidates and then backs both sides to make sure it picks the winner. Since Gore and the Democrats were not only complicit in that system but abused it to their own ends while in office, they were incapable of taking on that task even if they had wanted to. It took an outsider. Nader alone provided a meaningful choice in what is rapidly becoming a multimillion-dollar, corporate-sponsored charade, masquerading as democracy.

Nader was right not because there was no difference between the two main parties but because there was insufficient difference. The Democrats' pitch to potential Nader supporters was: "At least we're not Republicans." The 2.7m people who voted for Nader felt they wanted more from democracy than that.

Democrats love to blame Nader for Bush. Their logic is sloppy. Democrats deny a myriad of other far more compelling or equally tenuous factors that put Bush in the White House. They ignore the fact that, after two terms in office, they could not win Clinton's or Gore's home states. They deny that the situation was so close in Florida that any candidate who stood, including the Natural Law Party, could reasonably claim to have made the decisive difference.

One could as well blame Theresa LePore, the election supervisor who botched the ballot papers, or Katherine Harris, the Republican secretary of state in Florida who obstructed the recounts. In such a tight race, Nader was a factor not the factor. Under such circumstances, to fixate on him as the principal reason for Gore's defeat is perverse.

The charge also reveals astonishing political arrogance. It suggests that the Democrats have a right to the left vote regardless of what they say and do. Clinton can withdraw welfare benefits from the poor, promote a free-trade agreement (Nafta) that sells jobs to the lowest wages and weakest unions in the continent, broker global trade deals that hammer the poor or starve Iraqi children and still expect liberals to turn out for his successor.

Democrats scream betrayal without realising that before there is betrayal there must first be friendship and trust. They demand loyalty, but show none in return. Having spent a decade distancing themselves from the left, they express shock that the left might choose to respect that distance and go it alone.

None the less, the question of whether a principled stand against big money is best served by the practical outcome of a Bush presidency remains pertinent. The answer may change as his term progresses. For the time being, on balance, it was. For evidence look no further than Kyoto. Bush's decision to renege on the treaty is a vicious attack on the environment. But Clinton's record was not much better. He signed up to Kyoto, but he did not honour it. The US, by far the world's largest polluter, promised to cut carbon-dioxide emissions by 7% from 1990 levels by 2012. Instead, emissions rose by more than 10% on 1990 levels by 2000.

It was thanks to Clinton's administration that last year's climate talks in the Hague collapsed. The problem was not only that he could not get the legislation through a Republican Congress, it was that he dared not take on the might of the oil and gas companies. They gave Republican candidates $10m last year; but they gave Democrats, including Gore, $4m. Bush may be in hock to them, but Clinton was in awe of them.

But much also depends on what Nader does now. The corporate domination of American politics cannot be undermined once every four years at election time or on television-panel discussions and the lecture circuit. The truth is that it will take not just a party but a movement, joining together the disparate voices of labour unions, tree huggers and pressure groups that made themselves heard at Seattle, to make complete sense of his candidacy. Having made a difference at the polls, he must now make a difference in civil society. Only then will it be clear that the consequence of Nader's candidacy was not to derail the Democrats, but to restore democracy.

John Prescott flies to New York today to try to persuade Bush to change his mind about scrapping the Kyoto agreement on controlling greenhouse gases. So first, some truth. There is a difference between Bush and his Democratic challenger, Al Gore. For Nader to have claimed otherwise during his campaign was disingenuous and opportunistic. We do not know what Gore would have done by this stage had he won, but we can be quite sure it would not have been this. His first decision as president would not have been to deny aid to non-governmental organisations that support abortion overseas through surgery, counselling or lobbying. Nor would Gore have put forward a budget planning to eliminate $309m in grants to help public housing authorities get rid of drug dealers or a programme to preserve wetlands so that he could give trillions to the wealthy. And least of all would he have turned his back on the Kyoto accord. Now, for a consequence. If Nader had not stood, then Gore would be president. This is as close to a political fact as a statistic dares to be. True, polls showed that one-third of those who voted for Nader would otherwise not have voted at all. But it is also true that more than half of Nader's supporters would have voted for Gore, delivering him majorities in both Florida and New Hampshire and winning him the electoral college. For the left not to acknowledge this is spineless. If it wants to be taken seriously it must first take itself seriously. Nader stood to make a difference and he succeeded. In politics, as in life, a sign of maturity is accepting responsibility for your actions. Moreover, only once those points have been conceded is it possible to mount a credible defence of Nader's candidacy. Because Nader not only had a right to stand but was right to stand. The problem with George Bush is not that he is a vicious rightwing ideologue - the man can barely tie his shoelaces - it is that he is the paid representative of corporate America. It is no good challenging Bush without challenging the system that produced him - a system in which big money, not ideas, selects the candidates and then backs both sides to make sure it picks the winner. Since Gore and the Democrats were not only complicit in that system but abused it to their own ends while in office, they were incapable of taking on that task even if they had wanted to. It took an outsider. Nader alone provided a meaningful choice in what is rapidly becoming a multimillion-dollar, corporate-sponsored charade, masquerading as democracy. Nader was right not because there was no difference between the two main parties but because there was insufficient difference. The Democrats' pitch to potential Nader supporters was: "At least we're not Republicans." The 2.7m people who voted for Nader felt they wanted more from democracy than that. Democrats love to blame Nader for Bush. Their logic is sloppy. Democrats deny a myriad of other far more compelling or equally tenuous factors that put Bush in the White House. They ignore the fact that, after two terms in office, they could not win Clinton's or Gore's home states. They deny that the situation was so close in Florida that any candidate who stood, including the Natural Law Party, could reasonably claim to have made the decisive difference. One could as well blame Theresa LePore, the election supervisor who botched the ballot papers, or Katherine Harris, the Republican secretary of state in Florida who obstructed the recounts. In such a tight race, Nader was a factor not the factor. Under such circumstances, to fixate on him as the principal reason for Gore's defeat is perverse. The charge also reveals astonishing political arrogance. It suggests that the Democrats have a right to the left vote regardless of what they say and do. Clinton can withdraw welfare benefits from the poor, promote a free-trade agreement (Nafta) that sells jobs to the lowest wages and weakest unions in the continent, broker global trade deals that hammer the poor or starve Iraqi children and still expect liberals to turn out for his successor. Democrats scream betrayal without realising that before there is betrayal there must first be friendship and trust. They demand loyalty, but show none in return. Having spent a decade distancing themselves from the left, they express shock that the left might choose to respect that distance and go it alone. None the less, the question of whether a principled stand against big money is best served by the practical outcome of a Bush presidency remains pertinent. The answer may change as his term progresses. For the time being, on balance, it was. For evidence look no further than Kyoto. Bush's decision to renege on the treaty is a vicious attack on the environment. But Clinton's record was not much better. He signed up to Kyoto, but he did not honour it. The US, by far the world's largest polluter, promised to cut carbon-dioxide emissions by 7% from 1990 levels by 2012. Instead, emissions rose by more than 10% on 1990 levels by 2000. It was thanks to Clinton's administration that last year's climate talks in the Hague collapsed. The problem was not only that he could not get the legislation through a Republican Congress, it was that he dared not take on the might of the oil and gas companies. They gave Republican candidates $10m last year; but they gave Democrats, including Gore, $4m. Bush may be in hock to them, but Clinton was in awe of them. But much also depends on what Nader does now. The corporate domination of American politics cannot be undermined once every four years at election time or on television-panel discussions and the lecture circuit. The truth is that it will take not just a party but a movement, joining together the disparate voices of labour unions, tree huggers and pressure groups that made themselves heard at Seattle, to make complete sense of his candidacy. Having made a difference at the polls, he must now make a difference in civil society. Only then will it be clear that the consequence of Nader's candidacy was not to derail the Democrats, but to restore democracy. gary.younge@theguardian.com

webTitle: Trade dispute between China and South Korea

fields.headline: China sniffs at an aromatic victory in Asian food fight
fields.standfirst: Garlic is the new banana
fields.trailText: Now that the trade war between the European Union and the US over bananas appears to be over, a new food fight in international trade diplomacy has begun.
fields.body:
Now that the trade war between the European Union and the US over bananas appears to be over, a new food fight in international trade diplomacy has begun.

This time, it pits South Korea against China and the issue is that prized aromatic bulb. China has threatened to block imports of South Korean mobile phones in protest over Seoul's refusal to accept the last tranche of the 32,000 tonnes of garlic it promised to buy from China.

"The government is agonising over the garlic imports," South Korean commerce minister Chang Che-shik said yesterday. The South Koreans say the problem is there is just not enough demand for it. It took Europe and the US more than a decade to sort out their trade spat through the labyrinthine procedures of the World Trade Organisation.

China has yet to join the WTO, so its approach is more direct: it has given Seoul a week to import the remaining 10,000 tonnes or it will suspend imports of South Korean mobile phones and polyethylene worth $550m (£393m).

It looks as if the small guy will have to concede, and South Korean mobile phone and plastic manufacturers are figuring out what it would cost them to import the garlic.

The dispute arose after South Korea raised its import duty on Chinese garlic tenfold between November 1999 and May 2000. China retaliated by banning imports of South Korean mobiles and plastics.

In August, the pair reached an agreement which required South Korea to import a set amount of garlic per year at discounted tariffs until 2003.

fields.headline: Equitable may build negligence case
fields.standfirst: Insurer hires leading City solicitors to investigate if claims are possible against former executives and advisers
fields.trailText: Insurer hires leading City solicitors to investigate if claims are possible against former executives and advisers.
fields.body:
Equitable Life may take its former advisors and executives to court if its lawyers find evidence to pursue them for negligence during the fateful period which ultimately forced the mutual insurer to close for new business.

The decision will be taken on the advice of City law firm Herbert Smith, which was appointed by the world's oldest mutual at the weekend to investigate the possibility of making negligence claims. Those in the firing line include accountants Ernst & Young, lawyers Denton Hall and former senior executives such as Alan Nash, previously the head of the business.

No allegations of professional liability have been made yet and the lawyers at Herbert Smith are not expected to finish their investigation for some months. The move to hire legal advisers is part of new chairman Vanni Treves's strategy of maximising returns to policyholders, who are bitterly divided between those who believe troublesome guarantees were at the root of the group's problems and those who do not.

The insurer has already commissioned top QC Nicholas Warren to consider whether there are any grounds for trying to overturn last year's surprise judgment preventing Equitable from reducing payments to guaranteed annuity policyholders. The ruling left Equitable with a £1.5bn bill for rectifying the position, forcing the group to close to new business and eventually sell the rump of its assets to the Halifax banking group.

Mr Warren has yet to inform Equitable whether he believes there is any chance that this decision could be overturned but Mr Treves, himself a senior lawyer, is expected to update policyholders at next month's crucial general meeting.

Equitable said yesterday: "We are going to use a firm of independent lawyers to investigate whether there was any professional liability on the part of anybody. There's no current obvious evidence but a full investigation is merited."

Fresh from a series of roadshows with disgruntled policyholders up and down the country, Mr Treves is attempting to show that he is trying to get the best outcome for all policyholders, because he is trying to strike a comprise between the holders of guaranteed annuity polices -the minority - and the rest. If a deal can be reached, the price paid by the Halifax will increase by as much as £500m.

But it is far from clear if an agreement can be found to give the 90,000 guaranteed annuity policyholders a one-off payment to buy them out and finally cap the size of the Equitable's liabilities.

To try to gauge the opinions of policyholders - who must vote on any compromise - Equitable has asked pollsters Mori to measure the opinions of 1,000 policyholders. Striking such a compromise is the biggest challenge faced by Mr Treves, who holds both types of policies himself.

Mr Treves is part of the fresh management being installed at the insurer. Last week, new non-executive directors were named to the board and will need to be officially voted in by policyholders at next month's AGM. This could cause some discomfort for directors as at least one policyholder is thought to be considering standing for election to the board.

Although the insurer is being sold to the Halifax, under the terms of the intricately structured takeover Equitable Life will continue to exist as a mutual company. Halifax has bought, among other things, Equitable's highly regarded sales force and customer base.

Equitable was regarded as one of the most attractive insurance companies for a potential bidder because of its relatively wealthy customer base. But the bidding process almost collapsed when rivals expressed anxiety about the full scale of the bill for maintaining the pledges to guaranteed policyholders. While there were initial expectations of windfalls for policyholders - similar to those received by members of building societies ending their mutuality - these were quickly quashed when the scale of the situation started to materialise.

webTitle: Cesaria Evora, the singer who thrives on misery

fields.headline: Paint it black
fields.standfirst: Peter Culshaw meets Cesaria Evora, the singer who thrives on misery
fields.trailText: Peter Culshaw meets Cesaria Evora, the singer who thrives on misery.
fields.body:
Jose da Silva first came to Sao Vicente in the Cape Verde Islands after hearing Cesaria Evora sing in a Lisbon restaurant. "She was living in a ruin with her mother and two daughters," says the man who is now her manager. "They were living in one room, and you could see the room below through the holes in the floor. The worst problem was that her mother was almost blind and they had to guide her every step." At least they usually had enough to eat. "They never starved because Cesaria went to the bars and just about made enough. Her voice saved them."

Cape Verde, a group of 10 islands in the Atlantic a few hundred miles east of Senegal, is not some balmy paradise, but essentially a rocky and sandy extension of the Sahara. Evora's new album is called Sao Vicente di Longe - after the island she comes from - and its cover shows the 60-year-old singer among the dunes, in what looks like a moonscape. In one affecting photo she is carrying a cockerel and holding out two eggs to the camera, with a typically impassive expression. "It's very bleak," says Evora, "but there's a beauty in the bleakness."

The same is true of Evora's music. The lush instrumentation - strings, horns and shuffling percussion - makes her songs far more enjoyable than the sometimes dirge-like Portuguese fado from which they partly derive. As a result, each of her haunting albums, such as Miss Perfumado, Cesaria and Cafe Atlantico, has had more success than the last.

When you see her perform, she seems to move between melancholy, longing and that untranslatable bittersweet Portuguese word soudade. If the Inuits have a string of words for snow, Cesaria seems to have discovered a whole range of gradations of sadness. She sings what is known as morna, as Cape Verdean as the tango is Argentinian, only occasionally lifting the tempo with another indigenous song form, the comparatively lively coladeira.

Last week, in what was billed as Cesaria Evora's Fiesta, she performed with other Cape Verdean groups in a 17,000-seat Lisbon arena. But if the word fiesta summons up images of bright colours and wild dancing, you'd be mistaken (Cesaria says her favourite colours are "black, black and black"). No one moves and it's impossible to gauge the audience's reaction. But at the end of the set they stomp and cheer and flick their lighters, and at the third encore everyone gets up and dances.

Evora is becoming a serious global star. She has now sold 4m albums - Britain is the only European country to have resisted her. Her forthcoming American tour will include a date at the Hollywood Bowl, and an appearance on David Letterman. Madonna asked her to perform at her wedding and again for her birthday, but Evora turned her down both times.

Backstage in Lisbon, the record company talk is of demographics, territories and "lifestyle marketing", which seems to mean getting the record played in restaurants. A Swedish journalist asks Evora what it is like to be known as "the drinking and smoking grandmother of pop". She says, reasonably enough, that lots of grandmothers drink and smoke, and in any case she's given up the whisky. Someone else wants to know why she's wearing shoes - after all, the one thing everyone knows about her is that she is the "barefoot diva". It turns out she has had an operation on her ankle but will return to her normal shoelessness as soon as she can. Then she sits on her own to eat a Cape Verdean buffet dinner.

She doesn't appear to be even slightly impressed by the circus around her. Is it difficult to retain the ambience of the music in the kind of large arenas she now plays? She is still doing some of the same material that she used to as a bar singer in Cape Verde. "I perform the same way whether it's in front of a president, a group of fishermen in a bar, or in a big concert hall." She exudes an almost rock-like equanimity, but then perhaps that is the best way to cope with the extremes of her life. "I don't feel happy or sad when I sing my music, I feel myself."

But she does get animated talking of Cape Verdean cooking, comparing the new album to a stew that had to be prepared using exactly the right ingredients and then shared with the world. The album is full of sublimely heartwrenching music, above all a duet with Caetano Veloso that suggests hope through the gloom, a mythical moment of magical realism when Cape Verde became green: "The rain/our friend/sends its salvation/the entire island became a garden."

"It did rain like that once," Evora says, "but that was so many years ago I can hardly remember."

 Sao Vicente di Longe is out on BMG.

webTitle: Going out: Picks of the week

fields.headline: Picks of the week
fields.trailText: Pop | Classical | Theatre | Exhibitions | Cinema
fields.body:
Pop

Monday
Papa Roach

Papa Roach have tuned into the prevalent mood of boredom and inner pain that is, post-Kurt Cobain, the currency of rock music in America.

Brixton Academy, Stockwell Road, SW9 (020-7771 2000) 7.30pm, £12.50.

Tuesday
Stephen Malkmus

Stephen Malkmus seems to be relishing his recent release from his former group, Pavement. The qualities of that group - a ramshackle melodic sense coupled with an off-the-wall, but often touching lyricism - mainly belonged to Malkmus, and it is these that we find in his debut solo album.

Shepherd's Bush Empire, Shepherd's Bush Green, W12 (020-7771 2000) 8pm, £11.

Wednesday
Stereophonics

Stereophonics represent solidity, a nice singing voice, something as reliable as a workbench.

Ocean, Mare St, E8 (020-7314 2800) 8pm, phone for prices.

Thursday
Mogwai

As much rock as they are post-rock, Mogwai have for each ounce of their avant-garde ambition a basic primal urge to make noise, and it's in this volatile combination that much of their genius lies.

Shepherd's Bush Empire, Shepherd's Bush Green, W12 (020-7771 2000) 8pm, phone for prices.

Friday
Van Morrison

Undoubtedly one of the greats on the strength of his work pre-1975 alone, Van Morrison nowadays cuts a stately figure, revisiting old generic stomping grounds with a surly vigour.

Royal Albert Hall, Kensington Gore, SW7 (020-7589 8212) 7.30pm, £18-£30.

John Robinson

Classical

Tuesday
Happy Birthday Igor

To celebrate his 70th birthday, Igor Oistrakh plays Mendelssohn's violin concerto, just as he did at his British debut in 1953. For good measure he also throws in Beethoven's violin concerto in this concert with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra. With a programme like that it doesn't look as though he has any thought of retiring.

Barbican Hall, Barbican Centre, Silk St, EC2 (020-7638 8891) 7.30pm, £10.50-£28.50.

Wednesday
London Mozart Players

Pascal Roge is the soloist in the brilliant second piano concerto by Saint-Saëns, along with symphonies by Mozart and Bizet and Ravel's Mother Goose Suite.

Queen Elizabeth Hall, South Bank Centre, SE1 (020-7960 4201) 7.45pm, £7.50-£21.

Three Evenings Festival

Last of three concerts which attempt to demystify experimental music, this time with sampled bouzouki, mini-disc and voice creating a "disturbing socio-political message".

Cheltenham Music Library, Chester Walk (01242-227070) 8pm, £4 on the door only.

Thursday
Otello

Elijah Moshinsky's production of Verdi's opera returns to Covent Garden with a cast that includes Jose Cura as Otello and Amanda Roocroft as Desdemona.

Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, WC2 (020-7304 4000) 7.30pm, £5-£150.

Friday
Czech Philharmonic

While the LSO are busy playing as much Bohemian music as possible, along comes the Czech Philharmonic under Vladimir Ashkenazy with two programmes stuffed with Viennese and Russian classics: tonight Prokofiev's fifth symphony, tomorrow Strauss's Four Last Songs and Mahler's fifth symphony. Prepare to fight your way in.

Barbican Hall, Barbican Centre, Silk St, EC2 (020-7638 8891) 7.30pm, £6-£30.

Christopher Lambton

Theatre

Shock-Headed Peter

This show's mixture of the macabre, malevolent and the monstrously funny, combined with the weird, compelling music of The Tiger Lilies, has won it a cult following.

Piccadilly, Denman Street, W1 (020-7369 1734) Tue, Wed, Fri & Sat 8pm, Thurs 6.30 & 10pm, £10-£29.50.

Blasted

The Royal Court revives the 1995 play that caused controversy and outrage on its premiere. Sarah Kane's suicide two years ago has given her a Sylvia Plath type status, a pity because the work deserves to be judged on its own terms.

Royal Court, Sloane Square, SW1 (020-7565 5000) 7.30pm, Sat mat 3.30pm, £10-£24.50.

Mill On The Floss

First produced in 1994, Helen Edmundson's version of George Eliot's novel has taken a long time to reach the West End, but it undoubtedly deserves its berth. It is devastatingly good.

New Ambassadors, West Street, WC2 (020-7369 1761) 7.30pm, £12.50-£24.

Henry V

Edward Hall's modern dress production is a bruising and intelligent consideration of what heroism and national identity mean today.

Barbican, Silk St, EC2 (020-7638 8891) Thurs-Sat 7.30pm, Sat mat 1.45pm, £9-£29.

The Junebug Symphony

It's circus but with a new twist. James Thierre and his company cause delirum in an acclaimed show that should give the entire family an Easter treat.

Queen Elizabeth Hall, South Bank, SE1 (020-7960 4242) Mon and Tues only 7.45pm, Mon mat 1.45pm, £11-£15.

Lyn Gardner

Exhibitions

Legacies Of Silence

Drawings and paintings made by artists who witnessed first hand the horrors of the ghettos, deportation centres, and extermination camps set up under Nazi rule.

Imperial War Museum, Lambeth Road, SE1 (020-7416 5000) until 28 August, £5.50.

Kate Bright

These glitter and acrylic paintings of snow-capped mountain peaks and shimmering waters are far from kitschy, retaining instead a certain gloomy quality, aided by their flat monochrome colours.

Emily Tsingou Gallery, Charles II Street, SW1 (020-7839 5320) until 28 April, free.

Candy Factory

Collaboration between the outlandish artist Genesis P-Orridge (of Psychic TV and Throbbing Gristle fame) and Eric Heist.

Centre of Attention, Cotton's Gardens, E2 (020-78395320) until 6 May, free.

Gary Lee Boas

Although shabby and blurred, these photographs of Hollywood celebrities shot by this star-struck amateur are weirdly sublime.

Photographers Gallery, Great Newport St, WC2. (020-7831 1772) until 26 May, free.

Ceal Floyer

Projections of light switches and felt-tip pens drained into blotting paper, Ceal Floyer's subtle minimalism is imbued with lightheartedness.

Peer, Shoreditch Town Hall, Old Street, EC1 (020-7739 8080) until 29 April, free.

Jessica Lack

Cinema

Best In Show

In this little gem of a comedy, director and co-writer Guest tells the story of the "Mayflower Dog Show", following the fraught lives of the key competitors and their tremulous, talented pooches. A nimble, agile, quick-witted, intelligent little film.

(12) (Christopher Guest, 2000, US) Christopher Guest, Parker Posey. 90 mins ****

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

A martial arts movie in a traditional Chinese action idiom which manages to be both electrifyingly exciting and sweetly romantic.

(15) (Ang Lee, 2000, China/US) Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zhang Ziyi. 120 mins *****

A Hard Day's Night

Easily the best Beatles film, directed by Richard Lester who emerges as a neglected modern master, chucking the camera about with wonderful flair, capturing the sheer joy of the Fab Four in the springtime of their career. webTitle: Rich's ex-wife to testify on Clinton

fields.headline: Rich's ex-wife to testify on Clinton
fields.trailText: Denise Rich, the songwriting socialite who won a pardon during the last hours of the Clinton presidency for her former husband Marc, has struck a deal in return for immunity from prosecution.
fields.body:
Denise Rich, the songwriting socialite who won a pardon during the last hours of the Clinton presidency for her former husband Marc - wanted on suspicion of tax dodging - has struck a deal to give evidence about the circumstances of the pardon, in return for immunity from prosecution.

Marc Rich was accused of evading $48m (£33.5m) in taxes on $105m in alleged illegal oil trading profits. An outcry in and outside government at Bill Clinton's pardon for him has led to an investigation by the US attorney for southern Manhattan, Mary Jo White, into a deal lay behind the former president's action.

Ms Rich, 57, who has written songs for Diana Ross, Celine Dion and Donna Summer, gave about $1.5m to Clinton causes, including his presidential library in Arkansas and the Democratic party. The investigators want to know if these donations were linked to the pardon, and if any of them were made with money originating from Mr Rich, a fugitive in Switzerland since 1983.

"Immunity was inevitable for her, given the theory that they are investigating," a lawyer for another witness in the case told Time magazine. "It doesn't mean the investigation is necessarily going anywhere." Mr Clinton granted 140 pardons and commuted 36 prison sentences before he left office on January 20. The justice department is particularly shocked at the Rich pardon, because the charges were so serious.

In a further twist in the Clinton pardon scandal, the former president's brother Roger is to appear before a grand jury at the end of this week. Two Texans claim they paid $200,000 to a group that included Roger Clinton, to secure a pardon for a relative. They say the group achieved nothing on their behalf.

Bart Williams, Roger Clinton's lawyer, said that he did not know whether his client would testify or plead the fifth amendment as insurance against incriminating himself.

"It's always a very serious matter when one is asked to testify before the grand jury and one should proceed cautiously," he said.

"Pardongate" has sullied further the Clinton legacy, which the former president had hoped to crown with a Middle East peace deal rather than a toxic aftertaste stimulated by favours for cronies. It has also demolished any hopes Hillary Clinton might have had about running for the presidency in 2004. The new US senator for New York state has been obliged to rule this out though she has been more equivocal about 2008.

Ms White is also looking into the clemency granted to four Hassidic Jews from the village of New Square, about 30 miles north of Manhattan, who were convicted of stealing up to $40m in government grants for schemes that included a non-existent school.

She wants to know if Mr Clinton granted clemency to the men in return for the village's support for his wife in her election to the Senate in November.

New Square backed her by 1,359 votes to 10 and the convicts' sentences of up to 78 months were reduced to a maximum of 30 after the community's grand rabbi visited the White House for a meeting at the end of last year attended by both Clintons.

A lawyer close to the case said it would be hard to establish that a crime had been committed even if Mrs Clinton had promised to lobby the president in return for votes. "Politicians make promises all the time," he said. "That's nothing new, or illegal."

webTitle: Aminata's tale of tears and cruelty

fields.headline: Aminata's tale of tears and cruelty
fields.trailText: Weeping with fear, 10-year-old Aminata confessed that she had taken biscuits from the kitchen in the safehouse where she had arrived 24 hours earlier. She had been ravenous after four months of hard work and little food, but was terrified the nuns  looking after her would beat her. Her owner used to whip her.
fields.body:
Weeping with fear, 10-year-old Aminata confessed that she had taken biscuits from the kitchen in the safehouse where she had arrived 24 hours earlier. She had been ravenous after four months of hard work and little food, but was terrified the nuns looking after her would beat her. Her owner used to whip her.

A passer-by found Aminata sleeping under a bench in Libreville, the capital of Gabon, after she had run away from her owner. For four months she had worked for him selling cakes in the market, alongside dozens of other slave children, some as young as six.

"The children are not highly valued: they're a commodity," said Mike Sheil, a photojournalist who met Aminata when he travelled to Gabon last month to document the traffic in child slaves from Benin and Togo. "The trade is technically illegal, but it's very much accepted.

Aminata grew up in Sokode, Togo, where her mother struggled to hold her large family together after the father walked out. Then a neighbour promised the family money and said she could find Aminata work abroad.

Aminata was driven 1,000 miles to Ibono in Nigeria, where dozens of children were loaded on to a boat for a 1,000-mile sea voyage to Libreville. Now she shares a house there with 16 other former slaves. The two teachers who run the rescue scheme have repatriated more than 80 children in the last year, but struggle to find the funds.

webTitle: Fears grow for children as slave ship goes missing

fields.headline: Fears grow for children as slave ship goes missing
fields.trailText: There was growing concern last night about the fate of dozens, possibly hundreds, of children held on a slave ship that has gone missing off the west coast of Africa.
fields.body:
There was growing concern last night about the fate of dozens, possibly hundreds, of children held on a slave ship that has gone missing off the west coast of Africa. The Nigerian-registered MV Etireno was transporting the children from Benin to work on plantations in Gabon. But the ship was turned away from two ports when its cargo was discovered and its whereabouts are now unknown.

The authorities in Benin estimate there are 180 children on board. The UN children's agency, Unicef, says it fears for the safety of the young people on the MV Etireno and what the captain now intends to do with them.

"We are very worried about the welfare of these children," said Unicef's representative in Benin, Esther Guluma. "These children were destined to work on plantations in Gabon. Now they cannot go there, we are very worried about what the people who are holding them on the ship intend to do with them and the conditions they are in."

There is concern that the ship will secretly dock somewhere else and dump the children ashore to avoid problems with the authorities back in Benin, or sell them into slavery with new buyers. The UN has also said it fears the captain may try to dump the children overboard at sea to remove any evidence against him.

The Etireno took on fuel during its last stop, in Cameroon, but the port authorities say the ship had only limited food supplies. Conditions were said to be very unsanitary.

The police in Cameroon told aid workers that some of the children were quite ill after what should have been a four-day journey turned into more than a fortnight's sailing over 1,250 miles. The vessel loaded the children - believed to be aged as young as nine - in Cotonou, Benin, about a fortnight ago. It sailed for Gabon, where they were destined for forced work on plantations. But when the Gabonese authorities discovered the cargo, they refused the vessel permission to dock.

The ship headed for Cameroon in the hope of selling the children there. Officials again refused to allow them to be unloaded but did allow the vessel to refuel.

The governments of Gabon and Cameroon have not explained why they did not detain the vessel and free the children as they would have been entitled to do under national and international law. The Nigerian captain filed sailing plans in Cameroon claiming that his destination was Benin, the children's homeland. That journey should take no more than two days, and the ship was expected to arrive on Saturday. But it has not been seen or made radio contact since.

Over the past five years, the MV Etireno has been a regular visitor to Benin - one of the world's poorest countries - to load children sold into slavery. Many are destined for relatively prosperous, oil-rich Gabon or Ivory Coast with its cocoa plantations. Others end up as servants in the homes of the rich in Libreville or Lagos.

Benin says it has alerted neighbouring governments to detain the ship. One possibility is that it will head for its home port of Lagos.

The authorities in Benin have also named a local businessman they are seeking for allegedly buying the children and arranging transport on board the Etireno. The social protection minister, Ramatou Baba Moussa, said the man concerned, Staneslas Abatan, was in Gabon awaiting the arrival of the ship.

fields.headline: Self-serving leaders keep Bosnia divided
fields.standfirst: Five years after the peace deal, people struggle for normal lives
fields.trailText: Five years after the peace deal, people struggle for normal lives.
fields.body:
Brightly lit at night, the giant cross looms over the divided city of Mostar - a new ethnic marker on the same clifftop where artillery rained shells on Muslim buildings in the city during the Bosnian war of the early 90s. The Christian symbol may be less lethal now but to every Muslim family here it carries just as clear a message of separateness and attempted supremacy.

It is more than five years since the US pressed Balkan leaders at an air force base in Dayton, Ohio, to sign a peace deal for Bosnia. During that time, $5bn (£3.5bn) has been pumped in to the country and 20,000 Nato-led troops are still in place trying to secure the peace.

Yet the country is still as far from unity as it was when the guns fell silent. If the international community fails in Bosnia, Kosovo's chances are slim.

The cross above Mostar went up only five months ago, coinciding with the start of a powerful campaign by Bosnian Croat hardliners to set up their own mini-state.

Western governments were shocked: they had long seen Bosnia's Serbs as the fledgling country's main problem. They thought the fall of the Serb strongman next door in Yugoslavia, Slobodan Milosevic, would open a more optimistic page for Bosnia. Already in Croatia proper, a more democratic regime had arrived.

Instead, the moves towards democracy in Serbia and Croatia have frightened and provoked their ethnic kin in Bosnia, making them more rather than less extreme.

In elections in December, the SDS - the party of Radovan Karadzic, the Serb leader in Bosnia charged with war crimes by the international tribunal at the Hague - emerged as the strongest party in Serb areas of the republic. In Bosnia's Croatian areas, the equally nationalist Croatian Democratic Union, HDZ, won close to 90% of the vote.

At least this triumph of extremism was not emulated by Bosnia's Muslims, who for the first time since the war, gave half their votes to parties with a civic rather than a nationalist agenda. But the Bosniacs, as the Muslims are known, have always had a stronger stake in a unified state with its own identity.

They also benefit more than Serbs and Croats from the international community's huge presence in the capital, Sarajevo, providing jobs for thousands of translators, drivers and secretaries, as well as scores of programmes meant to foster a healthy civil society.

The biggest problem is in the Serb and Croat areas, which became largely monoethnic after the wartime "cleansing". Under the Dayton agreement, the Serbs got a separate "entity" covering 49% of Bosnia. The Croats remained in a federation with the Muslims.

The Serb entity and the Muslim-Croat federation were supposed to share central institutions in a single state. There is a Bosnian central bank, a common currency (the mark, convertible at par with the deutschmark), and common car licence plates which make it easier for people to travel with less risk of being set upon than if plates were ethnically differentiated.

But the common political institutions, such as parliament and the three-man presidency, are not yet working to a consensus. And now even the division into two entities - the Serb one, and the Muslim-Croat one - is challenged.

In the words of a disillusioned western diplomat, "The Serbs got their mafia statelet. The Muslims got the country as a whole. The Croats got nothing. Instead, they were lumped with the people they like least. Now they want a statelet like the Serbs got." The Croats made their challenge in early March when the HDZ set up an illegal Croat parliament. They then tried to persuade Croat officers and soldiers to defect from the Muslim-Croat federation army to build up a force loyal to the separatists.

The federation's defence minister, Mijo Anic, a moderate Croat, claimed some success last week in stemming the desertions, reporting that around three-quarters of the soldiers in central and north-eastern Bosnia had gone back to barracks. In the hardline nationalist region of Herzegovina it was less than half.

But Nato-led peacekeepers in Bosnia said yesterday that they had begun removing weapons from several Croat-controlled barracks.

The optimistic view on the latest events is that the Croat rebellion is a last defiant stand by the hardliners rather than the unravelling of the Dayton accords. "This is happening because we're succeeding, not because we're failing," says the bullish head of the UN mission, Jacques Klein. Yet the city of Mostar is a symbol of troubled Bosnia. Depending on which side of the city they live, people pay their bills to different branches of the electricity utility and the phone company. The police and other public servants get their wages separately.

Wolfgang Petritsch, the Austrian diplomat who is the international community's high representative, recently started to go after the real source of the nationalists' power - their money. After five years of trying to build up civic institutions in the hope that democratic forces would vote the extremists out, the new strategy is to hit the wealth that helps the militants secure support.

Ten days ago federal police raided Hercegovacka Banka, a new bank set up by leaders of the HDZ in Mostar and other cities, and took control of it.

The international peacekeeping force, S-For, failed to provide enough protection, with the result that several auditors were taken hostage and threatened by Croat thugs. But computer hard disks and other documentation were seized, and this may allow fraud charges to be brought. Through the Hercegovacka Banka, the HDZ was able to control salaries and loyalties, as well as allegedly creaming off part of people's pensions or earning interest on delayed payments. If Mr Petritsch and his team win this struggle they will have given a big boost to Croat moderates. International officials are repeatedly exposing the hardliners for robbing their own people.

The snag is that even the moderates are not always what they seem. International officials and the western governments backing them have spent four years using various regulations to exclude nationalists from power and to cultivate moderate prime ministers in the Bosnian Serb entity, Republika Srpska.

But these western-backed men, operating from the town of Banja Luka, have generally proved no less corrupt and just as obstructive of Bosnian unification as the nationalists.

The main signs of hope since the signing of the Dayton agreement in November 1995, are that openness and debate in each community are gaining ground. The press is bolder and more willing to tackle corruption and criticise leaders.

More refugees are also returning to their home areas even if it means going back to places where a different ethnic group is in charge.

"I have had no trouble from our neighbours," he says. "Most people are all right. They get manipulated by their leaders."

Dragan Obrenovic is to be sent to the Hague tribunal for trial. He has been questioned about the killings in Srebrenica, which fell to Serb forces in July 1995. Some 7,000 Muslims are believed to have been executed afterwards.

The Christian symbol may be less lethal now but to every Muslim family here it carries just as clear a message of separateness and attempted supremacy. It is more than five years since the US pressed Balkan leaders at an air force base in Dayton, Ohio, to sign a peace deal for Bosnia. During that time, $5bn (£3.5bn) has been pumped in to the country and 20,000 Nato-led troops are still in place trying to secure the peace. Western governments were shocked: they had long seen Bosnia's Serbs as the fledgling country's main problem. They thought the fall of the Serb strongman next door in Yugoslavia, Slobodan Milosevic, would open a more optimistic page for Bosnia. Already in Croatia proper, a more democratic regime had arrived. The Serb entity and the Muslim-Croat federation were supposed to share central institutions in a single state. fields.headline: SS officer admits Genoa massacre
fields.trailText: Italy has asked Germany to arrest a 92-year-old pensioner for war crimes he committed when he was known as the Executioner of Genoa.
fields.body:
Italy has asked Germany to arrest a 92-year-old pensioner for war crimes he committed when he was known as the Executioner of Genoa.

German television tracked down the former Nazi SS officer, Friedrich Engel, to a suburb in Hamburg at the weekend, two years after he was sentenced, in his absence, to life in prison by an Italian court for murdering 246 hostages.

He admitted partial responsibility for killing 59 prisoners, but said he was following the direct orders of Adolf Hitler.

Engel was head of the SS in the northern region of Liguria in 1944-45 when it carried out at least four massacres.

Piero Fassion, the justice minister, said: "Unfortunately, in Germany, the law prevents the extradition of German citizens, but all the same we can obtain an answer to our request for arrest, especially now that that there is a definitive condemnation."

Snowy-haired and sprightly, Engel was confronted by the German channel ARD while pushing a wheelbarrow in his garden in the Lockstedt suburb of Hamburg, where he has lived since the second world war.

In an interview in yesterday's edition of Corriere della Sera of Milan, he admitted taking part in a massacre in spring 1944. "I am responsible, but only in part, for the execution of 59 Italian prisoners of war. For me to have resisted would have been impossible. Imagine, if you can, how you would have resisted the personal wishes of the Führer."

It was a reprisal for the bombing of a Genoa cinema which killed six German sailors. Hitler's orders were to execute 10 for every German killed by partisans.

"Yes, I was involved. I did not oppose it. And I regret it immensely. They died as heroes, as martyrs. They didn't cry; they didn't shout, they didn't ask for pity."

However he rejected a Turin military court's 1999 conviction of him for another three massacres. "False, totally false," he said in the interview at his home. "I do not have a terrible record in Italy. I love its music, its art, its melodic language."

After the war he lived openly in Hamburg. He set up a company importing and exporting furniture and travelled to the United States, Europe and Japan, but never went to Italy.

He regretted not going back to Genoa. "I love that city and its people. I would have liked to have known it better, learned its history. I'm sorry, I am truly sorry for the pain I have caused."

webTitle: After 38 years, race trial gives city chance for justice

fields.headline: After 38 years, race trial gives city chance for justice
fields.standfirst: It was one of the worst atrocities of the civil rights era, but a Klansman faces court at last for killing four schoolgirls
fields.trailText: It was one of the worst atrocities of the civil rights era, but a Klansman faces court at last for killing four schoolgirls.
fields.body:
Three preachers take turns to beat out a strident message devoted to a loving and forgiving saviour, a member of the sparse congregation for the Easter service punctuating their words with an occasional "amen" or a "yes". On the face of it there is nothing to separate the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church from dozens of others. The denomination's churches run to more than four pages in the Birmingham telephone book.

Down in the basement, though, among black and white photographs of the church's former pastors, old banners and a model of the slave ship Spirit of Amistad is the artefact resting on beige and white linoleum tiles that makes Sixteenth Street different. It is a timepiece, made by the Radio Advertising Clock Co, with its hands forever at 10.22, the red seconds indicator at 43 seconds, the time when the electricity supply failed.

This was the place and this the time at which a bomb made out of 19 sticks of dynamite exploded on September 15, 1963: when the rubble had settled and the dust cleared enough for anyone to tell, four Sunday school girls in their best white dresses and black patent leather shoes were dead.

Today, nearly 38 years later, that clock in a sense starts to tick again on one of the deadliest events of the sixties civil rights struggle, when 62-year-old Thomas Blanton finally goes on trial accused of murdering the girls, one aged 11, the others 14. No one was charged then, even though a FBI report named the likely killers, because witnesses were scared to testify and it was thought unlikely that any jury would convict. "No one believed that a local jury would return any kind of guilty verdict, so things just sat for a while," says Robert Langford, the retired FBI supervisor who reopened the case in 1994 after talking to black leaders.

Blanton would have been joined in the dock by another former member of the Ku Klux Klan had not the court ruled last week that 71-year-old Bobby Frank Cherry is mentally and physically unfit to stand trial, at least for the time being. "It's a good time, a very opportune time to become mentally incapable," says Sixteenth Street's assistant pastor, the Reverend Joseph Decatur, standing beside the door that leads to the room where the girls died.

"I think it will give people closure if they can bring it to a conclusion but now that the men are not being tried together, that's going to prolong the issue. These men have been allowed to grow old and even if they are convicted they won't have long to serve because they're going to die soon.

"I really think it would be a travesty if they were found not guilty. People would be very upset and would express that vociferously but I don't think there would be any violence. Black people realise that they've come so far that they will never go back."

Some black people, certainly. The church is part of a complex known as the civil rights historic district and Birmingham promotes its constituent parts on the guide to the city's attractions in precisely the way it does the vintage motor sports museum, Visionland amusement park (the newest in the South) and the zoo.

Across the street from the church is the Civil Rights Institute, whose mission is to follow the path of the city's part in the movement to have black people treated as equals. Opposite the institute is Kelly Ingram park, where protesters would gather almost 40 years ago before setting off on civil rights marches.

Here birds twitter above a statue of Martin Luther King Jr, sculptures of heroes who endured beyond provocation, and representations of police setting slavering dogs on young blacks. Carvings in stone say at each entrance that it is a "place of revolution and reconciliation". Come dusk, this holy place in the movement's history is also a gay pick-up spot and hang-out for the homeless. Behind a monument, out of sight of the landmark sites, the Adamsville Church of God operates a soup kitchen from a truck for a dozen people, most of them men, all of them black.

"I just come down here to chill out and to see if I can get me a drink," says Jimmy Pless, a 47-year-old former truck driver. "It's a gay park. This is where we come. The trial? The bombing happened a long time ago. Let God be the judge, let him do what he's got to do. I don't think we should be having the trial after all this time."

His is not the majority view among the quarter-million population of a two-thirds black city that is proud of its transformation from reliance on steel and coal to a medical and technology centre. But still, you can park your car for two-and-a-half hours at a meter in exchange for 25 cents and Mr Pless's bottle of wine costs $2.65.

A local radio station is asking listeners to get in touch: "Call in to our poll on Frank Cherry. Is he really unable to help with his defence or is he just gold-bricking?" It is barely worth mentioning the response.

An FBI memorandum delivered in 1965, 18 months after the killings, said: "The bombing was the handiwork of former Klansmen Robert E Chambliss, Bobby Frank Cherry, Herman Frank Cash and Thomas E Blanton jr." Blanton is said to have driven his '57 Chevy to the church and waited with the others while "Dynamite Bob" Chambliss set the bomb.

Chambliss was eventually found guilty in 1977, dying in jail eight years later; Cash died without ever facing a jury; Cherry might never come to trial now; which leaves only Blanton, a chip off the old racist block, son of Pops Blanton, a notorious Birmingham white supremacist.

Mark Potok, a spokesman for the Southern Poverty Law Centre, says that racist groups are not exactly rallying to the Blanton cause. "Even if you believe in racial separation, it's difficult to get behind the murder of four little girls. It's also a trial from another era. It's like trying a Nazi war criminal."

That era was one in which blacks, now Afro-Americans, were referred to as negroes in polite society; when freelance bigots performed the role in which today police in cities such as New York, Los Angeles - and now Cincinnati - are cast.

There was no direct reference during the Sixteenth Street Easter service to the bombing so long ago, but a reading from Luke 23:24 might have been taken as one: "And Jesus said: 'Father forgive them; for they know not what they do.'"

webTitle: Precarious peace as Cincinnati enters fourth curfew night

fields.headline: Precarious peace as Cincinnati enters fourth curfew night
fields.trailText: Riot-torn Cincinnati clung on to a precarious peace yesterday after another night of violence was narrowly averted by the intervention of religious leaders, a police noose around the ghetto area and a torrential downpour of rain.
fields.body:
Riot-torn Cincinnati clung on to a precarious peace yesterday after another night of violence was narrowly averted by the intervention of religious leaders, a police noose around the ghetto area and a torrential downpour of rain.

It had been hoped that last night's curfew - the fourth since an explosion of rioting last Wednesday - would be lifted, but the authorities elected to re-impose it. Mayor Charles Luken said the curfew would start at 11pm instead of 8pm to allow families more time to celebrate Easter. "Hopefully today can be a day of prayer. A day of peace. A day of coming together," he said.

The extension came after some 200 people, almost all youths, were arrested in minor clashes with the police during the early hours of yesterday as the curfew was spurned by large numbers for the first time. The trouble began after crowds had gathered in the Over-the-Rhine neighbourhood, close to the spot where police shot and killed 19-year-old Timothy Thomas on April 7.

The city had been brought to the brink of serious rioting following Thomas's last rites on Saturday. As crowds left the funeral a group of four police squad cars pulled up at the entrance to the ghetto and officers opened fire down the street with a new type of crowd control ammunition - bean-bags loaded with metal shot. Two women were injured.

The city authorities are now desperate to establish normality in their town. The mayor has crucial and difficult meetings today with executives from the city's main employer, Proctor and Gamble, and owners of the local baseball team - the Cincinnati Reds - whose continued absence from their new stadium near the scenes of the riots is becoming a symbol of the crisis and of white exasperation. The Reds have a match on Tuesday and Mayor Luken is under extreme pressure to test the city's nerve, lift the curfew and allow them to play it.

Yesterday, the mayor faced the unwelcome arrival of the New York-based black leader Al Sharpton, whose presence is likely to make dynamics in the unsettled black area of the city all the more complex. Each night, increasing number of youths with masked faces roam the streets after curfew time threatening to "tear it down" once it is lifted.

"The city should still be burning," says Eugene Vassar, "We don't feel like this is our community."

Yesterday morning's clash was only averted by the intervention of Pastor Damon Lynch, who administered at Thomas's funeral. Parleying with both the rioting youths and police, he diverted the crowd towards a separate rally and the two converged into a procession of thousands suddenly marching around the town whooping and singing gospel songs.

webTitle: Schröders on the trail of their father's war grave

fields.headline: Schröders on the trail of their father's war grave
fields.trailText: The sister of Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany believes she has traced the grave of their father, who died 57 years ago while fighting the Russians in the second world war.
fields.body:
The sister of Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany believes she has traced the grave of their father, who died 57 years ago while fighting the Russians in the second world war.

A Berlin-based organisation that compiles records on the whereabouts of army dead wrote to Gunhild Kamp-Schröder last week to say that her father lies, together with three fallen comrades, in a communal grave in the shadow of a Romanian country church.

The Sunday tabloid Bild am Sonntag, which reported the news yesterday, said its reporters had visited the village, Ceanu Mare, near the city of Cluj. There, the paper had interviewed a woman of 85 who claimed to have buried the four soldiers after they were killed fighting the advancing Russian army.

Ana Cuc said: "My neighbour, Haberan Procopic, fetched them in an ox cart. I myself laid them in the open grave. Their bodies were shot up and their uniforms were covered in clay." fields.headline: No 1859
fields.standfirst: Clipper
fields.trailText: Clipper
fields.body:
Age: It looks like you're writing Pass Notes. Would you like help?

Eh? Get help with writing Pass Notes.

What? Or just type Pass Notes without help?

Oh, I see. It's that paperclip man on Microsoft Word. One of several "assistant options" included in Microsoft Office 97 - along with Rocky, Scribble and Earl the Cat - Clippy has been helping computer users for five years. "Though nothing more than a thin metal wire," the blurb ran, "Clipper will help you find what you need and keep it all together."

Hah! Fat chance! It's true that the little fella's habit of appearing at unhelpful moments to offer useless advice and contort himself into a series of wacky shapes has generated some resentment among Microsoft customers.

I'll say. I loathe the pixellated pest. Relax. He's just an algorithm existing as a series of magnetic fields on a hard drive.

But I can't get rid of him! Never fear. Microsoft is doing it for you. Clippy has been sacked.

More downsizing in Silicon Valley? The official line is that the company's new Office package works so well, the blinking paperclip has been rendered obsolete.

Rejoice, rejoice! Clippy is so unpopular that journalists reporting his dismissal have been forced to sign a non-disclosure agreement guaranteeing his creator's anonymity.

What next for the superfluous software? Microsoft has launched a website on which Clippy is pitching for business. Users can vote to recast the redundant assistant as a lockpick or the lead singer in a metal band.

Ah, that famous Microsoft sense of humour. Clippy haters may wish to take part in an online game, which allows them to take potshots at the object of their ire with a staple gun.

Cruelty to dumb paperclips! Someone should set up the RSPCPC. Yes, very good.

Not to be confused with: Flipper, Bill Gates, Lara Croft.
