fields.headline: All played out
fields.standfirst: Not long ago he was Stan the Man, England's most expensive footballer and seemingly destined to become one of the greatest players of his era. Now, at 30, he should be at the peak of his game. Instead, Stan Collymore has retired after years of disappointment on the pitch - and tales of depression and violence off it. So, asks  Simon Hattenstone, where did it all go wrong?
fields.trailText: Not long ago he was Stan the Man, England's most expensive footballer and seemingly destined to become one of the greatest players of his era. Now, at 30, he should be at the peak of his game. Instead, Stan Collymore has retired after years of disappointment on the pitch - and tales of depression and violence off it. So, asks Simon Hattenstone, where did it all go wrong?
fields.body:
I'm expecting Stan Collymore any second. Well, I think I'm expecting Collymore. People have warned me. You can't rely on him. Tread carefully, don't get on his wrong side, take a minder. His agent tells me, unnecessarily, that I'll recognise Stan - he's a very, very big man.

Collymore was an outstanding footballer - fast, strong, skilful, it once seemed he could make anything happen when he put his mind to it. He should be one of the great British players of his era. Instead, he's regarded as the biggest screw-up of his generation. Stan the Man became Bad Boy Stan, Stan the Vandal and now Stan the Loser. At 30, he should be peaking. Instead he has just retired. People have compared him with Paul Gascoigne, but at least Gascoigne got his 50 plus caps for England. The more appropriate comparison is with George Best. Like Best, Collymore was, and still is, beautiful, and like Best he had a very serious problem. With Best it was drink, with Collymore it was depression. He lost his energy, lost his will to win, hit out at the world, and most famously hit out at his celebrity girlfriend, Ulrika Jonsson. His career went into freefall.

Collymore arrives at the grand Birmingham hotel on the dot of 10.30am. He shakes hands. His hands are soft, small for his size. His legs are huge, and bend in all directions like a clay model. He says last night he watched his first match in ages - Liverpool vs Barcelona. "Not just since retirement, but in a long time. I wanted to watch the Liverpool game because obviously it's a massive game, and I played for them..." He joined Liverpool for £8.5m in 1995, the record British transfer fee at the time. In his first game, he scored a wonder goal. His first season was successful. By the second he was depressed and had fallen out with the management. Collymore always seemed to fall out with management.

Does he miss football? "No, not really. I'm spending a lot more time with the family, my little boy and fiance. Tom's five and into all sorts."

Collymore and his partner, Estelle, have just moved into a new house in Cannock, a tiny working-class town in the Midlands where he has lived most of his life. His mum lives down the road, her parents live down the road, their best friends live down the road. He's always been a bit of a home boy. There were angry stories emanating from Liverpool about how half-hearted he was because he never moved there. Why should he have uprooted, he says, when he was only an hour's drive away?

Collymore came up the hard way. Rejected after six months as an apprentice, he clawed his way back through Crystal Palace and Southend, before a £2m transfer to Nottingham Forest. There, he scored at a phenomenal rate (45 goals in 78 games), and the fans loved him. But even then there were problems. When his fellow players appeared not to congratulate him for scoring a goal, it blew into a big story. "In the press you have your goodies and baddies, and I guess I've been portrayed as a baddie. On one or two occasions, I guess, rightly so, but I think there's been a lot of real rubbish talked."

His decline was alarming. By the end, his was a great talent every club wanted rid of. Does he feel he threw it all away? "No," he says adamantly. "As a kid I set myself three targets. To be a professional footballer, which I was for 10-12 years. To play for Aston Villa, the club I supported as a kid, and I did. How many kids who support a team actually get out and play for them? And I wanted to play for England. Again, I didn't get 50 caps, but I got three and one was against Brazil." How can you call that failure, he asks?

But, of course, you can, and most of us have done. A man of his ability winning three England caps. "I always find people who do criticise are middle-aged, pot-bellied, really scruffy hacks, and I think to myself: how on earth have you got the nerve?" I hold my belly in. He has a point, though. We do tend to judge success in absolutes.

In writing his football obituary, many commentators suggested that ultimately Collymore didn't love the game enough. He scorns the very notion. "It's typical football manager spiel. There is not a person on this planet that loves playing football more than I do." He criticises few of his colleagues by name, but he can never forgive the Aston Villa manager John Gregory for the way he reacted to his depression.

He points to other problems with the game. The fact that so many young players get so much, so early, for instance. "Kids now, if they show promise at 16, are getting contracts for five years and at the end of those five years they could retire without having to achieve anything." Although he's all of 30, much the same could be said of him. Collymore is such a complicated creature. The vulnerable small-town boy mixed in with the super-ego run wild. It's strange to hear him talking about the erosion of standards like a grand old man of the game. It can sound hypocritical - after all, he benefited as much as anyone from the mad money, and he was not exactly famous for knowing his place. But it does make a confused sort of sense. He wanted figures to look up to, and when he didn't find them, he lost it.

He says the way football is run is shambolic. "You have to have no qualifications whatsoever to be a football manager. At Liverpool, I said what other industry do you know that would buy an asset for £8.5m and not know how to utilise it properly, and I got absolutely slaughtered for saying that." Managing talented, vulnerable kids requires a sophisticated mind, he says.

Dodgy managers, ropy decisions, bad press, a mercenary football culture: Collymore has suffered from all of them. But in the end it was his character, or his illness, that did for him.

Most footballers grew up with dads who patted them on the back whenever they succeeded, growled at them when they failed. Collymore was brought up by his mum who told him to play for pleasure. He talks about his time at Crystal Palace as a youngster, when all the seasoned pros relentlessly mocked his brummie monotone. They all seemed so hard. "I think you get hurt because when you play football as a kid, all the teams you play in, they're all mates. I worked in a completely non-jealous, 100% productive environment as a young footballer." He says he had no idea that the dressing room would be so hostile. "It can be so bitchy, a player walks out of the dressing room, and it's 'he's a fucking tosser, he is', or 'he's a wanker, he is', and he comes back in the dressing room and it's 'all right, mate, all right, brilliant'." You wonder whether this 6ft 3in bruiser was too sensitive for professional football. He says whenever people meet him for the first time, they are surprised. What do they expect him to be like? "I suppose... ignorant, unintelligent, ultra-aggressive, greedy, all of those things."

It was at Aston Villa in 1999, after a £7m transfer, that Collymore first announced he was depressed. His career at Liverpool had fizzled out. At Villa, it never really took off. In June 1998 he was involved in a shocking public assault on his then celebrity girlfriend, Ulrika Jonsson. He punched her in the face in a public bar. What made it worse was that it came a couple of months after Ulrika had cheered after Collymore had been cleared in court of assaulting the mother of his child. There were other stories. The papers dragged up the time he was cleared of assaulting two men in Cannock. The tabloids claimed he was a serial abuser.

Collymore apologised straight after the incident, said it was unforgivable. In every interview he has given since then he has apologised. He also claims that, despite the allegations, he has never hit another woman. One of the most disturbing stories reported an alleged attack on his girlfriend, Estelle, in which he allegedly knocked her unconscious after finding her chatting to another man in their flat.

"Yes, Estelle. Estelle really wanted to go the full distance against the Sun." Estelle is now his fiancee. So why didn't he sue? "Your first reaction is, right, I'm going to take them to court and say, you come and prove this. Then you've got two years going through the courts, whereas in two weeks the story's probably gone. Then in two years it will be there for all to see again. Our families are very close. We know the reality of the situation. They're in the wrong, we're in the right. We're close, we've been together for six years, we've got a baby on the way, we've moved into a new home, we're very happy, so why rock the boat for ourselves, just to give them another week's worth of news two years down the line?"

He never used to be so phlegmatic. He says he used to be desperate to avenge himself, however petty the accusation. Even when a radio commentator criticised him. "I always wanted to react to it, phone the radio stations, and talk to the geezer and say 'you're talking absolute bollocks here'. Now I just let them have their say."

He had a breakdown in 1999. Doctors told him that it had been three years in the making. He realised, in retrospect, that even during those giddy times at Liverpool, he had felt terrible. "It was like an ongoing joke with one mate. He said, 'You're playing for one of the biggest clubs in the world, you've just scored two goals, you've got people dripping off you, and you look the most miserable man I've ever seen'. And I didn't have an answer. If my leg had been hanging off, I could say, well, my leg's hanging off, but I didn't have a clue what it was."

Collymore spent three weeks in the Priory, followed by a few months as a day patient. John Gregory told him to pull his socks up. "He said, 'My idea of someone who's depressed is the woman living on the 20th floor flat with 10 kids'. Yeah, that may well be the case. But just as the Queen can get cancer like the bloke who sweeps the road, so a footballer can get depression." Collymore tells me of a Sun leader dedicated to him. "It said the Sun says to all Aston Villa's brilliant fans kick this fool out out of football; how can he be depressed when he's earning x amount? And that's the national newspaper that's purporting to represent a fair chunk of British views. Again, I think it's that white, middle-aged, hard-core football mentality."

What does he mean? Well, he says, look at how alcoholism is treated in football. "Ninety nine percent of football managers are white, working-class blokes. They grew up with football and alcohol. You can be an alcoholic and get sent to prison and be welcomed back for your strength of character in English football. But if you suffer from an illness that millions suffer from, one of the only illnesses in which people take their own lives, you're called spineless and weak."

And yet, he says, he'd walk out on the streets and strangers would tap him on the shoulder, commiserate and say, "my Nan had that, or my sister had depression".

What did he actually feel like? "With me it was very physical. I was drained. My body and mind was like a flat battery. I had nothing left. Couldn't concentrate, couldn't get motivated. People think any kind of mental distress - straitjacket and you're loony and you're talking crap, the Black Adder thing, two pencils up your nose, and you're talking wibble. But I was just very tired mentally. The brain wasn't fresh enough to make the body do all those real things with conviction or motivation."

The night before he went to hospital, he told Estelle he couldn't go on. Was he thinking of killing himself? "Well, not really in terms of going to jump under a tube..." He trails off.

In hospital, he was treated with antidepressants and psychotherapy. I ask him if he met loads of celebrities at the Priory, and he says that's a misconception. "A lot of the referrals there are NHS ones. People think of it as a celebrity hangout, but it's a psychiatric hospital. In a nutshell, there's a depression unit, eating disorders unit and addictions unit. People think you go in there saying, 'Oh, poor me', while eating grapes and caviar. Believe me, it's not like that at all." By the time he left hospital he had re-evaluated his life. He was upbeat, determined not to be too hard on himself, or others, again. But his football went down the pan.

By the end, he says, he had fallen out of love with football and fallen back in love with life. He wanted to be with Estelle and Tom, and his mates from Cannock. "I heard Tony Adams say the other day that he's not had the time through his football commitments to always be with his kids. At what price? What price?"

It sounds such a clearcut decision, but it wasn't. Who knows what priority family would have had if he'd been preparing for Liverpool's match against Barcelona? Although he had eased up on himself, he admits, "I was thinking, shit, I should still be at Liverpool, not at Bradford or Oviedo or whatever".

But he was also thinking that perhaps he had never really fitted into the world of football. Collymore wasn't particularly academic at school (four O-levels without trying) but he was bright and inquisitive. As a grown-up footballer, he liked reading the broadsheets and watching Newsnight, and he didn't get much change from his colleagues.

He calls himself a Blairite, streaked with a few old Labour priorities. "I'd like to see some degree of national control over the utilities. We need more balance between the private and public sector." He says his values come from Cannock. "I've always said I don't mind paying whatever tax as long as you can see there's genuine tangible benefits to people; not people who want to sit around doing bugger all, all day, but people who genuinely can't get out of the poverty trap: for schools, for social services."

Most successful footballers aren't interested in politics, he says, because it is irrelevant to their lives. "Like I say, football is a cocoon. Everything is done for you. This is ball-signing day, and you have your lunch ready after training, and you forget there's a whole world out there."

Collymore doesn't rule out a comeback, but nor does he plan one. He says there are so many things to do, none of them involving playing football. First, there's the election. He'd love to canvas in Cannock, tell people how important it is to vote. He could be a great asset to the Labour party, but he must know they would regard him as a liability.

There have been stories suggesting he's off to Hollywood to be the new Vinnie Jones. Collymore laughs. "I told a Spanish paper, tongue in cheek, that I wanted to be the first black James Bond." No, he doesn't want to act. But he has started up a television production company, which he hopes will make light entertainment programmes and documentaries. "Real documentaries, none of this reality TV where they make a celebrity of someone just dragged in off the street." He says one of the advantages of owning the production company is that he can control the product. Again, he knows that owning the production company may be the only way of fulfilling an ambition of presenting on television. His history will follow him around for a long time yet.

He says he's already been approached a couple of times for TV work, but an offer has never quite materialised. "I know there'll be obstacles. There's the perception, and the Ulrika Jonsson thing." He pauses, frustrated. With the world? With himself? It's hard to tell. "It was three years ago. Yes it was something that happened ... it was five seconds of my life three years ago. Am I going to have to talk about this every time? Believe it or not, I've got a hell of a lot more to talk about." As he leaves, I notice his nails for the first time. They are bitten to the quick.

But just as the Queen can get cancer like the bloke who sweeps the road, so a footballer can get depression." Collymore tells me of a Sun leader dedicated to him. "It said the Sun says to all Aston Villa's brilliant fans kick this fool out out of football; how can he be depressed when he's earning x amount? And that's the national newspaper that's purporting to represent a fair chunk of British views. Again, I think it's that white, middle-aged, hard-core football mentality." What does he mean? Well, he says, look at how alcoholism is treated in football. "Ninety nine percent of football managers are white, working-class blokes. They grew up with football and alcohol. You can be an alcoholic and get sent to prison and be welcomed back for your strength of character in English football. But if you suffer from an illness that millions suffer from, one of the only illnesses in which people take their own lives, you're called spineless and weak." And yet, he says, he'd walk out on the streets and strangers would tap him on the shoulder, commiserate and say, "my Nan had that, or my sister had depression". What did he actually feel like? "With me it was very physical. I was drained. My body and mind was like a flat battery. I had nothing left. Couldn't concentrate, couldn't get motivated. People think any kind of mental distress - straitjacket and you're loony and you're talking crap, the Black Adder thing, two pencils up your nose, and you're talking wibble. But I was just very tired mentally. The brain wasn't fresh enough to make the body do all those real things with conviction or motivation." The night before he went to hospital, he told Estelle he couldn't go on. Was he thinking of killing himself? "Well, not really in terms of going to jump under a tube..." He trails off. In hospital, he was treated with antidepressants and psychotherapy. I ask him if he met loads of celebrities at the Priory, and he says that's a misconception. "A lot of the referrals there are NHS ones. People think of it as a celebrity hangout, but it's a psychiatric hospital. In a nutshell, there's a depression unit, eating disorders unit and addictions unit. People think you go in there saying, 'Oh, poor me', while eating grapes and caviar. Believe me, it's not like that at all." By the time he left hospital he had re-evaluated his life. He was upbeat, determined not to be too hard on himself, or others, again. But his football went down the pan. By the end, he says, he had fallen out of love with football and fallen back in love with life. He wanted to be with Estelle and Tom, and his mates from Cannock. "I heard Tony Adams say the other day that he's not had the time through his football commitments to always be with his kids. At what price? What price?" It sounds such a clearcut decision, but it wasn't. Who knows what priority family would have had if he'd been preparing for Liverpool's match against Barcelona? Although he had eased up on himself, he admits, "I was thinking, shit, I should still be at Liverpool, not at Bradford or Oviedo or whatever". But he was also thinking that perhaps he had never really fitted into the world of football. Collymore wasn't particularly academic at school (four O-levels without trying) but he was bright and inquisitive. As a grown-up footballer, he liked reading the broadsheets and watching Newsnight, and he didn't get much change from his colleagues. He calls himself a Blairite, streaked with a few old Labour priorities. "I'd like to see some degree of national control over the utilities. We need more balance between the private and public sector." He says his values come from Cannock. "I've always said I don't mind paying whatever tax as long as you can see there's genuine tangible benefits to people; not people who want to sit around doing bugger all, all day, but people who genuinely can't get out of the poverty trap: for schools, for social services." Most successful footballers aren't interested in politics, he says, because it is irrelevant to their lives. "Like I say, football is a cocoon. Everything is done for you. This is ball-signing day, and you have your lunch ready after training, and you forget there's a whole world out there." Collymore doesn't rule out a comeback, but nor does he plan one. He says there are so many things to do, none of them involving playing football. First, there's the election. He'd love to canvas in Cannock, tell people how important it is to vote. He could be a great asset to the Labour party, but he must know they would regard him as a liability. There have been stories suggesting he's off to Hollywood to be the new Vinnie Jones. Collymore laughs. "I told a Spanish paper, tongue in cheek, that I wanted to be the first black James Bond." No, he doesn't want to act. But he has started up a television production company, which he hopes will make light entertainment programmes and documentaries. "Real documentaries, none of this reality TV where they make a celebrity of someone just dragged in off the street." He says one of the advantages of owning the production company is that he can control the product. Again, he knows that owning the production company may be the only way of fulfilling an ambition of presenting on television. His history will follow him around for a long time yet. He says he's already been approached a couple of times for TV work, but an offer has never quite materialised. "I know there'll be obstacles. There's the perception, and the Ulrika Jonsson thing." He pauses, frustrated. With the world? With himself? It's hard to tell. "It was three years ago. Yes it was something that happened ... it was five seconds of my life three years ago. Am I going to have to talk about this every time? Believe it or not, I've got a hell of a lot more to talk about." As he leaves, I notice his nails for the first time. They are bitten to the quick.

webTitle: Inside story: the demise of tank warfare

fields.headline: A farewell to armour
fields.standfirst: Their bulk has dominated 20th-century conflict, but recent reports reveal Britain is to phase out its main battle tanks as a practical instrument of modern warfare. Yet, says  Patrick Wright, their symbolic power to terrify and quell rebellious citizens remains as potent as ever
fields.trailText: Their bulk has dominated 20th-century conflict, but recent reports reveal Britain is to phase out its main battle tanks as a practical instrument of modern warfare. Yet, says  Patrick Wright, their symbolic power to terrify and quell rebellious citizens remains as potent as ever.
fields.body:
It is reported in the current issue of Jane's International Defence Review that the age of the tank is finally drawing to a close. The announcement, actually made some weeks ago by Britain's Master General of the Ordnance, Major General Peter Gilchrist, was that, by 2025, when the current models have run their time, the 70-ton main battle tank will have had its day.

These remarks echo announcements that have been coming out of the Pentagon for a number of years. The tank is dead not because war is over, as some fondly imagined after the iron curtain came down in 1989, but because the basis of warfare has been transformed. If the future belongs to lighter weapons systems, this is partly because war is less likely to be between massed armies, as was envisaged in the cold war scenarios.

Instead, the military is reorganising itself around an idea that the Americans call "force projection" - a kind of fly-swatting operation in which western powers can expect to pour in to some benighted place from a safe distance, deliver the necessary impact and then get out, preferably as fast as they came. You can't do that with a tank force like the one that went to Iraq in 1991 and was two months in transit.

The tank has been fighting off suggestions of redundancy ever since the first world war, when the first models were invented by the British to overcome the lethal stasis of trench warfare. The machine is, after all, a contradiction in terms. It is a platform that must combine three partially contradictory parameters: firepower, mobility and protection. The heavier a tank is, the less mobile it is likely to be, and vice versa.

Every nation that has designed a tank has its own "tank triangle", shaped according to the priorities placed on the respective parameters. Technological advances are now making that balancing act seem unnecessary. If you can fire off a whole battery of missiles instantaneously, why have a single gun that needs to be rotated and aimed each time? And why weigh yourself down with tons of armour when you can achieve protection by other means, perhaps by switching on a heavy magnetic field?

And yet there is another side to the history of this weapon, which may be more visible to civilians than to the spooky prophets of new age warfare. The tank may be a practical instrument of modern warfare, but in the eyes of the many people who have had to face it since 1916, it is more like a monster, a hideous throwback to the age of the dinosaurs, an expression of the most primitive kind of power. It is less a practical instrument with known capabilities than a phantasm, which can compel by its mere appearance.

In US military circles, this aspect of the tank is recognised as the "shock effect". But in the very early days of the tank it was known as the "moral effect" - the power of the machine to compel merely by appearing on the scene - as if the end of the world had arrived on a pair of groaning caterpillar tracks.

When the first tanks were shipped to the western front they were met with laughter. In London theatres, dancing girls were soon performing the "Tanko". The symbolic dimension of the tank was accepted as part of its military power. This fact was recognised by the French and British during the first world war, and afterwards exploited in many, often colonial, locations.

The representative tank of the late 20th century was not actually the latest digitised machine equipped with "total situational awareness". It is more like the one that forms the closing image of Don Delillo's novel Mao II. This is a graffiti-ridden but still apocalyptic rattletrap, grinding along at the head of a wedding party carousing its way through the eerie ruins of Beirut - "an old T-34, some scarred and cruddy ancient, sold and stolen two dozen times, changing sides and systems and religions".

Hi-tech Abrams and Challengers were seen in action during Operation Desert Storm, but elsewhere the tank has remained a grinding, primitive thing, serving as a prop for murderous warlords like the late Serbian butcher Arkan, or a handy implement for the Taliban in Afghanistan, who use tanks to erase ancient Buddhas from their landscape, or for pushing over walls on to men found guilty of homosexuality.

And it is not just for the Taliban that the tank has continued to work as a primitive monster. It has long functioned as the embodiment of state power, lined up against its own civilians. And in this capacity, it has never been excessively reliant on technological sophistication. All that matters is that it scares the hell out of the unarmed onlooker.

This side of the tank's history does not consist of planned battles in which tanks advanced en masse, as at Cambrai or Amiens in the first world war, and later in Hitler's Blitzkrieg operations of the second world war, or in the massive clashes in which tank army met tank army, as at Kursk in 1943. Instead, it opens with events such as occurred in 1919: in Glasgow, where the British government used tanks to overawe socialist strikers; in Ireland, where British tanks were used repeatedly against the struggle for independence; or in Berlin, where captured British tanks were used to suppress the Spartacus uprising.

This version of "tank warfare" would later be practised in the Soviet bloc: in the East Berlin uprising of 1953, when tanks were confronted by protesting citizens; in Budapest in 1956; in Prague in 1968, and in Poland during martial law. Its history includes the events of July 1967, when American tanks were used against rioters on the near west side of Detroit, and of all too many coups. They were on the streets in Athens during the colonels' coup of 1967; when Pinochet launched his coup against Allende's elected Popular Unity government in Chile in 1973; and when President Marcos ordered them out in Manila in 1986, against nuns, priests and children who eventually overwhelmed them.

This civilian image of the tank, in which the excesses of diverse CIA-prompted coups are symbolically wedded to those of the unyielding communist state, was repeated most memorably in Tiananmen Square in 1989. PLA tanks crushed demonstrators, and the abiding image was created a day or two later when a single civilian stepped into a deserted boulevard and arrested a whole column of approaching tanks.

The fact that this apparently primitive imagery can overwhelm even the most sophisticated hardware is suggested by the case of Israel, which has designed its own tank, albeit using huge subventions of US money. The Merkava was designed in the 80s, after the Yom Kippur war of 1973, in which the over-confident Israeli Tank Corps suffered grievious losses as they came up against Egyptian soldiers equipped with hand held "Sagger" anti-tank missiles.

The Merkava was to be the ultimate tank. It has phenomenal powers and an innovative design whereby its whole mechanism, including the fuel, is wrapped around the crew as protection. But what is Israel doing with its tanks? Using them as primitive monsters to oppress more or less unarmed Palestinians, turning them against stone-throwing youths, or driving them into the concentration camp known as the Gaza Strip to crush Palestinian huts.

Tank symbolism can recoil on its users. The British stopped using tanks in Northern Ireland after Operation Motorman of July 1972, in which Centurions were used to break into "Free Derry" and other republican no-go areas. The image of tanks breaking into civilian streets played right into republican hands, proving the Soviet-like monstrosity of the British state. Similarly, the Israelis are going to have to face down the photographs emerging from their tank operations in the Gaza Strip, including an already much-used one taken of a youth throwing a stone at a huge and overwhelming tank.

The symbolic power of the tank has proved irresistible in more ways than one. Hitler was passionate about them - wanting to mount them as monuments in parks and fantasising about vast 180-ton models. Margaret Thatcher proved her status as the "Iron Lady" by climbing into a Challenger in 1986. But Michael Portillo failed dismally: as John Major's defence minister, he once climbed out of the hatch of a British armoured vehicle in the Balkans, teetered and then nearly collapsed in front of the cameras.

The technicians and prophets of future warfare may see all this as primitive, theatrical stuff. But the symbolic force of the tank has been central to its effectiveness as a weapon, and it is by no means redundant. With the military now becoming more concerned with peacekeeping, or, in the suggestive American jargon, "operations other than war", this sort of symbolic warfare may, for better or worse, be entering a new phase. When the Americans took over the peacekeeping role in the Balkans, they took tanks with them, and planted them on ridges and bridges as a sign of their serious intentions. The principle was well known to Clough Williams Ellis, the architect of Portmeirion, who also served as a major with the Tank Corps during the first world war. As he wrote in 1919: "It is infinitely more humane to appal a rioter or a savage by showing him a tank than to shoot him down with an inoffensive-looking machine-gun."

 Tank: the Progress of a Monstrous War Machine, by Patrick Wright, is published by Faber and Faber, priced £25.

fields.headline: Take five: the daily news quiz
fields.trailText: Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).

A1 Easter Monday traditions include:

(a) Thread the needle

(b) Catch the rabbit

(c) Wind the bunting

(d) Blind man's rounders

A2 In Hallaton today they will be playing:

(a) Shove ha'penny

(b) Spillikins

(c) Bottle kicking

(d) Cat hunting

A3 Hallaton residents will also be "scrambling" for:

(a) Shard toffee

(b) Goose buns

(c) Sticklebacks

(d) Hare pie

A4 In Preston they will be:

(a) Egg-coddling

(b) Egg-rolling

(c) Egg-sucking

(d) Egg-fu-yung-ing

A5 Prestoners collect their egg shells to keep them:

(a) In their pockets

(b) For later

(c) In tall glass jars

(d) From witches

 Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by April 25. The winner will be notified by May 4. One entry per person. No purchase necessary.

fields.headline: History in the unmaking
fields.standfirst: The recent glut of documentaries about the Nazis has revealed us to be a nation of small-minded bigots, says Hywel Williams. And they show that we've forgotten what the war was all about
fields.trailText: The recent glut of documentaries about the Nazis has revealed us to be a nation of small-minded bigots, says Hywel Williams. And they show that we've forgotten what the war was all about.
fields.body:
Sometimes the memories lie too deep for tears; sometimes the eyes are just naturally watery. The tragic parade of the survivor, the collaborator, the perpetrator and the observer, rounded up by the researcher and paraded before the lens has become a very familiar sight.

The second world war documentary was, for years, a bankable commodity; the feeding frenzy of the ratings came with a convenient moralising gloss. It was supposed to instruct, to keep us alert to the danger of fascistic recrudescence. Once viewed, never forgotten. Supposedly.

Jeremy Isaacs's The World At War was the grandfather of the genre - and also the model that has never been bettered. Laurence Rees's The Nazis - A Warning From History took the warhorse in hand for another successful canter. But there's an iron law in British television that decrees that a failing genre has to be pursued way beyond the point of diminishing return.

Television looks immediate but is slow on the uptake. The business is expensive and money is allocated through slow and painful channels. Ideas that seem prescient often turn to celluloid ash by the time the programmes arrive on screen.

Now British television's idée fixe lurches into its decadence. Hitler's Henchmen is getting an audience share of just 3% on Channel 5. Channel 4's Science And The Swastika took a profound theme - German science in the service of racism. But it persuaded only 1.1m viewers to watch, a mere 4% of audience share compared to the channel's average of 10%.

Hitler's Women - another Channel 4 confection - showed the genre sliding into schmaltzy absurdity. Eva Braun's over-familiar films of life at the wolf's lair flickered before our lazy eyes. Cut-glass Princess Metternich tells us that Magda Goebbels was not as petit bourgeois as Mrs Heydrich. Psycho-historians babble about Clara Hitler's possessive influence over her son and speculate over the Führer's low sex drive. All the tired Freudian categories of sublimation come into play as the barrel is scraped and Adolf's valet yet again struts his stuff. There are, it seems, only so many times we want to see those Mädchen waving their hoops around at the Nuremberg rallies. The in-your-face school of history as horror means that we have had our fill and want closure. Perhaps we've grown disgusted by the mechanical ease of our own moralising.

You now need to be in your 70s to have had first-hand experience of the war. An "upmarket, male audience" is the only hope for this stuff, which shows that history does indeed repeat itself - first as tragedy and then as film banality. But behind our growing indifference there may be more than mere fickle callousness.

The programmes take the gravest of themes, generating an appetite for explanation, and then opt for the human interest angle. But the Berghof can't be turned into the Big Brother set and there are wider stories to be told.

The German catastrophe, which turned into the European tragedy, made the 20th century into an age of death. In Britain's case it also inaugurated a period of self-satisfied mediocrity in the century's second half. These programmes - and their predecessors - are celebrations of a victory grown old. Anti-Germanism is implicit in the code and the political dimension is unavoidable.

Both left and right derive comfort from the idea of Britain standing alone in 1940-1. The left likes it because the rejection of fascism created a taste for the virtues of community and solidarity. Something of this is seen in Channel 4's rather grim little series, The 1940s House, which recreates the spam-consuming domestic austerity. The right celebrates the John of Gaunt tradition, which isolates sovereign England set in a silvery sea. Both schools stultify.

Because Britain's popular history became fixated with Germany on the telly, it has lost sight of the wider story. It has collapsed into, first, a western-Euro-centric and, then, an insular view of our past. Britain's director's-chair-warriors seem to have forgotten that 1939-45 was a world war - and, for Britain, an imperial one. The Blitz was a rare British excitement. But that was a domestic affair - with the home front discovering alfresco sex in the blackout. For Britain as a great power, the war that mattered was the one in the Middle East and the Far East with its consequences for Palestine and Burma, for India, Hong Kong and Singapore. Concentration on western Europe both flatters the British contribution to the European war and ignores the wider imperial collapse.

The 20th century in Europe was determined by what happened in the east as the Teuton pushed against the Slav. That is the thousand-year story which finished off the thousand-year Reich. The obsessive thrust determined the end of the first world war and it also sealed the fate of Hitlerite Germany. This was a greater and bloodier drama even than the one fought out in the Normandy landings.

Britain's failure to manage the transition from imperial power to European state has been influenced by films and documentaries that distort and, now, bore. The amnesiac view forgets, for example, how Angles and Saxons are themselves Germanic races. Inspect the average German physical specimen and you will find distressingly little evidence of difference from the English model. The boring joke that the royal family are Germans forgets that that is what makes them a good racial fit for English rule.

Right up until the 1920s it was Germany, not France, that was the approved English cultural model. The clichéd view that the Germans were an inherently authoritarian race - whose craving for Ordnung could be traced back to Luther - is one that comes out of the two wars. But who led the way in inventing a welfare state long before Lloyd George? It was Bismarck - and his combination of welfarist capitalism and state subsidies was the model for 20th-century western Europe.

Moreover, for most of modern British history, it was France and not Germany that was seen as the dangerously expansionist power. France was the country that had a tradition of military strong men seizing power by coup d'état. Germany by contrast was the land of a regulated parliamentary liberty which seemed to flatter England by imitation.

British television has succeeded in presenting national socialism as the quintessence of Germany's sick soul rather than an aberration. But it's also hopeless at understanding fascism as a family collection of nasty doctrines. In Spain it looked back to the 12th-century Christian Reconquista. In Italy it only became anti-Semitic in the mid-30s, and many Jews were active supporters of Mussolini in the 20s. In Romania it had the local trade of vampirism to feed its ideology. These peculiarities escape the telly historian obsessed by Hitlerism.

One serious result of the distorting complacence is that it obscures what was, for Britain, the most important result of the war: its emergence as an American colony. Here is a real subject of illusion and reality. No one spoke of a special relationship before the second world war, and the uniqueness lay in the extent of the debt Britain had to shoulder, at American insistence, in order to pay for the war from 1941. For Britain these are more pregnant issues than whether Hitler fancied his niece for coprophiliac purposes.

Self-congratulatory snootiness about the war being won is now a turn-off. Not being invaded was an important fact as well as something of an accident. An invaded Britain would have been rather like any other European country: a few shits on the make, a lot of looking the other way and a few brave souls.

For the French, the occupation was a boon - it prompted a national debate about guilt, identity and responsibility. It also produced great art of spiritual depth in the films of Robert Bresson and of Marcel Carne. Olivier's vulgar Henry V and the hideous class consciousness of Coward's In Which We Serve embarrass by comparison.

Germany - transfigured by a terrible purgation - emerged redeemed, democratised and rich in a new self-consciousness and humility. Would that the same were true of Britain - now most insecure of all European countries, squalid in her infrastrucure, clinging to the vestiges of a meaningless sovereignty, subservient to a death-row specialist ensconced in the White House by electoral fraud. As we switch off and allow the dead to bury the dead - our period of self-examination is only just beginning. Would that we had the film-makers to offer a history that helps rather than hinders that process.
fields.bodyText: Sometimes the memories lie too deep for tears; sometimes the eyes are just naturally watery. The tragic parade of the survivor, the collaborator, the perpetrator and the observer, rounded up by the researcher and paraded before the lens has become a very familiar sight. The second world war documentary was, for years, a bankable commodity; the feeding frenzy of the ratings came with a convenient moralising gloss. It was supposed to instruct, to keep us alert to the danger of fascistic recrudescence. Once viewed, never forgotten. Supposedly. Jeremy Isaacs's The World At War was the grandfather of the genre - and also the model that has never been bettered. Laurence Rees's The Nazis - A Warning From History took the warhorse in hand for another successful canter. The business is expensive and money is allocated through slow and painful channels. Ideas that seem prescient often turn to celluloid ash by the time the programmes arrive on screen. Now British television's idée fixe lurches into its decadence. Hitler's Henchmen is getting an audience share of just 3% on Channel 5. Channel 4's Science And The Swastika took a profound theme - German science in the service of racism. You now need to be in your 70s to have had first-hand experience of the war. An "upmarket, male audience" is the only hope for this stuff, which shows that history does indeed repeat itself - first as tragedy and then as film banality. But behind our growing indifference there may be more than mere fickle callousness. The programmes take the gravest of themes, generating an appetite for explanation, and then opt for the human interest angle. fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you.
fields.body:
 As the schedules settle into their pre-summertime lull, trust the BBC to inject a note of viscera into proceedings with their imminent showcase Murder In Mind. A seven-part series devoted to the madcap psyches of various killers, the corporation are promising their baby will provide "feature films for busy people" (as opposed to those designed for the indolent) and "star-studded" casts featuring the "cream of British acting". And, with Denise Van Outen and Keith Allen cropping up along the way, who can argue?

 All of which means that EastEnders, the corporation's traditional repository of bloody mayhem, is free to relax into a fug of hitherto forgotten plotlines. And so it looks set to prove, with impending glimpses into the troubled marriage of Little Mo, and troubled everything of chip-shop magnate Ian Beale. For what it's worth, we were much more tickled by the rumour that balding members of the cast are barred from cropping their lifeless domes in deference to Steve "Phil" McFadden - hence the glut of scrapeovers, combovers and general tonsorial monstrosities on display throughout the Square.

 Meanwhile, an epoch-making moment looms with the 3,000th episode of Countdown - a landmark Channel 4 appear to be getting very excited about. "A modern miracle," is how 4's Michael Jackson describes the show, possibly a tad over-enthusiastically.

webTitle: Satellite, cable & digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable & digital: Return Of The Jed | Star Wars Episode 1: The Phantom Menace | Gregory's Girl | Zulu | Live Football
fields.body:
Films

Return Of The Jedi (Richard Marquand, 1983) 10am, 7pm, Sky Premier
The concluding, and weakest chapter of the original Star Wars trilogy. The opening section, in which Mark Hamill's now mature Luke Skywalker and friends rescue Harrison Ford's Han Solo from the clutches of gruesome Jabba the Hutt, is a humdinger; but after that the Force is pretty much absent. The space armada battles look too familiar, and when the future of the galaxy rests in the furry paws of the Ewoks, you know you're in trouble.

Star Wars Episode 1: The Phantom Menace (George Lucas, 1999) 12.20pm, 9.20pm, Sky Premier
The hugely anticipated prequel to the original Star Wars saga had fans paying at the box office just to catch the trailers, but the finished product is pretty disappointing. We're now focusing on the childhood of young Anakin Skywalker (Jake Lloyd) the nascent Jedi who will become Darth Vader; his mentors are Ewan McGregor's youthful Obi-Wan Kenobi, and Liam Neeson's ageing hippie-Jedi Qui-Gon Jinn. We should be talking space epic, but this is unforgivably dull, apart from the occasional flurry of computer-generated mayhem. Star of the show is martial arts expert Ray Park as the evil-incarnate Darth Maul; we don't see nearly enough of him.

Gregory's Girl (Bill Forsyth, 1981) 8pm, FilmFour
Forsyth's ever lovable teenie romance about a young lad smitten by a soccer-playing new girl at his school. It's a beautifully crafted tale, poking tender fun at adolescent courtships and presenting a refreshing picture of Scotland that sent out the ripples that became the Scottish new wave (Trainspotting and all). Performances are brilliant: Dee Hepburn the team's new and stunning striker; her friend Claire Grogan, John Gordon Sinclair the awkward lovestruck youth; and the extraordinary 10-year-old Allison Foster as his little sister patiently instructing him in the ways of the world.

Zulu (Cy Endfield, 1963) 8pm, Bravo
Archetypal bank holiday fare: Michael Caine, Stanley Baker and a cast of thousands. The lads play Lieutenants Bromhead and Chard, commanding a 100 or so Welsh soldiers out on the veldt. The thousands are Zulu emperor Cetshwayo's warriors; the occasion the heroic, desperate defence of Rorke's Drift in 1879. Great large-scale action, thumping music and good rugged character-sketching from the leads and the likes of James Booth and Nigel Green. Never has Men of Harlech sounded so stirring.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Football 5.30pm, Sky Sports 1
Easter weekend is when the season starts getting really interesting. So many games, so little time, and the situation at both ends of the table is starting to become clearer. Take Liverpool's quest for a Champions' League spot, which suffered a setback on Friday. Today they face Everton, a test they could do without, given that Barcelona visit on Thursday. Too good for their own good, perhaps.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: TV review: Coronation Street | The Whistle-Blower

fields.headline: I'll give it till Christmas
fields.trailText: TV review: Coronation Street | The Whistle-Blower
fields.body:
The wedding guests in Coronation Street (Granada) would have daunted the stoutest heart. A worse advertisement for marriage it would be hard to imagine.

They waited like a row of crows on a blasted oak. Rita, whose husband chased her along Blackpool prom with a hatchet until, luckily, he was flattened by a tram; Gale, whose husband was murdered; Emily, who married a bigamist; Anthony, who is divorcing his demented wife; Hayley, who, though blissfully united with Roy, is legally a man; and Norris, who was briefly married to a direct descendant of Boadicea. I mention these things at random. Most have been married many times.

They waited in vain for the happy couple as Sally and Danny were fully occupied having a punch-up with Kevin, the bride's former husband. Kevin's resemblance to one of the smaller, snappier terriers is now actually disturbing. His little legs stiffen, his whiskers bristle, his yapping shrills to a crescendo. When Kevin's around, cries of "Down, boy! Down, ouch!" barely drown the noise of torn trousers.

Meanwhile, back at the Rovers, the object of those late-night poker sessions is becoming clear. Ever since Duggie "Crusher" Ferguson took over, the place has been going to the dogs. A fact which Toyah did not hesitate to point out: "This used to be a great little pub, now it's full of gamblers and snakes." The dishevelled snakes around the poker table took another swig at their watered whisky, set their cheap cigars at a randier angle and endeavoured, bless 'em, to look beyond redemption. This bunch of hungover drunks will be prime, if implausible, suspects in Toyah's brutal backstreet rape.

There is Duggie, who cannot speak her name without spraying dentine, Peter, the black sheep of the Barlows, Steve and Vik, leaning helplessly against each other like two sides of a triangle that are greater than the third. Oh, and there's a stray minicab driver called Vern, who doesn't seem to have an owner. Anyone round here lost a Vern? Possibly on purpose?

The Whistle-Blower (BBC 1) by Patrick Harbinson took two big bites out of the weekend and will have trouble justifying its appetite.

We plunged into the thick of things at once as Laura (Amanda Burton), a bank clerk, stole evidence of laundered drug money. The authorities were pleasantly surprised. "Nice house, nice job, why on earth is she doing this?"

Was it pique that she had been passed over for promotion? Was she herself involved in the laundering? Was she the illegitimate daughter of Sir Alastair, the bank's chairman, whose first words, "Let innocence be our shield!", would have made a saint suspicious?

No, no and, again, no.

Amanda Burton is the fair Miss Frigidaire in the flesh. You feel no drop of sweat could escape that impermeable skin. She is precisely the person to keep her own counsel for three hours. By which time you would gladly have shot her yourself. As her preternaturally patient husband (Neil Pearson) said, "I don't seem to know anything about you any more, Laura. What was true. What wasn't. Was anything true?"

The boredom of hiding in safe houses was shown almost too accurately. It all leaped into life again - by which, of course, I mean death - towards the end. The stylised meeting of Laura, Sir Alastair, their secret daughter and the hit man, arriving like chessmen for a checkmate in a city square, reminded me very much of the opening titles of The Power Game, which used to thrill us in the 60s.

"I've got someone on the roof with a high-powered rifle", said the hit-man (Zach Grenier), whose jokey menace came across strongly like a thrown punch. "Just kidding", he added. He wasn't kidding, but you appreciated the effort anyway. It was the only joke.

Laura lay in a coma. As her small son (the nicely natural Liam Hess) rattled away, you wondered if that was a minimal movement of her mouth. You weren't sure. But, then, with Amanda Burton, it's hard to say.

webTitle: Mark Lawson: Women on the small screen

fields.headline: Women on the small screen
fields.standfirst: We've come some way since women were portrayed on TV as plump, sex-starved matrons and blue-rinsed spinsters. But have they now achieved equality on the small screen?
fields.trailText: We've come some way since women were portrayed on TV as plump, sex-starved matrons and blue-rinsed spinsters. But have they now achieved equality on the small screen asks Mark Lawson?
fields.body:
There has never been a theatre critic whose column consisted purely of jokes about the presumed idiots who ran the National and the RSC. Nor has any reviewer of the visual arts made a reputation entirely through punning on the names of the impressionists. In the criticism of television, however, neither of the equivalent careers would seem at all odd.

This is because commentary on the small screen is the only branch of arts criticism that frequently proceeds from the position that most of the products are rubbish. And, like a lapsed Catholic making jokes about the Pope, television self-hatingly adds to the calumnies whenever the medium considers itself. With the exception of self-glorying awards ceremonies, analysis of television by TV generally consists of giggling compilations of the art form falling on its arse (It'll Be Alright On The Night, TV's Biggest Blunders, TV Hell.)

A welcome exception is Ball Breakers On The Box (Channel 4), the glibly alliterative title of which disguises a thoughtful exploration of television's depiction of women. It helps that this is a rare case of an archive-based show inspired by something greater than the desire to provide nostalgic programming for viewers who grew up with 70s TV. Hamish Mykura's film marks the 30th anniversary of the Equal Pay Act, but deals with the subject of employment equality through the entertainment most easily available to people when they came in from work.

Did television drama and comedy offer equal opportunities? Most of those watching the programme will suspect that the television of the past was probably sexist but, even so, some of the evidence supporting this proposition still shocks. A 1970s sketch from The Two Ronnies - fantasising about a world run entirely by women - now seems almost pathologically misogynist. Diana Dors as a bigger-busted Thatcher presides over a society in which Feminazi stormtroopers in black leather march through the streets, the lingering shots of their bottoms hinting at a single possible consolation for the chaps if this ever happened.

Even when less surprising, the programme is still neat, showing, for example, how professionally successful women on screen were always shown as manless but desperate to possess one, the clear implication being that no bloke wanted to be on the job with a woman who had one. The sex-crazed matrons of Hattie Jacques in Carry On films gave way to Mollie Sugden in Are You Being Served? There's always the risk of taking sit-com too seriously, but the male writers of that show can also be accused of having a heavy agenda considering the department store's senior female, Mrs Slocombe, was given not only a surname referring to delay in reaching orgasm but a cat as a domestic companion, allowing the now-notorious weekly references to her need to get home so that she could stroke her pussy. Many have commented on these double-entendres before, but this documentary makes the interesting further point that the character is Mrs rather than Miss Slocombe: her husband left her and, by implication, because she worked too hard.

The risk with films of this kind is that the structure becomes a list: and then there was this one. This can be avoided by making connections both within the subject and beyond it. One sequence in Ball Breakers On The Box - dealing with 80s stereotypes of the business bitch - is an expert demonstration of such integration of ideas.

Scenes from the ITV drama Connie - in which Stephanie Beacham played a Midlands businesswoman inspired by American ideas - introduce the figure of the power-dressing feminist. The fact that Beacham was then recruited to appear opposite Joan Collins in Dynasty brings in the American treatment of these themes. Images from the American soap merge into an 80s magazine cover on which businesswoman Dame Shirley Porter is wearing the kind of shoulder-pads and heels popularised by Collins's character. In interview, Porter confirms that the photographer was aiming for the Alexis effect.

All television - and compilation documentaries especially so - risks becoming merely a string of images. In sections like the one described above, this film achieves a visual through-composition. In line with usual critical practice, I attributed this film in an earlier paragraph to the producer/director. But, in a case like this, substantial recognition should also be given to the names that speed past in the final credits and are noticed only by their relatives: film researchers Peter Scott and Christine Whittaker and researcher Rosie Schellenberg.

Often, in programmes based on archive, lack of time or failure to clear copyright means that the pictures are a very general illustration of the commentary. Here, the images are frequently a perfect punchline to the script's feed. An early 70s scene from Z-Cars, for example, in which a woman police officer saves her male colleagues' lives, appears to be pioneeringly feminist until we are shown a coda, in which the woman reveals that she'd rather remain behind a typewriter at the station, leaving the truncheon stuff to the men.

Channel 4's previous examinations of television - 100 best moments, 100 worst moments and so on - have depended on rescreening familiar scenes.

A rare example of intelligent criticism from the inside, Ball Breakers On The Box consistently shows moments that you either literally or metaphorically didn't see at the time.

 Ball Breakers On The Box, tonight, 8.45pm, Channel 4.

Nor has any reviewer of the visual arts made a reputation entirely through punning on the names of the impressionists. In the criticism of television, however, neither of the equivalent careers would seem at all odd. This is because commentary on the small screen is the only branch of arts criticism that frequently proceeds from the position that most of the products are rubbish. And, like a lapsed Catholic making jokes about the Pope, television self-hatingly adds to the calumnies whenever the medium considers itself. With the exception of self-glorying awards ceremonies, analysis of television by TV generally consists of giggling compilations of the art form falling on its arse (It'll Be Alright On The Night, TV's Biggest Blunders, TV Hell.) A welcome exception is Ball Breakers On The Box (Channel 4), the glibly alliterative title of which disguises a thoughtful exploration of television's depiction of women. It helps that this is a rare case of an archive-based show inspired by something greater than the desire to provide nostalgic programming for viewers who grew up with 70s TV. Hamish Mykura's film marks the 30th anniversary of the Equal Pay Act, but deals with the subject of employment equality through the entertainment most easily available to people when they came in from work. Did television drama and comedy offer equal opportunities? Most of those watching the programme will suspect that the television of the past was probably sexist but, even so, some of the evidence supporting this proposition still shocks. A 1970s sketch from The Two Ronnies - fantasising about a world run entirely by women - now seems almost pathologically misogynist. Diana Dors as a bigger-busted Thatcher presides over a society in which Feminazi stormtroopers in black leather march through the streets, the lingering shots of their bottoms hinting at a single possible consolation for the chaps if this ever happened. Even when less surprising, the programme is still neat, showing, for example, how professionally successful women on screen were always shown as manless but desperate to possess one, the clear implication being that no bloke wanted to be on the job with a woman who had one. The sex-crazed matrons of Hattie Jacques in Carry On films gave way to Mollie Sugden in Are You Being Served? There's always the risk of taking sit-com too seriously, but the male writers of that show can also be accused of having a heavy agenda considering the department store's senior female, Mrs Slocombe, was given not only a surname referring to delay in reaching orgasm but a cat as a domestic companion, allowing the now-notorious weekly references to her need to get home so that she could stroke her pussy. Many have commented on these double-entendres before, but this documentary makes the interesting further point that the character is Mrs rather than Miss Slocombe: her husband left her and, by implication, because she worked too hard. The risk with films of this kind is that the structure becomes a list: and then there was this one. This can be avoided by making connections both within the subject and beyond it. One sequence in Ball Breakers On The Box - dealing with 80s stereotypes of the business bitch - is an expert demonstration of such integration of ideas. Scenes from the ITV drama Connie - in which Stephanie Beacham played a Midlands businesswoman inspired by American ideas - introduce the figure of the power-dressing feminist. The fact that Beacham was then recruited to appear opposite Joan Collins in Dynasty brings in the American treatment of these themes. Images from the American soap merge into an 80s magazine cover on which businesswoman Dame Shirley Porter is wearing the kind of shoulder-pads and heels popularised by Collins's character. In interview, Porter confirms that the photographer was aiming for the Alexis effect. All television - and compilation documentaries especially so - risks becoming merely a string of images. In sections like the one described above, this film achieves a visual through-composition. In line with usual critical practice, I attributed this film in an earlier paragraph to the producer/director. But, in a case like this, substantial recognition should also be given to the names that speed past in the final credits and are noticed only by their relatives: film researchers Peter Scott and Christine Whittaker and researcher Rosie Schellenberg. Often, in programmes based on archive, lack of time or failure to clear copyright means that the pictures are a very general illustration of the commentary. Here, the images are frequently a perfect punchline to the script's feed. An early 70s scene from Z-Cars, for example, in which a woman police officer saves her male colleagues' lives, appears to be pioneeringly feminist until we are shown a coda, in which the woman reveals that she'd rather remain behind a typewriter at the station, leaving the truncheon stuff to the men. Channel 4's previous examinations of television - 100 best moments, 100 worst moments and so on - have depended on rescreening familiar scenes. A rare example of intelligent criticism from the inside, Ball Breakers On The Box consistently shows moments that you either literally or metaphorically didn't see at the time.  Ball Breakers On The Box, tonight, 8.45pm, Channel 4.

fields.headline: Jim Baxter
fields.standfirst: Scottish footballer whose outstanding talents tormented England in two famous matches at Wembley
fields.trailText: Scottish footballer whose outstanding talents tormented England in two famous matches at Wembley.
fields.body:
The footballer Jim Baxter, who has died of cancer aged 61, came out of the Fife coalfield in June 1960 to join Rangers for £17,500 and begin a career that blazed with colour. He was probably the most gifted, outrageous and celebrated player in Scotland's football history.

In an era when footballs were heavier and boots less dynamically designed, his ability to swerve shots and passes, delivering the ball to team-mates with a touch that made it appear to be weightless, was quite astonishing. When Baxter, a wing half, took control of a match, he dictated its entire shape.

Yet by November 1970, aged 31, he had retired, after being freed at the end of a short, ignominious second tour with the Ibrox club. He played 254 games for Rangers, scored 24 goals - and made it from supernova to black hole in one momentous decade.

Baxter's talent was utterly natural, recalling Arthur Ashe's words about a similarly blessed tennis contemporary, Ilie Nastase. "Ilie doesn't have to practise," said Ashe. "He already has all the shots. The rest of us have to work like mules on our technique. All he has to do is keep himself fit enough to play."

It was all Baxter needed, but it was too much to ask. In the early stages of an international career that would bring him 34 caps between 1961 and 1967, Dave Mackay, another great Scottish wing half, counselled him to train hard and not to pursue the wild lifestyle. The advice fell on deaf ears.

When Baxter arrived at Ibrox on £22 per week plus bonuses - the same rate as the other Rangers squad players - the first thing he did was buy a Jaguar, for no other reason than to attract the women who would be as integral a part of his life as football itself. From his earliest days at Ibrox, he would be seen in the shower in the mornings, sucking on peppermints - trying to rid himself of the effects of serious drinking even before training began.

It was a habit that he neither regretted nor defended. "I did it all because I liked it," he always said. Philandering, drinking and gambling being the short route to financial chaos, Baxter wasted no time in getting to the terminus. "I reckon I've done in £500,000," he said recently. That is a conservative estimate, considering the rate at which his cash was squandered over a 30-year period.

Perhaps his background as a pit-boy lay at the core of this impulsive behaviour. He was born in Hill o' Beath, Fife, and on leaving school spent eight months as an apprentice cabinet-maker before taking the cage to the place that Jock Stein called "the darkest place on earth".

Stein, himself a miner from Lanarkshire, said "there's nothing as dark as the darkness down a pit, the blackness that closes in on you if your lamp goes out. You'd think you would see some kind of shapes but you can see nothing, nothing but the inside of your head. I think everybody should go down the pit at least once to learn what darkness is."

Baxter's emergence into the light, when he became a full-time footballer, had been preceded by a short spell with the Fife junior team, Crossgates Primrose, and he joined Raith Rovers as a part-timer in 1957. He spent two years on national service with the Black Watch before signing for Rangers for a Scottish record transfer fee. His first match was a League Cup tie against Partick Thistle in August 1960, in which he played at inside left.

That November he scored his first goal for Rangers, against Clyde. In 1961, Rangers won the league championship and were runners-up in the European Cup Winners' Cup. That year too Baxter debuted for his country against Northern Ireland.

In 1963 he was part of Rangers' double-winning team. But, even at the height of his greatest triumphs, his sense of mischief could not be suppressed. When Scotland beat England 2-1 at Wembley in 1963, Baxter scored twice on his first appearance at the great stadium as the visitors were reduced to 10 men when left back Eric Caldow broke a leg. Baxter admitted to being tempted to put one into his own net near the end so that he could claim a hat-trick.

The following year Rangers won the league title and the Scottish and league cups, but in May 1965 he moved to Sunderland for £72,500. The late Scot Symon, the Rangers manager who had taken him to Ibrox, knew even then that he was on the way down. After 98 games and 12 goals, in December 1967 Baxter was sold for £100,000 to Nottingham Forest, where he numbered another sporting giant, Gary Sobers, among his closest friends. A further 50 appearances for the midlands club was followed by a free transfer back to Rangers.

In 1967, when the Scots inflicted England's first defeat as world champions, Baxter's incomparable touch on the ball allowed him not only to humiliate the home side, but also to concoct a plan with Billy Bremner to give Alan Ball a bad experience. Baxter delivered one of those teasing 50-50 passes to Bremner which was more 55-45 in the Scotland captain's favour, Ball took the bait, and Bremner hit him like a train.

In October of what may be called Jim Baxter's annus mirabilis of 1963, he represented the rest of the world in a match against England to celebrate the centenary of the Football Association. None of the greatest players of the era would argue with his right to be there.

After his retirement he applied for, and was given, a publican's licence. In 1994, he had two liver transplants. He is survived by his partner Norma and two sons.

 Jim (James Curran) Baxter, footballer, born September 29 1939; died April 14 2001

fields.headline: David Lloyd Owen
fields.standfirst: Warrior who ranged deep behind enemy lines in north Africa
fields.trailText: From 1943 to 1945, David Lloyd Owen, who has died aged 83, was commander of the Long Range Desert Group, regarded by some as one of the most cost-effective special forces in the history of warfare.
fields.body:
From 1943 to 1945, David Lloyd Owen, who has died aged 83, was commander of the Long Range Desert Group, regarded by some as one of the most cost-effective special forces in the history of warfare.

During the five years of its existence, it carried out more than 200 operations behind enemy lines. Throughout this time, there were only two short months without such LRDG patrols.

Formed in July 1940, under the command of Major Ralph Bagnold, a notable prewar desert explorer - and brother of the writer Edith Bagnold - the group's task was to reconnoitre the great Libyan desert on the western border of Egypt and the Sudan.

The unit, initially equipped with Ford trucks, which were later replaced by 30cwt Chevrolets, ranged freely across north Africa, travelling hundreds of miles behind enemy lines to gather information for the 8th Army. Its troops, many of them tough Rhodesians and New Zealanders, were adept at navigating the desert by the stars-and-sun compass. They were experts in maintaining their vehicles, driving in the sand, conserving water and "reading the tracks". As Lloyd Owen put it, "you hardly ever saw a track of a vehicle. And if you did we knew exactly who had made them, 1920s Bagnold's cars, or ourselves. We could read those tracks."

The Special Air Service, formed in November 1941, came to rely on the LRDG to deliver its parties to their objectives and, when necessary, recover them. But while the LRDG, with a reputation for professionalism and reliability, worked closely with the SAS, it was first and foremost a reconnaissance and intelligence unit. It could and did inflict considerable damage on the enemy, but this was not its primary function.

Born in Hampton, Middlesex, Lloyd Owen was the son of a Royal Navy captain. After Winchester College and the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst, he was commissioned into the Queen's Royal Regiment in 1938, and saw service in Palestine during the Arab revolt. With the second world war and the Italian army's move towards Mersa Matruh, the Queen's was sent to Egypt in December 1940, where Lloyd Owen saw action as a company commander at Sidi Barrani and Tobruk.

But by the late spring of 1941, Lloyd Owen, much to his chagrin, found himself posted back to Cairo as an instructor at the Middle East officer cadet training unit. The existence of the LRDG was kept as quiet as possible, but Lloyd Owen heard about it from a Guards officer friend - and applied. He was interviewed by Bagnold, who "asked me questions to which I had no answer, I knew so little". Despite rating his chances of acceptance as "nil" because he knew nothing about vehicles and had little knowledge of the desert, he impressed Bagnold sufficiently to be taken on trial and was given command of Yeomanry Patrol, made up of men from the dismounted Yeomanry of the 1st Cavalry Division, whom Lloyd Owen described as "25 men of jolly good yeomanry regiments and a few commandos who were without a role in the Middle East".

A man of normally immaculate appearance, Lloyd Owen began to blend in with his informal and often decidedly scruffy comrades. To command the special type of soldier who served with the LRDG required a special type of officer. Lloyd Owen's relaxed and friendly style of leadership relied on persuasion, personal example and the recognition of shared hardships. He won the loyalty and respect of his men by his daring, sheer stamina and first-rate tactical skills.

Awarded an MC for his part in the joint raid on Tobruk by the LRDG and SAS in September 1942, he was severely wounded shortly afterwards in an air raid on Kufra, the LRDG's main base, but was fit enough to rejoin his unit for the final stages of the north Africa campaign. By May 1943, the LRDG was in Lebanon, training for a new role in mountain warfare, but was then unexpectedly posted to the Aegean. During the battle for Leros, the commanding officer was killed, and Lloyd Owen was appointed to command.

Based in Bari, in southern Italy, the LRDG, under Lloyd Owen, mounted a successful raid on Corfu as well as operations in the Dalmatian islands and Yugoslavia, eventually parachuting into Albania in September 1944. The drop had taken place at night and, shortly after landing, Lloyd Owen fell 30ft into a ravine, badly damaging his spine. Although treated in a field by an LRDG doctor specially parachuted in, Lloyd Owen was in continual pain, but despite this managed to direct a number of successful operations in the mountains.

Eventually evacuated to Italy, he was operated on and, notwithstanding orders to desist from operations, managed to wangle his way back to Albania, although this time he went by sea. For his leadership in the Balkans, Lloyd Owen was awarded the DSO in 1945 and mentioned in dispatches.

Following a period on the War Office's military operations staff, in 1948-49 he was appointed military assistant to the high commissioner in Malaya at the height of the emergency. For his work there he was awarded an OBE and again mentioned in dispatches. From 1957 to 1959 he commanded his own regiment, the 1st Battalion the Queen's Royal Regiment, in Germany, before joining the staff at Sandhurst.

During the Radfan campaign of the early 1960s, he commanded 24 Infantry Group in Kenya and Aden.

In 1968-69 he was general officer commanding, Near East Land Forces, and from 1969 until his retirement with the rank of major-general in 1972, president of the Regular Commissions Board. He was appointed CB in 1971.

In later life, Lloyd Owen, who made his home in Norfolk, was chairman of the Wildflowers Association of Great Britain and also of a charitable trust devoted to helping disabled people and those with learning difficulties to take part in sailing and other pastimes on the Broads. He published two memoirs, The Desert My Dwelling Place (1957) and Providence Their Guide (1980), and was, for more than 50 years, chairman of the LRDG Association.

His wife, whom he married in 1947, survives him together with their three sons. A man of great charm, Lloyd Owen was a courageous soldier and a remarkable leader of men.

 David Lanyon Lloyd Owen, soldier, born October 10 1917; died April 5 2001
