webTitle: Leader: Hope is disappearing in Middle East

fields.headline: Hope is disappearing
fields.standfirst:
Sharon's policies are leading nowhere

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The lurching descent of Ariel Sharon's government into increasingly harsh military action against the Palestinians is a mark of its bankruptcy.
fields.body:
The lurching descent of Ariel Sharon's government into increasingly harsh military action against the Palestinians is a mark of its bankruptcy. Sharon is a leader pledged to bring peace and security, but with no idea of how to achieve either, whether by diplomatic or military means.

His initial formula for a return to negotiations was so unrealistic that only the most deluded sympathiser could imagine there was any chance that Yasser Arafat, beleaguered though he is, could accept it.

His more recent position is that, following a complete end to Palestinian violence, there might be a possibility of a Palestinian state on a maximum of 42% of the West Bank and Gaza. This is not just unrealistic but surrealistic.

Possibly Sharon does not really mean it, since one presumes that Shimon Peres, his foreign minister, has been trying to open up talks with the Palestinians on a somewhat different basis. But, with a public position of this kind, the distance the Israeli prime minister might move in actual talks is reduced to a few percentiles, not remotely enough to bring Palestinians back into a peaceful dialogue.

Arafat has sent envoys to security talks, and there has been one high-level meeting in Athens, followed by lower-level encounters in Israel, with another meeting due this week. Arafat may indeed have to consider a ceasefire, but if he does so, it would only be out of desperation, to gain himself and the Palestinians a needed breathing space. If there were to be such a deal, a renewal of violence is as predictable as the sunrise.

Sharon himself has ceased to mention peace except in a perfunctory manner, and has begun to warn Israelis that they will need "a lot of stamina" to endure a long and "grim" struggle. Yet his military options seem as unpromising as his diplomatic ones.

He has escalated Israeli responses to Palestinian attacks, sending in helicopter gunships to hit barracks housing Palestinian security forces, and staging abductions in Palestinian areas and political assassinations in Gaza.

Last week, the Israeli Defence Force, at Khan Younis, for the first time invaded territory that had supposedly passed under the full control of the Palestinian Authority. There was another smaller incursion at Rafah this weekend. But a full reoccupation of Palestinian areas would be a step that Sharon would find hard to take, with its obvious costs in terms of casualties, in international condemnation, and in its impact on relations with Arab neighbours.

The renewal of hostilities across the Lebanese border remains a dangerous possibility as yesterday's attack and counter-attack shows. What applies to reoccupation applies equally to the policy of withdrawal from parts of the West Bank that some have suggested: it would be ideologically impossible for Sharon because it would involve abandoning a number of settlements.

Meanwhile, the fighting is daily eroding the will to peace on both sides. Even those Palestinians who have their doubts about the wisdom of this second intifada blame the Israelis for creating circumstances in which it was unavoidable, while a majority of Israelis, a recent poll suggests, no longer believe peace with the Palestinians can be achieved.

What is left? One possibility is a continuation of the conflict, but with more incursions into Palestinian territory, more shelling, more assassinations, and more severe economic measures. The other is that such pressures will lead to a cease-fire, but one not followed by substantive negotiations and which will ultimately fail. These grim alternatives will satisfy neither the Israeli nor Palestinian peoples.

Suzanne Goldenberg in Khan Yunis, Gaza Strip

Sharon himself has ceased to mention peace except in a perfunctory manner, and has begun to warn Israelis that they will need "a lot of stamina" to endure a long and "grim" struggle. Yet his military options seem as unpromising as his diplomatic ones. He has escalated Israeli responses to Palestinian attacks, sending in helicopter gunships to hit barracks housing Palestinian security forces, and staging abductions in Palestinian areas and political assassinations in Gaza. Last week, the Israeli Defence Force, at Khan Younis, for the first time invaded territory that had supposedly passed under the full control of the Palestinian Authority. There was another smaller incursion at Rafah this weekend. But a full reoccupation of Palestinian areas would be a step that Sharon would find hard to take, with its obvious costs in terms of casualties, in international condemnation, and in its impact on relations with Arab neighbours. The renewal of hostilities across the Lebanese border remains a dangerous possibility as yesterday's attack and counter-attack shows. What applies to reoccupation applies equally to the policy of withdrawal from parts of the West Bank that some have suggested: it would be ideologically impossible for Sharon because it would involve abandoning a number of settlements. Meanwhile, the fighting is daily eroding the will to peace on both sides. Even those Palestinians who have their doubts about the wisdom of this second intifada blame the Israelis for creating circumstances in which it was unavoidable, while a majority of Israelis, a recent poll suggests, no longer believe peace with the Palestinians can be achieved. What is left? One possibility is a continuation of the conflict, but with more incursions into Palestinian territory, more shelling, more assassinations, and more severe economic measures. The other is that such pressures will lead to a cease-fire, but one not followed by substantive negotiations and which will ultimately fail. These grim alternatives will satisfy neither the Israeli nor Palestinian peoples. webTitle: Michele Hanson: being a proper vegetarian

fields.headline: If you can't stand the meat
fields.trailText: Now that I have decided to be a proper vegetarian instead of nearly one, the whole household has gone mad for meat
fields.body:
Now that I have decided to be a proper vegetarian instead of nearly one, the whole household has gone mad for meat. They are suddenly into minced beef in a big way and keen to cook spaghetti bolognese. And we only have one kitchen.

Our house is electric with clashing waves of envy and desire. Who will start the bolognese cooking? Who will dominate the kitchen area? Whose will taste the best? What luck that I am not involved in this and can just scurry up to my office with a cheese sandwich.

Meanwhile, Gardener has innocently got to the kitchen first. He is adhering to an esteemed Italian recipe which takes four hours. This means sitting about in the kitchen to observe simmering and prevent sticking. Meanwhile, up on the first mezzanine, Mother is also simmering, waiting to descend and cook mincemeat-balls. In tomato sauce.

But wait. What's the matter with Daughter? Up on the second floor, she is in a white hot fury because for weeks she's been waiting to make a bolognese. I bought the mincemeat at her request, but then forgot and promised it to my mother for the meatballs. Meanwhile Gardener had whizzed out, bought more stinky mincemeat and begun his sauce.

We have layers of people stewing in various ways: waiting, cooking, seething. Downstairs Gardener cooks on, unaware of the furies upstairs. Once notified, he agrees to a postponement. His sauce will be frozen, so we can have meatballs first, Daughter's bolognese second and his creation last. An endless run of minced corpse. And not only do I object on ethical grounds, but I never liked these dishes anyway.

I told my friends Toad and Nina about the mince problem, but to them spag bol is a dish from the distant past, when only foreigners ate garlic and no one went to Tuscany. But we are still back in the Dark Ages here with our cooking, battling with primitive rivalries: upstarts pushing the matriarch from her domain, a chap encroaching on women's territory, Daughter pitted against a usurper, all to produce my least favourite meal, from meat into which shit has possibly seeped. I read about it in this newspaper.

So tomorrow it's my turn to carry on. Nut loaf for everybody.

webTitle: Caroline suspect is wanted across Europe

fields.headline: Caroline suspect is wanted across Europe
fields.trailText: France may not be alone in seeking the extradition from America of Francisco Arce Montez, the alleged serial sex offender suspected of murdering the British schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson in a Brittany youth hostel five years ago.
fields.body:
France may not be alone in seeking the extradition from America of Francisco Arce Montez, the alleged serial sex offender suspected of murdering the British schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson in a Brittany youth hostel five years ago.

Judicial sources confirmed yesterday that Montez, a Spanish restaurant worker being held in a Miami jail on suspicion of sex offences, is also wanted for at least four rapes and attempted rapes in Germany and Spain.

"He also spent quite some time in the Netherlands and in Britain. It is by no means impossible that he may be linked to as yet unsolved sex crimes in those countries too," said a French justice official who asked not to be named.

Scientists at the Paris police laboratory this weekend found 18 points of similarity between a sample of the waiter's DNA supplied by US police and traces found on Caroline's body. The 13-year-old was raped and suffocated in her first-floor room at the Pleine-Fougères hostel on July 18, 1996.

Under French law, nine points of similarity are enough for a suspect to be placed under formal investigation, the step before being charged.

One genetic fingerprinting expert said yesterday that the possibility of Montez not being Caroline's killer was "something like one in 6bn".

French police confirmed they had drawn up an international arrest warrant for Montez, 51, which would be sent to the US judicial authorities via Interpol in the next couple of days. But a formal request to start a more complex extradition process will take much longer and may be hindered by similar efforts from other countries.

The Spaniard has now been linked with a string of sex offences committed around Europe in the past 20 years.

His first conviction, for exhibitionism, was in Bremen, Germany, in 1980. He was subsequently found guilty in his absence of the attempted rape of two hitchhikers in Tübingen in 1988, and sentenced to two years in jail.

In 1993 and 1994, French gendarmes twice had to release Montez for lack of evidence after he was accused of trying to force Irish schoolgirls into his Dutch-registered car near the Chateau de la Herserie, a youth activity centre in central France popular with Irish tourists.

The inquiry into the murder of Caroline also revealed that a man answering his description had been spotted outside Brittany youth hostels in Saint-Brieuc, Saint-Malo and Antrain in June and July 1996.

On the night of her killing, another British schoolgirl, Kate Wrigley, narrowly escaped being raped in a hostel at nearby Saint-Lunaire.

In September of that year, a British waitress was attacked by a man resembling Montez in a hotel in Beauvoir, northern France.

In late 1997, Montez jumped bail and disappeared after being detained for an attempted rape in Llanes, not far from his birthplace in Gijon, in Spain's Asturias region.

He arrived in the US in February this year and was arrested in Miami on March 13 for burglary and lewd behaviour.

webTitle: Scientists find cheer with new 'healthy' dessert wine

fields.headline: Scientists find cheer with new 'healthy' dessert wine
fields.standfirst: Set the table for the latest health supplement - white dessert wine.
fields.trailText: Set the table for the latest health supplement - white dessert wine.
fields.body:
A team of scientists in Israel and New York say they have produced a sweet white wine with all the natural health-promoting chemical ingredients of French red wines.

The news will be presented to an international scientific meeting on alcohol and red wine on April 26 in Palo Alto, California.

Until a decade or so ago, wine was nobody's idea of a health food. But it has gradually emerged as the most plausible explanation so far for the "French paradox" - that despite a high fat-diet deaths in France from coronary heart disease are considerably lower than anywhere else in the western world.

Researchers have come to understand more about the apparent health virtues of red wine. The skins of grapes concentrate a series of chemicals known as flavonoids, probably to protect the fruit against disease or insect attack. These have powerful cholesterol-countering properties. Red wine manufacture - which uses the skins of the grapes as well as the fruit, concentrates the flavonoid content.

Michael Aviram of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology worked with a kosher wine producer to find a new way of making white wine - by throwing in the white grape skins as well.

"We concluded that by processing white wine by putting grape skins of chardonnay or muscat grapes in contact with alcohol for short periods helped extract the skin's flavonoids, and produced white wine rich in potent antioxidants similar to those found in red wine," Professor Aviram said.

The catch was the grape skins could not be left longer than 18 hours without spoiling the taste of the wine. So the scientists added wine-based alcohol to the squeezed grapes to hurry the process. This increased the flavonoid content fivefold.

The new health-conscious white wine is 16% alcohol by volume and sweet. It serves, says the institute, as a dessert wine.

"We set out to understand why our red wine studies in 1995 found twice as much reduction in cholesterol oxidation as the French studies," said Prof Aviram. "It turns out the difference lies in the strength of flavonoids of Israeli grapes."

webTitle: Birth pill 'cuts risk of bowel cancer'

fields.headline: Birth pill 'cuts risk of bowel cancer'
fields.trailText: Taking the contraceptive pill has helped make women nearly 20% less likely to develop bowel cancer, scientists report today in the British Journal of Cancer.
fields.body:
Taking the contraceptive pill has helped make women nearly 20% less likely to develop bowel cancer, scientists report today in the British Journal of Cancer.

They believe the action of the oestrogen hormone in the pill might help explain why the death rate from the disease among women in the last 20 years has fallen far faster than for men.

Bowel cancer is the second largest killer among cancers in the UK. It was responsible for the deaths of 8,582 men and 8,133 women in 1999.

The new finding emerged from a review of 19 international studies by a team led by Carlo La Vecchia, of the Institute of Pharmacological Research in Milan. The review concluded that the risk to women who took the pill between the mid-1960s and mid-1980s was reduced by as much as 18%.

Dr La Vecchia commented: "Mortality rates for female bowel cancer have steadily dropped over the last 20 years. We believe this is partly due to the pill. "In the future, it may be possible to develop new treatments that take advantage of the anti-cancer qualities of the pill."

The supposition is that oestrogen blocks the growth of cancer cells by reducing bile acids. It may also lower the levels of another hormone, IGF-1, that has been linked to increased risk of bowel cancer. Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said: "The results show that women might have a secret weapon against the disease that kills 46 people in the UK a day."

Anne Szarewski, senior clinical research fellow with the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, said the study added to the pill's known health benefits, which included a 50% reduction in risk from cancer of the ovaries.

webTitle: Plan to give out free digital TV sets

fields.headline: Plan to give out free digital TV sets
fields.trailText: The government is to give away digital television equipment to targeted "neighbourhoods" in order to pave the way to switching off analogue television signals.
fields.body:
The government is to give away digital television equipment to targeted "neighbourhoods" in order to pave the way to switching off analogue television signals.

Ministers want to gauge reaction to digital television from the kind of households that have been slow to make the change to multi-channel television. There are fears that, unless the take-up of digital spreads to the middle-aged and elderly, a "digital divide" could open up.

The main TV providers have signed up to the plan, and the location of the first "digital neighbourhood" will be announced in the next two months.

The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, said: "Already, one in three households, and one in two families with children, have digital TV. We need to ensure that Britain leads the world in the development of digital television, that every community shares in the benefits, and that we don't see the creation of a digital divide."

Digital households would get free access to the internet, electronic shopping, and email, in addition to the five terrestrial channels in digital form (which typically means better pictures) and the free-to-air digital channels such as BBC Choice, BBC News 24 and ITV2.

The BBC, BSkyB, ITV and ONDigital have agreed to take part in the scheme, which ministers said would "help government and industry understand better the practical and social issues people face in deciding whether to switch from their existing analogue television homes to digital TV".

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has said he wants to switch off analogue between 2006 and 2010. The process would be gradual and would not happen until almost all households in a given area are digital.

fields.headline: Ganging up on Cuba
fields.trailText: That the UK is to co-sponsor another resolution condemning Cuba for alleged human rights abuses at the UN human rights commission in Geneva (Diary, April 13) is bitterly disappointing.
fields.body:
That the UK is to co-sponsor another resolution condemning Cuba for alleged human rights abuses at the UN human rights commission in Geneva (Diary, April 13) is bitterly disappointing.

Ever since Robin Cook distanced Britain from the US blockade at the Labour conference in 1999, we in the Cuba Solidarity Campaign harboured the faint hope that Britain might use its special relationship with Washington to help bring about a change in its insane obsession. Britain is supposed to have an ethical foreign policy and a commitment to "constructive engagement" with Cuba. It is hard to see what is ethical or constructive about supporting this US-instigated resolution.

First, it is an annual event to which no other country, not even known torture states - which Cuba is not - such as Saudi Arabia, is subjected. Second, by taking part in an exercise that is clearly vindictively motivated, Britain is placing its desire to appease Washington before principle. This clear taking of sides will surely poison rather benefit UK relations with Cuba.

What we suspect is that the Bush administration is threatening to implement the Helms-Burton law, which would unleash court actions in the US against UK companies and individuals that are investing in Cuba. The price Washington is exacting for not doing so is support for its unfair resolution in Geneva.

Even Amnesty International agrees that it is perhaps not the best way to approach the issue of civil rights in Cuba. Human rights everywhere will not be served if the Geneva commission falls into disrepute.
Dr Steve Wilkinson
Cuba Solidarity Campaign steve@cuba-solidarity.org.uk

webTitle: Letters: More wars break out over the census

fields.headline: More wars break out over the census
fields.trailText: I have just received my census form ( It's J-E-D-I, April 14). For one person, there are eight pages of densely written instructions and questions and you need a sophisticated level of literacy to be able to read it and fill it in.
fields.body:
I have just received my census form ( It's J-E-D-I, April 14). For one person, there are eight pages of densely written instructions and questions and you need a sophisticated level of literacy to be able to read it and fill it in.

Many people with poor reading skills are going to find completing the form very daunting, and for some it will be impossible. But nobody involved in the planning of the census seems to have considered this.

I wasn't asked by the person delivering the form if I needed help reading it, and though there is a helpline number, the recorded message offers nothing for those unable to read. As well as causing tremendous anxiety, the statistics derived from the census may be distorted, since many people will simply not complete it. If it's a legal requirement, the state should ensure that help is available for all who need it.
Ruby Lescott
London Yappse6@aol.com

 I rarely lodge complaints about individuals, but I have made a exception after I noticed that the lady delivering my census form was sporting a large "Conservative - Keep the Pound" badge. This is at best inappropriate and is, at least in my case, offensive. Are census staff not supposed to be politically neutral?
David Stewart
Torquay, Devon david@stewartgd1.fsnet.co.uk

 I am writing to reassure unregistered Jedi that it is not an offence to enter "Jedi" in their answer to question 10 on religion. Question 10 is not covered by the Census Act 1920, as clearly stated on the census form.
Tristan Dorling
Arthog, Gwynedd

 I could almost be persuaded by John O'Farrell to put down Jedi as my religion if it wasn't for the uneasy feeling that in another 1,000 years or so major wars and atrocities would be carried out between the Kanobe Liberation Army and the One True Church of Yoda Popular Front.
Monica McCartney
Manchester

 My wife and I have been Jedi knights for the last 20 years. We were not amused by O'Farrell's article.
LS Walker
Beverley Hills, California

fields.headline: Cheers for white wine
fields.standfirst: But plain grape juice might be better
fields.trailText: A team of American and Israeli scientists has helped produce a new white wine that claims to have the natural health-promoting ingredients of French red wine.
fields.body:
It is not going to stop the arguments, but it was a logical development in the battle between red and white wine. A team of American and Israeli scientists has helped produce a new white wine that claims to have the natural health-promoting ingredients of French red wine.

A succession of studies have suggested it is red wine that explains the French paradox: although French people have a high fat diet and smoke more than most, they suffer lower rates of heart disease and cancer.

Scientists have suggested red wine, which is made with the grape skin, contains an important health-giving ingredient: flavonoids, which help both to reduce the tendency for the blood to clot and encourage oxidisation, which prevent the arteries from furring up. Accordingly, the new Israeli wine involves using the skins of chardonnay and muscat grapes for a short period to extract the skin's flavonoids to produce a wine rich in red wine's antioxidants.

The findings are to be delivered to an international scientific meeting in Palo Alto, California, later this month. Several predictable results will follow. There will be further studies from beer-producing states of the benefits that beer bestows. Dutch, German and Australian scientists have already suggested beer helps reduce heart attacks. There will be further French studies to demonstrate the virtue of red wine. Then there will be the unexpected, like the study in Texas by researchers without Irish names, who found Irish coffee reduced strokes. If the Scots join in, suggesting it is alcohol that helps, not grape skin, there is an obvious question: why does Scotland have such a high rate of heart disease?

It is not yet time for Bordeaux to panic. There is nothing dry about the new white wine. Would anyone really want three glasses of sweet white wine to improve their health. Would they not be better off just drinking plain grape juice? Or even eating peanuts. They too contain flavonoids.

A succession of studies have suggested it is red wine that explains the French paradox: although French people have a high fat diet and smoke more than most, they suffer lower rates of heart disease and cancer. Scientists have suggested red wine, which is made with the grape skin, contains an important health-giving ingredient: flavonoids, which help both to reduce the tendency for the blood to clot and encourage oxidisation, which prevent the arteries from furring up. Accordingly, the new Israeli wine involves using the skins of chardonnay and muscat grapes for a short period to extract the skin's flavonoids to produce a wine rich in red wine's antioxidants. The findings are to be delivered to an international scientific meeting in Palo Alto, California, later this month. Several predictable results will follow. There will be further studies from beer-producing states of the benefits that beer bestows. Dutch, German and Australian scientists have already suggested beer helps reduce heart attacks. There will be further French studies to demonstrate the virtue of red wine. Then there will be the unexpected, like the study in Texas by researchers without Irish names, who found Irish coffee reduced strokes. If the Scots join in, suggesting it is alcohol that helps, not grape skin, there is an obvious question: why does Scotland have such a high rate of heart disease? It is not yet time for Bordeaux to panic. There is nothing dry about the new white wine. Would anyone really want three glasses of sweet white wine to improve their health. Would they not be better off just drinking plain grape juice? Or even eating peanuts. They too contain flavonoids.

fields.headline: Spirit in the sky
fields.standfirst: Work has at last begun on Norman Foster's 'erotic gherkin'. Prepare to fall in love, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Work has at last begun on Norman Foster's 'erotic gherkin'. Prepare to fall in love, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
A new wave of tall buildings is about to hit our cities. Do we need them? Will we come to love them as Americans rightly do the Empire State and Chrysler buildings? Maybe. But only if they turn out to be more subtle and special than the structures that bloomed so awkwardly in previous decades.

Sixties office towers, in particular, tended to be selfish things, exercises in corporate self-aggrandisement or symbols of developers' might. The new towers must connect with city life, rather than rise up from the pavements like massive closed books.

Enter the Swiss-Re building, rather stupidly nicknamed the "erotic gherkin". This is the 40-floor, 590ft office tower designed by Foster and Partners for the Swiss Reinsurance Company and dogged by controversy almost since the plans were completed. It is at last beginning to rise on the site of the former Baltic Exchange in the City of London.

The hole in the ground here comes courtesy of the IRA, which blew the old building to bits in 1992. The new structure promises to be one of the most distinctive towers yet built. What the company did not want was a bland, ecologically and socially irresponsible block; what it is getting is a very special building, where the latest in computer-aided design has been matched to an acute environmental awareness.

The shape of the Swiss-Re tower may look odd at first glance, but it grows on you as you begin to understand it. As it rises up over the City skyline, the tower tapers. The top is a cone. This reduces the visual bulk of what is, by any standards, a massive building. In addition, in wind-tunnel tests the shape proved to be aerodynamically efficient. This may not seem important - office blocks, after all, are not expected to fly - yet it is. Too many four-square office towers generate vicious downdrafts on windy days, making them unpleasant and even dangerous to walk past.

Moreover, the wind-load on slab-sided towers demands heavy-duty structural engineering. Because the wind will flow around Swiss-Re like air over and under a plane's wing, currents will be swept away from and well above pavement level; and because they will caress rather than buffet the building, the structure can be made lighter than conventional towers. This a lightweight, diagonally braced steel and aluminium frame connected internally to a central concrete core containing lifts.

There is a further advantage, and this one is great for the several thousand people who will work here. Air currents will be drawn into vents spun gently up and through the office floors. Since the windows will open (a real luxury for today's office workers), the Foster tower will therefore rely to a very limited degree on air-conditioning. Stale air will be exhausted into the tower's spiralling atria, or "sky gardens", where it will be re-oxygenated by trees and plants. The Swiss-Re will be as permeable as an emmenthal cheese.

Because the building will need little in the way of air-con equipment, its roof will be glazed and entirely free of the usual unsightly clutter. In fact, the top floors are to be a glamorous restaurant and bar. At this stage there can be no guarantee that these will be open to the public, but Swiss-Re is working on the idea. Let's hope it happens. Otherwise, public access will be via a two-floor shopping gallery at the base of the tower, which will rise from a new public plaza with trees, all-year open-air cafes and low walls designed to double up as benches. In summer, the walls of the tower above them will open up like some giant pinecone as windows lever outwards. From day to day, hour to hour, in fact, the skin of the building will change its appearance: the fall of light and shadow will never be quite the same.

Back inside, the tower promises encouraging working conditions for Swiss-Re staff. Aside from the fresh air, office floors are not stacked one on top of the other. Instead, they spiral up the inside of the tower following the "sky gardens", each of which is an atrium six floors high. What Swiss-Re wanted from the start was a building that connected staff rather than separated them. The idea here, is that most of the best ideas in the course of a working day stem from staff meeting casually on stairs, by water-dispensers, anywhere away from desks and computer screens.

The computer-aided design employed by Foster's team, alongside the engineers Ove Arup and Partners, is known as parametric modelling. It is intriguing to sit alongside the architects and to see how this tool, familiar to designers of the next generation of airliners, can offer structural and design options at supersonic speed while instantaneously reckoning the cost implications of extending a floor here or raising the height of an atrium there. In no way does this digital wizardry reduce the architects' role.

For all the logic behind the form and planning of Swiss-Re, it was still the architects' desire to shape a special building that looked like no other. Will we come to love it? Let's hope so. But what we must do is learn to demand that any new tall building in our city centres be as painstakingly and imaginatively designed as this.
